ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Fee schedule for certification, copying and facsimile transmission of documents. 
    The city establishes the following fee schedule for certification, copying and facsimile transmission of documents: 
Document copy ..... $0.10/page 
Document facsimile transmission .....  0.10/page 
Certification of document(s) or generation of information not in a report or other readily accessible form .....  20.00/hour 
All requests for information to be provided by mail shall be accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope with sufficient postage affixed thereto. 
All fees received for certification, copy or facsimile transmission of documents as described herein shall be deposited in the city's general fund. 
(Ord. No. 96-30, § 1, 8-6-96; Ord. No. 97-1, § 1, 1-7-97) 
Sec. 2-2. - Duties of city boards and commissions. 
(1)  Each city board and commission shall meet at least one time annually to elect officers. Such annual meeting shall take place between January 1 and January 31 of each calendar year. Within 30 days of the date of the meeting at which officers were elected, each board and commission shall provide a list of its officers to the clerk-treasurer. 
(2)  Each citizen member of a city board or commission shall be a resident of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-27, § 1, 6-1-99; Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 6-4-08) 
Sec. 2-3. - Youth commission gift fund-Created. 
(1)  There is hereby created the "City of Portage Youth Commission Gift Fund," which shall be a nonreverting fund. The fund shall be used to receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the commission. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purposes of the City of Portage Youth Commission without further appropriation. 
(2)  The clerk-treasurer is hereby specifically authorized to invest such funds with, or separately from, the remainder of the general fund in any suitable manner as is now provided by state statute and/or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 05-4, §§ 1, 2, 1-4-05) 
Cross reference- Drain maintenance fund, § 2-161; gift funds, § 2-162; cumulative capital development fund, § 2-163. 
Sec. 2-4. - Major moves construction fund-Created. 
(a)  Creation of fund. A major moves construction (MMC) fund is hereby created. All revenue received by the city from the major moves construction fund under IC 8-14-16-3 shall be deposited in the city's MMC fund. The MMC fund shall be administered by the city's clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  Use of MMC funds. Revenues deposited in the city's MMC fund may be used for the purposes specified in IC 8-14-16-5 as the same may be amended from time to time. Appropriations of money in the MMC fund must be included as part of the annual budget for the calendar year in accordance with IC 6-1.1-17. Money remaining in the fund at the end of a particular calendar year shall remain in the fund and shall not revert to any other fund. 
(Ord. No. 06-27, §§ 1, 2, 7-5-06) 
Cross reference- Drain maintenance fund, § 2-161; gift funds, § 2-162; cumulative capital development fund, § 2-163. 
Sec. 2-5. - Rainy day fund-Created. 
(a)  Creation of rainy day fund. There is hereby established a rainy day fund to receive transfers of unused and unencumbered funds of the type specified in IC 36-1-8-5.1 as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Purpose of the fund. The funds on deposit in the rainy day fund may be used for the operation of the city and its various departments when the city does not have sufficient levies or funds to pay such costs, including, but not limited to, salaries and wages, costs of services, supplies, equipment, capital improvements, repairs and similar expenditures, or to make temporary loans to other city funds. 
(c)  Transfer to fund. The common council shall determine the amount, if any, of unused and unencumbered funds available to be transferred to the rainy day fund and shall make such transfers subject to the provisions set forth in IC 36-1-8-5 and 36-1-8-5.1 upon adoption of an ordinance approving said transfers. 
(d)  Appropriations. The common council may authorize the expenditure of funds from the rainy day fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated that receive tax monies, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the funds is consistent with the intent of the fund. 
(Ord. No. 07-06, §§ 1-4, 2-6-07) 
Cross reference- Drain maintenance fund, § 2-161; gift funds, § 2-162; cumulative capital development fund, § 2-163. 
Sec. 2-6. - Vending machines placed on property owned by the city. 
    Vending machines approved by the city board of works may be placed on property owned by the city. Any vending machine currently on city property must also be approved by the board of works in order to remain on said property, including those vending machines in restricted areas. Failure to gain approval for a new or existing vending machine shall require removal of the machine and its contents from city property until such approval is granted. 
    Any vending machine placed on city property must be governed by a written contract, signed and executed by the appropriate governing body, department head or administrator for the property on which the vending machine will be placed. Said contract must detail the procedure for maintaining the vending machine and the division of funds for both maintaining the machine and commissions. 
    All revenue generated and costs incurred in operating vending machines located on city property must be accounted for by the clerk-treasurer and deposited into or paid out of the city general operating fund. 
    A vending machine may be placed in a restricted area. A restricted area for this section means an area other than those available to the public. The revenues from such a restricted vending machine may be restricted for the use and benefit of those employees who use said vending machine and generate the revenues. 
    All revenues and commissions received from a vending machine placed in an area where the public makes use of the machines and generates the resulting revenues shall be accounted for by the clerk-treasurer and then deposited into the city general operating fund unless otherwise provided for herein. The clerk-treasurer shall disburse the previously accounted for funds into each department's account based on the location of the vending machine. 
    Any board, commission or department of the city with jurisdiction over property, such as the city port authority, may enter into contracts for the placement [of] vending machines on property under its jurisdiction, so long as the contract complies with the requirements of this section. Said board or commission is authorized to retain any revenues and commissions from the placement of vending machines. 
(Ord. No. 08-23, 5-7-08) 
Sec. 2-7. - Approval of agreements. 
(a)  Agreements shall be defined to include any written contract, agreement, memorandum of understanding, pact, or commitment, including those of no monetary value, entered into by a department of this city and any third party. 
(b)  All agreements shall be approved by the board of works prior to the full execution of the agreement except: 
(1)  The park and recreation board shall approve agreements entered into by the department of parks and recreation. 
(2)  The port authority board shall approve agreements entered into by the marina and port authority. 
(3)  The redevelopment commission shall approve agreements entered into by the department of redevelopment. 
(c)  Upon approval by the board of works, the park and recreation board, the port authority board or the redevelopment commission, a copy of the agreement shall be forwarded to the clerk-treasurer who shall maintain a copy of each agreement. 
(d)  The common council may from time to time exempt certain agreements from the requirements of this section by resolution. 
(e)  Any agreement under this section which has a total monetary cost to the city, or any of its departments, boards, or subunits, of $1,000.00 or more shall be forwarded by the clerk-treasurer to the common council at its next regular meeting immediately following the approval of the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 17-2, § 1, 2-7-17) 
Secs. 2-8, 2-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-10. - American-made products purchasing specifications. 
(a)  The specifications for the purchase of goods shall include a requirement that: 
(1)  Unmanufactured articles, materials and supplies have been mined or produced in the United States; 
(2)  Manufactured articles, materials and supplies, except for vehicles, have been manufactured in the United States, substantially all from articles, materials or supplies mined, produced or manufactured in the United States. 
(3)  Vehicles have been manufactured in North America from at least 75 percent of articles, materials or supplies mined, produced or manufactured in the United States. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply if: 
(1)  The purchase price of the goods is less than $5,000.00; or 
(2)  The purchasing agent finds and certifies in writing to the board of works that articles, materials or supplies of sufficient and reasonable available commercial quantities and satisfactory quality are not available at a reasonable price. The price of American-made goods shall be generally considered reasonable if they are not six percent more than the cost of equivalent imported goods. 
(c)  Every contract for any public work let by the City of Portage, or its boards or commissions, in an amount greater than $50,000.00 shall contain a provision that in the performance of the work, the contractor shall use only such unmanufactured articles, materials and supplies as have been mined, produced or manufactured in the United States substantially all from articles, materials and supplies as have been mined, produced or manufactured in the United States. 
(d)  Subsection (c) shall not apply if the purchasing agent finds and certifies in writing to the board of works prior to the award of the contract that in respect to some articles, materials and supplies, it is impractical to make such a requirement, or that it would unreasonably increase the cost. A cost increase of less than six percent shall be considered reasonable. 
(e)  If a contractor is found to be in violation of the requirements of subsection (c) and has not been relieved of that requirement by action of the purchasing agent pursuant to subsection (d) prior to award of the contract, the purchasing agent shall make public the violation and the contractor shall not be eligible for award of another public works contract from the city for a period of three years. Notice of this consequence shall be made a provision of all public works contracts of the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-17, § 1, 9-5-17) 
Secs. 2-11-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMON COUNCIL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-26. - Conflict of interest. 
    No councilmember shall directly or indirectly be financially interested in any contract or agreement with the city for any matter, cause or thing by which liability or indebtedness is created against the city. No member shall purchase any bond, order, claim, or demand whatever against the city for less than the sum of the amounts specified therein. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-8(B)) 
Sec. 2-27. - Attendance, voting. 
    Every councilmember shall be present within the council room during the sitting of the council, unless excused or necessarily prevented, and shall vote on each question put unless he has a personal or pecuniary interest in such question. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-9) 
Sec. 2-28. - Enactment procedure for ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances shall be read two times before final passage, unless the rules are suspended. 
(b)  No ordinance may be passed at the same meeting in which it is introduced, unless under suspension of rules, and then only in case there are present and voting at least two-thirds of all the members elect of the council. 
(c)  A majority vote of all the members of the common council elected or appointed is required to pass an ordinance, unless a greater vote is required by statute. 
(d)  Subsections (a) and (b) shall not apply to ordinances described in IC 36-3-4-12(b) and (c). 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-13; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-2-02) 
State Law reference- Passage of ordinance requires majority vote, IC 36-4-6-12. 
Secs. 2-29-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS 

Sec. 2-41. - Regular time, place. 
    The regular, stated and fixed meetings of the common council of the city shall be held at the council chamber on the first Tuesday of each month at a time designated by the council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-1; Ord. No. 03-18, § 1, 8-5-03) 
State Law reference- Regular meetings, IC 36-4-6-7(a). 
Sec. 2-42. - Special. 
(a)  The call of a special meeting shall be in writing, and specify therein the particular purpose for which such meeting is called. Such call shall be signed by the mayor, when made by him, and when made by the council, by them, and sealed with the seal of the city, and countersigned by the clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  Certified copies of the call of a special meeting shall be personally served by the chief of police or his deputy, if practicable, upon every member entitled to be present at such special meeting. No business shall be transacted at such special meeting unless the subject thereof is named in the call. The minute sheet shall show the issuance of the call and the service of such notice for which purpose the chief of police or his deputy shall return copies of such notices to the clerk-treasurer at such special meeting. Written notice and the return thereof shall be waived by the presence of all councilmembers at such specially called meeting. 
(c)  Special meetings may be called in the manner provided in this section by four councilmembers in case the mayor is unable or refuses to call such meeting and the call in such cases shall state the mayor's inability or refusal. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-2) 
State Law reference- Special meetings, IC 36-4-6-7(b). 
Sec. 2-43. - Quorum. 
    Four councilmembers shall constitute a quorum; but a smaller number may meet, adjourn from time to time, and compel the attendance of members. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-3) 
State Law reference- Quorum, IC 36-4-6-10. 
Sec. 2-44. - Order of business. 
    The following shall be the order of business at all regular meetings of the common council: 
(1)  At the hour appointed for the meeting, the mayor shall call the meeting to order. If the mayor is not present at such meeting, the president pro tempore shall take the chair and call the meeting to order and preside as chairman of the meeting. If neither the mayor nor president pro tempore shall be present at such meeting, the council shall proceed to elect from among its members a temporary chairman, to preside as chairman of that meeting. 
(2)  The clerk-treasurer, or in his absence a member of the common council appointed by the mayor, shall proceed to call the roll of the members and mark the absentees, if any, and announce whether a quorum is present. 
(3)  The reading or suspending the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting or meetings of the council and the approval or amendment of the same. 
(4)  Clerk-treasurer's report. 
(5)  Communications, correspondences, announcements, etc., from the mayor; 
(6)  Report of city officials; 
(7)  Reports from standing committees; 
(8)  Reports from special committees; 
(9)  Introduction of ordinances; 
(10)  Unfinished or deferred business; 
(11)  New business; 
(12)  Reception of petitions, memorials, and remonstrances; and 
(13)  Adjournment. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-4) 
State Law reference- Presiding officer, IC 36-4-6-8. 
Sec. 2-45. - Rules of procedure. 
    The council may adopt rules of procedure to govern the conduct of its meetings. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-5; Ord. No. 16-23, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 2-46. - Duties of mayor. 
(a)  The mayor shall take the chair for the opening of the meeting. He shall immediately call the council to order, and on the appearance of a quorum, shall proceed with the order of business stated. All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by the presiding officer, subject to the approval of the council. The presiding officer shall have the right to call a recess at any time. 
(b)  The mayor shall preserve order and decorum, may speak to points of order, in preference to members, rising from his seat for that purpose, and shall decide questions of order, subject to an appeal by any member, on which appeal no member shall speak more than twice, unless by leave of the council. The question on the appeal shall be put thus: "Shall the decision of the chair stand as the decision of the council." 
(c)  The mayor may examine and correct the minutes before they are read; shall have a casting vote to resolve a tie vote, but not otherwise; shall sign all ordinances, commissions, deeds, contracts, licenses, permits, and all other papers ordered by the council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-6; Ord. No. 16-23, § 2, 12-6-16) 
State Law reference- Voting by presiding officer, IC 36-4-6-8; signature of presiding officer, IC 36-4-6-14. 
Sec. 2-47. - Questions of privilege. 
    Questions of privilege shall be: first, those affecting the council collectively, its safety, dignity, and the integrity of its proceedings; and second, the rights, reputation, and conduct of the members individually in their respective capacity only. All questions of privilege shall have precedence over all other questions except motions to adjourn. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-7) 
Secs. 2-48-2-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMITTEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-27, adopted May 1, 2001, repealed in its entirety Division 3, which pertained to committees, and adopted similar provisions as set out herein. The previous Division 3 derived from the following: Code 198, §§ 2-1-10-2-1-12, 2-1-12(A), and 2-1-12(B); Ord. No. 96-44, § 1, adopted Sept. 3, 1996; Ord. No. 00-35, § 1, adopted Aug. 1, 2000; and Ord. No. 01-04, § 1, adopted Jan. 2, 2001. 

Sec. 2-56. - Standing committees enumerated. 
    The following shall be the four standing committees of the common council: 
(1)  Budget and finance. 
(2)  Ordinance. 
(3)  Ways and means. 
(4)  Strategic planning. 
    Each standing committee shall consist of three members appointed by the president of the common council. The president of the common council shall also appoint a chairperson of each committee from its respective membership. The president of the common council shall be an ex-officio member of each standing committee and may attend its meetings and participate in its deliberations. The president of the common council shall not be entitled to vote in his capacity as an ex-officio member of a standing committee. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-57. - Duties of standing committees. 
(a)  The budget and finance committee shall make recommendations to the common council concerning: 
(1)  The annual city operating budget; 
(2)  The annual city employee salary budget; 
(3)  The annual elected officials salary budget; 
(4)  Revisions to salaries and/or staffing levels; and 
(5)  The actual expenditures made from all city accounts. 
(b)  The ordinance committee shall: 
(1)  Initiate the preparation of general ordinances relating to the governance of the city and special ordinances pertaining to special matters; and 
(2)  Review zoning and appropriation ordinances and ordinances amending the municipal code at the discretion of the chairperson. 
(c)  The ways and means committee shall make recommendations to the common council concerning: 
(1)  The initiation of general obligation and/or revenue bonds; 
(2)  The establishment and/or revision of fees; 
(3)  The establishment and/or revision of local tax levies; and 
(4)  Other matters which may affect the revenue afforded the City, such as tax abatement and other financial incentives. 
(d)  The Strategic Planning Committee shall: 
(1)  Identify and plan for the long-term capital needs of the City, including, but not limited to: 
a.  Health, safety and service facilities, including planning for sidewalk location, road paving and general beautification projects; 
b.  Rolling stock and equipment; 
c.  Systems, networks and related hardware and software; and 
d.  Different methodologies for service provision; and 
(2)  Review proposals and/or requests for annexation. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-58. - Operation of the standing committees. 
    It shall be the obligation of all common council standing committees to consider all matters referred to it as provided in these rules, and to make recommendations to the common council concerning those matters. A standing committee may consider any other matter properly concerning departments or subject matter indicated by the name of the standing committee. A standing committee may hear such testimony or public comment as the committee deems proper. In lieu of separate hearings, standing committees may meet with boards of corresponding city departments and/or department heads or employees. All standing committees shall meet in a fashion consistent with all prevailing open-door meeting notice requirements and with a frequency sufficient to meet the responsibilities outlined in this division. Standing committees shall meet on call of its chairperson or any two of its members. The clerk-treasurer, who shall maintain a record of such notices, shall communicate notice. A simple majority shall constitute a quorum, which shall be necessary to conduct the business of the committee. The chairperson may act as secretary, or the committee may appoint a secretary, who shall keep a memorandum of the proceedings and recommendations made during the meeting. In standing committee meetings, roberts rules of order shall be relaxed in order to encourage discussion, but general procedural decorum shall prevail. All standing committees shall establish and maintain an open, ongoing dialogue with the mayor, clerk-treasurer and department heads regarding committee business. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-59. - Appointment of special committees. 
    The mayor shall appoint all special committees, which may be ordered by the council from time to time, and the mayor shall designate the chairperson of each such special committee from the membership of the committee. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-60. - Meetings. 
    Any member of the common council shall be entitled to attend and participate in the discussions before any committee. The common council member introducing any proposal referred to a committee shall be a member of that committee while it is considering that proposal, but such common council member shall not be entitled to vote or be counted in determining a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-61. - Standing committee action and reports. 
    All standing committees, except the ordinance committee, shall report to the common council upon each matter referred to it within forty-five days of the referral. Should the president of the council withdraw or reassign the proposal, this rule shall not apply. After any hearing by a standing committee upon a proposal, the committee chairperson shall submit a report, either written or verbal, to the common council. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-62. - Ordinance review. 
    All ordinances amending the municipal code may be submitted to the ordinance committee for review prior to consideration at a city council meeting. After reviewing an ordinance submitted to it pursuant to this section, the committee shall place the ordinance on the agenda for an upcoming city council meeting with a favorable recommendation, or no recommendation. The committee shall complete its review and place an ordinance on the agenda for a city council meeting within one hundred twenty days of the date the ordinance is referred to the committee. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Sec. 2-63. - Dissolution. 
    A special committee, when its report, if made, is disposed of, and it has no other business, stands dissolved without a motion; but an affirmative vote on recommitment has the effect of reviving such committee. 
(Ord. No. 01-27, § 1, 5-1-01) 
Secs. 2-64-2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-81. - Acting as surety restricted. 
    No member of the common council of the city or other city officer shall become surety on the bond of any city officer, contractor, appointee, or other person required by law to give a bond payable to the city for the faithful performance of any duty, office or trust. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-8(A)) 
Sec. 2-82. - Bonds for city officials and employees.[3] 
(a)  The clerk-treasurer shall execute a bond payable to the state, with good and sufficient surety, to be approved by the mayor and conditioned on the faithful performance of the duties of his office and for the payment to the proper person of monies received by him in the performance of his office. 
(b)  Effective January 1, 2016, individuals who are employees or contractors of the city and whose official duties include receiving, processing, depositing, disbursing, or otherwise having access to funds that belong to the federal government, the state, a political subdivision or another governmental entity shall file and maintain a surety bond. 
(c)  The clerk-treasurer's bond shall be in an amount which equals $30,000.00 for each $1,000,000.00 of receipts of the clerk-treasurer's Office during the last complete fiscal year before purchase of the bond; provided, however, that the amount of the bond may not be less than $30,000.00 nor more than $300,000.00. 
(d)  The bond for the individuals described in subparagraph (b) shall be in the amount of $5,000.00. 
(e)  Effective January 1, 2016, all bonds must have a one-year term. Consecutive yearly bonds must provide separate coverage for each year. 
(f)  The city may purchase a blanket bond that: 
1.  Is endorsed to include faithful performance to cover the faithful performance of; and 
2.  Includes aggregate coverage sufficient to provide coverage amounts specified for all individuals who are required to file a bond under this section. 
(g)  The cost of the bonds or blanket bond shall be paid from the general fund of the city upon presentation to the clerk-treasurer of a voucher therefor and in the manner required for the payment of other municipal claims. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 10-6-15) 
State Law reference- Approval of claims against city, IC 36-4-8-5. 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, adopted Oct. 10, 2015, amended § 2-82 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-82 pertained to clerk-treasurer's bond and derived from the Code of 1985, § 2-2-6(A)(1), (B)-(D). 

Sec. 2-83. - Crime insurance policy. 
(a)  The city may purchase a crime insurance policy that provides coverage for criminal acts or omissions committed by officers, employees, contractors, commission members, and persons acting on behalf of the city. 
(b)  The cost of the crime insurance policy shall be paid from the general fund of the city upon presentation to the clerk-treasurer of a voucher therefor and in the manner required for the payment of the other municipal claims. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 2, 10-6-15) 
Sec. 2-84. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-85. - Take-home vehicles. 
(a)  The mayor shall submit to the common council by January 1 of each year a list of take-home vehicles for the upcoming year for approval of appropriation of expenditures for said vehicles. The list shall contain the employee assigned a vehicle, the reason for assignment of a take-home vehicle, the year, make, and model of the vehicle, and the annual cost of the vehicle if lease or loan payments will be due on the vehicle during the year. This list shall include the mileage of said vehicle, the date of purchase or lease and whether or not said vehicle has a city logo. 
(b)  Take-home vehicle assignment changes which occur after January 1 of each year, including new assignments, appropriation for said vehicle shall be approved by the common council prior to assignment of a take-home vehicle. That the city council president may remove the take-home Vehicle from any user if there is proven misuse or violation of this policy. 
(c)  Use of a city vehicle: 
(1)  The use of a take-home vehicle for commuting to and from work does not constitute work time and the employee is considered off the clock until they arrive at a bona-fide work assignment. Employees responding to an emergency situation with proper lights and sirens shall be considered working. 
(2)  Any employee on leave of absence, light-duty, workers' compensation, or suspension is not authorized to have a take-home vehicle. 
(3)  Only city employees are authorized to operate city vehicles. 
(4)  City vehicles are to be used as necessary to conduct the business of the city and its operations. Employees shall not operate city vehicles for the purpose of conducting a private business or enterprise or any other personal use. However, it is recognized that a de minimus amount of personal use during the course of a scheduled shift to include meal breaks are permitted. Take-home vehicles are not to be used unless the person is scheduled for work and working during the period of use. 
(5)  The use of city vehicles for overnight and out-of-town travel shall be for approved city business only. The city council president must approve this use. 
(6)  The use of alcohol, tobacco, e-cigarette, or vaping products are not permitted in city vehicles. 
(7)  The use of a cellular telephone is not permitted within city vehicles while the vehicle is in operation unless said device is in "hands-free" mode. 
(8)  City employees are required to follow all federal, state, and local laws and ordinances while operating a city vehicle. Any violation of federal, state or local laws and ordinances related to the operation of a city vehicle shall be a violation of city policy. 
(9)  An employee receiving a traffic citation while operating a city vehicle shall immediately notify the city attorney who shall maintain a list of all such citations. Said list shall be reported to the common council with the annual take-home vehicle list. The city assumes no responsibility or obligation to pay for any citations issued to any employee operating a city vehicle. 
(d)  All take-home vehicles, except for police and fire vehicles, shall be clearly marked with semi-permanent, large (not less than 18 inches diameter) city logo stickers on the front driver and passenger doors. Police vehicles which are not classified as "confidential" or "unmarked" by the chief of police shall bear the insignia of the police department. Fire vehicles shall bear the insignia of the fire department. All take-home vehicles, except for police and fire vehicles, shall bear the words "FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY" in capital letters not less than four inches tall horizontally across the back window of the vehicle. 
(e)  In order to be eligible for assignment of a take-home vehicle an employee must live within the corporate limits. An exception to this is for public safety. This shall specifically include police and fire vehicles. 
(f)  The non-administrative officers of the police department shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(g)  The initial take-home vehicle list shall be submitted to the common council for approval at their next regular meeting immediately following the passage of the ordinance from which this section derives and its approval by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 17-18, § 1, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 2-86. - Official emails. 
    Every elected or appointed official and employee of the city shall use only their official city e-mail account (@portage-in.com) for all e-mail communications related to city business. 
(Ord. No. 18-18, § 1, 10-30-18) 
Secs. 2-87-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY ENGINEER 

Sec. 2-96. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created in the city the office of city engineer. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-1) 
Secs. 2-97-2-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXPENSES 

Sec. 2-106. - Membership fees. 
(a)  The common council may appropriate necessary funds to provide membership for the city, elected and appointed officials, and members of the boards and agencies in local, regional, state, and national associations of a civic, educational, or governmental nature which have as their purpose the betterment and improvement of municipal operations. 
(b)  The common council shall designate the associations to which dues may be paid. 
(c)  The city may participate through duly designated representatives in the meetings and activities of such associations and the common council may appropriate the necessary funds to defray the expenses of such representatives in connection therewith. 
(Code 1985, § 2-6-1) 
Sec. 2-107. - Promotion of city interests. 
    The common council is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the general fund of the city to pay the expenses of or to reimburse city officials for expenses incurred in promoting the best interests of the city. Such expenses may include, but not necessarily be limited to the rental of meeting places, meals, decorations, memorabilia, awards, expenses incurred in interviewing job applicants, expenses incurred in promoting industrial, commercial and residential development, expenses incurred in developing relations with other units of government, and any other expenses of a civic or governmental nature deemed by the mayor to be in the interest of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 2-6-2) 
Sec. 2-108. - Travel and reimbursement. 
    Whenever any elected or appointed official travels on authorized city business, the following standards for reimbursement shall apply to that official's expenses while engaged in city business. Unless otherwise noted, itemized receipts are required for all reimbursements. In such instances where an official city credit card is used to charge expenses, the same standards shall apply. Officials charging unauthorized expenses on city credit cards shall be personally liable for such charges and any related interest and fees. 
(1)  Meals. Meals included in registration/conference fees are not eligible for additional reimbursement. Meal expenses incurred by an official when on city business outside of the normal work environment are eligible for reimbursement. The United States General Services Administration individual meal reimbursement rates as provided in the Meal & Incidental Expense breakdown table for the location of travel shall be the maximum allowable reimbursement amount for each meal. Alcohol expenses shall not be reimbursed. Gratuity up to 15 percent may be reimbursed. Meal costs related to an official's family traveling with them on city business shall not be reimbursed. 
(2)  Lodging. Lodging expenses may be reimbursed for travel on official city business at least 75 miles distant from the city. Reimbursement for lodging within the State of Indiana shall be limited to the maximum in-state lodging rate set by the Indian Department of Administration. An itemized receipt shall be required for reimbursement. While family may accompany an official on city travel when appropriate, the reimbursement rate shall be limited to the single occupancy or equivalent room rate. Luxury items such as movies, mini bar or similar charges shall not be reimbursed. Officials shall utilize the "conference hotel" for conferences and events reserving a block of rooms. For overnight stays exceeding three nights, prior approval by the department head is required. Officials may extend their stay after the conclusion of city business for personal reasons at their own expense, provided that authorized expenses are not greater than what these expenses would have been if the official did not extend their stay. 
(3)  Transportation. Transportation expenses (air fare, taxis, shuttles, car rental, parking, tolls, etc.) when on city business may be reimbursed. Airline reservations shall be made in whatever manner results in the lowest fare available. Seat or boarding upgrades are not reimbursable. Reasonable baggage fees may be reimbursed. Travel of distances less than 300 miles may not be by air. Itemized receipts are not required for parking and toll expenses however proof of the expense is required. Officials may be reimbursed for use of their personal vehicle while traveling on city business at the current per mile rate set by the Indiana Department of Administration. The mileage reimbursement is intended to cover all parking and toll expenses and no additional reimbursement for these expenses will be provided. When one or more officials are traveling via automobile to the same destination they shall car pool to the extent feasible. 
(4)  Local functions. Local events such as luncheons or banquets may be reimbursed when related to city business. 
(5)  Appropriation. It shall be the responsibility of the official seeking reimbursement, or the supervisor authorizing the trip, to ensure a sufficient appropriation balance exists to cover estimated expenses prior to travel. 
(6)  Security. Officials may not utilize security details provided by the police department or private security without prior authorization by the common council. 
(7)  Retreats. Meetings or retreats of city officials requiring travel outside the city may not occur more than one time per year without prior appropriation by the common council. Retreats may not be located outside the State of Indiana or Chicago metropolitan region. Overnight retreats require prior appropriation by the common council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-6-3; Ord. No. 86-2, §§ 1, 3, 1-7-86; Ord. No. 90-63, § 1, 11-7-90; Ord. No. 00-8, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 17-22, § 1, 10-3-17) 
Sec. 2-109. - Claim payments in advance of board allowance. 
(a)  With the prior written approval of the board having jurisdiction over the allowance of claims, the clerk-treasurer may make claim payments in advance of board allowance for the following kinds of expenses: 
(1)  Property or services purchased or leased from the United States government, its agencies, or its political subdivisions. 
(2)  License or permit fees. 
(3)  Insurance premiums. 
(4)  Utility payments or utility connection charges. 
(5)  General grant programs where advance funding is not prohibited and the contracting party posts sufficient security to cover the amount advanced. 
(6)  Grants of state funds authorized by statute. 
(7)  Maintenance or service agreements. 
(8)  Leases or rental agreements. 
(9)  Bond or coupon payments. 
(10)  Payroll. 
(11)  State, federal or county taxes. 
(12)  Expenses that must be paid because of emergency circumstances. 
(13)  Travel expenses in connection with authorized city business. 
(b)  Each payment of expenses under this section must be supported by a fully itemized invoice or bill, and certification by the clerk-treasurer. 
(c)  The city board having jurisdiction over the allowance of a claim shall review and allow the claim at its next regular or special meeting following the pre-approved payment of the expense. 
(Ord. No. 00-19, § 1, 6-6-00) 
Secs. 2-110-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-131. - Project labor agreements required for city construction projects. 
(a)  Policy statement. It is the policy of the City of Portage to provide for the negotiation of mutually acceptable project labor agreements with local labor unions representing experienced and skilled construction workers covering public construction, alteration or repair work. 
(b)  Project labor agreements. 
(1)  All solicitations for bids issued by the city shall, except as otherwise provided herein, include the following language: 
"Each successful bidder and any and all levels of subcontractors, regardless of tier, as a condition of being awarded a contract or subcontract will agree to abide by the provisions of the (INSERT NAME OF PROJECT) Project Labor Agreement as executed and effective by and between the Project Manager and/or Construction Manager authorized to negotiate and enter into such a Project Labor Agreement on behalf of the City of Portage and the local labor unions representing experienced and skilled construction workers and will be bound by the provisions of that Agreement in the same manner as any other provision of the contract." 
(2)  Any "Instructions to Bidders" or like document issued for a public works project by the city shall, except as otherwise provided herein, include the following language: 
"The general contract (and all independent subcontracts, i.e., subcontracts not included within a general contract and regardless of tier) will be awarded to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder complying with the conditions and requirements provided in these Instructions, the bid forms and the other bid documents. A 'responsible and responsive' bidder is a bidder demonstrably possessing the skill, ability and integrity necessary to faithfully perform the work called for by the contract, based upon a determination of competent workmanship in accordance with Indiana Code 36-1-12-4 or any successor statute. An 'eligible' bidder is a bidder who is not debarred from bidding under any applicable law, and which shall certify that it is able to furnish labor that can work in harmony with all other elements of labor employed or to be employed on the project. In the interests of such harmony, the long-term supply of skilled labor, and to provide a legally enforceable means of assuring labor stability and labor peace over the life of the project, each successful bidder and any and all levels of subcontractors, regardless of tier, as a condition of being awarded a contract or subcontract, shall be required to enter into a Project Labor Agreement for the (INSERT NAME OF PROJECT) project with local labor unions representing experienced and skilled construction workers for the development and construction of the project, and will be bound by the provisions of that Project Labor Agreement in the same manner as any other provision of the contract." 
(c)  Exception to use of project labor agreements. Project labor agreements shall not be required for professional services provided for a city project. There may be additional circumstances there the benefits of proceeding without a project labor agreement may substantially exceed the benefits of proceeding with such an agreement. In that case, the specific department involved in such project shall prepare and submit a written report to the common council. Based on that report, the common council shall determine whether to proceed without such an agreement. 
(d)  Enforcement. The common council retains its inherent authority to adopt means to enforce compliance by any contractor or subcontractor, regardless of tier, with the provisions of any project labor agreement entered into on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-8, §§ 1-4, 2-2-99) 
Sec. 2-132. - Authorized methods of payment to the city. 
(a)  Pursuant to Indiana Code Section 36-1-8-11, the City of Portage is hereby authorized to accept the following types of financial instruments for payment: 
(1)  Cash. 
(2)  Check. 
(3)  Bank draft. 
(4)  Money order. 
(5)  Bank card/debit card. 
(6)  Credit card. 
(7)  Electronic fund transfer. 
(b)  The clerk-treasurer has the authority to determine if, and under what circumstances, to accept for payment any of the financial instruments listed above as he, in his discretion, believes is in the best financial interest of the city. The procedure for acceptance of payments with a bank card or credit card must be uniformly applied to all payments of the same type. 
(c)  If the city incurs any charge for the use of any type of financial instrument set forth above, the city may collect a sum equal to the amount of the charge from the person or entity that uses the financial instrument. 
(d)  This subsection shall apply only to charges collected for the park non-reverting operating and park non-reverting capital funds. If recovery of the full amount of the charge for the use of any type of financial instrument incurred by the city is not permitted under any contract or other agreement with a credit card or bank card vendor, the city may absorb the charges. 
(Ord. No. 12-07, § 1, 5-1-12) 
Sec. 2-133 - Minimum internal control standards. 
(a)  Application. This section shall apply to all employees, officials, and officers of the city whose official duties include receiving, processing, depositing, disbursing, or otherwise having access to funds that belong to the federal government, state government, a political subdivision, or another governmental entity. 
(b)  Adoption of standards. Effective July 1, 2016, the Uniform Internal Control Standards of Indiana Political Subdivisions published by the Indiana State Board of Accounts shall be adopted in its entirety as the internal control standards for the City of Portage herein referred to as "Control Standards". 
(c)  Future changes by state board. the Control Standards shall incorporate all future, published modifications to the Uniform Internal Control Standards of Indiana Political Subdivisions by the Indiana State Board of Accounts. 
(d)  Training. The clerk-treasurer shall ensure employees identified in subsection (a) receive appropriate training within 60 days following adoption of the Control Standards. New employees shall receive training during their new employee orientation and before having access to any funds that belong to the city. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 6-7-16) 
Secs. 2-134, 2-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 1.5. - CREDIT CARDS FOR CITY PURCHASES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-23, § A, adopted Dec. 1, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 2-135-2-146. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, Ord. No. 15-23 has been codified herein as Div. 1.5, §§ 2-136-2-140.6 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-136. - Authority. 
    This article is adopted in compliance with the "State Board of Accounts Accounting and Uniform Compliance Guidelines Manual for Cities and Towns", chapter 7, authorizing a city to use credit cards and purchasing cards for city purchases. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-137. - Authorization. 
    City of Portage employees and officials may use city credit cards and purchasing cards for purchases related to the performance of city duties when such use is in the best interests of the City of Portage. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-138. - Clerk-treasurer to obtain. 
    The clerk-treasurer shall apply for and obtain credit cards and purchasing cards titled for the city for the clerk-treasurer and mayor. All credit cards and purchasing cards shall be held, maintained, and monitored by the clerk-treasurer and mayor respectfully. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-139. - Revocation of cards. 
    The clerk-treasurer is authorized to revoke any credit cards or purchasing cards that have been used in violation of city policy. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140. - Authorization and log. 
    City credit cards and purchasing cards shall be used only with the respective approval of the clerk-treasurer or mayor. The clerk-treasurer and mayor shall ensure that a proper accounting system or log is maintained on all credit cards and purchasing card usage. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140.1. - General use; log. 
    City credit cards and purchasing cards shall only be used with the approval of the clerk-treasurer and mayor. The clerk-treasurer and mayor shall each maintain a respective usage log for each card identified by card account number, with entries certified by the signature of the clerk-treasurer and mayor respectively. The log shall include the following information: (1) the name and position of the individual using the city's card; (2) the date the card is issued to an individual for use, the estimated amounts to be charged, the type of expenses, and the appropriation account numbers to be expended; and (3) the date the card is returned and the amount charged to the card. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140.2. - General use. 
    City credit cards and purchasing cards shall be used for city purposes only. No personal use of a city credit card or purchasing card is allowed, even if an employee offers to reimburse the city for the employee's personal use of a city credit card or purchasing card. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140.3. - Nonallowed charges. 
    Credit card and purchasing card charges that do not meet audit requirements, including the imposition of sales taxes for which the city is otherwise exempt, are the personal responsibility of the employee authorizing the charge. The city will take all necessary steps to obtain reimbursement of the charges which do not meet audit requirements from the employee authorizing the charge, including, but not limited to, the garnishment of the charging employee's city wages. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140.4. - Audit requirements. 
    Payment of credit card and purchasing card bills shall be subject to the audit requirements of accounts payable vouchers in conformity with IC 5-11-10 and IC 36-4-8 and the regulations of the Indiana State Board of Accounts. Itemized receipts are required for all credit card and purchasing card purchases, including restaurant charges. Payment will not be made on the basis of a credit card or purchasing card statement. Signed charge slips showing a total charge only, without an itemization of items purchased, are not acceptable. It is the personal responsibility of the employee authorizing the charge to obtain proper itemized receipts. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140.5. - Interest and penalties. 
    All claims for payment must be properly itemized and documented. Improperly itemized or documented charges, as well as all interest, carrying charges and/or penalties incurred due to late filing or delay in forwarding proper documentation, shall be the personal responsibility in the individual credit card or purchasing card user. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 2-140.6. - Lost or stolen cards. 
    The clerk-treasurer shall be notified immediately if a credit card or purchasing card is lost or stolen. If a credit card or purchasing card is lost due to the negligence on the part of a city employee, the employee shall be personally responsible for any and all expenses incurred on the lost credit card or purchasing card. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, § A, 12-1-15) 
DIVISION 2. - SELF-INSURANCE 

Sec. 2-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative expenses (ADMIN) means all expenses incurred in connection with the procedures detailed in sections 2-147 and 2-149. 
    City means the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    CITY means the City of Portage, Indiana, the department of parks and recreation of the city, and the Portage Utility Service Board. 
    City attorney means the attorney for the city; provided, that if the Portage Utility Service Board shall participate under this division, such expression shall mean the attorney for the sanitary board as to all claims anticipated or asserted against the sanitary board. 
    Claims means requests or demands for payment in connection with comprehensive general liability, physical damage, or administrative expenses. 
    Comprehensive general liability (CGL) means liability or potential liability asserted or anticipated against the city, arising out of the acts or omissions of any employees of the city specifically including liability for claims of discrimination of all types, but excluding, however, liability which is otherwise subject to state worker's compensation laws or worker's occupational diseases laws. 
    Earnings of the fund means all income earned through investment of fund monies, and all other sums payable to the CITY as a result of litigation or settlement in connection with fund purposes. 
    Expenses of investigation means costs, expenses, adjusting, and professional fees incurred in the investigation of any claim, whether the claim is anticipated or has been asserted. 
    Expenses of litigation means costs and expenses incurred in or associated with the litigation of any claim asserted against the CITY, or of any claim asserted by the CITY against others by way of subrogation or as a countersuit for assertion of a frivolous or unfounded claim, or of any claim asserted against any employees or elected or appointed officials of the CITY whose alleged misconduct occurred within the scope of their employment or duties as such elected or appointed official; such costs and expenses shall include, but shall not necessarily be limited to, court costs, deposition expenses, fees of expert witnesses, subpoena fees, the cost of preparing trial exhibits, and the reasonable fees of attorneys, paralegals, and law clerks, as established from time to time by the mayor. 
    Fund means the cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund created by this division. 
    Physical damage (PD) means any damage to physical property, including vehicles and equipment, owned by the city, but excluding buildings and structures and their contents, and also excluding street lights and traffic signals owned by the city. 
    Reserve for losses means an accounting determination by which the probable overall expense associated with a claim is estimated. 
    Subrogation means recovery of sums paid from the fund for physical damage to CITY property, where such damage was occasioned by the fault of someone other than the CITY or its employees or elected or appointed officials. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 1(1)-(6), (8)-(14), 6-2-87; Ord. No. 90-65, § 1, 11-7-90; Ord. No. 02-31, § 1, 7-2-02; Ord. No. 16-11, § 1, 7-5-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- Worker's compensation, IC 22-3-1-1 et seq.; occupational diseases, IC 22-3-7-2 et seq.; employment and training services, IC 22-4-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-142. - Creation of fund. 
    There is hereby created a cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund (the fund). The fund shall be nonreverting. It shall be used for the purposes and in the manner set forth in this division, and it shall be funded by appropriations or reappropriations made by the common council in such amounts and at such times as are necessary to meet the purposes of the fund and to otherwise comply with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 2, 6-2-87) 
Sec. 2-143. - Purposes of fund. 
(a)  The fund shall be used only in connection with comprehensive general liability and physical damage claims anticipated or asserted against the CITY, or against any employees or elected or appointed officials of the CITY against whom claims are asserted, so long as such claims arise within the scope of CITY employment or from the performance of duties as such employees or elected or appointed officials. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the fund shall be used for the following purposes: 
(1)  To pay any claim, so long as the same has been approved as required by this division, or has been reduced to final judgment against the CITY; 
(2)  To pay the expenses of investigation of any claim; 
(3)  To pay expenses of litigation associated with any claim; 
(4)  To pay the costs and expenses of any seminars (including reasonable transportation, meals, and lodging), other instructional courses, literature, and dues and membership fees associated with questions of city liability; and 
(5)  To pay the expenses of independent adjusters employed by the city, including persons engaged to consult on loss management techniques and internal loss controls. 
(6)  To pay for the cost of liability insurance policies. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provisions in this division to the contrary, the fund shall not be used to replace or repair any CITY buildings (including contents), or CITY street lights and traffic signals, or to pay any CITY worker's compensation claims. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this division to the contrary, funds accumulated in the city cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund may be transferred to the city health insurance fund. Money may be transferred under the authority of this subsection only after the mayor issues a declaration that the health insurance fund is in immediate financial danger which requires a transfer of money. No such transfer shall deplete the cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund below the amount necessary to cover reserves for losses and other anticipated administrative expenses during the year in which the transfer is made. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 3, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 91-43, § 1, 9-24-91; Ord. No. 16-11, § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 2-144. - Participation in plan. 
(a)  The city and the department of parks and recreation of the city and the Portage Utility Service Board shall participate in the plan of self-insurance created by this division, so long as such latter entities elect to do so and such election, made in writing, is accepted by the council and accompanied by such intergovernmental agreements, if any, as may by law be required. 
(b)  No participant in the plan of self-insurance created by this division shall undertake any potentially hazardous activity, or undertake or implement any program which has potential for personal injury and/or physical damage to any meaningful extent, except upon having first received prior approval of the advisory claims committee, in writing. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 4, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 16-11, § 3, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 2-145. - Amount funded. 
(a)  The city's share of the fund shall be funded by the council through total appropriations. For each year and until the fund balance, exclusive of the cost of comprehensive liability insurance and reserves for losses and other anticipated administrative expenses, reaches the sum of not less than $750,000.00, the council shall appropriate or reappropriate to the fund each year a sum not less than $225,000.00. 
(b)  If the Portage Utility Service Board participates in the plan of self-insurance, the council shall determine the first annual contribution to be made by it, based upon its prior claims experience and reasonably anticipated deviations from that experience, and it shall thereafter determine the amounts of the annual contributions from the Portage Utility Service Board primarily, but not entirely, upon its claims experience. 
(c)  In addition to the funding described above, to the extent that the cumulative total of the fund is insufficient to pay all claims and expenses associated with the purposes for which the fund was created, the council shall additionally appropriate or reappropriate such sums as are necessary to permit the fund to make such payments. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 5, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 16-11, § 4, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 2-146. - Earnings of fund; investments. 
    The earnings of the fund shall be deposited and redeposited in the fund, segregated from other funds of the CITY, and individually invested by the city's clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 6, 6-2-87) 
Sec. 2-147. - Investigation and defense of claims. 
(a)  Subject to employment by the city of independent adjusters and persons performing similar responsibilities, the investigation and defense of claims anticipated or asserted against the CITY shall be undertaken by the law department of the city, under the direction of the city attorney. 
(b)  In the investigation and defense of anticipated or asserted claims, the city attorney shall have the authority to undertake all or part of the legal work personally, to delegate any portion of the legal work to department members, to subcontract any portion of the legal work to other attorneys, paralegals, or law clerks, to employ claims adjusters, to employ experts, and to otherwise incur reasonable expenses, in the discretion of such attorney, in connection therewith. The city attorney shall remain primarily responsible for, and shall receive reasonably detailed and timely status reports with respect to, any matters the responsibility for which is so delegated or subcontracted. 
(c)  To the extent practical and possible, the police department shall assist in investigations if requested to do so. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 7, 6-2-87) 
Sec. 2-148. - Reserve for losses. 
    The city attorney may, in his/her sole discretion, within a reasonable time after a claim is asserted against the city or against any other plan participant, and after investigation of the same has been concluded, estimate an appropriate reserve for losses in connection with such claim, detailing each such estimate by expenses of investigation, expenses of litigation, and probable allowable claim, if any. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 8, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 16-11, § 5, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 2-149. - Prosecution of claims. 
    Upon authority of the council or the city's board of public works and safety, the city attorney shall prosecute civil claims for subrogation, for malicious prosecution and abuse of process, and for recovery of attorneys' fees and other damages in actions which were asserted against the CITY frivolously or without due regard to their merit. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 9, 6-2-87) 
Sec. 2-150. - Advisory claims committee. 
(a)  There is hereby created an advisory claims committee in and for the city. 
(b)  The advisory claims committee shall be composed of the mayor, one appointment from the council made by the mayor, one appointment from the council made by the council, the clerk-treasurer, one appointment from the Portage Utility Service Board made by the mayor, and one appointment from the Portage Park Board made by the mayor; provided, that in matters not involving the Portage Utility Service Board or the Portage Park Board, the absence of either of such board's appointed member shall not be considered for the purpose of determining the existence of a quorum; and further, no member appointed from the Portage Utility Service Board or from the Portage Park Board shall be entitled to vote on matters not directly affecting such board. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 10, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 16-11, § 6, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 2-151. - Approval of claims. 
(a)  PD Claims. All PD claims less than or equal to $10,000.00 shall be approved or rejected by the city's insurance administrator. All other PD claims shall be approved or rejected by the city's board of public works and safety. 
(b)  ADMIN claims. All ADMIN claims shall be approved or rejected by the city's board of public works and safety. 
(c)  CGL claims less than $20,000.00. All physical damage and property damage CGL claims less than or equal to $5,000.00 shall be approved or rejected by the city's insurance administrator. All other CGL claims for less than $20,000.00 shall be reviewed by the advisory claims committee, and a recommendation shall thereafter be made to the city's board of public works and safety, with such claims thereafter approved or rejected by the city's board of public works and safety. 
(d)  CGL claims $20,000.00 or greater. All CGL claims for $20,000.00 or more shall be reviewed by the advisory claims committee, and a recommendation shall thereafter be made to the council, with such claims thereafter approved or rejected by the council with the concurrence of the board of public works and safety. 
(e)  Judgment claims. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this division to the contrary, all claims, whether CGL or PD, which are represented by final judgment against the CITY shall not require approval of the advisory claim committee or the common council, but shall be submitted to and approved by the city's board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 11, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 90-21, § 1, 5-1-90; Ord. No. 94-15, §§ 1,2, 4-5-94; Ord. No. 16-11, § 7, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 2-152. - Payment of claims. 
    All PD claims, physical damage and property damage CGL claims approved by the insurance administrator pursuant to section 2-151 may be paid by the insurance administrator in his sole discretion. If so paid, the insurance administrator shall be reimbursed for those payments by the clerk-treasurer of the city unless the fund contains insufficient monies with which to make such payment; provided the clerk-treasurer shall first be presented with an appropriately signed claim form which meets the requirements of the Indiana State Board of Accounts and said claim from shall have been signed by a majority of the members of the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    All other claims approved as required by section 2-151 of this article shall promptly thereafter be paid by the clerk-treasurer of the city, unless the fund contains insufficient monies with which to make such payment; provided, that the clerk-treasurer shall first be presented with an appropriately signed claim form which meets the requirements of the Indiana State Board of Accounts, and said claim form shall have been signed by a majority of the board of public works and safety of the city. 
(Ord. No. 87-16, § 12, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 94-15, § 3, 4-5-94) 
State Law reference- State board of accounts, IC 5-11-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-153. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-11, § 8, adopted July 5, 2016, repealed § 2-153, which pertained to accounting reports and derived from Ord. No. 87-16, § 13, adopted June 2, 1987.
