DIVISION 3. - SPECIAL FUNDS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Youth commission gift fund, § 2-3; major moves construction fund, § 2-4; rainy day fund, § 2-5; emergency services, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, § ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 50; planning and development, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 70; vehicle inspection fund, § 78-32, utilities, ch. 82. 

Sec. 2-161. - Drain maintenance fund. 
(1)  Creation of fund. There is hereby created a drain maintenance fund, which shall be a nonreverting fund. Revenue received by the city from Porter County for drain maintenance shall be deposited into the fund. 
(2)  Uses of fund. Money in the drain maintenance fund may be used for the necessary or proper repair, maintenance, study or evaluation of the Justus arm of Willow Creek and related drains. If the amount of money in the drain maintenance fund is less than $500.00, the balance of the money in the fund may be transferred to the city's stormwater management board, in which event the drain maintenance fund shall be closed. 
(Ord. No. 07-51, §§ 1, 2, 9-11-07) 
Sec. 2-162. - Gift funds. 
(1)  Creation of gift funds. The following gift funds shall be created as nonreverting funds to be used for the purposes stated herein: 
(a)  Fire department CPR/EMS gift fund. This fund shall receive and hold money received by the fire department from the conduct of CPR classes, as well as all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of CPR/EMS activities. Monies deposited in the fund may be used for the purchase of CPR books and cards and the purchase and maintenance of CPR equipment without further appropriation. 
(b)  Fire department investigation team fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the fire department investigation team. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purposes of the fire department investigation team without further appropriation. 
(c)  Fire department dive team fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the fire department dive team. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purposes of the fire department dive team without further appropriation. 
(d)  Fire department fire prevention fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of fire prevention activities. Money deposited in the fund may be used to purchase fire prevention supplies and equipment and to conduct fire-prevention programs without further appropriation. 
(e)  Fire department training fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of fire department training. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the maintenance and purchase of training equipment and to pay for the cost of training activities without further appropriation. 
(f)  Fire department various purchases fund. This fund shall receive and hold money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the fire department generally. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purchase of various supplies and equipment by the fire department without further appropriation. 
(g)  Police department reserve fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the police department reserves. Money deposited in the fund may be used to maintain and purchase equipment and uniforms for the police department reserves without further appropriation. 
(h)  Handicap parking fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the city's handicap parking enforcement program. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purchase of cameras and other equipment for handicap parking enforcement without further appropriation. 
(i)  Police department K-9 fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the police department K-9 program. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purchase of equipment for the police dogs and the K-9 vehicles, as well as for K-9 training without further appropriation. 
(j)  Police department SWAT team fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the police department SWAT team. Money deposited in the fund may be used to purchase and maintain equipment for the SWAT team and for SWAT team training without further appropriation. 
(k)  Police department crash team fund. The fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the police department crash team. Money deposited in the fund may be used to maintain and purchase equipment and to pay for training for the crash team without further appropriation. 
(l)  Police department gift fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the police department in general. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purchase and maintenance of miscellaneous equipment for the police department without further appropriation. 
(m)  Animal control gift fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the department of animal control. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purposes of animal control without further appropriation. 
(n)  Police evidence gift fund. This fund shall receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of the city police department evidence officers. Money deposited in the fund may be used for the purposes of the city police department evidence officers without further appropriation. 
(2)  Investment of gift funds. The clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to invest the funds created by this section with or separately from the remainder of the general fund in any suitable manner as is now provided by state statute and/or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 07-91, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 13-27, § 1, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 17-9, § 1, 6-6-17) 
Sec. 2-163. - Cumulative capital development fund. 
(1)  Uses and purposes of fund. The city cumulative capital development fund and the uses associated therewith are modified herein. 
(2)  Uses of the fund. The funds accumulated in the city cumulative capital development fund may be used for one or more of the following purposes, to wit: 
(a)  For the improvement of bridges, approaches, and grade separations as described in IC 8-16-3 et seq. 
(b)  Cumulative building fund for spending for interstate air transportation as described in IC 8-22-3-25. 
(c)  Cumulative building fund for erection of levies, gates, pumping stations, or other facilities or the addition to or improvement of the facilities and the levies as described in IC 14-27-6-48. 
(d)  Cumulative maintenance fund for the maintenance of channel improvements, levies, water retarding, or impoundment structures as described in IC 14-33-14. 
(e)  For cumulative hospital building fund as described in IC 16-23-1-40. 
(f)  For cumulative firefighting building and equipment fund including the purchase of fire equipment, purchase of police radio equipment, and purchase [of] construction renovation or addition to a building or purchase of land or purchase of equipment as described in IC 36-8-14 et seq. 
(g)  For use in a cumulative transportation fund to provide money for the acquisition of buses and the establishment of routes and schedules as described in IC 36-9-4-48. 
(h)  For the establishment of a cumulative building or sinking fund or cumulative capital improvements fund to provide money for generally the construction of public buildings, demolition of any improvements, acquisition of rights-of-way, construction of a public way as described in IC 36-9-16-2. 
(i)  For the establishment of a cumulative capitol improvement fund for the purposes of public ways or sidewalks, construction and sanitary or storm sewers, maintenance of sanitary or storm sewers, and the purchase or lease of buildings or rights-of-way for the purposes of utility, acquisition of land for park purposes and the purchase price or lease of motor vehicles for the use of the police or fire departments as well as additional more specific purposes outlined and as described in IC 36-9-16-3. 
(j)  For the establishment of a cumulative street fund to provide money for the acquisition of rights-of-way for public ways or sidewalks, construction or reconstruction of public rights-of-ways or sidewalks as described in IC 36-9-16.5 et seq. 
(k)  For the establishment of a municipal general improvement fund that shall be used to construct, repair, or improve streets, alleys, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, and sewers as described in IC 36-9-17 et seq. 
(l)  For the establishment of a cumulative building fund for municipal sewers including, but not limited to, sewage disposal plants and storm sewers and infrastructure associated therewith as described in IC 36-9-26 et seq. 
(m)  For the establishment of a cumulative drainage fund and as described in IC 36-9-27-100. 
(n)  For the establishment of a cumulative building fund for the building, remodeling, or repair of park and recreation facilities or the purchase of land for park and recreation purposes and as described in IC 36-10-3-21. 
(o)  For the establishment of a cumulative building and sinking fund for the purposes of a park district cumulative building and sinking fund and as described in IC 36-10-4-36. 
(3)  Emergency use of the fund. Notwithstanding section above, funds accumulated in the city cumulative capital development fund may be spent for purposes other than the purposes stated in this section if the purpose is to protect the public health, welfare, or safety in an emergency situation which demands immediate action. Money may be spent under the authority of this section only after the mayor issues a declaration that the public health, welfare, or safety is in immediate danger that requires the expenditures of money in the fund. 
(Ord. No. 08-19, §§ 1-3, 5-7-08) 
DIVISION 4. - ELECTRONIC SIGNATURE AND ELECTRONIC RECORDKEEPING POLICY 

Sec. 2-164. - Definitions. 
    City business transaction(s) shall refer to an action or set of actions relating to the conduct of business, or commercial affairs between the city and another person or persons. 
    Electronic shall mean relating to technology having electrical, digital, magnetic, wireless, optical, electromagnetic, or similar capabilities. 
    Electronic record(s) shall refer to a record created, generated, sent, communicated, received, or stored by electronic means. 
    Electronic signature(s) shall refer to an electronic sound, symbol, or process attached to or logically associated with an electronic record and executed or adopted by a person with the intent to sign the electronic record. 
    Person(s) shall include an individual, firm, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, co-partnership, association, club, company, corporation, business, trust, estate, governmental entity organization, or any other legal entity or group acting as a unit, or its legal representatives, agents or assignees, or the manager, lessee, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
(Ord. No. 12-14, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Sec. 2-165. - Permissible uses of electronic signatures and electronic records. 
(1)  The city is authorized to use electronic signatures and electronic records to conduct city business transactions with another person. 
(2)  To the extent the decisions are consistent with IC 26-2-8 et seq. and federal law, city officials and city department heads are authorized to: 
a.  Determine when it shall be appropriate to use electronic signatures and electronic records while conducting city business transactions with other persons and determine how such signatures and records will be preserved; 
b.  Produce, receive, accept, acquire, transmit, forward, store, preserve, or maintain records in electronic form which involve city business transactions; 
c.  Establish policies and procedures for both use and acceptance of electronic signatures and electronic records for conducting city business transactions; and 
d.  Establish policies for what city departments shall make use of electronic signatures and electronic records for conducting city business transactions. 
(3)  Unless otherwise provided by law, electronic signatures may be used as a legal form of acceptance by a person to a contract with the city and such signatures shall not be denied legal effect or enforceability solely because they are in electronic format. 
(4)  Unless otherwise provided by law, electronic records of city business transactions shall be treated the same as any other business record and shall not be denied legal effect or enforceability solely because they are in electronic format. 
(Ord. No. 12-14, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Secs. 2-166-2-169. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MOTOR VEHICLE EXCISE AND WHEEL TAXES 

Sec. 2-170 - Municipal motor vehicle license excise wheel surtax. 
(1)  Creation of fund. There is hereby created a municipal surtax fund, which shall be a non-reverting fund. Revenues received from the Department of Motor Vehicles from taxes imposed under this section shall be deposited into the fund. 
(2)  Tax rates. Effective January 1, 2017 and in accordance with IC 6-3.5-10-2(c), the surtax shall be imposed at the following rates: 
a.  Passenger vehicles: $25.00 per year. 
b.  Motorcycles: $12.50 per year. 
c.  Trucks with a declared gross weight that does not exceed 11,000 pounds: $25.00 per year. 
d.  Motor driven cycles: $12.50 per year. 
(3)  Vehicle definitions. The definitions set forth in the Act shall apply to this section. 
(4)  Uses of fund. Funds in the municipal surtax fund may be used for one or more of the following purposes: 
a.  To construct, reconstruct, repair, or maintain streets and roads under the city's jurisdiction; 
b.  For the city's contribution to obtain a grant from the local road and bridge matching grant fund pursuant to IC 8-23-30. 
(5)  Transportation asset management plan. the mayor shall prepare a transportation asset management plan, approved by the Indiana Department of Transportation, as required by IC 6-3.5-10-2(e) and IC 6-3.5-11-2(c) and submit a copy of such plan to the common council on or before August 1 of each year. 
(6)  Accounting of fund. On or before August 1 of each year, the clerk-treasurer shall provide the common council an estimate of the surtax revenues to be received by the city under this section during the next calendar year. The city shall include the estimated surtax revenues in the city's budget estimate for the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 16-9, § 1, 5-5-16) 
Sec. 2-171 - Municipal wheel tax. 
(1)  Creation of fund. There is hereby created a municipal wheel tax fund, which shall be a non-reverting fund. Revenues received from the Department of Motor Vehicles from taxes imposed under this section shall be deposited into the fund. 
(2)  Tax rates. Effective January 1, 2017 and in accordance with IC 6-3.5-11-2(d), the wheel tax shall be imposed on the following non-exempt vehicles at the following rates: 
a.  Buses: $40.00 per year. 
b.  Recreational Vehicles: $12.50 per year. 
c.  Semitrailers: $40.00 per year. 
d.  Tractors: $40.00 per year. 
e.  Trailers: $12.50 per year. 
f.  Trucks: $40.00 per year. 
(3)  Vehicle definitions. The definitions set forth in the Act shall apply to this section. 
(4)  Uses of fund. Funds in the municipal wheel tax fund may be used for one or more of the following purposes: 
a.  To construct, reconstruct, repair, or maintain streets and roads under the city's jurisdiction; 
b.  As a contribution to an authority established under IC 36-7-23; 
c.  For the city's contribution to obtain a grant from the local road and bridge matching grant fund under IC 8-23-30. 
(5)  Transportation asset management plan. the mayor shall prepare a transportation asset management plan as required in section 2-170. 
(6)  Accounting of fund. On or before August 1 of each year, the clerk-treasurer shall provide the common council an estimate of the wheel tax revenues to be received by the city under this section during the next calendar year. The city shall include the estimated wheel tax revenues in the city's budget estimate for the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 16-9, § 1, 5-5-16) 
Secs. 2-172-2-174. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CITY OFFICIALS; ETHICS AND CONFLICTS OF INTEREST 

Sec. 2-175. - Definitions. 
    Agency means the City of Portage or any department, division, bureau, office, board, commission or committee of the city. 
    Assist means to: 
(a)  Help; 
(b)  Aid; 
(c)  Advise; or 
(d)  Furnish information to; 
a person. The term includes an offer to do any of the actions in clauses (a) through (d). 
    Business associate includes the following: 
(a)  An employer. 
(b)  A corporation, general or limited partnership, or other business entity, in which an official, consultant, or other person subject to the article: 
(1)  Has an investment interest; 
(2)  Owns; or 
(3)  Has a beneficial interest. 
(c)  A corporation, business association, or other business entity in which the official, consultant, or other person subject to the article serves as an agent or a compensated representative. 
    Candidate means an individual who seeks nomination or election to a city office. An individual is a candidate when the individual: 
(a)  Files a statement of candidacy or petition for nomination for office with the appropriate filing officer. 
(b)  Is nominated for office by: 
(1)  A party at primary; 
(2)  Nominating convention; or 
(3)  Petition for nomination; 
(c)  Solicits or receives and retains contributions, makes expenditures or gives consent to an individual, organized political party, or committee to solicit or receive and retain contributions or make expenditures to secure nomination or election to any office at any time, whether or not the office for which the individual will seek nomination or election is known when the: 
(1)  Solicitation is made; 
(2)  Contribution is received and retained; or 
(3)  Expenditure is made; or 
(d)  Is an office holder who is the subject of a recall election. 
    Charitable organization means an organization described in 26 U.S.C. § 170(c) as it currently exists or as it may be amended. 
    Compensation means any money, thing of value, service or economic benefit conferred upon or received by any person in return for services rendered or to be rendered. 
    Consultant means an individual other than an employee who contracts to: 
(a)  Evaluate bids for public contracts; or 
(b)  Awards public contracts for the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    Commission refers to the ethics commission created under section 2-176 of this article. 
    Dependent means an individual who is: 
(a)  The spouse, parent, sibling, child, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, grandparent or grandchild of an official or consultant; or 
(b)  A member of the household of an official or consultant. 
    Economic interest means an interest distinct from that of the general public in the city's purchase, sale, lease, contract, option or other transaction or arrangement involving property or services in which an official may gain an economic benefit of $50.00 or more. 
    Employee means any individual, other than an elected official, receiving compensation for services performed for the city except individuals who perform services as independent contractors. 
    Filer means an individual who is: 
(a)  An official; 
(b)  A candidate under the campaign finance laws of Indiana; 
(c)  A consultant who is required to file a statement of economic interest under this article. 
    Gift means money or other property having economic value which is transferred to an official without consideration in money or money's worth, other than a contribution pursuant to the Indiana campaign finance laws. The term includes a rebate or discount in the price of anything of value unless the rebate or discount is made in the ordinary course of business to a member of the general public without regard to that person's status as an official, candidate or consultant. 
(a)  The term does not include the following: 
(1)  Printed informational promotional material. Free printed material which can be distributed for the public awareness or public education, i.e., brochures, safety manuals, etc. 
(2)  A gift that: 
a.  Is not used; and 
b.  Not later than 30 days after receipt, is returned to the donor or delivered to a charitable organization and is not claimed as a charitable contribution for federal income tax purposes; 
(3)  A gift, devise, or inheritance from an individual's spouse, child, parent, grandparent, sibling, in-laws, or other relatives, so long as the donor is not acting as an intermediary for someone other than a person covered in this paragraph. 
(4)  A certificate, plaque or other token commemorative with a value that does not exceed $100.00. 
(5)  Food or beverage consumed on the occasion when participation in a charitable, civic, or community event which bears a relationship to the official's office and the official is attending in an official capacity. 
    Official means every individual elected to an office or position in any agency or appointed by the mayor as a department head. It also includes any person who does regular purchasing for any department of the city in amounts over $100.00. 
    Person means any individual, association, corporation, or other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 94-27, § 1, 7-5-94; Ord. No. 96-20, § 1, 6-4-96) 
Sec. 2-176. - Government ethics commission. 
(a)  Creation and composition of the commission. There is hereby created and established an ethics commission, consisting of five members who do not hold a position of employment in any agency, and who are not declared candidates for elected, non-party public office, or elected officials. 
(b)  Appointment of members and chairperson. The mayor of the city shall appoint two members of the commission. The common council shall appoint three members to the commission, one of whom shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Indiana. An attorney appointed hereunder shall either be a resident of the city or maintain an office in the city. All other members shall be residents of the city. All members shall have never been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony. 
(1)  The common council and the mayor shall each appoint not less than one member of the commission who shall be a member of the opposite political party of the majority of the council. Initially, one appointment by both the common council and the mayor shall serve for a term of one year, the other appointments shall serve for a term of two years. Thereafter, all terms shall expire after two years. Each appointee shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall be filled by the appointing authority which appointed the member creating the vacancy. A member appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve for the duration of the unexpired term. 
(c)  General authority of the ethics commission. The ethics commission shall have the powers and responsibilities: 
(1)  To adopt, amend, and rescind rules and regulations in furtherance of the operation of the commission. 
(2)  To make recommendations to the city council for amendments to this article and for such other legislation affecting the subject matter of this article as the ethics commission may deem necessary or desireable. 
(3)  To provide a continuing program of educational assistance and information regarding ethical conduct of all officials and consultants. 
(4)  To annually review statements of economic interest filed pursuant to section 2-177. 
(d)  Investigations. Upon request by the mayor, an official or employee, a member of the ethics commission, or any member of the city council, the commission may hold hearings to investigate possible violations of this article and if the commission finds that a violation of this article has occurred, it may recommend to the mayor or appropriate official a resolution of the violation, or public disclosure of the violation, or disciplinary action, which may include dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 94-27, § 2, 7-5-94; Ord. No. 96-52, § 1, 10-1-96) 
Sec. 2-177. - Economic interest disclosure. 
    Exceptions to reporting requirements. This section does not require the disclosure of economic information concerning the following: 
(a)  A spouse legally separated from the official or consultant. 
(b)  A former spouse. 
(c)  A gift from a family member. 
(d)  A campaign contribution that is permitted and reported to pursuant to Indiana campaign finance laws, if required. 
    The following individuals are required to file: 
(a)  All officials. 
(b)  Consultants. 
    When statements shall be filed: 
(a)  The statements of economic interest must be filed for the preceding year no later than February 1 of each year, complete through December 31 of the preceding year, except: 
(1)  In the case of an consultant employed after January 1, no later than March 1 or 41 days after employment. 
(2)  In the case of officials or consultants employed at the time of passage of this article, within 41 days after passage of this article. 
    This statement shall be made under oath subject to the criminal penalties for perjury in the State of Indiana and shall contain the following information: 
(a)  The name of the official, candidate or consultant; 
(b)  The business address of the official, candidate or consultant; 
(c)  The position in which the official, candidate or consultant serves an agency; 
(d)  The consultant's employer; 
(e)  A list stating to the best of the filer's knowledge and the ability to obtain that knowledge the amount and source of all gifts the official, candidate or consultant and his or her dependents received during the past calendar year having an aggregate fair market value in excess of $200.00 from any individual business entity doing business with an agency. 
(f)  A statement shall be made to the best of the filer's knowledge and the ability to obtain that knowledge, of whether or not the official, candidate or consultant or his or her dependents had a direct or indirect economic interest in any contract with the city, during the past calendar year, other than a contract of employment, and, if so, an explanation of the extent of the interest; 
(g)  The name of any person from which the official, candidate or consultant received any compensation which to the best of the filer's knowledge, does business with an agency during his or her term of office or employment with an agency or is in the process of bidding for a contract with an agency during his or her term of office or employment with an agency; and 
(h)  The name of any business entity in which the officer, candidte or consultant or his or her family member owns stock, bonds or other investments which represent ownership of five percent or more of the business or have a value in excess of $5,000.00 and which business entity, to the best of the filer's knowledge, is doing business with an agency or is in the process of bidding for a contract with an agency. 
(Ord. No. 94-27, § 3, 7-5-94) 
Sec. 2-178. - Standards of ethical conduct. 
(a)  Disqualification from acting on city business. Any official shall disqualify himself or herself and refuse to act on any matter in which such official, a dependent of the official, or the private employer of the official, has an economic interest or might derive a profit and upon which the official would be entitled to act in the discharge of his or her official duties. The participation of an official does not violate this section by discussion or voting at a meeting if: 
(1)  Disqualification of the official leaves the governing body of the agency with less than a quorum and, 
(2)  The official makes a disclosure under section 2-177 of this article. 
(b)  Improperly using official position. 
(1)  No official shall knowingly use, or permit the use of any individual, funds or property under his or her official control, direction, or custody, or any funds or property of an agency, for a purpose which is for the private benefit to the official or any other person. Nothing shall prevent the private use of property of an agency which is available on equal terms to the public generally (such as library books or tennis courts), or the use of property of an agency in accordance with municipal policy in the conduct of official business (such as the use of automobiles of an agency), or the use of off-duty equipment by law enforcement officers, if allowed by the rules of the respective department, if, in fact, the property is used appropriately. 
(2)  An official shall not advocate or cause the employment, appointment, promotion, transfer, or advancement of a dependent or business associate to a position in the city. an official shall not participate in an action relating to the employment or discipline of a dependent or business associate. 
(c)  Improper influence. No official, except in the course of official duties, shall assist any person in any transaction with an agency when such official's assistance is enhanced by that officials's position with an agency. The subsection shall not apply either to an official applying on his own behalf or representing himself as to any matter in which he has an economic interest, if not otherwise prohibited by law. 
(d)  Prohibition of certain financial interest No official, regardless of prior disclosure thereof, who has an ownership or equity interest, personally, or through a dependent, in any business entity doing or seeking to do business with any agency, shall knowingly influence or attempt to influence the selection of, or the conduct of business with, such business entity by any agency. 
(e)  Gifts or loans prohibited. No official shall solicit or receive anything of monetary value from any person when it has been solicited, received or given with the intent to give or obtain special consideration or influence as to any action by such official in his or her official capacity. Nothing shall prohibit contributions, including political contributions, which are reported in accordance with applicable law or which are accepted on behalf of any agency, or an honorarium, travel or other expenses reimbursed to any official as a result of a speaking engagement or personal appearance made as a result of that individual's official position. 
(f)  Gifts or honoraria prohibited. No official shall accept gifts or honoraria (including such received by his or her dependents) that exceed an aggregate value of $500.00 in any twelve consecutive months from an individual business entity and all subsidiaries thereof, that is doing business with the agency or is in the process of bidding for a contract with an agency in which the official holds an office or position. 
(g)  Disclosure of privileged information. No official shall disclose or use any information gained by reason of his or her official position for the immediate or anticipated personal gain or benefit of the official or any other person. However, nothing shall prohibit the disclosure or use of information which is a matter of public knowledge or which is available to the public on request. 
(h)  Prohibition of certain appointments. No dependent of an official may be appointed as a member of a city board or commission. 
(Ord. No. 94-27, § 4, 7-5-94; Ord. No. 96-34, § 1, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 2-179. - Complaints, investigations, hearings and appeals. 
(a)  Any person with personal knowledge may file a compliant alleging a violation of this article. If such complaint is filed by a member of the ethics commission, such member is then disqualified from participating in any proceedings that may arise from the complaint. 
(1)  The complaint shall be in writing and signed under the penalties of perjury by the affiant. The complaint shall state the nature of the alleged violation(s), the dates, time and place of each occurrence, and name of the persons charged with the violations. The complaint shall be filed with the secretary of the commission, the mayor, the president of the city council, and the person at whom the complaint is directed. The complainant shall also provide copies of any and all relevant documents to substantiate the allegations set forth. 
(2)  All complaints shall remain confidential. When a complaint reaches public hearing before the commission, the complaint and all records pertaining thereto shall become public records. 
(3)  Within 30 days after receipt of a complaint, the commission shall conduct a preliminary investigation. The commission may extend the time for the completion of such preliminary investigation if it determines that such extension is necessary or desirable and would not be prejudicial to the person charged with the violation. If the commission determines that the preliminary investigation must be completed in less than 30 days in order to avoid prejudice or irreparable harm to the person charged with the violation, the commission shall complete the preliminary investigation in a shorter period of time. 
(4)  If the commission determines, after preliminary investigation, that there are no reasonable grounds to believe that a violation has occurred, the commission shall dismiss the complaint. If the commission dismisses the complaint, it shall do so in writing, setting forth the facts and the provisions of law upon which the dismissal is based, and provide copies of the written dismissal to the complainant, to the person charged with the violation, to the mayor and to the president of the city council. The record shall remain confidential unless the person against whom the complaint was made requests disclosure. 
(5)  If, after preliminary investigation, the commission does not dismiss the complaint, the commission shall schedule the matter for hearing within 30 days, and the accused shall be given the opportunity to attend. The matter may be resolved at a prehearing conference between the commission and the person charged with the violation. 
(6)  All hearings that are held to determine whether the provisions of this article have been violated shall be conducted in conformance with the rules and regulations of the commission. 
(b)  The right to appeal decisions made by the commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  If an official objects to the findings of the commission he shall, within 15 days of notice thereof, file a notice of objection to the commission's findings. The official shall set forth specifically his objections and set forth specifically his request for relief. That notice shall be delivered to the office of the secretary of the commission. 
(2)  Within ten days of the delivery of notice the commission shall meet to consider the official's objections. The commission shall either affirm its original decision, amend its decision or reverse its decision based upon the request. 
(3)  If the official objects to the commission's decision, the official may appeal the commission's decision to the Porter Circuit or Superior Court. 
(4)  The standard of review shall be the same as the standard for reviewing all administrative decisions in the State of Indiana. 
(Ord. No. 94-27, § 5, 7-5-94) 
Sec. 2-180. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any official or consultant who knowingly fails to file a statement of economic interest when required by section 2-177 shall be subject to a fine of $25.00 for each 30 days the statement is delinquent. The commission shall have the discretion to waive any fine imposed by this section. 
(b)  Failure of any official, candidate or consultant to file a statement may also result in the commission reporting such failure to the appropriate supervisory or appointment authority and may be cause for suspension, discharge, removal from office, or other such disciplinary action as may, by the appropriate authority, be deemed necessary and proper. 
(c)  A violation of this article may be cause for suspension, discharge, removal from office, or such other disciplinary action as may, by the appropriate authority, be deemed necessary and proper, and consistent with personnel ordinances and rules. A written response outlining any action taken as a result of a recommendation of the ethics commission shall be made within 14 calendar days after receipt of the written recommendation. This section shall not derogate from employee rights under any collective bargaining agreement or personnel ordinance, or rule promulgated thereunto. If the appropriate authority determines that the written response required in this section cannot be made within 14 calendar days after receipt of the recommendation, because of procedures prescribed under any collective bargaining agreement, personnel ordinance, or rule promulgated thereunto, the appropriate authority shall so report within 14 days after receipt of the recommendation, stating the date on which the written response will be submitted to the ethics commission. Upon receipt of the written response, or in the event no response is received, the ethics commission shall review such matter and make such further recommendation(s) as may be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 94-27, § 6, 7-5-49) 
Secs. 2-181-2-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - POLICY CONCERNING NEPOTISM AND CONTRACTING WITH THE CITY 

Sec. 2-191. - Definitions. 
    City means the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    Direct line of supervision means an elected officer or employee who is in a position to affect the terms and conditions of another individual's employment, including making decisions about work assignments, compensation, grievances, advancement, or performance evaluation. The term does not include the responsibilities of the executive, legislative body, or fiscal body of the city, as provided by law, to make decisions regarding salary ordinances, budgets, or personnel policies of the city. 
    Elected official means the executive or a member of the executive body of the city; a member of the legislative body of the city; or a member of the fiscal body of the city. 
    Employed means an individual who is employed by the city on a full-time, part-time, temporary, intermittent, or hourly basis. The term does not include an individual who holds only an elected office. The term includes an individual who is a party to an employment contract with the city. 
    Member of the fire department means the fire chief or a firefighter appointed to the department. 
    Member of the police department means the police chief or a police officer appointed to the department. 
    Relative means any of the following: 
(1)  A spouse; 
(2)  A parent or stepparent; 
(3)  A child or stepchild; 
(4)  A brother, sister, stepbrother, or stepsister; 
(5)  A niece or nephew; 
(6)  An aunt or uncle; or 
(7)  A daughter-in-law or son-in-law. 
An adopted child of an individual is treated as a natural child of the individual. The terms "brother" and "sister" include a brother or sister by the half blood. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Sec. 2-192. - Employment of relatives. 
(a)  Individuals who are relatives may not be employed by the city in a position that results in one relative being in the direct line of supervision of the other relative. 
(b)  With regard to an individual who is employed by the city on the date the individual's relative begins serving a term of an elected office of the city may remain employed by the city and maintain the individual's position or rank even if the individual's employment would violate the prohibition against a relative being in the direct line of supervision of the other relative. 
(c)  An individual described in subsection (b) above shall not be promoted to a position, or in the case of an individual who is a member of a merit police department or merit fire department be promoted to a position that is not within the merit ranks; if the new position would violate the prohibition against one relative being in the direct line of supervision of the other relative. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Sec. 2-193. - Exclusions from section 2-192. 
(a)  An individual who is employed by the city on July 1, 2012 is not subject to these policies unless the individual has a break in employment with the city. Breaks in employment do not include the following: 
(1)  The individual is absent from the workplace while on paid or unpaid leave, including, vacation, sick, or family medical leave, or worker's compensation. 
(2)  The individual's employment with the city is terminated followed by an immediate reemployment by the city, without loss of payroll time. 
(b)  This chapter does not abrogate or affect an employment contract with the city that: 
(1)  An individual is a party to; and 
(2)  Is in effect on the date the individual's relative begins serving a term of an elected office of the city. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Sec. 2-194. - Contracting with relatives of current elected officials. 
(a)  The city may enter into a contract or renew a contract for the procurement of goods and services or a contract for public works with: 
(1)  An individual who is a relative of an elected official; or 
(2)  A business entity that is wholly or partially owned by a relative of an elected official; only if the requirements below are satisfied and the elected official does not violate IC 35-44-1-3. 
(b)  The city may enter into a contract or renew a contract with an individual or business entity described above if: 
(1)  The elected official files with the city a full disclosure, which must: 
a.  Be in writing; 
b.  Describe the contract or purchase to be made by the city; 
c.  Describe the relationship that the elected official has to the individual or business entity that contracts or purchases; 
d.  Be affirmed under penalty of perjury; 
e.  Be submitted to the common council and be accepted by the common council in a public meeting prior to final action on the contract or purchase; and 
f.  Be filed, not later than 15 days after final action on the contract or purchase, with: 
1.  Indiana State Board of Accounts; and 
2.  The clerk of the circuit court of the county; 
(2)  The appropriate agency of the city: 
a.  Makes a certified statement that the contract amount or purchase price was the lowest amount or price bid or offered; or 
b.  Makes a certified statement of the reasons why the vendor or contractor was selected; and 
(3)  The city satisfies any other requirements under IC 5-22 and IC 36-1-12. 
(c)  An elected official must also comply with the disclosure provisions of IC 35-44-1-3, if applicable. 
(d)  These provisions do not affect the initial term of a contract in existence at the time the term of office of the elected official begins. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Sec. 2-195. - Certification requirement. 
(a)  Each elected official of the city must annually certify in writing, subject to the penalties for perjury, that the elected official: 
(1)  Has not violated the provisions of IC 36-1-20.2 concerning nepotism; and 
(2)  Is in compliance with the provisions of IC 36-1-21 concerning contracting with the city. 
(b)  The elected official must submit the certification to the mayor not later than December 31 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Sec. 2-196. - Incorporation by reference. 
    This article is designed to comply with IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21. To the extent not expressly stated herein, the requirements of IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21 are incorporated by reference. To the extent required by IC 36-1-5-4, two copies of IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21 are on file in the office of the city's clerk-treasurer for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 7-3-12) 
Secs. 2-197-2-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SOCIAL MEDIA USE POLICY 

Sec. 2-200. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City social media sites means social media sites, pages, or accounts which the city, or any of its officials or employees, establishes and maintains for the city, any of its departments or any of its boards, and over which it has control over all postings, except for advertisements or hyperlinks by the social media site's owner, vendors, or partners. 
    Comment means a response to a city article or social media content submitted by a commenter. 
    Commenter means a city official or member of the public who submits a comment for posting in response to the content of a particular city article or social media content. 
    Posts or posting means information, articles, pictures, video or any other form of communication posted on a city social media site. 
    Social media means content created by individuals, using accessible, expandable and upgradable publishing technologies, through and on the internet. Social media uses many technologies and forms, including social-networking, blogs, wikis, photo-sharing, video-sharing, podcast, social bookmarking, mash-ups, widgets, virtual worlds, microblogs, Really Simple Syndication (RSS) and others. Examples of social media include, but are not limited to, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube, LinkedIn, Periscope, and Flickr. 
(Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, 10-2-18) 
Sec. 2-201. - Official city social media sites. 
(a)  The mayor shall authorize the creation of any city social media and designate officials and/or employees which may post to the site prior to the site's creation. 
(b)  All city social media sites shall bear the name and/or an official logo of the city or the appropriate department/board. 
(c)  City social media sites shall clearly state that such sites are maintained by the city and that the sites comply with the provisions of this article. Whenever possible, a hyperlink to this policy shall be displayed on each city social media site. 
(d)  Each city social media site shall include an introductory statement that clearly specifies the purpose and topical scope of the social media and social network site. 
(e)  Each city social media site shall utilize authorized city contact information for account set-up, monitoring and access. The use of personal email accounts or phone numbers by any city official or employee is not allowed for the purpose of setting up, monitoring, or accessing a city social media site. 
(Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, 10-2-18) 
Sec. 2-202. - Acceptable use. 
(a)  The city's official website at www.ci.portage.in.us (or any domain owned by the city) shall remain the city's primary means of internet communication. 
(1)  City social media sites shall link back to the city's official website for forms, documents, online services and other information necessary to conduct business with the city. 
(b)  The mayor shall determine the appropriate level of employee access, which includes what social media each department or individual is approved to use, as well as define their respective capabilities: publish, edit, comment or view only. 
(c)  Employees or officials representing the city on city social media sites shall conduct themselves at all times as a professional representative of the city and in accordance with all city policies and ordinances. 
(d)  City social media sites shall adhere to applicable federal and state laws, regulations and policies. 
(e)  Any employee or official authorized to post on any of the city's social media sites shall not express his or her own personal views or concerns through such posts. Instead, posts on any of the city's social media sites shall only reflect the views of the city. 
(f)  Posts, comments or responses on city social media sites, regardless of the commenter, shall not contain any of the following: 
(1)  Any personal information, except for the names of employees whose job duties include being available for contact by the public; 
(2)  Comments that are unrelated to the purpose and topical scope of the page; 
(3)  Comments in support of, or opposition to, political campaigns, candidates or ballot measures; 
(4)  Profane language, sexual content, pornography, obscenity, or links to any such content; 
(5)  Content that promotes, fosters or perpetuates discrimination on the basis of race, creed, color, age, religion, gender, disability, sexual orientation, political affiliations, citizenship, marital status, military/veteran status or national origin; 
(6)  Promotion or advertisement of a business or commercial transaction. 
(7)  Speech presenting a grave and imminent threat, fighting words, fraud and/or true threats. 
(8)  Conduct in violation of any federal, state, or local law and/or encouragement of illegal activity; 
(9)  Information that may tend to compromise the safety or security of the public or public systems; 
(10)  Comments on actual or potential legal claims, lawsuits or other legal issues; 
(11)  Defamatory or personal attacks; 
(12)  Comments which may reasonably interfere with, inhibit or compromise law enforcement investigations, police tactics, police responses to incidents and/or the safety of police staff and officers; or 
(13)  Content that violates a legal ownership interest of any other party. 
(g)  Comments posted to city social media sites not in conformity with the requirements of this article will be removed as soon as possible and without notice. 
(h)  A comment posted by a member of the public on any city social media site is the opinion of the commenter only, and publication of a comment does not imply endorsement of, or agreement by the city, nor do such comments necessarily reflect the opinions or policies of the city. 
(Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, 10-2-18) 
Sec. 2-203. - Public records. 
    The city acknowledges that city social media sites represent public records and shall act accordingly to preserve those records in accordance with state statute whenever possible. 
(Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, 10-2-18) 
Chapter 3 - HUMAN RIGHTS 
ARTICLE I. - PURPOSE 

Sec. 3-1. - Statement of purpose. 
    The City of Portage wishes to enshrine the values of its diversity as a strength, and appreciates the culture and history of its various communities of people, including immigrant communities, in the Municipal Code of the City of Portage as a permanent testament. 
(Ord. No. 18-2, § 1, 1-23-18) 
Sec. 3-2. - Commitment to the support of human rights. 
    The City of Portage recognizes that the United States Constitution and its amendments, particularly the Bill of Rights, guarantee fundamental human rights and civil liberties for the residents of Portage. 
    The city welcomes individuals of diverse racial, ethnic, religious, and national backgrounds and we recognize that our diversity is critical to the economic, cultural, and social progression of our region. 
    The city is committed to upholding the human rights of all persons in Portage, including United States citizens and citizens of other nations, and the free exercise and enjoyment of any and all rights and privileges secured by the constitutions of the United States of America and the State of Indiana. 
    The city calls upon all city officials and employees to respect the human rights and civil liberties of all members of this community and eliminate discrimination based on race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, age, disability, and veteran status. 
    Likewise, the city calls upon all private citizens, including residents, employers, educators and business owners, to demonstrate similar respect for human rights and civil liberties and eliminate discrimination based on race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, age, disability, and veteran status. 
    The city commits to working collaboratively with elected officials, city leadership, business owners, church leaders, educators and residents to create a safe, welcoming, equitable and inclusive city for everyone. 
(Ord. No. 18-2, § 1, 1-23-18) 
Sec. 3-3. - Periodic review. 
    The common council of the City of Portage shall review the issue of human rights within the city from time to time and take action as may be deemed appropriate the uphold the commitment of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 18-2, § 1, 1-23-18) 
Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18; obscenity, § 54-31 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 58; waterways, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Employment of children in places of amusement, IC 20-8.1-4-21.5; regulated amusement devices, IC 22-15-7-1 et seq.; municipal regulation of exhibitions, fairs and other public gatherings, IC 36-8-2-9. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXHIBITIONS; CARNIVALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carnival means and includes amusement activities, rides, merry-go-rounds, booths for the conduct of games of skill, food-dispensing facilities operated by amusement companies, and sideshows. 
    Exhibition means and includes circuses, menageries, carnivals, sideshows, and other similar amusement enterprises which are open to the public and for which an admission fee is charged. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 1, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 91-11, § 1, 3-5-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 6-27. - Penalties; closure of operations. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined an amount not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(b)  In addition to the monetary penalties provided under this section, the chief of police is authorized to close any carnival or exhibition being operated in violation of any of the provisions of this article until such time as those violations have been corrected. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 10, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-28. - Enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to examine all carnivals and exhibitions subject to the provisions of this article in order to determine if all the provisions of this article have been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be in violation thereof. 
(b)  The police shall enforce this article by demanding proof of a license. If the operator and/or sponsor of a carnival or exhibition fails to produce a license, that party shall be given a uniform traffic ticket with the word "Warning" written across the face of it and a note on the remarks line that the party failed to produce a license. The law enforcement officer shall inform the party that they have one hour to acquire a license and that they are to immediately discontinue the operation of the carnival or exhibition. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 9, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-29. - General responsibility of operator, sponsor. 
    The operator and sponsor of a carnival or exhibition shall each be wholly responsible for maintaining order and for keeping the site clean, free of trash, papers and other debris. Trash containers in adequate numbers shall be placed in convenient locations for the use of the public. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 7(a), 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-30. - Utilities, sanitary connections. 
    The operator and sponsor of a carnival or exhibition coming under this article shall each be responsible for obtaining water, electricity and other utilities for use during the carnival and/or exhibition and for providing and maintaining adequate public restroom facilities. No carnival or exhibition shall open itself to the public until the utility connections and public restroom facilities have been inspected by the building department and such other officers or employees of the city having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 7(d), 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-31. - Safety requirements for rides. 
    No ride coming under this article shall be placed in operation for public use until such ride has been inspected for mechanical, structural, electrical and other hazards, by the carnival operator and unless such ride is in good operating condition. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 7(b), 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-32. - Security officers. 
    Adequate security officers shall be provided at all times during the operation of a carnival or exhibition coming under this division by the sponsor of the carnival or exhibition. In this regard, a minimum of three security officers shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 7(c), 9-5-89) 
Secs. 6-33-6-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-46. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate any exhibition or carnival which is open to the public within the city without first securing a license therefor and complying with the other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 2, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-47. - Applications. 
(a)  Applications for a license required by this division shall be made to the clerk-treasurer's office in writing and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the person or organization sponsoring the exhibition or carnival and the purpose for the exhibition or carnival. 
(2)  Information identifying the owner/operator of the carnival or exhibition. If the owner/operator is an individual, this information shall include the person's name, address, date of birth and social security number; if a partnership, the name and address of the partnership and the names, addresses, dates of birth, and social security numbers of all partners; if a corporation, the name and address of the corporation, the state of incorporation, the name and address of the resident agent, and whether the corporation is duly authorized to act in this state. 
(3)  The name, address and social security number of all persons responsible for management or supervision of the exhibition or carnival, including a facial photograph of each such person. 
(4)  The place within the city where the carnival or exhibition will take place, the dates and number of days the carnival or exhibition will be open to the public and the proposed hours of operation. 
(5)  Whether or not the person having management or supervision of the carnival or exhibition has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor. 
(6)  Whether there are any unsatisfied judgments entered against the carnival owner/operator or exhibition owner/operator arising out of the negligent operation of a carnival or exhibition. 
(7)  A list of all carnival/exhibition employees including names, addresses and social security numbers. This list shall be updated as appropriate between the date the application is filed and the date of the carnival or exhibition. A facial photograph of each carnival/exhibition employee who is not a resident of the county, taken within the last 60 days from the filing of the application, shall also be provided. 
(8)  Such other reasonable information as may be appropriate for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  The application shall be signed by the person or group sponsoring the carnival or exhibition and by the owner on whose property the carnival or exhibition shall take place or the owner's duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 3, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 89-49, § 1, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 91-11, § 2, 3-5-91) 
Sec. 6-48. - Insurance. 
    No license shall be issued under this division for conducting an exhibition or carnival until there has been placed on file with the clerk-treasurer a certificate of insurance indicating that there is in effect public liability insurance covering any damages arising out of the use and operation of any and all devices and facilities operated in connection with such carnival or exhibition. The bodily injury and property damage liability insurance required by this section shall be in the minimum of $1,000,000.00 combined single limit. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 4, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 92-9, § 1, 3-3-92) 
State Law reference- Insurance required for amusement devices, IC 22-15-7-2. 
Sec. 6-49. - Fees. 
    The applicant shall, at the time the application for a license required by this division is filed, pay to the clerk-treasurer the sum of $50.00 for carnivals or exhibitions remaining in operation for up to five days. If the license is refused or not issued, the fee shall be returned to the applicant, except that the sum of $25.00 shall be retained by the clerk-treasurer to cover the cost of investigating the application. Carnivals or exhibitions which remain in operation longer than five days shall be subject to reinvestigation and payment of an additional license fee in the sum of $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 5, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-50. - Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, an investigation into the business reputation of the applicant, the owner/operator of the carnival or exhibition and/or the person responsible for the management or supervision of the carnival or exhibition shall be made by the police department as deemed necessary for the public good. Upon completion of the investigation, all licenses shall be approved by the board of public works and safety and signed by the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 6, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 6-51. - Exhibition. 
    The license issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted at the site of the carnival or exhibition. 
(Ord. No. 89-36, § 8, 9-5-89) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Municipal ordinances on rabies control, IC 15-2.1-6-13; running at large of livestock and poultry, IC 15-2.1-21-8; licensing and taxation of dogs and kennels, IC 15-5-9-1 et seq.; local animal control, IC 36-8-2-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandon means to desert an animal or to leave the animal permanently in a place without making provision for adequate long-term care of the animal. This term does not include leaving an animal in a place that is temporarily vacated for the protection of human life during a disaster. 
    Animal means any living vertebrate, domestic, or wild, not including man. 
    Animal shelter means any facility operated by the humane society or municipal agency, or its authorized agents, for the purpose of impounding or caring for animals held under the authority of this article or state law. 
    At large means any animal which is not confined in a pen, completely fenced in yard, cage, house, or other secure enclosure, without means of escape, or is not secured by a leash or a lead under the control of its owner or a responsible person. 
    Beat means to unnecessarily or cruelly strike an animal, or to throw the animal against an object causing the animal to suffer severe pain or injury. The term does not include reasonable training or disciplinary techniques. 
    Bite means the seizure with the teeth or jaws of an animal so that the skin of the human being or animal seized has been pierced, lacerated, or has received any break or abrasion of the skin. 
    Board means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    Bodily injury means any injury to the body, including physical pain. 
    Confined means the restriction of an animal at all times by the owner in a pen, completely fenced-in yard, cage, house or other secure enclosure, without means of escape. 
    Dangerous animal means an animal meeting any of the following criteria: 
(1)  Any animal which bites and inflicts serious bodily injury on any person or animal, without provocation, on any public property or in any place outside or over the boundaries of its owner's property; or 
(2)  Any animal which, without provocation and while on its owner's property, bites and inflicts bodily injury on any person or animal, where the victim was acting peaceably, was not provoking the animal, and was not committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises, or otherwise had a legal right to be on said property at the time of the bite or attack; or 
(3)  Any animal which on more than one occasion, without provocation, bites and inflicts bodily injury upon any person or animal, on any public property or in any place outside or over the boundaries of its owner's property; or 
(4)  Any animal owned or harbored primarily for the purpose of dog or other animal fighting and has through use for this purpose, become a threat to the safety of other animals and persons. 
    Dangerous animal does not include law enforcement animals owned by any government agency working within the scope and course of its duties. 
    Dog means all members of the family canis familiaris. 
    Domestic animal means any animal which has been domesticated by man so as to live and breed in a tame condition, and which is customarily regarded for human companionship, such as a dog or cat. 
    Domestic livestock means any animal, other than a domestic pet, that is kept for commercial purposes or is a member of, but is not limited to, one or more of the following species: alpaca, bison, elk, cattle, donkey, goat, horse, llama, mule, ostrich, emu, poultry, pig, rabbit, or monkey. 
    Euthanasia means death brought by any method which produces instant loss of consciousness and results in painless death. 
    Farm animals means cattle, horses, sheep, swine, lambs, goats, poultry, rabbits, and any other animals generally considered as indigenous to agriculture. 
    Harboring means providing any care, shelter, refuge, restraint, food or nourishment in such a manner as to control an animal's activities, whether done within the person's home, enclosure, yard, place of business or on any premises where such person resides or controls. 
    Kennel means any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, selling or training of animals; or any household or noncommercial establishment harboring four or more animals, excluding farm animals, birds, or fish. 
    Leash or lead means a cord, rope, strap, or chain which shall be securely fastened to the collar or harness of a dog or other animal and which shall be of sufficient strength to keep such dog or other animal under control. 
    Neglect means endangering an animal's health by failing to provide or arrange to provide the animal with food or water, if the animal is dependent upon the person for the provision of food or water; restraining an animal for more than a brief period in a manner that seriously endangers the animals life or health; restraining the animal in a manner that seriously endangers the animal's life or health; failing to provide reasonable care; or leaving a domestic pet or livestock outdoors and exposed to the elements without adequate shelter appropriate to its species. 
    Owner means any person having a right of property in a dog or other animal, or who keeps or harbors a dog or other animal, or who has in his care, or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits a dog or other animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. 
    Restraint means that an animal shall be considered under restraint when it is secured by a leash or a lead to its collar or harness and under the control of its owner or a responsible person. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes: 
(1)  Serious permanent disfigurement; 
(2)  Unconsciousness; 
(3)  Extreme pain; or 
(4)  Permanent or protracted loss or impairment of the function of a bodily member or organ. 
    Spayed female dog means any female dog that is or has been rendered physically incapable of conceiving offspring. 
    Stray animal means any animal not secured by a leash or lead and under the immediate control of its owner or a responsible person, and for which after a reasonable search, no owner can be ascertained. 
    Tether means attaching a domestic pet to a stationary object or pulley run by means of a chain, rope, cable, or other similar restraint. Tether does not include the use of a leash to walk a domestic pet. 
    Veterinarian means a person licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the state. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-2; Ord. No. 16-18, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- Definitions pertaining to animal health, IC 15-2.1-2-1 et seq.; the Indiana Veterinary Practice Law, IC 15-5-1.1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-27. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide harmonious relationships in the interaction between man and animal by: 
(1)  Protecting the citizens of the city from rabies by specifying such preventive and control measures as may be necessary; 
(2)  Providing peace and security to residents from annoyance, intimidation, and injury from dogs and other animals; 
(3)  Protecting animals from improper use, abuse, neglect, inhumane treatment, and health hazards, and particularly rabies; 
(4)  Encouraging responsible pet ownership; and 
(5)  Providing for the assessment of penalties for violators and for the enforcement and administration of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-1) 
Sec. 10-28. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the animal warden or deputy animal warden, and in their absence or unavailability, by the police department, or any other law enforcement officer. 
(Code 1985, §§ 3-1-3, 3-1-4) 
Sec. 10-29. - Penalties. 
(a)  Each day the terms of this article are violated shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(b)  A person found to be violating any provisions of this article may be first served by the animal warden, deputy animal warden, or police officer with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a time limit for satisfactory correction thereof. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, any person who shall continue any violation of this article beyond the time limit provided for in such written notice or any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as follows: 
(1)  For the first offense the fine shall be not less than $25.00 nor more than $100.00; 
(2)  For the second offense the fine shall not be less than $50.00 nor more than $200.00; and 
(3)  For the third or any subsequent offense, the fine shall not be less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-18) 
Sec. 10-30. - Animal warden. 
(a)  There is hereby created the position of animal warden. The animal warden shall perform any duties assigned to him by the mayor. 
(b)  The animal warden shall have the power and authority to issue notices for any provisions of this article. 
(c)  For the purposes of discharging the duties imposed by this article and to enforce all of its provisions, the animal warden, deputy animal warden, and any police officer or any other law enforcement officer is hereby empowered to enter at reasonable times upon any property upon which any dog or animal is found, kept or harbored, when in the opinion of the warden or officer it requires humane treatment, or to serve a notice to the owner for violating the terms and provisions of this article. 
(d)  No person shall hinder, molest, or interfere with the animal warden, deputy animal warden, or any police officer in the performance of any duty provided by this article. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-4) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 10-31. - Deputy animal warden. 
    There is hereby created the position of deputy animal warden of the city. The duties of the deputy animal warden shall be to assist the animal warden in the enforcement of this article and any other duties assigned by the mayor. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-5) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 10-32. - Animal care. 
(a)  No owner shall fail to provide his animal with sufficient wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, and with humane care and treatment. The City of Portage does hereby specifically adopt the American Veterinarian Medical Association's "Estimated Vehicle Interior Air Temperature v. Elapsed Time." (b)  No person shall beat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise abuse an animal. 
(c)  Any person who, as an operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal, shall immediately stop and render such assistance as may be possible and shall immediately report such injury or death to the animal's owner. If the owner cannot be ascertained or located such operator shall at once report the accident to the police department. 
(d)  No person shall willfully or maliciously administer poisonous substances to any animal and/or expose any poisonous substance with the intent that the substance shall be taken and consumed by the animal; however, this provision is not meant to prohibit the use of commercially sold poisons for the control of rats, mice, groundhogs, moles or other similar rodents so long as the person administering the poisons takes reasonable care to ensure that domestic pets and livestock are not exposed to the poisons. 
(e)  No person shall allow animal feces to accumulate in any yard, pen or premises in or upon which such animal shall be confined or kept, so that it becomes offensive to those residing in the vicinity. 
(f)  The owner shall confine any female dog in heat within a building or other secure enclosure, in such a manner that the dog will not be accessible to other dogs except for planned breeding, and will not attract other male dogs. 
(g)  The owner shall provide medical care and treatment for any obvious or apparent ailments, segregate diseased animals from other animals so as to prevent the transmittal of disease in accord with the guidelines set forth in IC 15-17-10, et seq. 
(h)  If animals are kept in an enclosure, the enclosure shall be appropriate to the individual species and/or breed of animal, and the enclosure shall: 
(1)  Keep the animal clean and dry; 
(2)  Prevent the animal's injury or escape; 
(3)  Permit the animal to rest on a solid surface; and 
(4)  Provide appropriate flooring, which does not permit the animal's feet or legs to fall through. 
(i)  No person shall tether a domestic pet for more than one hour without immediate access to food, water and shelter, or in such a fashion that violates this article; or tether any un-sterilized dog for any period of time unless it is monitored by a competent adult for the duration of such tethering; or tether or confine an animal at a vacant structure or premises for any purpose or time when it is not monitored by a competent adult who is present at the property for the duration of such tethering or confinement. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-6(A), (B), (E)-(H); Ord. No. 16-18, § 2, 12-6-16; Ord. No. 17-26, § 1, 12-5-17) 
State Law reference- Offenses relating to animals, IC 35-46-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-33. - City domestic animal licenses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, harbor or to have custody of any dog or cat over the age of six months within the city, unless such domestic animal is licensed as provided in this section. 
(b)  Application for a domestic animal license shall be made to the city clerk-treasurer or his designee and shall state the name, address and telephone number, if any, of the owner of such animal, the name, breed, color, sex, age, distinguishing marks, date of rabies immunization, and any other pertinent and necessary information regarding such animal to be licensed. Each applicant shall certify that they meet the requirements for licensure provided in this section. 
(c)  The city clerk-treasurer shall issue a tag for each animal licensed. 
(d)  Licenses shall be issued without cost, except for replacement tags, which shall be issued for a replacement fee of $5.00. 
(e)  Licenses must be renewed annually, irrespective of ownership duration of less than one license year, and shall be due on or before January 31 of each year, or at such later date as the animal may be acquired or may have attained six months of age. 
(f)  The yearly license fee for a kennel of four or more dogs shall be $50.00, provided that the kennel is located in an area for that use. 
(g)  The owner shall keep current rabies immunization and license tags on the animal at all times, attached to the collar or harness worn by such animal, in such a manner that both such tags can be plainly seen. 
(h)  No person shall use a city domestic animal tag for any animal, except the one for which it was issued. 
(i)  The licensing provisions of this section shall not apply to animals owned by or in the charge of nonresidents of the city temporarily in the city for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
(j)  The clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to distribute applications and domestic animal licenses to all veterinary offices, hospitals and clinics within the city. These offices, hospitals and clinics shall be authorized designees of the clerk-treasurer's office for the purpose of issuing domestic animal licenses. These designees shall, on a weekly basis, provide the clerk-treasurer's office with a list of all licenses issued. 
(k)  If an individual receives two or more separate citations concerning any dog or cat residing in their residence, the individual's license will not automatically be renewed. The individual must go before the board of public works and safety to request the license be renewed. 
(l)  A license shall not be issued unless the applicant provides proof of liability insurance coverage for not less than $100,000.00 for any injury, damage or loss caused by said animal. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-7; Ord. No. 86-18, §§ 1, 2, 8-5-86; Ord. No. 88-45, §§ 1, 2, 10-4-88; Ord. No. 89-19, §§ 1-4, 7-5-89; Ord. No. 10-26, § 1, 6-1-10; Ord. No. 13-28, § 1, 12-3-13) 
State Law reference- Accommodations for person with disability with guide dog, IC 22-9-6-5. 
Sec. 10-34. - Maximum number of animals. 
    No person shall keep in excess of four animals more than six months of age, in any household. 
(Ord. No. 88-45, § 2, 10-4-88) 
Sec. 10-35. - Rabies vaccination. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess, harbor or keep any dog, cat or ferret over the age of three months which is not currently immunized against rabies.
