The inability of the owner to provide a current valid rabies vaccination certificate shall constitute prima facie evidence that the dog, cat or ferret is not currently immunized against rabies. 
(b)  No person who owns, keeps, possesses, harbors or has custody of a dog, cat or ferret which is over the age of three months and is not currently immunized against rabies shall allow such dog, cat or ferret to run at large. 
(c)  The rabies vaccination of a dog, cat or ferret shall be maintained by ongoing revaccination of the animal as follows: 
(1)  Ferrets shall be revaccinated within 12 months of the prior vaccination. 
(2)  Dogs and cats that are vaccinated with a rabies vaccine whose label recommends annual boosters shall be revaccinated within 12 months of the prior vaccination. 
(3)  Dogs and cats that are vaccinated with a rabies vaccine whose label recommends a booster one year later and triennially thereafter shall be revaccinated within 12 months of the first vaccination and shall be revaccinated within 36 months of each vaccination thereafter. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-13(A), (C); Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 8-7-07) 
Sec. 10-36. - Animal bites. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone knowing that a person or animal has been bitten by another animal to fail to immediately notify the animal warden, deputy animal warden, or police department of such bite. 
(b)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner of any animal which has bitten any other animal or person to immediately notify the animal warden or police department of such bite, and to immediately confine such animal. 
(c)  The owner of any such animal which has bitten any other animal or person, shall on demand of the animal warden, deputy animal warden, or police officer, surrender such animal for rabies observation for a period of ten days unless: 
(1)  The owner of such biting animal presents proof of a current rabies immunization, the animal warden may in his discretion allow the biting animal to be confined on the premises of its owner under the observation of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten days in such a manner which will prohibit it from biting any person or animal; and 
(2)  The owner of a biting animal under home confinement shall be required to furnish evidence of examination by a licensed veterinarian of the biting animal on the first, fifth and tenth day of such home confinement, all at the cost of the owner. 
(d)  If any owner of any biting animal fails or refuses to immediately surrender such animal for rabies observation, the animal warden, deputy animal warden, police officer, or other law enforcement officer is hereby empowered to take all reasonable means to seize and impound such animal, including the power to enter upon private property to do so, but not to enter a private home without legal process. 
(e)  Any biting animal, surrendered or impounded for rabies observation, shall be kept by the animal warden in an animal shelter designated by the board for a period of ten days, the cost of which shall be paid by the owner of such biting animal. 
(f)  If such biting animal is not found to be infected with rabies at the expiration of the period for observation for rabies, the animal shall be returned to the owner upon payment of the costs of the keep of such animal during such period of observation, including any fee for veterinary services attributed to the bite. 
(g)  When an animal confined for biting shows signs of rabies or acts in a manner which would lead a person to believe that the animal may have rabies, the owner, veterinarian or animal shelter personnel shall immediately notify by telephone, or in person, the animal warden and the person bitten, or the physician attending the bitten person, and a responsible health agency as soon as he receives notice of such signs. 
(h)  If such biting animal is determined to be infected with rabies after examination by a licensed veterinarian, it shall be euthanized, at the cost of the owner. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, possessing, keeping, harboring, or having custody of any animal that has bitten any other animal or person, to sell, give away, or permit such biting animal to be taken beyond the corporate limits of the city, or otherwise dispose of any such biting animal, until it is released by the animal warden. 
(j)  In all cases where an animal has bitten a person or another animal, it shall be the duty and responsibility of the animal warden or deputy animal warden, or in their absence or unavailability the duty and responsibility of the police department, to investigate and fill out an animal report bite form, using information from the bite victims, their families, animal owners and any other person having knowledge of an animal bite, which forms shall be kept on record by the animal warden. 
(k)  If an animal that has bitten a person dies, is accidentally killed, or is humanely euthanized before the tenth day following the bite, such animal shall have its head removed, packed in an ice container, and the head forwarded immediately to the state board of health laboratory for examination. If such a biting animal is a small animal such as a bat, mouse or hamster, the body of the entire animal shall be forwarded to the state board of health laboratory for examination. 
(l)  Any person violating this section, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-14) 
State Law reference- Exposure of person to rabies, IC 15-2.1-6-11. 
Sec. 10-37. - Animals creating a nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner to allow his dog or animal to become a public nuisance. 
(b)  A dog or animal is hereby declared to be a public nuisance if it: 
(1)  Frequently or continuously causes noise or odor which disturbs the comfort or repose of persons in any dwelling, apartment house, or residence; 
(2)  Molests or chases passers-by or passing vehicles; 
(3)  Is repeatedly at large; 
(4)  Attacks other persons or animals; 
(5)  Damages private or public property; or 
(6)  Deposits animal waste on public or private property other than that of the owner. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-15(A), (B); Ord. No. 95-54, § 1, 11-8-95) 
Sec. 10-38. - Animal waste. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or any person exerting control of any animal to permit such animal to defecate or leave its waste on any public or private property other than the private property of its owner. 
(b)  Any person who permits any animal to defecate or leave its waste upon an unauthorized place shall be required to immediately remove such excrement. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-16) 
Sec. 10-39. - Proclamation of quarantine. 
(a)  Whenever it becomes necessary to safeguard the public from dangers of rabies, the mayor, if he deems it necessary to prevent the spread thereof, shall issue a proclamation ordering every person owning or keeping a dog, cat, or other animal capable of carrying rabies to confine it securely on his premises, unless such dog, or other animal shall have a muzzle of sufficient strength to prevent it from biting any person or other animal, and on a leash, under the control of the owner or responsible person. 
(b)  Any unmuzzled dog, cat, or other such animal not on a leash found during the time of the proclamation shall be seized and impounded. 
(c)  Any dog, cat, or other such animal found at large during the time of the proclamation which has been impounded, and found to be infected with rabies, shall be euthanized. 
(d)  Any dog, cat, or other such animal found at large during the time of such proclamation, and found not to be infected with rabies, shall be returned to its owner in accordance with sections 10-53 and 10-54. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-17) 
Sec. 10-40. - Liability insurance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, harbor, or to have custody of any animal capable of biting someone, unless such person has liability insurance coverage for not less than $100,000.00 for any injury, damage or loss caused by said animal. 
(Ord. No. 13-28, § 2, 12-3-13) 
Secs. 10-41-10-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 10-51. - Animals running at large prohibited. 
(a)  No owner of any dog or domestic animal shall permit such dog or domestic animal to run at large in the city. 
(b)  Each owner of any dog or domestic animal shall, at all times, keep and maintain his dog or domestic animal confined or under restraint. Dogs and other domestic animals weighing less than 30 pounds may be confined or restrained by invisible animal fences, as permitted by section 66-642(6). The authority to confine or restrain dogs and other domestic animals by invisible animal fences may be denied or revoked at the discretion of the animal control department. 
(c)  A prohibition of animals running at large shall not apply to on-duty police and fire canine officers or for official training and exercise purposes. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-8; Ord. No. 00-68, § 2, 12-5-00; Ord. No. 01-62, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 17-4, § 1, 2-7-17) 
Sec. 10-52. - Impoundment authorized. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the animal warden, deputy animal warden, and/or any police officer to seize and impound, in an animal shelter designated by the board: 
(1)  Dogs not licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Dogs or animals found running at large or not under restraint. However, the animal warden at his discretion may return properly licensed dogs and cats to their owner, provided he keeps a log of such returns and the animal has not been returned under this subsection within the preceding year; 
(3)  Abandoned dogs or animals; 
(4)  Any stray animal in the public way or within a public place or upon private premises of any person other than the owner; and 
(5)  Any dog or animal that has bitten or attacked a person or other animal. 
(6)  An animal found to be a dangerous animal where the owner has not implemented the reasonable conditions imposed upon him/her pursuant to section 10-56 herein within 15 days of notice of the reasonable conditions. 
(7)  An animal found to be a dangerous animal and the owner does not comply with section 10-56(c)(3). 
(b)  If there be no means by which any dangerous or vicious dog or animal can be safely seized and impounded, the animal warden, deputy animal warden, police officer, or other law enforcement officer shall have the power to destroy such dog or animal; provided however, that any destruction of such dangerous and vicious dog or animal shall be done in a reasonable manner taking into account the location, and possible harm or damage to life, personal, or real property, or to the public at large. 
(c)  In addition to or in lieu of impounding an animal, the animal warden may issue the animal's owner a citation for violations of this article and may return the animal to the owner's property if the animal can be secured safely, and such return is determined by the impounding officer to be in the best interests of the animal. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-9; Ord. No. 13-28, § 3, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 16-18, § 3, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-53. - Notice of impoundment; service of notice. 
(a)  Immediately after impounding any dog or animal, it shall be the duty of the animal warden to enter upon the records of his office, in a book to be kept by him for such purpose, the date and time of impounding, the owner's name, address and telephone number, if known, license or tag number, species or breed, color, sex, and physical condition of the animal. 
(b)  If by a dog license tag or other reasonable means the owner of an impounded dog or animal can be identified, it shall be the duty of the animal warden, immediately upon impoundment, to call by telephone, if the owner's telephone number can be ascertained, such owner and notify such owner of the impoundment of such dog or animal. It shall also be the duty of the animal warden within 12 hours after impoundment of any dog or animal to cause notice to be served upon the owner, if known, of any such impounded dog or animal by United States certified mail, return receipt requested, that such dog or animal has been impounded. 
(c)  If the owner of an impounded dog or domestic animal is unknown and cannot by reasonable means be ascertained, the animal warden shall post written notice for three days in the city hall, city police station, and U.S. Post Office describing the animal and the time, date and place of taking. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-10) 
Sec. 10-54. - Redemption of impounded animals. 
    The owner of any dog or domestic animal impounded pursuant to the provisions of this division may redeem it from the animal shelter designated by the board, upon the following conditions: 
(1)  For properly licensed domestic animals under section 10-33, by paying to the clerk-treasurer a redemption fee of $30.00 for the first time any such animal is seized or impounded by the animal warden; a redemption fee of $50.00 for the second occurrence; and a redemption fee of $75.00 for the third or any subsequent occurrence. For unlicensed domestic animals, by paying to the clerk-treasurer a redemption fee of $50.00 for the first time any such domestic animal is seized or impounded by the animal warden; a redemption fee of $75.00 for the second occurrence; and a redemption fee of $100.00 for the third or any subsequent occurrence. 
(2)  Presenting proof of the current city license tag for a dog if the owner is a resident of the city; 
(3)  If a dog, presenting proof of rabies immunization; 
(4)  If the dog has not been immunized against rabies, or the owner cannot show proof of a current rabies immunization, the owner must present a receipt showing prepayment of the cost of a rabies immunization from a duly licensed veterinarian, and within five days present to the clerk-treasurer, the current rabies immunization certificate; and 
(5)  Pay the animal shelter for the cost of the board and keep of any impounded dog or domestic animal, including all necessary treatment costs, for the period it was impounded. 
    Release of the impounded animal to its owner may be denied by the animal warden if it is determined the animal is a danger to public health and safety of the citizens of Portage or for any other good and sufficient reason at the discretion of the animal warden. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-11; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 2-4-92; Ord. No. 06-38, § 1, 8-1-06; Ord. No. 13-28, § 4, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 16-18, § 4, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-55. - Disposal of unredeemed animals. 
    If a dog or domestic animal is not redeemed by the owner within three days after impoundment, such owner's rights shall be terminated and such impounded dog or domestic animal shall become the sole and exclusive property of the animal shelter designated by the board, and may be disposed of in one of the following ways, at the sole discretion of the animal shelter: 
(1)  Released for adoption by a new owner who shows evidence of ability and intention to provide the dog or domestic animal with an appropriate home and humane care; provided however, that no unspayed female dog shall be released for adoption unless a licensed veterinarian certified in writing that he has been paid in full for spaying of the dog and will perform the operation within 30 days or before the dog's first oestrual period; or 
(2)  Euthanasia, using a method approved by the Humane Society of the United States. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-12) 
DIVISION 3. - DANGEROUS ANIMAL REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, adopted Dec. 6, 2016, repealed the former Div. 3, §§ 10-56-10-59.7, and enacted a new Div. 3 as set out herein. The former Div. 3 pertained to dangerous dog regulations and protection and derived from Ord. No. 09-41, §§ 2-12, adopted July 7, 2009; Ord. No. 11-32, §§ 1-5, adopted Sept. 6, 2011. 

Sec. 10-56. - Determination of a dangerous animal. 
(a)  Any person may submit a report of a dangerous animal to the animal warden. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a valid report of a dangerous animal, the animal warden shall investigate the facts and circumstances surrounding the allegation that said animal is dangerous and prepare a written report stating whether the animal is dangerous. The animal warden may impose reasonable conditions on the owner of the dangerous animal in order to ensure the effective restraint of the dangerous animal as well as public safety. The reasonable conditions include but are not limited to the following: (1) humane destruction of the dangerous animal; (2) confinement of the dangerous animal; and/or (3) owner's purchase of liability insurance. 
(c)  If the animal warden determines that the animal is dangerous and imposes reasonable conditions on the owner, the following shall occur: 
(1)  The dangerous animal shall be immediately impounded, if not already. 
(2)  If the owner of the dangerous animal agrees to the proposed conditions, the owner shall have three days to pay for all impoundment, kennel and penalty fees incurred to date and to post a bond equal to 15 days' impoundment and kennel fees. The owner shall have 15 days from the date of notice of the proposed conditions to provide sufficient evidence of compliance with the conditions. The dangerous animal shall remain impounded until such evidence of compliance is provided. 
(3)  If the owner of the dangerous animal disagrees with the proposed conditions, the dangerous animal shall remain impounded and the owner shall have the right to appeal the decision to the Porter County, Indiana Superior or Circuit Court. The owner shall have three days to pay for all impoundment, kennel and penalty fees incurred to date and to post a bond equal to 30 days' impoundment and kennel fees. The owner shall renew the bond at the end of each 30 day period until the court issues an order in the appeal. If the owner fails to pay for all impoundment, kennel and penalty fees incurred and to post a bond equal to 30 days' impoundment and kennel fees within three days of notice of the proposed conditions or fails to renew the bond at the end of a 30 day period, then the owner shall be presumed to have surrendered all rights and claim of ownership and control of the animal. 
(d)  If the animal warden determines that an animal is not a dangerous animal, then the animal shall be released to its owner after compliance with all impoundment and release procedures and fees. 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-57. - Acquisition of a dangerous dog prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall own or harbor any dog for the purpose of dog fighting, or train, torment, badger, bait or use any dog for the purpose of causing or encouraging said dog to attack human beings or domestic animals when not provoked. 
(b)  No person shall sell, offer for sale, buy or attempt top buy any dangerous dog within the City of Portage. 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-58. - Dangerous animal registration. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to own a dangerous animal in the City of Portage without first having registered the dangerous animal with the animal warden pursuant to this division. 
(b)  A registration required by this division shall be made on forms provided by the animal warden, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The owner's name, address and telephone number where the owner can be reached in the event of an emergency; 
(2)  The address and type of premises where the animal is kept; 
(3)  A detailed description of each animal registered; and 
(4)  Any other information deemed necessary and appropriate by the animal warden. 
(c)  During the term of the registration, the owner of an animal registered under this article shall notify the animal warden in writing of any change in circumstances which would render the information contained in the registration incomplete or inaccurate. 
(d)  There is no fee for the registration of an animal under this division. 
(e)  The term of the registration shall expire on the last day of December of the year in which the registration is made and shall be renewable upon application therefor. 
(f)  The animal warden may revoke a registration issued under this division for any violation of this division committed by the owner of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-59. - Warning signs required. 
    The owner or occupant of the premises where a dangerous animal is kept shall post, at each entrance to such premises, conspicuous signs which state: "WARNING: DANGEROUS ANIMAL." 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-59.1 - Humane destruction of dangerous animal. 
    The animal warden may order the humane destruction of any animal that kills or causes serious bodily injury to a human being or kills a domestic animal, or whose owner does not comply with the requirements of section 10-56. 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-59.2. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to any federal, state or city law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 10-59.3. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this division shall be subject to a fine of not less than $500.00 nor more than $5,000.00. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who violates a provision of division 1 or 2 of this article II shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 16-18, § 5, 12-6-16) 
ARTICLE III. - PET SHOP REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-60. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall be applicable for the purposes of this article: 
    Animal. Any live, nonhuman, vertebrate, or invertebrate creature that is domestic, wild, or exotic. 
    Animal control agency. Any governmental or private entity charged with or contracted with and given authority for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter for and on behalf of the city. 
    Animal warden. A person authorized to carry out the provisions of this chapter. When used in this chapter, "animal warden" shall be read to include the deputy animal warden and any law enforcement officer designated by the animal warden. 
    Exotic animal. Any animal whose normal native habitat is not indigenous to the continental United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. This definition does not include fish, fur-bearing animals commercially bred for the furrier trade, and birds protected under federal laws and regulations. 
    Owner. Any person having temporary or permanent custody of, sheltering or having charge of, harboring, exercising control over, or having property rights to any Animal covered by this chapter. 
    Pet. Any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility. 
    Pet shop. Any person, group of persons, partnership, or corporation, whether operated separately or in connection with another business enterprise, which sells or barters animals. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-61. - General animal care requirements. 
    Every pet shop operating within the corporate limits of the city shall see that each of its animals: 
(a)  Is kept in a clean, sanitary, and healthy manner and is not confined so as to be forced to stand, sit, or lie in its own excrement; 
(b)  Has sufficient and wholesome food and water, which is proper and nutritional for that species of animal; 
(c)  Lives in a structure, meeting minimum veterinary standards, which will protect that animal from all elements of the weather and will allow that animal to stand, sit, and lie down without restriction, and which is kept in a sanitary manner; 
(d)  If ill, diseased, or injured, receives proper and timely veterinary care as necessary to promote the good health of the animal and prevent the transmittal of a disease to other animals or human beings; 
(e)  Is not beaten, ill-treated, overloaded, tormented or otherwise abused or neglected, or involved in any dog fight, cockfight, bullfight, or other combat between animals and humans; 
(f)  Is not physically altered in any manner by anyone other than a veterinarian, except for tattooing for identification purposes and grooming. Specifically, no rabbit, chick, gosling, duckling, turkey, or other fowl may be dyed or otherwise colored artificially; nor shall any dyed or artificially colored rabbits, chicks, goslings, ducklings, turkeys, or other fowl be sold, offered for sale, displayed, used as barter, or given away. 
(g)  Is not abandoned, neglected, or tortured; 
(h)  In the case of a dog or cat over the age of three months, is properly vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian annually, or upon such frequency as may be specified by state law, and such animals shall be licensed as required by this chapter and state law; 
(i)  Is properly restrained and not at large; 
(j)  During mating season, is kept in a secure enclosure in such a manner that it cannot come into contact with another animal of the same species, except for planned breeding; 
(k)  Is not transported in an unenclosed truck bed or open section of any vehicle unless the animal is enclosed in a cage which is securely fastened to the vehicle. At the request of an animal warden, a law enforcement officer may act to remedy the hazard by any means, including gaining entry to impound the endangered animal. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-62. - Dangerous and poisonous animals. 
    No pet shop shall harbor, possess, sell, offer for sale, buy or attempt to buy within the city any poisonous animal (whether by birth or otherwise), reptile, amphibian, fish, or insect, or any animal that poses a threat to the public health and safety. Such animal may be impounded by the animal control agency and disposed of in a manner determined to be in the best interest of the animal and the public. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-63. - Protected animals. 
(a)  No pet shop shall possess, offer for sale, sell, attempt to buy or buy within the city any of the following animals of either thoroughbred or hybrid stock or pedigree: 
(1)  All wild cats of the family felidae; 
(2)  Wolves; 
(3)  Vicuna (Vicugna); 
(4)  Alligator; 
(5)  Caiman or crocodile; 
(6)  Sea otter (Enhydra lutris); 
(7)  Pacific ridley turtle (Lepidochelys olivacea); 
(8)  Atlantic green turtle (Chelonia mydas); 
(9)  Mexican ridley turtle (Lepidochelys kempi); 
(10)  Any animal poisonous by birth or otherwise, including rear-fang snakes; 
(11)  Constrictor snakes, including, but not limited to, boa, python, and anaconda; 
(12)  Game cocks and other fighting birds; 
(13)  Monkeys, including old world (cercopithecidae) and new world; 
(14)  Piranha fish (Characidae); 
(15)  Spiders and insects which are poisonous; 
(16)  Monitor lizard; or 
(17)  Wild animals, including, but not limited to, raccoons, skunks, foxes, squirrels, and chipmunks. 
(b)  No pet shop shall buy, sell, or offer for sale or own a native or foreign species or subspecies of mammal, bird, amphibian, fish, or reptile, or the dead body or parts thereof, which appears on the threatened and endangered species list designated by the United States Secretary of the Interior and published in the Code of Federal Regulations pursuant to the Endangered Species Act of 1969 (Public Law 135, 91st Congress) as amended. 
(c)  No pet shop shall import or cause to be imported into the city any part of the plumage, skin, or dead body of any species of hawk, owl or eagle. 
(d)  An animal warden may seize and impound any animal being offered for sale or owned in violation of this section. In addition to any fine(s) issued for violation of this section, the person or firm violating any provision of this section shall be responsible for any and all costs expended by the animal control agency in transporting, keeping and/or handling the animal(s). 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-64. - Pet shop permit. 
(a)  No person, partnership, or corporation shall operate a pet shop without first obtaining from the city a pet shop permit and paying the necessary fees. Any person holding a pet shop permit shall furnish, at the time of sale, to each customer purchasing a dog or cat a written statement containing the following information: 
(1)  Date of sale; 
(2)  Name, address, and telephone number of the purchaser and permit holder; 
(3)  Permit holder's number; 
(4)  Species, breed, description, age, and sex of dog or cat sold; 
(5)  The animal's origin, its owner's name and address, and its health papers, as required under state law; 
(6)  Vaccination and parasite medication administered to the animal, date administered, and name of veterinarian or person who administered the same; and 
(7)  Guarantee of good health for a period of not less than one week, with recommendation to have the animal examined by a licensed veterinarian. 
(b)  The permit holder shall retain a copy of the written statement for a period of 12 months from the date of sale, and provide a duplicate copy to the licensing authority if the purchaser resides within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  The permit holder shall also deliver to the purchaser at the time of sale a written statement of the registration and licensing requirements applicable to the purchased animal if the purchaser resides within the corporate limits of the city. Such statement shall be prepared by the city and provided by the animal control agency. 
(d)  All pet shops shall take care to house animals in a sanitary manner and to provide appropriate veterinary services, humane care, and housing according to the needs of individual species. 
(e)  Pet shop permits shall cost $100.00 annually. 
(f)  Any pet shop permit provided for hereinabove may be revoked after notice and a hearing before the board of public works and safety of the city. A pet shop's permit, however, shall only be revoked after the board finds that the pet shop owner or permit holder has failed to comply with any requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-65. - Issuance of permits-Additional requirements. 
(a)  (1)  A person may apply for a permit with the city clerk-treasurer. The applicant shall include, on the appropriate forms, the following information: his or her name, address, and phone number; convictions of cruelty to animals, floor plans, knowledge and experience in handling and keeping animals; the number and description of animals; proof of a valid rabies vaccination by a licensed veterinarian, if required by law; information regarding sterilization; and the appropriate registration or permit fee. Appropriate state and federal permit numbers must be provided in cases involving wildlife or federally protected animals, or any animal which requires any state or federal permit. 
(2)  All applicants shall comply with all other applicable federal, state and local laws, and the applicant shall not have been convicted of any cruelty to animal offense pursuant to Indiana Code. 
(3)  Applicants for permits shall allow, upon reasonable notice, the city's animal control department to conduct on-site inspections prior to the issuance of any permit and/or at any time during the valid term of such permit. 
(4)  The applicant shall, at the time of making application for a permit under this article, file with the city a bond, with one or more sureties, in which the applicant shall be the obligor. Such bond shall be in the penal sum of $5,000.00 and shall run to the city for its use against the obligor of such bond under the provisions of this article. Such bond shall be conditioned on the obligor faithfully conforming to and abiding by the provisions of this article and all rules and regulations lawfully made by the city under this article, and will pay to the city any and all money that may become due or owing to it from the obligor by virtue of the provisions of this article. such bond shall be subject to the approval of the board of public works and safety. If the clerk-treasurer shall find at any time that the bond is insecure or exhausted or otherwise doubtful, an additional bond, to be approved by the board of public works and safety, in the sum of not less than $5,000.00 shall be filed by the licensee within ten days after the written demand upon the licensee by the city. 
(b)  The city shall have the authority to issue or deny an application for a permit. In determining whether to approve or deny an application for a permit, the city shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  Whether the person has been convicted of cruelty to animals; 
(2)  Whether the applicant has the proper facilities in place for a specific species as required by this law; 
(3)  Whether the applicant has sufficient knowledge and proof of previous experience in handling and keeping such animal species; and 
(4)  Whether the applicant has a history, documented by the animal control agency or the city's designated agent, of providing inadequate or improper care for such animals. 
(c)  Permits shall be issued for a term of one year, effective January 1 through December 31 of each year. Every licensee shall, on or before December 1, pay to the clerk-treasurer the sum of $100.00 as an annual license fee for the year commencing January 1 and shall, at the same time, file with the clerk-treasurer an application and bond in the same amount and of the same character as required by this section. Such license shall be approved or rejected prior to December 31. 
(d)  Upon approval of an application for a permit, the city shall issue a permit in written form which shall include the permit number, and any pertinent information. 
(e)  All fees shall be paid at the time of application and prior to the issuance of the permit. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, to cause to be manufactured, or to have in his possession or control a stolen, counterfeit, or forged permit, or other form of licensing or documentation required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-66. - Inspection. 
(a)  Whenever it is necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of or perform any duty imposed by this article, or when there is reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any violation of the provisions of this article or state law, a health officer, police officer, code enforcement officer or animal warden is authorized at all reasonable times to inspect the same for compliance with the provisions of this article or any state law, provided that: 
(1)  If the property is occupied, the officer shall first present proper credentials to the occupant and request entry, explaining the reasons therefore; and 
(2)  If the property is unoccupied, the officer shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having control of the property and request entry, explaining the reasons therefor. 
(b)  In the event the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the keeping or maintaining of an animal is so hazardous, unsafe, dangerous, or constitutes a public nuisance as to require immediate inspection to safeguard the animal or the public health or safety, the officer shall first present proper credentials and request entry, explaining the reasons therefore. If entry is refused or cannot be obtained, the officer shall have recourse to secure lawful entry and inspection of the property. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-67. - Enforcement. 
    This article shall be enforced by the police department, code enforcement department and/or the animal control department or their duly authorized and designated representatives. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06) 
Sec. 10-68. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  A pet shop that violates any of these provisions, including those specifically mentioned in subsection (b) below, shall be subjected to a fine and/or permit revocation: 
(1)  Each day that the terms of this article are violated shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(2)  A pet shop found to be violating any provisions of this article including those specifically mentioned in subsection (b) below, may be served by: 
a.  The animal warden; 
b.  A deputy animal warden; 
c.  Police officer; or 
d.  Code enforcement officer. 
and provided with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a time limit for satisfactory correction thereof. 
(3)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, any pet shop owner who shall continue any violation of this article, including those specifically mentioned in subsection (b) below, beyond the time limit provided for in such written notice or any pet shop violating any provision of this article, including those specifically mentioned in subsection (b) below, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as follows: 
a.  First offense - $100.00 
b.  Second offense - $200.00 
c.  Third or any subsequent offense - at least $500.00 but not more than $2,500.00. 
(b)  The city shall require the pet shop to be closed and thoroughly sanitized for violations as outlined in subsections (1) and (2) listed below. The city may require the pet shop to be closed and thoroughly sanitized for violations outlined in subsection (3) below: 
(1)  Failure to provide a customer making a purchase proof of vaccination and parasite medication administered as provided for in subsection 10-64(a)(6) above. 
(2)  Selling an animal that fails to survive beyond the expiration of the guarantee of good health provided for in subsection 10-64(a)(7) above. 
(3)  If an Indiana licensed veterinarian verifies, within ten days, that an animal with a contagious disease has been sold from a pet shop. 
    Any pet shop committing any of the following violations and/or offenses, and is required to be closed, shall remain closed for a minimum of one full day, and until such time that an inspection, as dictated in section 10-66 above, has been satisfactorily completed. 
    Any violation under this section shall include the fines payable under subsection (a) above. The fines payable shall be for each violation and not for each day closed due to the pet shop's failure to properly sanitize and have the premises inspected. During the time closed, however the pet shop may incur additional penalties and violations for the failure to care for and/or keep any animals in a clean, sanitary and healthy environment. Prior to reopening under this section, each domestic animal shall receive and pass a complete veterinary check at the pet shop's expense. 
(c)  Multiple violations under subsection (b) above may result in the permanent closing and revocation of the permit of any pet shop if the health of any animal and/or person is deemed to be in continuous danger. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 5-3-06; Ord. No. 09-37, § 1, 7-7-09) 
Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18; community development, ch. 30; land alterations, § 42-71 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; planning, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 82; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Fire safety, building and equipment laws, IC 22-12-1-1 et seq.; fire prevention and building safety commission, IC 22-12-2-1 et seq.; fire and building services department, IC 22-12-5-1 et seq.; building inspection and regulations, IC 36-7-2-3 et seq.; enforcement of building standards, IC 36-7-9-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Construction site fund. 
(1)  Creation of fund. A construction site fund is hereby created. All revenue received by the city from developer's or contractor's performance bonds and maintenance bonds shall be deposited in the city's construction site fund. 
(2)  Use of construction site funds. Revenues deposited in the city's construction site fund shall be used to perform and complete the work which the bonds were posted to guarantee. 
(Ord. No. 05-39, §§ 1, 2, 8-2-05) 
Secs. 14-2-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING COMMISSIONER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 14-26. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created and established in the city the office of building commissioner. 
(Code 1985, § 4-3-1(A)) 
Sec. 14-27. - Appointment, removal, supervision. 
    The building commissioner shall be appointed by the mayor and shall be removed from his appointment at the pleasure of the mayor. The building commissioner shall be under the supervision, direction, and control of the mayor in all matters pertaining to the duties of his office. 
(Code 1985, § 4-3-1(B)) 
Sec. 14-28. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The building commissioner shall have the authority to approve or reject building permits in accordance with the provisions of this article or any ordinances now in effect or which may hereafter be established. 
(b)  The building commissioner shall have authority to enforce any city, federal, state, county, or township laws and regulations pertaining to the erection, construction, alteration, remodeling, repair, or removal of private and commercial buildings or other building structures in the city. 
(c)  The building commissioner shall make necessary inspections and examinations of all erections, construction, alteration, remodeling, repair, or removal of buildings or other building structures in the city whenever practicable and necessary to determine whether the laws and ordinances or regulations in relation thereto are fully complied with. 
(d)  The building commissioner shall have the right at any reasonable time to enter upon the premises and building structures in the city for the purpose of inspection and examination to determine if any applicable law, ordinance, or regulation is being properly and lawfully fulfilled. 
(e)  The building commissioner shall direct and administer procedures and duties of inspectors who will be appointed by the building commissioner. The building commissioner will appoint a building inspector, plumbing and health inspector and electrical inspector. Such inspectors shall be removed from their duties and appointment at the will and desire of the building commissioner. 
(Code 1985, §§ 4-3-2, 4-4-1-4-4-3) 
Secs. 14-29-14-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSPECTORS 

Sec. 14-51. - Building inspector. 
(a)  The building inspector shall make necessary building inspections to enforce any building code or ordinance of the city. 
(b)  If no building commissioner is appointed, or if the building commissioner is absent or disabled, the building inspector shall act as the building commissioner and shall have all of the duties and responsibilities of the building commissioner. 
(c)  The building inspector shall fulfill his duties to enforce the building standards adopted by the common council, and shall be under the direction of the building commissioner. 
(Code 1985, § 4-4-1) 
Sec. 14-52. - Electrical inspector. 
(a)  The electrical inspector shall make the necessary electrical inspections to enforce any building standards of the city. 
(b)  The electrical inspector shall fulfill his duties to enforce the building standards adopted by the common council, and shall be under the direction of the building commissioner or any person authorized to act as building commissioner. 
(Code 1985, § 4-4-2) 
Sec. 14-53. - Plumbing, health inspector. 
(a)  The plumbing and health inspector shall make necessary plumbing and health inspections to enforce the building standards of the city. 
(b)  The plumbing and health inspector shall fulfill his duties to enforce the building standards adopted by the common council, and shall be under the direction of the building commissioner or any person authorized to act as building commissioner. The plumbing and health inspector shall also act as the health inspector and enforce all health ordinances as are now in effect or as may be later established. 
(Code 1985, § 4-4-3) 
Secs. 14-54-14-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    NIPSCO means the Northern Indiana Public Service Company. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 14-77. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to provide minimum standards for the protection of life, health, environment, public safety and general welfare, and for the conservation of energy in the design and construction of buildings and structures. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 2, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-78. - Authority. 
    The building commissioner is hereby authorized and directed to administer and enforce all of the provisions of this article. Whenever in this article, it is provided that anything must be done to the approval of or subject to the direction of the building commissioner or any other officer of the city, this shall be construed to give such officer only the discretion of determining whether this article has been complied with; and no such provision shall be construed as giving any officer discretionary powers as to what this Code shall be, or power to require conditions not prescribed by ordinances or to enforce this article in an arbitrary or discriminatory manner. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 3, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-79. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article apply to the construction, alteration, repair, use, occupancy, maintenance and addition to all buildings and structures in the city. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 4, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-80. - Adoption of rules by reference. 
(a)  Building rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission as set out in the following articles of Title 675 of the Indiana Administrative Code are hereby incorporated by reference in this article and shall include later amendments to those articles as the same are published in the Indiana Register or the Indiana Administrative Code with effective dates as fixed therein: 
(1)  Article 13. Building codes: 
a.  Fire and Building Safety Standards. 
b.  Indiana Building Code. 
c.  Indiana Building Code Standards. 
d.  Indiana Handicapped Accessibility Code. 
(2)  Article 14. One- and two-family dwelling codes: 
a.  Indiana One and Two Family Dwelling Code. 
b.  CABO One- and Two-Family Dwelling Code; Amendments. 
(3)  Article 16. Plumbing code: 
a.  Indiana Plumbing Code. 
(4)  Article 17. Electrical code: 
a.  Indiana Electrical Code. 
b.  Safety Code for Health Care Facilities. 
(5)  Article 18. Mechanical codes: 
a.  Indiana Mechanical Code. 
(6)  Article 19. Energy conservation codes: 
a.  Indiana Energy Conservation Code. 
b.  Modifications to the Model Energy Code. 
(7)  Article 20. Swimming pool codes: 
a.  Indiana Swimming Pool Code. 
(b)  Copies of this article and the rules, regulations, and codes adopted by reference in this section are on file as required by law with one set on file in the building department of the city and one set on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 5(A)(1), (2)(a), (b), (3)-(7), (B), 2-2-88) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference of state rules, IC 22-13-2-3. 
Sec. 14-81. - Permit required. 
    A permit shall be obtained before beginning construction, alteration or repair of any building or structure the installation of which is regulated by an Indiana building code. The permit shall be applied for using forms furnished by the building commissioner, and all required fees shall be paid to the clerk-treasurer's office. 
(1)  Where equipment replacements and repairs must be performed in an emergency situation, the permit application shall be submitted within the next working business day to the building department. 
(2)  Every permit issued shall expire unless the work authorized by such permit is started within 180 days after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended for a period of 180 days after the time the work is started. 
(3)  The building commissioner is authorized to suspend or revoke a permit issued wherever the permit is issued in error or on the basis of incorrect, inaccurate or incomplete information, or in violation of any ordinance or regulation. 
(4)  The building permit or copy thereof shall be prominently displayed on the work site until the completion of the project. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 7, 2-2-88; Ord. No. 07-17, § 1, 5-1-07; Ord. No. 08-32, § 1, 7-2-08) 
Sec. 14-82. - Application for permits. 
    No building permit shall be issued under this article unless the application for a permit is accompanied by a plat or sketch of the proposed location showing lot boundaries, and by plans and specifications showing the work to be done. In addition, a copy of a design release, issued by the state building commissioner and the state fire marshal pursuant to IC 22-15-3-1, shall be provided to the building commissioner before issuance of a permit for construction covered by such design release. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 6, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-83. - Compliance with other provisions. 
    All work done under any permit issued under this article shall be in full compliance with all other provisions of this Code and city ordinances pertaining thereto. In addition to the fees required for permits, there shall be paid any other fees prescribed by such provisions. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 8, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-84. - Fees. 
    Permits required by section 14-81 shall be issued upon payment of the following fees: 
(1)  For building permits for residential dwelling units, other than manufactured housing in mobile home parks, including accessory structures like porches and decks but excluding basements and detached garages, the fee is $0.28 per square foot. The fee for manufactured housing in mobile home park is $0.15 per square foot. The fee for basements is $0.15 per square foot. The fee for detached garages is $0.25 per square foot. The fee for constructing a deck on a pre-existing residential dwelling unit is $50.00. The fee for interior finishing/remodeling shall be $4.00 per each $1,000.00 of estimated construction costs for work costing more than $15,000.00, with a minimum fee of $50.00 regardless of the cost of the work. 
(2)  For building permits for commercial or industrial buildings and accessory buildings and additions thereto, the fee is: 
a.  $0.32 per square foot for the construction of the shell and interior improvements at the same time; 
b.  $0.16 per square foot for the construction of the shell only; and 
c.  For interior finishing/remodeling, $0.16 per square foot, or $6.00 per each $1,000.00 of estimated construction costs for work costing more than $15,000.00, whichever is greater; provided, however, that the minimum fee for interior finishing/remodeling shall be $100.00. 
(3)  Building permit fees for signs shall be $50.00. 
(4)  The fee for moving a building from one parcel to another shall be $100.00. 
(5)  In addition to a building permit, a plumbing permit shall be required in all cases where new plumbing construction is involved or modification is made to an existing system as opposed to normal maintenance of an existing system. The fee for a permit shall be $10.00 per plumbing fixture for more than three plumbing fixtures. The fee for three or less plumbing fixtures shall be $50.00. A plumbing fixture, for the purpose of this subsection, means one complete unit placed within the structure for the purpose of receiving water or for modifying temperature or chemical composition of the water. 
(6)  In addition to a building permit, an electrical permit shall be required in all cases where a project involves installation, construction or modification of materials, fixtures or equipment used for the distribution or transmission of electrical energy. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to minor repairs, including replacing flush and snap switches, refusing outlets, replacing wall sockets and receptacles, taping bare joints and repairing of drop cords and electrical appliances. The fee for an electrical permit shall be as follows: 
a.  Residential wiring ..... $125.00 
b.  Miscellaneous rewiring/upgrade ..... 75.00 
c.  Commercial and industrial wiring 
One-phase service: ..... 125.00 
Three phase service. ..... 300.00 
plus $0.50 an amp over 200 amps 
(7)  In addition to a building permit, a mechanical permit shall be required in all cases where a project involves installation, construction or modification of materials, fixtures or equipment used for the distribution or flow of warm or cold air. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to minor repairs, cleaning, etc. of existing equipment. The fee for a mechanical permit shall be as follows: 
a.  Heating, per unit ..... $80.00 
b.  Air-conditioning, per unit ..... 80.00 
c.  Fireplaces, wood-burning stoves, per unit ..... 80.00 
d.  Noncentral heating/cooling units, per unit/room ..... 40.00 
e.  Miscellaneous heating/cooling work (i.e., duct work) ..... 40.00 
(8)  For building permits for roofing projects, the permit fee shall be: 
a.  Reshingle ..... $50.00 
b.  Re-roof/replacement of roof decking ..... 75.00 
(9)  Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraphs (1)-(8) above, the minimum permit fee for pools, sheds, siding, gutters, replacement windows, residential interior remodels, fences and similar projects shall be $4.00 per $1,000.00 estimated construction cost, with a minimum fee of $40.00 regardless of the cost of the work. 
(10)  Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraphs (1)-(9) above, only a building permit fee shall be due in conjunction with the construction of a mobile home. Fees for plumbing, electrical and mechanical permits shall be waived. 
    Political subdivisions, churches and other civic/charitable organizations are hereby excluded from the payment of any fees as required by this section if all work involved, including design and architecture, is performed by volunteers but are not excluded from any other requirements of this article, except the payment of such permit fees. If political subdivisions, churches and other civic/charitable organizations utilize paid labor for building projects, they shall be required to pay the permit fees specified herein. 
(11)  The fee for the installation or replacement of a hood system shall be $125.00 per unit. 
(12)  The fee for the demolition of buildings or parts of buildings shall be $30.00. 
(13)  A processing fee of $30.00 will be charged for the refunding of an unused building permit or the reissuance of a building permit resulting from a change of the scope of work covered by the permit. The reissued permit fee will be adjusted to reflect the new scope of work to be performed. Refunds will be available upon request by the permit holder for up to 30 days beyond the expiration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 9, 2-2-88; Ord. No. 90-18, § 1, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 91-46, § 1, 9-24-91; Ord. No. 99-63, § 1, 12-7-99; Ord. No. 00-18, § 1, 6-6-00; Ord. No. 02-58, § 1, 10-1-02; Ord. No. 05-25, § 1, 5-3-05; Ord. No. 06-28, §§ 1A.-1F., 7-5-06; Ord. No. 08-52, § 1, 9-9-08; Ord. No. 10-25, § 1, 6-1-10; Ord. No. 15-5, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 14-85. - Review of application. 
    Prior to the issuance of any building permit under this article, the building commissioner shall: 
(1)  Review all building permit applications to determine full compliance with the provisions of this Code. 
(2)  Review all building permit applications for new construction or substantial improvements to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. 
(3)  Review building permit applications for major repairs within the floodplain area having special flood hazards to determine that the proposed repair: 
a.  Uses construction materials and utility equipment that are resistant to flood damage; and 
b.  Uses construction methods and practices that will minimize flood damage. 
(4)  Review building permit applications for new construction or substantial improvements within the floodplain area having special flood hazards to assure that the proposed construction, including prefabricated and mobile homes: 
a.  Is protected against flood damage; 
b.  Is designed or modified and anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure, flood damage; and 
c.  Uses construction methods and practices that will minimize flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 10, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-86. - Inspections. 
(a)  After the issuance of any building permit under this article, the building commissioner shall make or shall cause to be made inspections of the work being done as are necessary to insure full compliance with the provisions of this article and the terms of the permit. Reinspections of work found to be incomplete or not ready for inspection are subject to assessment of reinspection fees of $50.00 per reinspection. 
(b)  Upon completion of the structure and after all inspections are made and approved, the building department shall authorize NIPSCO to release electric for the structure. The building commissioner at his discretion may release through NIPSCO, the electric before the structure is completed and has final approvals. 
(c)  When electrical service reconnection is desired where service has been disconnected for a period of 90 days or more, an inspection of the electrical service by the building department is required. The owner/lessee is responsible to contact the building department to schedule an inspection. A $25.00 inspection fee must be paid and any deficiencies found must be corrected by the building owner/lessee before the building department will authorize NIPSCO to restore electrical service. An additional fee of $50.00 will be assessed for a miscellaneous electric permit fee to correct deficiencies found. 
(d)  Compliance with air sealing requirements of the Indiana residential energy code through the visual inspection option shall be demonstrated through the submission to the building department of an air barrier and insulation inspection report by a party approved by the building commissioner, independent from the installer of the insulation or general contractor of record. Such report shall verify that the requirements of 675 IAC 14-4.3-139.1 have been met through their visual inspection. 
(e)  When required to determine the measured air exchange rate for the proposed design in seeking compliance with the simulated performance alternative of the Indiana Residential Energy Code, tested envelope leakage shall be determined and documented by a party approved by the building commissioner, independent from the installer of the insulation or general contractor of record. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 11, 2-2-88; Ord. No. 06-28, § 2, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 08-68, § 1, 11-5-08; Ord. No. 10-17, § 1, 5-5-10; Ord. No. 12-17, § 1, 7-3-2012; Ord. No. 15-5, § 2, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 14-87. - Inspection assistance. 
    The chief of the fire department, or his designated representative, shall assist the building commissioner in the inspection of fire suppression, detection and alarm systems, and shall provide reports of such inspection to the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 12, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-88. - Entry. 
    Upon presentation of proper credentials, the building commissioner or his duly authorized representatives may enter at reasonable times any building, structure, or premises in the city to perform any duty imposed upon him by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 13, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-89. - Stop order. 
    Whenever any work is being done contrary to the provisions of this article, the building commissioner may order work stopped by notice in writing served on any persons engaged in the doing or causing such work to be done. Any such person shall immediately stop such work until authorized by the building commissioner to proceed with the work. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 14, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-90. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    No certificate of occupancy for any building or structure erected, altered or repaired after February 2, 1988, shall be issued unless such building or structure was erected, altered, or repaired in compliance with the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful to occupy any such building or structure unless a full, partial, or temporary certificate of occupancy has been issued by the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 15, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-91. - Workmanship. 
    All work on the construction, alteration, and repair of buildings and other structures shall be performed in a good and workmanlike manner according to accepted standards and practices in the trade. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 16, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-92. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether as owner, lessee, sublessee, or occupant, to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, improve, remove, convert, demolish, equip, use, occupy, or maintain any building or structure, other than fences, in the city, or cause or permit the same to be done contrary to or in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 17, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-93. - Right of appeal. 
    All persons shall have the right to appeal the building commissioner's decision first through the city, and then to the fire prevention and state building safety commission in accordance with the provisions of IC 22-13-2-7 and IC 4-21.5-3-7. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 18, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-94. - Remedies. 
    The building commissioner shall in the name of the city bring actions in the circuit or superior courts of the county for mandatory and injunctive relief in the enforcement of and to secure compliance with any order or orders made by the building commissioner, and any such action for mandatory or injunctive relief may be joined with an action to recover the penalties provided for this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 19, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 14-95. - Penalties. 
    If any person shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or fail to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of this article, or shall fail, neglect, or refuse to obey any lawful order given by the building commissioner in connection with the provisions of this article, such person shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, § 20, 2-2-88) 
Secs. 14-96-14-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SMOKE DETECTORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Smoke detection devices, IC 22-11-18-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm signal means an audible signal indicating the detection of visible or invisible particles or products of combustion other than heat. 
    Authority having jurisdiction means the fire department and the building department of the city which have enforcement responsibility for this division. 
    Common usage area means a space in a dwelling unit or accessory structure that is designed for the usage of all occupants, such as a kitchen, living room, dining room, family room or similar living area. 
    Family living unit means that structure, area, room, or combination of rooms in which a family or individual lives. This is meant to cover living area only and not common usage areas in multi-family buildings such as corridors, lobbies, basements, etc. 
    Labeled means equipment or materials to which has been attached a label, symbol or other identifying mark of an organization acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction. 
    Listed means equipment or materials included in a list published by an organization acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction and which product meets appropriate standards or have been tested and found suitable for use in a specified manner. 
    NFPA74 means Standard 74 of the National Fire Protection Association, which is located at 1 Batterymarch Park, Quincy, Massachusetts 02269-9101. 
    Rental agent means any person who rents, subleases, lets, or otherwise grants for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. This term shall not be construed to mean a real estate agent who is employed for the sole purpose of selling residential units. 
    Single and multiple-family dwelling unit. Any building that contains living quarters, including, but not be limited to, hotels, motels, boarding houses, sleeping room houses, buildings of mixed occupancy having any residential units, nursing homes, convalescent homes, licensed half-way houses, lodging houses and mobile homes. 
    Sleeping areas means the areas of the family living unit in which the bedrooms or sleeping rooms separated by other use areas, such as kitchens or living rooms, but not bathrooms, shall be considered sleeping areas. 
    Sleeping room means a room designated for sleeping and/or any room of a dwelling unit that meets IRC habitability requirements that is located along an exterior wall, has entry from a hall or common usage area and has a permanent door permitting privacy and separation from common usage areas shall be considered a sleeping room for the provisions of sections R310 (egress) and R313 (smoke detectors) of the Indiana Residential Code. 
(1)  The building commissioner may grant exceptions if a room that otherwise meets the definition of a sleeping room, is intended by its design for a non-bedroom use. A habitable room may be exempted from being considered a sleeping room if there is no closet and it has permanently built-in features specific to the intended non-bedroom use. Sewing rooms, dens, studios, lofts, game rooms, bonus rooms and any other habitable room along an exterior wall will be considered to be sleeping rooms unless the room is specifically exempted. 
(2)  This definition applies only to construction permitted after the adoption date of this amendment by the common council (May 5, 2010). 
    Smoke detector means a device which senses visible or invisible particles of combustion and conforms to the minimum standards for type, components, and maintenance prescribed by the National Fire Protection Association. The smoke detector shall be equipped with a test button, and it shall produce an alarm signal upon detection of any visible or invisible particles or products of combustion. It may be either battery powered with a minimum 9 volt or it may be powered by a 110 volt alternating current. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 1a-h, j, 10-4-88; Ord. No. 95-33, § 1, 6-6-95; Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 5-5-10) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 14-107. - Enforcement. 
    The city fire department and the city building department shall be charged with the duty of enforcing the terms of this division. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 6, 10-4-88) 
Sec. 14-108. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this division, or who shall fail to comply with an order as affirmed or modified by the authority having jurisdiction shall be subject to a fine of $20.00. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 7, 10-4-88) 
Sec. 14-109. - Basic requirements. 
(a)  The owner of each new or existing multifamily dwelling unit or single-family dwelling unit, hotel, motel, hospital, nursing home, and residential custodial care facility shall install smoke detectors as required by this division. 
(b)  The owner of each hotel and motel shall also be subject to IC 22-11-18-1 et seq. 
(c)  No residential property may be sold or traded in the city unless and until the seller installs or provides for the installation of smoke detectors in accordance with this division. Where a common hallway is used, smoke detectors shall be placed not more than 25 feet apart in the hallway. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 2c, d, 10-4-88; Ord. No. 95-33, § 2, 6-6-95) 
Sec. 14-110. - Installation, location generally. 
(a)  A minimum of one smoke detector, or its equivalent or better as described in the NFPA74, shall be installed in each family living unit within the city. 
(b)  All smoke detectors must be installed according to the manufacturer's instructions and subject to the approval of the authority having jurisdiction. 
(c)  The smoke detectors shall be installed to protect the sleeping areas and shall be located outside of the bedrooms but in the immediate vicinity of the sleeping areas, within 15 feet of all rooms used for sleeping areas. Where a common hallway is used, smoke detectors shall be placed not more than 25 feet apart in the hallway. 
(d)  The smoke detector shall be installed on or near the ceiling, not less than six inches from any wall, or on a wall, not less than six inches nor more than 12 inches from the ceiling, and its installation shall be subject to approval by the authority having jurisdiction. No detector shall be recessed into the ceiling. 
(e)  All smoke detectors shall be accessible for servicing and testing. 
(f)  If a smoke detector is AC powered, it must be directly attached to a junction box not controlled by any switch other than the main power supply. The installation of AC powered detectors shall conform to all electrical standards adopted by the city building department. A smoke detector required under this division shall be installed according to the directions and specifications of the manufacturer, but if in conflict with any electrical standard, the electrical standard shall take precedence. 
(g)  If a smoke detector is AC powered, there shall be a battery operated backup to ensure against potential power failure or power outage. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 3, 10-4-88; Ord. No. 95-33, § 2, 6-6-95) 
Sec. 14-111. - Additional requirements for commercial, industrial buildings. 
(a)  The owner of each commercial or industrial building shall install smoke detectors as required by this division. 
(b)  No commercial or industrial property may be sold or traded in the city unless and until the seller installs or provides for the installation of smoke detectors in accordance with this division. 
(c)  A minimum of one smoke detector, or its equivalent or better as described in the NFPA74, shall be installed in each storage area in every commercial or industrial building within the city. 
(d)  The smoke detectors required to be installed in commercial and industrial buildings shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of section 14-110(b), (d), (e), (f) and (g). In addition, each smoke detector installed in a storage area of a commercial or industrial building shall be equipped with an outdoor alarm signal. 
(Ord. No. 92-7, § 1b-e, 3-3-92) 
Sec. 14-112. - Maintenance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or remove any smoke detector, except when it is necessary for maintenance or inspection purposes. Any smoke detector removed for repair or replacement shall be reinstalled or replaced so that it is operable and in place during normal sleeping hours. 
(1)  Owner occupied dwelling units. Each smoke detector shall be tested in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations, and shall be tested at six-month intervals, and maintained as necessary, to ensure it is in operable condition. 
(2)  Nonowner occupied dwelling units. Each smoke detector shall be tested in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations, and shall be tested at six-month intervals in every individual unit, and maintained as necessary, to ensure it is in operable condition. At any change of tenancy, smoke detectors shall be tested and be in operable condition before the unit is reoccupied. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 4, 10-4-88) 
Sec. 14-113. - Duty of property owner, manager, or rental agent. 
    Every owner, or the manager or rental agent of such owner, or manager of property coming under this division shall be responsible for the installation of all smoke detectors. It is the responsibility of the tenant to maintain all such smoke detectors provided by the owner in good working order until such tenant vacates the premises unless such smoke detector requires AC power supply, then the responsibility for maintaining such smoke detector shall be the responsibility of the owner, manager or rental agent of the property, whichever the case may be. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 5, 10-4-88) 
DIVISION 3. - EMERGENCY TELECOMMUNICATIONS NETWORKS 

Sec. 14-114. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to ensure the uninterrupted operation of the City of Portage's (the "city") public safety, law enforcement, and other emergency-related telecommunications networks. These telecommunications networks are essential to the health, safety, and welfare of the city by providing communications for law enforcement activities, emergency medical treatment, fire suppression, government business, and times of disaster. The construction or erection of certain structures in the city has interfered with the use of these telecommunications networks in certain areas. This division requires that persons or entities constructing or erecting structures in the city do so in a manner which does not interfere with the city's telecommunications networks. 
(Ord. No. 14-15, § 1, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 14-115. - Violation. 
    It shall be a violation of this division for a property owner, lessee, licensee, contractor, or a government entity not otherwise exempt by law to erect a building or other structure, or portion thereof, or cause a building or other structure, or portion thereof, to be erected or constructed in a manner that creates interference with the city's public safety, law enforcement, or other emergency-related telecommunications network. 
    Failure to comply with the provisions of this division shall result in denial of a building permit. If the violation is discovered after the issuance of the building permit, the building permit may be revoked and/or the occupancy permit withheld. If a violation is discovered after issuance of the occupancy permit, the violator may be fined pursuant to section 1-16. Each day a building or structure, or portion thereof, constructed or erected after the effective date of this division, creates such interference shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 14-15, § 1, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 14-116. - Nuisance. 
    Violation of this division constitutes a nuisance because it threatens the health, safety, and welfare of the residents and visitors to the city. In addition to any other remedies or enforcement procedures provided herein, the city may seek an injunction to restrain such a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 14-15, § 1, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 14-117. - Review procedure. 
(a)  Any person or entity intending to construct or erect a structure within the city that is higher than 50 feet tall shall contact the fire department and/or police department to review the proposed structure. 
(b)  The fire department and/or police department shall provide an applicant with a determination whether a proposed structure will interfere with the city's public safety, law enforcement, or other emergency-related telecommunications networks within 30 days of the date a complete application for such a determination is submitted. 
(c)  If the fire department and/or police department determine that interference will result from the erection or construction of the proposed structure, the structure may still be erected or constructed without violating this division if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  General. Except as otherwise provided, the erection, construction, or change in the use of any building or structure, or any part thereof, shall support adequate radio coverage for the city's radio communications system, including but not limited to firefighters and police officers. For purposes of this division, adequate radio coverage shall include all of the following: 
a.  A minimum signal strength of -95 dBm available in 90 percent of the area of each floor of the building when transmitted from the closest city radio communications system site; 
b.  A minimum signal strength of -95 dBm received at the closest city radio communications system site when transmitted from 90 percent of the area of each floor of the building; 
c.  A frequency range of 760 to 860 MHz. 
(2)  In-building radio system. Buildings and structures which do not provide adequate radio coverage shall be equipped with at least one of the following: (1) a radiating cable system or (2) an internal distributed antenna system ("DAS") with or without FCC certificated bi-directional 800 MHz amplifiers as needed. If any part of the installed system or systems contains an electrically-powered component, the system shall be capable of operating on an independent battery and/or generator system for a period of at least 12 hours without external power input. The battery system shall automatically charge in the presence of an external power input. 
(3)  Testing procedures. 
a.  Acceptance test procedure. When an in-building radio system is required, and upon completion of installation, it will be the building owner's responsibility to have the radio system tested to ensure adequate radio coverage, as defined above. 
Each floor of the building shall be divided into a grid of approximately 20 equal areas. In the event that three or more of the areas fail to provide two-way signal strength of at least -95 dBm, the building owner must have the system altered to meet the 90 percent coverage requirement. 
The test shall be conducted using a current police or fire department radio, or equivalent, talking through the city's radio communications system as specified by the police or fire department. A spot located approximately in the center of a grid area will be selected for the test. Once the spot has been selected, prospecting for a better spot within the grid area will not be permitted. Then the radio will be keyed to verify two-way communications between the building and the city radio communications system. 
The gain values of all amplifiers shall be measured and the test measurement results shall be kept on file with the building owner so that the measurements can be verified each year during the annual tests. In the event that the measurement results become lost, the building owner will be required to rerun the acceptance test to re-establish the gain values. 
b.  Annual tests. When an in-building radio system is required, it shall be the building owner's responsibility to have all active components of the system, such as amplifiers, power supplies and backup batteries tested a minimum of once every 12 months. The annual tests shall be performed by a member of the city's fire department. The building owner shall contact the fire department to schedule the annual tests. Amplifiers shall be tested to ensure that the gain is the same as it was upon initial installation and acceptance. Backup batteries and power supplies shall be tested under load of a period of one hour to verify that they will properly operate during an actual power outage. If within the one hour test period, and in the opinion of the testing technician, the battery exhibits symptoms of failure, the test shall be extended for additional one hour periods until the integrity of the battery can be determined. All other active components shall be checked to determine that they are operating within the manufacturer's specifications for the intended purpose.
