ARTICLE IV. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS; ITINERANT MERCHANTS; ITINERANT VENDORS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Home solicitation sales, IC 24-5-10-1 et seq.; transient merchants, IC 25-37-1-1 et seq.; local regulation of transient merchants, IC 25-37-1-11; local regulation of the operation of businesses, crafts, professions and occupations, IC 36-8-2-10. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient merchant or itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor means any person who, whether as owner, agent, consignee, or employee, engages in a temporary business of selling and/or delivering any goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purposes, goes from house to house or hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, boat, public room in a hotel, lodging house, apartment, shop or other building or any portion thereof or any street, alley or any place within the city for the exhibition and sale of goods, wares and merchandise for present or future delivery, either privately or at public auction. A person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant, or auctioneer or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant, or auctioneer. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 3, 7-5-89) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 18-152. - Enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to examine all places, businesses and persons engaged in such business subject to the provisions of this article in order to determine if all provisions set forth in this article have been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be in violation thereof. 
(b)  The police shall enforce this article by demanding proof of a license. If a transient merchant, itinerant vendor or itinerant merchant fails to produce a license, that person shall be given a uniform traffic ticket with the word "warning" written across the face of the ticket and a note on the remarks line that the person failed to produce a license. The law enforcement officer shall inform the person that they have one hour to acquire a license and that they are to immediately discontinue the sale of goods and merchandise. At the expiration of the one-hour period, the police department shall confiscate all goods and wares being offered for sale without a license. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 11, 7-5-89) 
Sec. 18-153. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any person, individual, copartner, limited liability company or corporation which grows the goods, wares or merchandise that is sold or offered for sale; 
(2)  A person who makes crafts or items by hand and sells them or offers them for sale; 
(3)  An auctioneer who is licensed under IC 25-6.1; 
(4)  A resident of the county in which the sale takes place who conducts a sale of tangible personal property for no more than four days per calendar year; 
(5)  An organization that is exempt from the Indiana gross retail tax under IC 6-2.5-5-26; 
(6)  A person who: 
a.  Sells merchandise; 
b.  Offers to sell merchandise; and 
c.  Provides proof that the sale is being conducted as part of an activity sponsored by an organization described in subsection (5); 
(7)  A person who: 
a.  Organizes; 
b.  Sells merchandise at; 
c.  Offers to sell merchandise at; or 
d.  Exhibits at; 
a trade show or convention; 
(8)  A person who holds a registered retail merchant's certificate under IC 6-2.5-8. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 15, 7-5-89; Ord. No. 98-32, § 1, 7-7-98) 
Sec. 18-154. - Waiver. 
    The board of public works and safety, upon proof that the transient merchant, itinerant merchant, or itinerant vendor is involved in a charity or a charitable type business operation, may waive the requirements of any provision of the article. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 14, 7-5-89) 
Sec. 18-155. - Street vending. 
    If the business of the applicant for a license under this article is to be carried on by selling goods, wares and merchandise on or from a city sidewalk, the following provisions shall be complied with in addition to the other provisions contained in this article: 
(1)  No more than one transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor shall occupy each side of a city block; 
(2)  No transient merchant, itinerant merchant, or itinerant vendor shall offer for sale his goods, wares, and merchandise if 70 percent of such products are in direct competition with a business within 100 feet of the location where the same product is being offered for sale or display. For purposes of this subsection, "permanent business" means a business which is established within any building for a period of time exceeding 30 days; 
(3)  There shall be a five-foot setback from the curb of a street where no merchandise, goods, or wares shall be displayed or sold or within which no vendor or merchant may stand or sell such goods, wares, or merchandise; 
(4)  There shall be a triangular area on each corner where two city streets intersect where no wares or merchandise shall be sold or displayed. For purposes of this subsection, "unobstructed corner" means a triangular area formed by the street property lines and a line connecting them at points 25 feet from the intersection of the street lines or, in the case of a rounded property corner, from the intersection of the street property lines when extended; and 
(5)  Street vendors must provide receptacles for waste disposal and shall not obstruct storefronts or entrances thereto. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 6, 7-5-89) 
Sec. 18-156. - Noise control. 
    No licensee under this article, nor anyone in his behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell, or use any other sound device including, but not limited to, any loudspeaking radio or amplifying system, upon any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard on the streets, avenues, alleys, or parks or at other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which the licensee proposes to sell. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 10, 7-5-89) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 42-26 et seq. 
Secs. 18-157-18-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-166. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant, or itinerant vendor to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 2, 7-5-89) 
Sec. 18-167. - Application. 
(a)  Applicants for a license required by this division shall file a written, sworn application with the clerk-treasurer including the following information: 
(1)  The name, photograph taken within the last 60 days from the filing of the application, and social security number of each person responsible for the management or supervision of the applicant's business to be carried on in the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address of such person; the capacity in which such person will act while engaged in such business in the city; 
(2)  The name and address of the person under which the business will be carried on in the city; and, if a corporation, the state of incorporation, whether the corporation is duly authorized to act in the state, the name and address of the resident agent; and if a partnership, the names and addresses of all the partners; 
(3)  The place in the city where the applicant proposes to carry on such business and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business will be conducted, including the hours of operation; 
(4)  The place other than the permanent place of business of the applicant within the six months preceding the date of application to the city at which the applicant conducted such business and the nature thereof and the post office or street address of any location at which such business was conducted; 
(5)  A statement of the nature, character, and quality of the goods, wares, or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city; whether such goods are to be sold from stock in possession of the applicant or from stock in possession and by sample, at auction, by direct sale, and/or by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods, wares, or merchandise proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods, wares or merchandise or products are located at the time the application is filed; 
(6)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers. Copies of all advertising whether by handbills, circulars, newspaper advertising, or otherwise shall be attached to the application and exhibits thereto; 
(7)  Whether or not the person having management or supervision of the applicant's business or the person conducting business on behalf of the applicant in the city has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or violation of any ordinance; the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(8)  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business which authorizes the applicant to act as such representative; and 
(9)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the board of public works and safety may deem proper to fulfill the purposes of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(10)  The phone number of the manager or supervisor of the applicant's business who will be available during the hours of solicitation. 
(b)  The application for license shall be signed by the person responsible for the management or supervision of the applicant's business or by all partners if a partnership or by the president if a corporation. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 4, 7-5-89; Ord. No. 13-29, § 1, 12-3-13) 
Sec. 18-168. - Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application, a background check, including a criminal record check, shall be completed for each person signing the application, as well as each person who will conduct business within the city on behalf of the applicant. The background check shall be performed by Safe Hire Solutions, and the cost of the background check(s) shall be paid for by the applicant, in addition to any other fees due pursuant to this article. Upon completion of the background check(s), all licenses shall be approved by the board of public works and safety and signed by the clerk-treasurer. No license shall be issued for less than one month or longer than one year. A license shall authorize the licensee to conduct business within the city between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. As a condition of issuing a license, a manager or supervisor of the applicant's business shall be available by phone, at the number listed in the application, during the hours the business may be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 5, 7-5-89; Ord. No. 13-29, § 2, 12-3-13) 
Sec. 18-169. - Exhibition. 
    The license issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted in the place of business named in the application. If such person applying for the license desires to do business in more than one location within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each location and licenses shall be conspicuously placed at each location. If the licensee has no permanent or temporary business location, the licensee and/or agents of the licensee shall have the license on their person. In addition, the licensee and/or agents of the licensee shall conspicuously display a city-provided I.D. card while conducting business within the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 7, 7-5-89; Ord. No. 13-29, § 3, 12-3-13) 
Sec. 18-170. - Fees. 
    Each applicant shall pay a nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $25.00. The application fee is due at the time the application is submitted. The fees for the license required by this article shall be as follows: 
Per year ..... $200.00 
Per six months ..... 120.00 
Per month ..... 50.00 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 8, 7-5-89; Ord. No. 13-29, § 4, 12-3-13) 
Sec. 18-171. - Transfer. 
    No license shall be transferred without written consent from the board of public works and safety. Consent shall be withheld until all of the application procedures for the transferee have been completed. A transfer fee of $25.00 will be payable upon such transfer. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 9, 7-5-89) 
Sec. 18-172. - Records. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall submit the record of licensees, together with the license number, to the chief of police, who shall report to the city clerk-treasurer any complaints against any licensee and any conviction for violation of this article. The city clerk-treasurer shall keep a record of all information pertaining to applications, licenses, and any complaints and violations reported by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 12, 7-5-89) 
Sec. 18-173. - Revocation. 
(a)  The licenses issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the board of public works and safety after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares, or merchandise or the application therefor; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this division in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of a hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed with postage paid to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for such hearing. 
(c)  Any person or business entity who has had: 
(1)  A license revoked under this section; 
(2)  An application for a license refused; or 
(3)  A waiver under section 18-154 refused; 
may, within ten days of such action, appeal such action to the common council and the council shall, at its next regularly scheduled meeting if the notice of appeal has been brought to the attention of the city clerk-treasurer no less than five days prior to the meeting or at its next regularly scheduled meeting thereafter, review the determination of license status and either uphold the status or direct the clerk-treasurer to reissue such license. 
(d)  Any person who has had a license revoked according to this section shall not be permitted to obtain another license in the city for a period of one year after revocation, whether that license is requested to be issued to the person, a partnership in which the person is a partner, or a corporation in which the person owns more than one percent of the stock. 
(Ord. No. 89-20, § 13, 7-5-89) 
Secs. 18-174-18-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DEALERS IN USED PRECIOUS METALS AND GEMS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Valuable metal dealer regulation, IC 25-37.5-1-1 et seq.; pawnbrokers, IC 28-7-5-1 et seq.; hearing complaints against persons licensed by city, IC 36-4-5-5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-196. - Records and investigations. 
(a)  Every person operating a business described in this article shall keep a tightly bound record of all scheduled articles purchased from the public. Such record shall show the date of the purchase, the description, including any numbers and/or initials thereon, a photograph of the articles purchased, purchase price paid and the name and address of the person from whom purchased. The seller shall execute a document stating that he is at least 18 years of age and the property sold is his. 
(b)  For the purpose of discovering violations of this article and securing information lawfully required or otherwise necessary, the police department may, by person duly designated by it, investigate and examine the bound record books and picture files that coincide with such purchase transactions. The duly designated representatives of the police department shall have and be given free access to the place of business during routine and normal course of business hours. The licensee shall keep such bound record books and photographs for a period of one year after making final entry of the same. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-6) 
Sec. 18-197. - Unlawful transactions. 
    No licensee under this article shall purchase or trade any article: 
(1)  From a person under 18 years of age or from any person whom he has reason to suspect or believe to be under 18 years of age; or 
(2)  That he has reason to suspect or believe to be stolen. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-7) 
Secs. 18-198-18-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-211. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or conduct a business for the purchase, sale or trade of used precious metals or precious gems including but not limited to gold, silver, platinum, plated articles, diamonds, rubies, sapphires, or opals in any form without having first obtained a license therefor, and without complying with the provisions of this article. Any person that shall operate or conduct a business as described in this section shall be a "dealer". 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-1) 
Sec. 18-212. - Application. 
    Application for a license under this division shall be made to the clerk-treasurer in writing and shall state the full name and place of residence of the applicant, or if the applicant be a partnership, of each member thereof, or, if a corporation or association, the name and address of each officer thereof, together with the place or places where the business is to be conducted. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-2(A)) 
Sec. 18-213. - Bond. 
    The applicant shall, at the time of making application for a license under this division, file with the city a bond, with one or more sureties, in which the applicant shall be the obligor. Such bond shall be in the penal sum of $1,000.00 and shall run to the city for its use and for the use of any person who may have a cause of action against the obligor of such bond under the provisions of this article. Such bond shall be conditioned on the obligor faithfully conforming to and abiding by the provisions of this article and all rules and regulations lawfully made by the city under this article, and will pay to the city and to any such person any and all money that may become due or owing to them from the obligor by virtue of the provisions of this article. Such bond shall be subject to the approval of the board of public works and safety. If the clerk-treasurer shall find at any time that the bond is insecure or exhausted or otherwise doubtful, an additional bond, to be approved by the board of public works and safety, in the sum of not less than $1,000.00 shall be filed by the licensee within ten days after the written demand upon the licensee by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-2(B)) 
Sec. 18-214. - Fee. 
(a)  An application for a dealer license under this division shall be accompanied by a fee of $25.00 per annum for each place of business conducted by the licensee payable to the clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  Every licensee shall, on or before December 1, pay to the clerk-treasurer the sum of $25.00 as an annual license fee for the year commencing January 1 and shall at the same time file with the clerk-treasurer an application and bond in the same amount and of the same character as required by sections 18-212 and 18-213. Such license shall be approved or rejected prior to December 31. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-3) 
Sec. 18-215. - Issuance. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a license under this division, the payment of the license fee, and the approval of the required bond, the clerk-treasurer shall notify the chief of police who shall investigate the financial standing and character of the applicant, and of the members thereof, if the applicant be a partnership, and the officers and directors thereof if the applicant be a corporation, to determine whether the business will be operated honestly, fairly, and efficiently, and within the purpose of this article, and that the public necessity exists for the operation of such business in the community wherein such applicant proposes to operate. The chief shall then report to the clerk-treasurer who, with the approval of the board of public works and safety, shall issue a license authorizing the applicant to engage in the business in dealing within the definition of this article. Such license shall remain in full force and effect until it is surrendered, revoked, or suspended. If the clerk-treasurer shall later find otherwise, the clerk-treasurer shall notify the board of public works and safety, and the board of public works and safety shall notify the applicant of the denial and return to the applicant the bond and the sum paid by the applicant as a license fee. The board of public works and safety shall give every applicant a reasonable opportunity to be heard and shall approve or deny, by written order, every application for license under this division within 30 days from the hearing hereof. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-4) 
Sec. 18-216. - Revocation. 
    The board of public works and safety, upon recommendation by the clerk-treasurer, shall upon ten days notice to the licensee, stating the contemplated action, and in general the grounds therefor, and upon reasonable opportunity to be heard, revoke, suspend or cause to be surrendered, by written order, any license issued under this division if it shall find that: 
(1)  The licensee has failed to pay the annual license fee or to maintain in effect the bond required under the provisions of this division, or to comply with any ruling or requirements of this article lawfully made pursuant to and under the authority of this article; 
(2)  The licensee has violated any provision of this article or any rule or regulation lawfully made under the authority of this article; or 
(3)  Any fact or condition exists which, if it had existed at the time of the original application for such license, clearly would have warranted the board of public works and safety in refusing to issue such license. 
(Code 1985, § 8-3-5) 
Secs. 18-217-18-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - JUNK DEALERS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of billboards and junkyards, IC 8-23-20-1 et seq.; requirements for junkyards and scrap metal processing facilities enacted by political subdivisions, IC 8-23-20-21. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-236. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junk dealer means any person who exercises, carries on or engages in the business of buying, selling, bartering, storing, exchanging, dismantling for sale, or otherwise dealing or offering to deal in any of the following articles: used or salvaged rope, paper, rags, glass, animal matter; and used motor vehicles, machinery, and equipment, or parts of any of the same. 
    Junk yard means any place in the city where personal property, waste, or scrap materials are or may be stored, bought, sold, exchanged, sorted, baled, packed, disassembled, or handled, including but not limited to used or salvaged scrap iron and other metals, used or salvaged rope, paper, rags, glass, rubber, lumber, millwork, brick, and other similar property, except animal matter; and used motor vehicles, machinery, and equipment or parts of any of the same which are used, owned, possessed or stored for the purpose of wrecking or salvaging parts therefrom; but excluding those established entirely within enclosed buildings of neat appearance and built according to the building codes of the city, and further excluding motor vehicles, machinery and equipment used for agricultural purposes. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 18-237. - Compliance with ordinances and comprehensive plan. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a junk dealer and/or operate a junk yard, unless such person has met and fulfilled all the ordinances and the comprehensive plan of the city which are made a part of and incorporated by reference in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-7) 
Sec. 18-238. - Sale of assembled motor vehicles and bicycles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer or junk yard operator to sell or offer to sell or trade any motor vehicle or bicycle without first dismantling such vehicle, or to assemble any motor vehicle or bicycle for sale, which motor vehicle or bicycle or part thereof has been purchased by such junk dealer or junk yard operator as and for junk. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-8) 
Sec. 18-239. - Obtaining goods. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to receive any article or thing by way of pledge or pawn, nor shall any junk dealer receive any article or thing as security on money loaned or advanced. No junk dealer shall be permitted to receive or hold a license to carry on the business of a pawnbroker. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person licensed by this article to purchase, take or receive any articles, goods or things from any such person while such person is in an intoxicated condition. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-10) 
Sec. 18-240. - Records, inspection. 
(a)  Every person licensed as a junk dealer under the provisions of this article shall keep a record of all purchases. Such record shall show the date and description, including any numbers thereon, of the articles purchased, and the name and address of the person from whom the articles were purchased. 
(b)  All records of junk dealers and articles on hand shall be open for inspection by members of the police department during normal business hours. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-9) 
Sec. 18-241. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(b)  Any licensee violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to revocation of his license. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-11) 
Sec. 18-242. - Junk storage and dismantling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether a licensed junk dealer or junk yard operator or otherwise, to store, place, park, keep or dismantle any of the articles listed in section 18-236 upon any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or parkways within the city or upon any premises within the city, unless within a building of neat appearance, built and constructed according to the building codes of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-6) 
Secs. 18-243-18-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-256. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to exercise, carry on or engage in the business as a junk dealer or have, allow or operate a junk yard without first having obtained a license from the city. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-2) 
Sec. 18-257. - Application. 
    Every junk dealer or junk yard operator, and every person desiring to engage in the business of being a junk dealer or desiring to have or operate a junk yard, shall make application in writing to the board of public works and safety, setting forth the place in which the applicant conducts or intends to conduct such junk dealer business or junk yard. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-3(A)) 
Sec. 18-258. - Bond. 
    The applicant for a license under the provisions of this division shall submit with his application a bond executed to the city with good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the board of public works and safety, in the sum of $1,000.00 conditioned on the due observance of all ordinances of the city with respect to conducting the business of a junk dealer or the operation of a junk yard. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-3(B)) 
Sec. 18-259. - Fee, issuance. 
(a)  The board of public works and safety shall have the power to approve or disapprove any application for a license under this division. Upon approval of any such application, the applicant shall pay to the clerk-treasurer a license fee in the sum of $50.00 per annum, which shall cover the cost from January 1 to December 31 of each year, or any part thereof. It shall be the duty of the clerk-treasurer to issue such license on such printed form as the board of public works and safety shall prescribe. 
(b)  Any person desiring to maintain or carry on a business as a junk dealer and/or operate or maintain a junk yard in more than one location shall pay an additional license fee to the clerk-treasurer of $50.00 per annum for each additional location so maintained. Each location where the applicant maintains or stores articles listed in section 18-236 shall be considered a separate location. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-4) 
Sec. 18-260. - Term. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this division shall expire on December 31 of each year following the date of their issuance. Upon the expiration of any license, the licensee shall be required to reapply for renewal of the license in the same manner as provided for the issuance of an original license. 
(Code 1985, § 8-2-5) 
Secs. 18-261-18-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TAXICABS[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Motor fuel tax on gasoline used for operating a taxicab, IC 6-6-1.1-903; financial responsibility as to vehicles, IC 9-25-4-1 et seq.; regulation of public vehicles for hire, IC 36-9-2-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-281. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Driver means any person who is actually in physical control of a taxicab. 
    License means a franchise to operate taxicabs within the city. 
    Operator means the company or other entity to whom or to which a license has been issued. 
    Rate system means the system used to determine fares in place of a taximeter. 
    Taxicab means a motor vehicle which is: 
(1)  Held out to the public for hire at a fare based upon length of trips or time consumed; 
(2)  Not operated over a definite route; and 
(3)  A part of a commercial enterprise in the business of providing taxicab service. 
    Taxicab service means a company or other entity which provides vehicles for hire for the transportation of individuals with the destination of being designated by the passengers at the time of transportation. 
    Taximeter means an instrument or fare registering device attached to a taxicab and designed to register mechanically the distance traveled by such taxicab, to record the time such taxicab is in waiting and to indicate upon such record, by figures, the fare to be charged in dollars and cents. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 2, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 09-81, § 1, 11-4-09) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- "Taxicab" defined, IC 6-6-1.1-103. 
Sec. 18-282. - Authority of traffic commission. 
    The traffic commission of the city shall regulate and control the licensing and operation of taxicabs within the city. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 3, 3-3-87) 
Sec. 18-283. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any other penalties which may be imposed by the traffic commission pursuant to this article, any driver, operator or other person who violates any one or more of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 17, 3-3-87) 
Sec. 18-284. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-10, § 1, adopted March 7, 2000, repealed § 18-284, which pertained to taxicabs from other cities and derived from Ord. No. 87-11, § 16, adopted March 3, 1987. 
Sec. 18-285. - Public stands. 
(a)  The traffic commission may designate taxicab stands at convenient places within the city for the exclusive use of taxicabs licensed under the terms of this article. If taxicab stands are designated by the traffic commission, it shall be unlawful for any other vehicle of any kind whatsoever to use or park in the taxicab stands so designated; provided, however, that such stands may be used at any time by the owner or occupants of the buildings and real estate fronting upon the stands for loading and unloading goods and merchandise onto the real estate or into the buildings situated thereon. 
(b)  If more than one operator is licensed under the terms of this article, the traffic commission may allocate any designated taxicab stands among all licensed operators. After those stands have been allocated, it shall be unlawful for taxicabs to use a stand which has been allocated to another operator. 
(c)  Each taxicab stand, if any, designated pursuant to this article shall be appropriately marked under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 4, 3-3-87) 
Sec. 18-286. - Fares. 
(a)  All operators of taxicabs shall determine the fare by use of either: 
(1)  The use of a standard taximeter; or 
(2)  The use of a rate system that has been approved by the traffic commission. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab when soliciting business from the public or to represent himself/herself as the driver, operator, or owner of a taxicab unless the vehicle is: 
(1)  Equipped with a taximeter; or 
(2)  Displaying of an approved rate system. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 5, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 09-81, § 2, 11-4-09) 
Sec. 18-287. - Taxicab drivers. 
(a)  No person shall drive a taxicab or be hired or permitted to do so unless he/she is duly licensed as a public passenger chauffeur. No person shall drive a taxicab in the city without first being approved by the traffic commission of the city. The traffic commission has the final decision in this matter. The prospective taxicab driver must be of a nonviolent temperament, free of any convictions of a felony or a crime against another person. It is the responsibility of the operator of a taxicab service to provide an all state criminal background check, a certified copy of the prospective driver's driving record, and current driver's license to the traffic commission pursuant to subsection (b). 
(b)  Upon receipt of information that the prospective driver has not been convicted of a felony or a crime against another person, and that the prospective driver has been approved by the traffic commission, the chief of police shall issue an annual identification card with colors matching the required annual sticker or tags bearing the photograph and name of the driver as well as the identity of the service for which he/she drives which shall: 
(1)  Serve to affirm that the driver has met all required qualifications to act as a driver for a specific taxicab service and has been approved by the traffic commission. 
(2)  At all times when he/she is driving a taxicab, be mounted above the meter or be mounted in a manner so that it will be plainly visible and in view of the passenger at all times. 
(3)  At all times when he/she is driving a taxicab be able to produce said identification card upon request by any passenger and/or law enforcement officer. 
(4)  This identity card remains the property of the City of Portage and must be surrendered upon demand of the traffic commission or any law enforcement officer, upon the receipt of a new annual identity card and/or upon termination from the taxi service or employment. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab while on duty to consume any intoxicating liquor or drugs, to shout or call to prospective passengers, or to disturb the peace in any way. 
(d)  Each taxicab driver shall have a duty to obey all traffic rules established by statute or ordinance. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a taxicab driver to permit any passenger or other person to occupy the front seat of his taxicab unless the rear seat is occupied by two or more persons. If both the front and rear seat are occupied in compliance with this subsection, the driver of the taxicab shall not be required to transfer the person in the front seat to the rear seat when the passengers in the rear seat get out at their destination. It shall be lawful for the driver to permit the person to remain in the front seat until he arrives at his destination. It shall be lawful to permit a handicapped person, who could not ride comfortably or with safety in the rear seat, to occupy the front seat. 
(f)  It is the responsibility of the driver and operator to notify the traffic commission if the driver has been convicted of a felony, a crime against another person, a violation of the traffic laws, or has violated the city's traffic ordinances. Such notification shall be provided within ten days of the date of the conviction or violation. The traffic commission may also revoke a person's authority to drive a taxicab, if it finds that the person was untruthful or failed to disclose the information required by this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, §§ 13, 14(B), 3-3-87; Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 9-1-98; Ord. No. 07-27, §§ 1A.-1C., 6-5-07; Ord. No. 09-81, § 3, 11-4-09; Ord. No. 10-61, § 1, 10-12-10) 
State Law reference- "Chauffeur" defined, IC 9-13-2-21; "public passenger chauffeur" defined, IC 9-13-2-143; chauffeur's license, IC 9-24-4-1 et seq.; public passenger chauffeur's license, IC 9-24-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 18-288. - Register. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall keep a register showing the name and address of each person owning and operating a taxicab licensed under this article, together with the license number, make, and description of the taxicab. This register shall be a public record and open to inspection to the public at all reasonable times. Certified or authenticated copies of the records or portions thereof shall be conclusive of the contents of the records. The books necessary to keep these records shall be furnished and paid for by the city. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 15, 3-3-87) 
Secs. 18-289-18-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-301. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab upon the streets of the city unless the person shall first procure and hold a license to operate the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 6(A), 3-3-87) 
Sec. 18-302. - Application. 
(a)  Any person intending to operate a taxicab upon the streets or alleys of this city shall first file with the city clerk-treasurer his application for a license upon the forms to be supplied by the city clerk-treasurer. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  If the applicant is a partnership, a copy of the partnership agreement shall be filed, together with the full names and addresses of all the partners. 
(3)  If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of the articles of incorporation shall be filed, and the application shall show the names and addresses of all the officers and directors of the corporation. 
(4)  The number of taxicabs for which the applicant seeks a license. 
(5)  A complete description of each taxicab, including the make, year of manufacture, engine number, serial number, and color, and the applicant shall designate the color to be used. 
(6)  Any other information the city clerk-treasurer or traffic commission may deem necessary to show compliance with this article. 
(7)  Attached to or accompanying the application shall be an insurance policy or certificate of self-insurance, as required by section 18-304, and cash or check for a basic license fee or individual taxicab fees. 
(8)  The application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(b)  Applications for the annual license for the ensuing year shall be filed on or before November 1 of each year. The city clerk-treasurer, if the provisions of this section are complied with, shall issue the annual license valid on January 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 6(B), (C), 3-3-87; Ord. No. 07-27, § 1D., 6-5-07; Ord. No. 09-81, § 4, 11-4-09) 
Sec. 18-303. - Fees. 
(a)  A basic annual license fee of $500.00 per year shall be paid by each taxicab, licensee. This license shall permit the operator to operate one vehicle with one driver within the city. 
(b)  The operator shall be permitted to operate as many additional vehicles as he/she may desire when an additional license fee of $50.00 per annum shall be paid for each additional vehicle upon as per section 18-305. 
(c)  The operator shall be permitted to employ as many additional drivers as he/she may desire when an additional license fee of $15.00 per annum shall be paid for each additional driver upon as per section 18-287. 
(d)  If at any time for any reason the required tag or sticker must be replaced on any vehicle for hire a replacement fee of $5.00 will apply. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 10, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 07-27, § 1E., 6-5-07; Ord. No. 09-81, § 5, 11-4-09) 
Sec. 18-304. - Insurance. 
(a)  No license shall be issued for any taxicabs or to any operator thereof until the owner of the taxicab shall file with the city clerk-treasurer an insurance policy issued by a responsible insurance company licensed to do business in the state. The insurance company and the form of policy shall be approved by the city attorney. These policies shall provide insurance coverage for each and every taxicab owned and operated by the applicant within the city with a combined single limit of $500,000.00 for the injury or death of any one or more persons, and for property damage in one accident, regardless of whether the taxicab was being driven by the owner or an employee. Such insurance policy shall provide that it may not be cancelled until ten days' written notice of cancellation shall have been given to the taxicab operator and to the clerk-treasurer. If a policy for insurance shall be cancelled and the taxicab operator shall fail to procure and file with the clerk-treasurer another policy of insurance prior to cancellation, then the license issued for all taxicabs covered by such cancelled policy of insurance shall automatically become null and void. 
(b)  In lieu of filing a policy of insurance as required by subsection (a) of this section, a licensee may submit proof that he has obtained a valid certificate of self insurance from the state bureau of motor vehicles which certificate is still in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 12, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 00-10, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 00-62, § 1, 11-8-00; Ord. No. 08-105, § 1, 12-17-08) 
State Law reference- Required minimum amounts of financial responsibility, IC 9-25-4-5. 
Sec. 18-305. - Equipment. 
    No license shall be issued for a taxicab unless it meets the following requirements: 
(1)  Floor mat. Each vehicle shall be equipped with a floor mat made of rubber, leather, metal chain, or other similar nonabsorbent, washable material and shall be easily removed. 
(2)  Dome light. Every vehicle shall be equipped with an interior dome light of sufficient candlepower to illuminate the entire interior. 
(3)  Name and number of cab. The name of the owner operating the taxicab and the number of the cab shall be painted in letters at least two inches in height on both sides of the taxicab. 
(4)  Mechanical condition. The vehicle shall be equipped with properly working brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear view mirror, and windshield wipers. The vehicle shall also be in a safe condition as determined by an inspection conducted by the police department. 
(5)  Rate schedule. The rate schedule must be posted in a prominent place visible to the passenger. 
If the operator chooses to use a taximeter it must comply with the following criteria: 
(6)  Taximeter. If a taximeter is used the vehicle shall have affixed thereto a taximeter of standard size and design. The taximeter shall be illuminated by a suitable light or arranged so as to throw a continuous steady light on the face of the dial thereof, which shall be visible to the passenger. The case of the taximeter shall be sealed and its cover and gear must be intact and in proper working order at all times. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 7, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 09-81, § 6, 11-4-09) 
Sec. 18-306. - Issuance. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a license under this division with an insurance policy or certificate of self-insurance as described in section 18-304, the clerk-treasurer shall forward a copy of the same to the traffic commission. The traffic commission shall review the application and examine the applicant at the next scheduled meeting, provided that the completed application is received a minimum of ten business days prior to the meeting. If the completed application is not received ten business days prior to the meeting, the review of the application and examination of applicant will be placed on the agenda for the following scheduled meeting. No license shall be granted to: 
(1)  A person who has any convictions of a crime against another person. 
(2)  A corporation any of whose officers or directors has any convictions of a crime against another person. 
(3)  An applicant who has an unsatisfied judgment against it arising out of the operation of a motor vehicle. 
(4)  A corporation if it is not qualified to do business in the state. 
(5)  A corporation if it is not in good standing with the secretary of state. 
(b)  If the commission finds that issuance of a license is not prohibited pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, it shall advise the clerk-treasurer to issue a license to the applicant provided the applicant pays the license fee in full by cash, certified check, or money order. The commission may authorize the issuance of a temporary license to an applicant pending completion of the record clearance required pursuant to section 18-287. A copy of the minutes of the traffic commission meeting at which the temporary license was approved shall constitute the temporary license. At the next traffic commission meeting after the record clearance required by section 18-287(b) has been completed, the traffic commission shall take action on the application. 
(c)  Upon approval of an application by the traffic commission and compliance with subsection (b) of this section, the clerk-treasurer shall issue to the applicant the following: 
(1)  A license authorizing the applicant to operate a vehicle for hire upon the streets of this city for the ensuing calendar year. 
(2)  Tags or stickers for each vehicle for hire to be operated showing the licensee's number and individual number assigned to that vehicle. 
(3)  The tags or stickers shall be of a distinctly different color each year and shall be displayed at all times in the rear window on the driver's side of the vehicle. 
(4)  The individual tags or stickers shall not be transferred to any other vehicle, other than that vehicle for which it was issued. 
(5)  If at any time a tag or sticker must be replaced on a vehicle, a fee for the replacement tag or sticker as set forth in section 18-303 shall be collected by the office of the clerk-treasurer prior to the issuance of the replacement tag or sticker. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 8, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 98-17, § 1, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 07-27, § 1F., 6-5-07; Ord. No. 09-81, § 7, 11-4-09) 
Sec. 18-307. - Transfer. 
(a)  No license issued by the city clerk-treasurer shall be transferred to another person. 
(b)  No license issued by the city clerk-treasurer shall be transferred to another vehicle except as per subsection (c). 
(c)  If a vehicle is to be retired permanently from service during the year, then an application shall be made to the city clerk-treasurer showing the information required in section 18-305 and having attached thereto the rider to the insurance policy covering the substitute vehicle. The addition vehicle fee as set forth in section 18-303 would not be required for a replacement of a vehicle for the remainder of the licensed calendar year. 
(d)  The fee for the replacement tag or sticker as set forth in section 18-303 shall be collected by the office of the clerk-treasurer prior to the issuance of the replacement tag or sticker. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 11, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 09-81, § 8, 11-4-09) 
Sec. 18-308. - Term. 
(a)  Licenses shall be issued under this division for a full calendar year beginning on January 1 of each year and expiring on December 31 of each year. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of a license issued pursuant to this article, it shall be unlawful for the holder of such expired license to continue operating taxicabs within the city until the expired license has been renewed. The license may be renewed upon payment of the licensing fee established by section 18-303 and submission of sufficient information to the commission to establish that the operator and the taxicab owned by him remain qualified to be licensed under the terms of this division. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 9, 3-3-87) 
Sec. 18-309. - Suspension. 
    The traffic commission may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to this division for cause after conducting a hearing at which a quorum of the commission is in attendance. Complaints may be brought against any operator by any person including members of the commission. Any operator against whom a complaint has been made shall be given at least five days' notice of the hearing to be had upon such complaint. Such notice shall be served in person or by mail with a written statement of the complaint made. Upon filing of a complaint with the traffic commission, such complaint shall be heard by the commission at its next regular meeting. After the hearing has been held the commission may revoke the license, suspend the license for a period of time not exceeding six months or take no action against the operator against whom the complaint has been filed. The decision of the commission shall be final except any person against whom an order of suspension or revocation has been entered shall be entitled to a hearing upon filing an affidavit with the traffic commission disclosing that he has new or additional evidence to present to the commission which he had no opportunity to present at the original hearing and which came to his knowledge thereafter. Upon filing of such affidavit, such person shall be entitled to be heard at the next regular meeting of the traffic commission. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, a temporary license issued pursuant to section 18-306(b) may be revoked by the traffic commission without holding a hearing. In the event a temporary license is revoked, the holder of the license shall receive a refund of a pro rata share of the unused license fee from the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 87-11, § 14(A), 3-3-87; Ord. No. 98-17, § 2, 4-7-98) 
Secs. 18-310-18-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - USED MERCHANDISE REGULATION 

Sec. 18-326. - Recording purchases of used merchandise. 
    Any merchant of goods who purchases, sells or trades any item(s) of used merchandise shall keep and maintain a record in which shall be entered and legibly written in ink or typed, at the time of each receipt, purchase or acceptance in trade of such item(s), an accurate account and description of such item(s) and the name and address of the person delivering the item(s). No entry made in such record shall be erased, obliterated or defaced. The records may be made on cards, individual sheets or order pads if each sheet or card is numbered, so that if an entry is removed it will be obvious. The records shall be maintained and preserved for a period of one year from the date of the transaction. All records required by this article and used merchandise on hand shall be open for inspection by members of the city police department. In addition to the foregoing, any merchant of goods who purchases, sells or trades any item(s) of used merchandise shall report each transaction to Leads on Line. 
(Ord. No. 94-18, § 1, 5-4-94; Ord. No. 13-17, § 1, 9-3-13) 
Sec. 18-327. - Unlawful transactions. 
    No merchant of goods shall purchase or accept in trade any used merchandise from any person under the age of 18 years unless such person is accompanied by the person's parent, guardian or other person having custody of the minor or unless the merchant can positively identify the minor by means of a picture I.D., drivers license or by any other means that would verify the minor's identity. This would include the merchant documenting the minor's full name, social security number, if applicable, date of birth, address, parent's name and telephone number. 
(Ord. No. 94-18, § 2, 5-4-94) 
Sec. 18-328. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to dealers of any used personal property governed by state certificate of title statutes, e.g., automobiles, motorcycles, aircraft, boats, etc. This article shall not apply to junk dealers as defined in sections 18-236 et seq. of the city's municipal code or dealers in used precious metals and gems as defined in sections 18-196 et seq. of the city's municipal code. 
(Ord. No. 94-18, § 3, 5-4-94) 
Secs. 18-329-18-349. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PRODUCTS CONTAINING SYNTHETIC CANNABINOIDS 

Sec. 18-350. - Prohibited activity. 
    For purposes of this section, the following conduct shall be prohibited within the city: 
(a)  Products containing synthetic cannabinoids ("products"), such as K2/Spice, or similar products which contain one or more of the following chemical compounds: 
(1)  (6aR, 10aR)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6, 6-dimenthyl-3-(2methyloctan-2-yl)-6a, 7, 10, 10a-tetrahydrobenzo [c] chromem-1-ol, also known as HU-210; 
(2)  1-Penty1-3-(1-naphthoy)indole, also known as JWH-018; 
(3)  1-Buty1-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole, also known as JWH-073; or 
(4)  Any other equivalent compound or derivative; 
shall not be sold, marketed or offered for sale within the city; and 
(b)  Products containing synthetic cannabinoids ("Products") may not be burned, incinerated or ignited in any public place or on any property owned, leased or controlled by the City of Portage. 
(Ord. No. 10-62, § 1, 10-12-10) 
Sec. 18-351. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Enforcement of this chapter shall be by the city police department. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city attorney, to whom the city police department shall report any violation of the provision of this chapter, to cause proceedings to commence against the person violating the provision of this chapter and to prosecute to final termination. 
(Ord. No. 10-62, § 2, 10-12-10) 
Sec. 18-352. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Persons or entities violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to the penalty imposed for a Class B Infraction, as set forth in I.C. 34-28-5-4. Accordingly, this article shall be in force by the provisions of I.C. 34-28-5. 
(b)  Violations of this article within the city shall be a Class B Infraction and upon conviction shall be punishable as follows: 
Punishable by a judgment of up to $1,000.00. 
(c)  The city attorney is authorized to bring a civil action pursuant to I.C. 36-1-6-4 to enjoin any person or business from violating this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-62, § 3, 10-12-10) 
Chapter 22 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Theft of utility or cable television services, IC 35-43-5-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE TELEVISION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 or Ord. No. 95-61, adopted Dec. 5, 1995, repealed art. II in its entirety. Formerly, art. II consisted of §§ 22-26-22-54, which pertained to cable television and derived from §§ 19-3-1, 19-3-3(A)-(E), 19-3-3(H)-(P), 19-3-3(R)-(V), and 19-3-4-19-3-30 of the 1985 Code. Section 1 of Ord. No. 95-61 also provided for new provisions regarding cable television, which have been included herein as §§ 22-26-22-42 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 22-26. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Portage Cable Television Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 as the same may be amended from time to time. 
    Additional services means any communication services other than regular subscriber service and pay television offered by the grantee over the CATV system including, but not limited to, burglar alarm, data or electronic intelligence transmission, facsimile reproduction, meter reading, and home shopping. Additional services shall not include the delivery of the CATV system or any programming on the educational access channels or public access channels, which programming is included in regular subscriber service. 
    Audit means a formal examination or verification of all financial and other records of a grantee in order to determine compliance with this article and/or the existing franchise agreement by someone specifically engaged by the city for that purpose. 
    Board means the citizens cable board established pursuant to this article. 
    CATV means community antenna television. 
    CATV system means a system of cables, wires, lines, towers, wave guides, microwaves and laser beams, and any associated converters, equipment, or facilities designed and constructed for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying, and distributing any audio, video, or other forms of electronic or electric signals to and from subscribers and locations in the city. 
    Cable service means: 
(1)  The one-way transmission to subscribers of: 
a.  Video programming; or 
b.  Other programming service; and 
(2)  Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other programming service. 
    Channel means a band of frequencies, six megahertz wide, in the electromagnetic spectrum which are capable of carrying either: 
(1)  Audiovideo television signals and nonvideo signals; or 
(2)  Nonvideo signals. 
    Converter means an electronic device which converts signals to a frequency not susceptible to interference within the television receiver of a subscriber and which, by an appropriate channel selector, also permits a subscriber to view all signals delivered at designated dial locations. 
    Federal Communications Commission or FCC means that agency as presently constituted by the United States Congress or any successor agency with jurisdiction over CATV matters. 
    Grantee means the person granted a franchise pursuant to this chapter and its lawful and approved successor, transferee, or assignee. 
    Gross revenues means all revenue collected directly or indirectly from the operation or use of all or part of a cable television system franchise pursuant to this chapter by the grantee, including, but not limited to, revenue from regular subscriber service fees, premium pay channels and additional services, installation and reconnection fees, leased channel fees, converter rentals, studio rental, production equipment, and personnel fees and advertising revenues; provided, however, that this shall not include any taxes on services furnished by a grantee herein imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the state, local, or other governmental unit and collected by a grantee on behalf of said governmental unit or bad debt. 
    Public way means the surface, the air space above the surface, and the area below the surface of any public street, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, drive, bridge, tunnel, park, parkway, waterway, or other public right-of-way including public utility easements or rights-of-way, and any temporary or permanent fixtures or improvements located thereon now or hereafter held by the city which shall entitle the city and a grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing and maintaining grantee's cable television system. 
    State of the art means equipment that: 
(1)  Is readily available with a reasonable delivery schedule from two or more sources of supply; 
(2)  Has the capability to perform the intended functions demonstrated within communities with similar characteristics including, but not necessarily limited to, population, density, subscriber penetration, etc., under actual operating conditions for purposes other than test or experimentation; and 
(3)  Can be implemented by the grantee in an economically feasible manner taking into account monthly subscriber rates, economic waste, early retirement of assets, etc. 
    Subscriber means any person who receives any service delivered by the grantee over the CATV system. 
    User of CATV system means any person who utilizes the CATV system to produce or to transmit programs or other communications to subscribers. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-28. - Requirement of a franchise. 
    No person shall construct, install, maintain, or operate a CATV system within the city, or within any other public property of the city, unless a franchise has first been obtained pursuant to this article, and unless such franchise is in full force and effect. Such franchise shall not take the place of any other license or permit which may be legally required of a grantee in order to conduct such a business, or construct or install buildings, structures, facilities, or equipment within the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-29. - Initial franchise application. 
(a)  After receiving an application for an initial franchise from a person, the common council or its designee, after considering the legal, financial, technical, and character qualifications of the applicants, in the public interest, may grant one or more nonexclusive franchises creating a right to construct and operate a cable television system within the public ways of the city; provided, however, no provision of this article shall be deemed or construed as to require the city to grant a franchise. 
(b)  The application for a franchise shall be submitted to the common council or its designee on a written form included in the request for proposals furnished by the city in accordance with procedures and schedules to be established by the city. The application form may request facts and information the city deems appropriate. An application for an initial franchise from a person shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in an amount determined by the city, which amount shall be used by the city to offset direct expenses incurred in the franchising and evaluation procedures, including, but not limited to, staff time and consulting assistance. 
(c)  The board shall review the application and make a written recommendation to the common council concerning the granting of a franchise to the applicant. 
(d)  An applicant (grantee) to whom the common council grants a nonexclusive franchise shall execute a franchise agreement with the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-30. - Franchise conditions. 
(a)  The franchise agreement shall contain any reasonable conditions and terms the common council or its designee deem appropriate. 
(b)  The term of an original franchise and a renewed franchise shall be for a period of time deemed appropriate by the council. No franchise granted pursuant to this article shall give any exclusive right to a grantee and every such franchise shall be deemed to reserve the right to grant other franchisees to use and occupy the public ways of the city for cable television or any other purpose. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-31. - Franchise renewal. 
    A renewal of any franchise shall be done pursuant to applicable state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-32. - Subject to police powers of city. 
    The construction, maintenance, and operation of the grantee's CATV system and all property of the grantee subject to the provisions of any franchise granted under this article shall be subject to all lawful police powers, rules, and regulations of the city. The city shall have the power at any time to order and require the grantee to remove or abate any pole, line, tower, wire, cable, guide, conduit, electric conductor, or any other structure or facility that is dangerous to life or property. In the event the grantee, after written notice, fails or refuses to act, the city shall have the power to remove or abate the same at the expense of the grantee, all without compensation or liability for damage to the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-33. - Compliance with state and federal laws. 
    The grantee shall at all times comply with the Act and all laws, rules, and regulations of the federal and state governments and any administrative agencies thereof. If any such state or federal law, rule or regulation shall require or permit the grantee to perform any service or shall prohibit the grantee from performing any service in conflict with the provisions of this article, any franchise granted under this article, or any other ordinance, rule, regulation, or Charter provision of the city, then immediately following knowledge thereof the grantee shall notify the common council in writing of the point of conflict believed to exist between such state or federal law, rule, or regulation, and the parties may negotiate a modification to the franchise agreement to the extent necessary to carry out the full intent and purpose of the franchise. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city shall have sole authority to revise this article to reconcile any conflict between the article and such state or federal law, rule, or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-34. - Payment to city. 
(a)  As consideration for any franchise granted under this article, the council may require the payment of a franchise fee to the city by the grantee. 
(b)  The franchise fee payable under this section shall be exclusive of and in addition to all ad valorem taxes or special assessments for municipal improvements. 
(c)  The franchise fee described in this section and any other funds generated by this article shall be receipted into the cable television franchise fund with the funds therein to be spent when appropriated in accordance with the law. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-35. - Grantee's rules. 
    The grantee shall have the authority to promulgate such rules, regulations, terms, and conditions governing the conduct of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to enable the grantee to exercise its rights and to perform its obligations under this franchise and to assure an uninterrupted service to all subscribers; provided, however, such rules, regulations, terms, and conditions shall not be in conflict with any of the provisions of any ordinance of the city, of the terms of the franchise agreement, the provisions of this article, the laws of the state and the United States of America, and the rules and regulations of the FCC and any other federal agency having jurisdiction. A copy of the grantee's rules, regulations, terms and conditions shall be filed with the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-36. - Rates. 
    The council or its designee has the right to regulate, in accordance with state and federal rules and regulations, the rates charged by the grantee to subscribers. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-37. - Revocation of franchise. 
    In addition to all other rights and powers of the city by virtue of this article or otherwise, the city reserves as an additional, separate, and distinct power the right to terminate and cancel any franchise granted under this article. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-38. - Miscellaneous. 
    Minimum public notice of any public meeting relating to this article shall be published at least once in a local newspaper of general circulation at least ten days prior to the meeting and posting of notice at city hall at least ten days prior to the meeting. Commencing on the 15th day prior to the meeting, the grantee shall notify its subscribers of the meeting by announcement on at least one channel of its CATV system between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. for five consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-39. - Performance evaluations. 
    The city and the grantee shall hold scheduled performance evaluation sessions every two years during the term of the franchise. All such evaluation sessions shall be open to the public. Special evaluation sessions may be held at any time during the term of this franchise at the request of the city or the grantee. All evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and announced in a newspaper of general circulation in accordance with legal notice. The grantee shall notify its subscribers of all evaluation sessions by announcement on at least one channel of its system between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m., for five consecutive days preceding each session. Topics which may be discussed at any scheduled or special evaluation session may include, but not be limited to, service rate schedules, franchise fees, penalties, free or disconnected services, application for new technologies, system performance, services provided, programming offered, customer complaints, privacy, amendments to this article, judicial and FCC rulings, line extension policies, and grantee or city rules. During a review and evaluation by the city, the grantee shall fully cooperate with the city and shall provide such information and documents as the city may need to reasonably perform the review. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-40. - Citizens cable board. 
(a)  There shall be established a citizens advisory board called the Portage Citizens Cable Board. The board shall consist of five members to be appointed as follows: The mayor shall appoint three members thereof: One member for a term of one year, one member for a term of three years, and one member for a term of four years, respectively; and the common council shall appoint two members thereof: One member for a term of two years and one member for a term of four years, respectively. Thereafter, as the terms expire each new appointment shall be for a term of four years. 
(b)  The board shall adopt bylaws governing its procedures and actions for the selection and tenure of the board's president, vice-president and secretary. 
(c)  Responsibilities of the Portage Citizens Cable Board shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Monitoring compliance by all grantees with all the terms and conditions of this article and their respective franchise agreements; 
(2)  Advising the council on provisions of the city's franchise agreement(s), this article, and related ordinances; 
(3)  Serving as a regulatory and coordinating body for the public-access and educational-access channels of cable television and any institutional networks that may be developed; 
(4)  Conducting, in association with the council and the city administration, the required performance evaluations every two years during the term of the franchise; 
(5)  Advising the city government of objectives to be obtained in the city's cable communication system based on its continued evaluation of the city's cable communication franchise and continued assessment of cable technology; 
(6)  Developing criteria for measuring impact of cable communications upon the community's "quality of life"; 
(7)  Establishing procedures for institutional operations and services, use of dedicated channels, and sharing of public facilities; 
(8)  Preparing an annual report to the council and city administration; and 
(9)  Any other functions which may be assigned to it by the city administration and/or council. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-41. - Limits on grantee's recourse. 
(a)  Except for actions seeking injunctive relief or specific performance and as expressly provided in this article, a grantee shall have no recourse against the city for any loss, expense, or damage resulting from the terms and conditions of this article or any franchise granted hereunder or because of the city's enforcement thereof or the city's failure to have the authority to grant the franchise. 
(b)  The decision of the council concerning grantee selection and awarding of a franchise shall be final, subject to appeal rights available to a prospective grantee under applicable law. 
(c)  A grantee shall not apply for any waivers, exceptions, or declaratory rulings from the FCC or any other federal or state regulatory agency without prior written notice to the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 22-42. - Franchise validity. 
(a)  The grantee shall agree, in its acceptance of any franchise, to accept the validity of the terms and conditions of this article and the franchise agreement in their entirety and that it will not, at any time, proceed against the city in any claim or proceeding challenging any term or provision of this article or any franchise granted hereunder as unreasonable, arbitrary or void, or that the city did not have the authority to impose such term or condition. 
(b)  In case of conflict or ambiguity between this article, the franchise agreement, and the grantee's franchise application, the franchise agreement shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 95-61, § 1, 12-5-95)
