Chapter 30 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 42; parks and recreation, ch. 58; planning, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 82; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Planning and development, IC 36-7-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - TAX ABATEMENT 

Sec. 30-1. - Evaluation factors. 
    The following factors shall be considered by the common council in evaluating an application for tax abatement benefits: 
(a)  Tax abatement should be used to foster and reward advanced manufacturing technologies. 
(b)  New construction or reuse of a facility for its originally intended purpose is preferable to the rehabilitation of an existing facility for a nontraditional use. 
(c)  A significant benefit for the city from granting a tax abatement centers on the number of jobs created and whether Portage's and Porter County's workforce would receive priority consideration for such vacancies. 
(d)  The creation of skilled positions with the potential for growth and the compensation such positions afford are preferable to unskilled positions. 
(e)  New business should be environmentally conscious and responsible. 
(f)  Promoting diversity in locating business and industry in Portage will produce greater long-term prospects for uninterrupted employment opportunities for the local work force. 
(Ord. No. 05-5, § 1, 6-4-05) 
Sec. 30-2. - Information to supplement statement of benefits form. 
    In addition to the statement of benefits form, applicants for tax abatement shall provide the following information, in writing, together with the statement of benefits form: 
(a)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant, subsidiary, and any parent company. 
(b)  The state of incorporation of the applicant, subsidiary, and any parent company. 
(c)  The names and titles of the officers and directors of the applicant company. 
(d)  The name of each person who holds at least five percent of the outstanding shares of stock of the applicant. 
(e)  A list of all divisions, subsidiaries and facilities of any parent company. 
(f)  A financial statement for the applicant, subsidiary, and any parent company for each of the preceding three years, prepared by a certified public accountant in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, including the following information about the applicant, subsidiary, and any parent company: 
1.  Volume of sales; 
2.  Operating profits; 
3.  Book value of plant, land and equipment; 
4.  Net capital investments; 
5.  Net assets; 
6.  Capacity utilization; and 
7.  Liabilities, itemized by the following categories: Loans, mortgages, unfunded pension liabilities, unfunded environmental liabilities, other unfunded liabilities. 
(g)  Whether the business for which tax abatement is being requested has other operations in Indiana; and, if so, the location of other operations. 
(h)  A description of the product(s) manufactured by the applicant. 
(i)  A description, in as much detail as possible, of the impact on the applicant's business (e.g., loss of jobs, production, contract cancellations, etc.) if the proposed project is not undertaken. 
(j)  The name, title, address and telephone number of the person to which annual tax abatement compliance surveys should be sent. 
(k)  Address of the property for which tax abatement is being requested. 
(l)  Whether the applicant currently conducts operations at this location; and, if so, how long the applicant has been at this location. 
(m)  Whether building permits have been obtained or construction started. 
(n)  The current zoning of the property, and the case approval number of any variance, rezoning or approval petition which is/are required or has/have been obtained for this project. 
(o)  The size of the subject real estate (acres). 
(p)  Whether the property is currently developed or undeveloped. 
(q)  Property tax assessment and payment information for the subject real estate. 
(r)  A description of the project for which tax abatement is requested. 
(s)  A list of all public subsidies received by the applicant, subsidiary, or the parent company during the preceding ten years on the facility for which a deduction is sought, or for any other facility that is owned by the applicant, subsidiary or the applicant's parent company and is located in Indiana. The list must include: 
1.  The type of subsidy received (such as property tax deduction, industrial revenue bonds, urban action grants, and job training funds); 
2.  The amount of the subsidy; 
3.  Term of the subsidy; and 
4.  The public benefit that was promised when the subsidy was applied for (such as infrastructure or the creation or retention of jobs), and the current number of jobs, including wages and fringe benefits, created or retained as a result of the subsidy. 
(t)  A description of the construction jobs resulting from the proposed development, rehabilitation or installation of new manufacturing equipment. 
(u)  A description of the permanent jobs resulting from the proposed development, rehabilitation or installation of new manufacturing equipment, including: 
1.  The estimated total number of jobs that will be held by Portage residents; 
2.  The number and category of full-time and part-time employees currently employed by the facility; 
3.  Anticipated date for hiring to begin; and 
4.  Quarterly hiring projections from project completion date until hiring completion date. 
(v)  A description of the jobs that will be lost as a result of the proposed redevelopment, rehabilitation or installation of new manufacturing equipment, including: 
1.  The estimated number of jobs that will be lost; 
2.  The title and occupation skill levels of those jobs; and 
3.  The wages and fringe benefits of those jobs. 
(w)  A description of jobs that will be temporarily or permanently restructured, reclassified or reassigned as a result of the proposed redevelopment, rehabilitation or installation of new manufacturing equipment, including: 
1.  The lengths of tenure and estimated number of jobs that will be restructured, reclassified or reassigned; 
2.  The titles and occupational skill levels of those jobs; and 
3.  The wages and fringe benefits of those jobs. 
(x)  Whether applicant's employees are represented by a union; and, if so, by whom. If not, will applicant pay prevailing wage? 
(y)  1.  Total number of existing employees (permanent full-time): _______; 
2.  Total number and percentage of existing employees (permanent full-time) from Portage: 
# _______ % _______; and 
3.  Total number and percentage of existing employees (permanent full-time) from Porter County: 
# _______ % _______. 
(z)  Current and/or anticipated number of full-time permanent hourly employees by skill level (include average hourly wage rate excluding benefits and overtime): 
Skilled _______ Average Wage Rate _______ Semi-skilled _______ Average Wage Rate _______ Clerical _______ Average Wage Rate _______  
(aa)  Current and/or anticipated number of salaried employees, indicating average compensation, excluding benefits. 
(bb)  Approximate value of benefits for existing and new employees on a per-hour basis. 
(cc)  The average hourly wage rate, excluding benefits and overtime, for: 
Current hourly employees: $ _______ Retained hourly employees: $ _______ New hourly employees: $ _______  
(dd)  1.  Name, title and telephone number of person to be contacted concerning employment and hiring. 
2.  The local media that will be used for job advertisement. 
3.  The Portage location that will be used for interviews. 
(ee)  Whether any additional public facilities will be needed for the project; and, if so, a description of those facilities. 
(ff)  Whether the equipment or the business itself is new to Indiana or is being moved from an existing Indiana location. 
(gg)  Whether the equipment for which abatement is requested represents a technological advance over similar equipment in Portage, Porter County and northwest Indiana. 
(hh)  Whether the applicant will occupy and existing facility or construct a new facility. 
(ii)  Whether Portage's highly skilled work force will receive priority consideration for new job vacancies and whether non-Portage/Porter County residents will receive the next priority. 
(jj)  How Portage/Porter County residents will be made aware of job openings. 
(kk)  Where interviews for new job openings will be conducted. 
(ll)  Whether the new jobs to be created are skilled or unskilled positions. 
(mm)  Whether the applicant's business is environmentally advantageous, neutral or disadvantageous. 
(nn)  Whether the applicant's business contributes to the diversification of the local economy. 
(oo)  Whether applicant will use a project labor agreement for the construction of the project. 
(pp)  Whether the applicant will abide by the city's strike and replacement worker resolution. 
(qq)  Whether applicant, any subsidiary or parent company, has pending litigation or liabilities with the EPA, OSHA, IOSHA, NLRB or EEOC. 
(rr)  Whether applicant, any subsidiary or parent company has a pending tax appeal. 
(ss)  Whether applicant will sign a memorandum of agreement with the city if tax abatement is granted. 
(Ord. No. 05-5, § 1, 6-4-05) 
Sec. 30-3. - Meeting attendance. 
    It is mandatory that a representative of the applicant, well versed in the information contained on the statement of benefits form and about the additional information required by this division, attend the meeting at which the application for tax abatement will be considered to answer any questions which the common council may have. 
(Ord. No. 05-5, § 1, 6-4-05) 
Sec. 30-4. - Property tax appeals. 
    If a recipient of tax abatement, during the life of its abatement, successfully prosecutes a real property or personal property tax appeal which reduces its assessed valuation below the amount in effect at the time the tax abatement was granted, the council may revoke or reduce the tax abatement as it deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 05-5, § 1, 6-4-05) 
Sec. 30-5. - Personal property tax abatement. 
    An applicant for personal property tax abatement under IC 6-1.1-12.1-4.5 shall only be entitled to tax abatement for a period of five years. 
(Ord. No. 06-10, § 1, 4-4-06) 
Sec. 30-6. - Tax abatement fee. 
(a)  IC 6-1.1-12.1-14 shall be incorporated by the common council into its initial approval of a property owner's statement of benefits and deduction at the time of that approval with the property owner's consent. 
(b)  The provisions of IC 6-1.1-12.1-14 shall apply to both personal property and real property tax abatements. 
(c)  During each year in which a property owner's property tax liability is reduced by a deduction, the property owner shall pay a fee to the county treasurer in the amount of 15 percent of the additional amount of property taxes that the property owner would have paid if the deduction had not been in effect, or $100,000.00, whichever is less. 
(d)  Fees collected shall be distributed to one or more public or nonprofit entities established to promote economic development within the corporate limits of the city. The common council shall notify the county auditor of the entities that are to receive distributions under this section and the relative proportions of those distributions. 
(e)  If the common council determines that a property owner has not paid a fee imposed under this section, the council may adopt a resolution terminating the property owner's deduction under IC 6-1.1-12.1-3 or IC 6-1.1-12.1-4.5. 
(Ord. No. 06-10, § 1, 4-4-06) 
Sec. 30-7. - Improvement of property upon which tax abatement has been granted. 
    For any property upon which a tax abatement has been granted, the grantee of the abatement has one year in which to improve the subject property. If the subject property has not been improved within one year of the granting of the abatement, the abatement shall be automatically recalled with any savings payable under the penalty provision of this division. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 1, 8-5-08) 
Sec. 30-8. - Penalty for failure to follow abatement or for withdrawal. 
    This section applies to both real estate and personal property as outlined below: 
(1)  Real estate -For any property upon which a tax abatement has been given, the following provisions apply: 
a.  The failure to improve the property within one year of the abatement shall result in a loss of the abatement and require the owner to pay the tax savings to the city. 
b.  The failure of the owner of the real property to remain at the location of the abatement for the duration of the abatement, ten years, plus an additional five years, may result in the repayment of the tax savings during the original ten-year duration of the abatement. 
(2)  Personal property -For any personal property upon which a tax abatement has been given, the following provision apply: 
a.  The failure to improve the property within one year of the abatement shall result in a loss of the abatement and require the owner to pay the tax savings to the city. 
b.  The failure of the owner of the personal property to remain at the location of the abatement for the duration of the abatement, five years, plus an additional five years, may result in the repayment of the tax savings during the original five-year duration of the abatement. 
(3)  Wages and number of employees -The entity receiving the tax abatement shall work diligently to obtain the level of wages and number of employees it has set forth in its application for abatement. Upon the entity not obtaining 90 percent of the level of wages and number of employees it has set forth in its application for abatement within the time frame set forth in its application, the city may, at it sole discretion, revoke the abatement and seek reimbursement for all tax savings realized by the entity. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2, 8-5-08) 
Secs. 30-9-30-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Economic Development, IC 36-7-12-1 et seq.; establishment of department of economic development, name, IC 36-7-12-4. 

Sec. 30-26. - Created. 
    There is hereby created in the city a department of economic development, to be controlled by the Portage Economic Development Commission. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-4(A)) 
Sec. 30-27. - Board of commissioners-Composition, appointment. 
    The department of economic development shall be governed by a board of three members, to be appointed by the mayor as follows: One of the members so appointed shall be selected by the mayor; one member shall be selected by the county council; and one member shall be selected by the common council. The commissioners so appointed shall take office upon their appointment. Each commissioner shall be appointed by the mayor within ten days after receiving a nomination, and the members shall serve for staggered terms of four years. If any person appointed by the mayor shall fail to qualify within ten days after the mailing to him of notice of his appointment, or if any member after qualifying shall die, resign, or vacate such office, or be removed, a new member shall be chosen and appointed to fill any vacancy in the same manner as provided for the member with respect to whom such vacancy occurred, and the member so chosen shall be appointed to serve for the remainder of the vacated term. Such commissioners shall receive no salary but shall be entitled to reimbursement for any expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duty. Each commissioner shall be paid a per diem allowance of $25.00 for each day such commissioner attends a meeting, regular or special, of the economic development commission. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-4(B)) 
Sec. 30-28. - Same-Qualification, oath of office. 
    No person shall be appointed as a commissioner under this article who is not a resident of the city, employed in the city, or owner of a business in the city. If any commissioner shall cease to qualify in one of the above categories his appointment on such board shall thereby terminate and his office shall become vacant. Each commissioner, before entering upon his duties, shall take and subscribe an oath of office in the usual form, to be endorsed upon the certificate of his appointment, which shall be promptly filed with the clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-4(C)) 
State Law reference- Oath of public officers and deputies, IC 5-4-1-1. 
Sec. 30-29. - Same-Meetings, officers. 
    The commission created in this article shall meet to reorganize in the month of February of each year. The commission shall elect one of its members as president, one as vice-president, and one as secretary. Each of the officers shall serve from the day of his election until January 31 next following his election and until his successor is elected and qualified. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-4(C)) 
Sec. 30-30. - Same-Organization. 
    The economic development commission is authorized to adopt such by-laws, rules and regulations as it may deem necessary for the proper conduct of its proceedings, the carrying out of its duties and the safeguarding of the funds and property placed in its custody. Regular or special meetings shall be held at such times as it may determine and upon such notice as it may fix, either by resolution or in accordance with the provisions of the by-laws, rules and regulations adopted. A majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum and the concurrence of a majority shall be necessary to authorize any action. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-4(D)) 
Sec. 30-31. - Same-Powers, duties. 
    The economic development commission shall have all the powers, privileges, and duties as provided by state law. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-4(E)) 
Sec. 30-32. - Economic development fund. 
    There is hereby created an economic development fund which shall be a non-reverting fund. Application fees and other monies collected by the economic development commission shall be deposited into the economic development fund. The fund shall be used for paying all expenses of the economic development commission including, but not limited to, the cost of legal notices and members' per diem allowances. 
(Ord. No. 95-9, § 1, 3-7-95; Ord. No. 95-9, § 1, 3-7-95) 
Secs. 30-33-30-50. - Reserved.

Sec. 30-52. - Redevelopment commission. 
(a)  The department of redevelopment of the city shall be controlled by a board of five members to be known as the city redevelopment commission. The members of the commission shall be appointed pursuant to state law. 
(b)  The city redevelopment commission shall conduct the business of the department of redevelopment in accordance with state law. The commission shall have all rights, powers, and duties as are prescribed by statute for the operations of the department of redevelopment, together with such other rights, powers and duties as are incidental thereto. 
(c)  Neither the commission nor any of its members nor the department of redevelopment shall have any rights or powers not specifically granted to them by state law, except for incidental rights and powers. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-3(B)-(D))

ARTICLE IV. - REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Redevelopment authority, IC 36-7-14.5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 30-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authority means the Portage Redevelopment Authority. 
    Commission means the City of Portage, Indiana, Redevelopment Commission. 
    The Act means IC 36-7-14.5-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 93-3, § 1, 2-9-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 30-77. - Created, name. 
    The city hereby creates a redevelopment authority under the Act to be known as the Portage Redevelopment Authority as a separate body corporate and politic and as an instrumentality of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-3, § 1, 2-9-93) 
Sec. 30-78. - Purposes. 
    The authority is organized for the following purposes: 
(1)  Financing, constructing, and leasing local public improvements to the commission; 
(2)  Financing and constructing additional improvements to local public improvements owned by the authority and leasing them to the commission; 
(3)  Acquiring all or a portion of one or more local public improvements from the commission by purchase or lease and leasing these local public improvements back to the commission, with any additional improvements that may be made to them; 
(4)  Acquiring all or a portion of one or more local public improvements from the commission by purchase or lease to fund or refund indebtedness incurred on account of those local public improvements to enable the commission to make a savings in debt service obligations or lease rental obligations or to obtain relief from covenants that the commission considers to be unduly burdensome; and 
(5)  Any other purposes permitted by the Act, including the issuance of bonds to finance local public improvements. 
(Ord. No. 93-3, § 2, 2-9-93) 
State Law reference- Purposes for organizing authority, IC 36-7-14.5-11. 
Sec. 30-79. - Board of directors. 
    The board of directors of the authority shall be composed of three members who are residents of the city and shall be appointed by the mayor for three-year terms. 
(Ord. No. 93-3, § 3, 2-9-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-7-14.5-8. 
Chapter 34 - ELECTIONS[1]

Sec. 34-1. - Voter registration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to vote at any general city election, primary city election, or any other election held in the city unless such person is, at the time of such election or primary, a registered voter under the requirements and provisions of the laws of the state. 
(Code 1985, § 5-2-1)

ARTICLE II. - COUNCILMANIC DISTRICTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Council election districts, IC 36-4-6-4. 

Sec. 34-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Precinct refers to the precinct by that name as established by the board of commissioners of the county and as approved by the state election board under IC 3-11-1.5, in existence on December 1, 1992. 
(Ord. No. 92-50, § 1(C), 12-1-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 34-27. - Composition of council, manner of election. 
    The council is composed of seven members. Five members of the council are elected from the districts established under this article. Two members of the council are elected at large by the voters of the entire city. 
(Ord. No. 92-50, § 2, 12-1-92) 
Sec. 34-28. - Division of city into districts. 
    The city is divided into the following districts for the purpose of conducting elections of council members: 
(1)  District 1. That part of the city located in Portage Township, Precincts 3, 7, 12, 17 and 32, inclusive. 
(2)  District 2. That part of the city located in Portage Township, Precincts 2, 5, 13, 25 and 26, inclusive. 
(3)  District 3. That part of the city located in Portage Township, Precincts 6, 21, 22, 27 and 37, inclusive; and Westchester Township, Precinct 17. 
(4)  District 4. That part of the city located in Portage Township, Precincts 1, 18, 20, 23 and 36, inclusive. 
(5)  District 5. That part of the city located in Portage Township, Precincts 9, 14, 19, 24, 35 and 38, inclusive. 
(Ord. No. 92-50, § 3, 12-1-92; Ord. No. 97-9, § 1, 4-1-97; Ord. No. 02-29, § 1, 7-2-02; Ord. No. 12-21, § 1, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 34-29. - Areas not included in district. 
    If any part of the city is not included in one of the districts established by this article, that territory is included within the district that: 
(1)  Is contiguous to that territory; and 
(2)  Contains the smallest population, as "population" is defined in IC 1-1-4-5. 
(Ord. No. 92-50, § 4, 12-1-92) 
Sec. 34-30. - Areas in more than one district. 
    If any part of the city is included in more than one of the districts established by this article, that territory is included within the district that: 
(1)  Is one of the districts in which the territory is described in this article; 
(2)  Is contiguous to that territory; and 
(3)  Contains the smallest population, as "population" is defined in IC 1-1-4-5. 
(Ord. No. 92-50, § 5, 12-1-92) 
Sec. 34-31. - Map adopted. 
    A map depicting the districts established under this article is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into this article. Two copies of this map are on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer for public inspection as required by IC 36-1-5-4. If a conflict exists between the districts as depicted on the map and as described in this article, the description in this article prevails. 
(Ord. No. 92-50, § 6, 12-1-92)

Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - AMBULANCES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 38-26-38-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY AMBULANCE SERVICE 

Sec. 38-36. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a city emergency ambulance service, which service shall be operated by the fire department of the city, with the rules and regulations for the operation of such service to be established and maintained by such department and by the fire chief. 
(Code 1985, § 13-1-1) 
Sec. 38-37. - Use restricted. 
    The city emergency ambulance service shall be provided for emergency ambulance use only. The determination of an emergency shall be made by the fire chief or emergency ambulance service employees. The emergency ambulance service shall routinely transport persons to the following hospitals: Porter Regional Hospital, Porter County, Indiana; St. Mary's Medical Center, Hobart, Indiana; Portage Community Hospital, Portage, Indiana; and Methodist Hospital Northlake Campus, Gary, Indiana. If persons using the emergency ambulance service require transportation to hospitals other than those named above, they shall employ a private ambulance service. 
(Code 1985, § 13-1-2; Ord. No. 99-4, § 1, 1-5-99; Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 6-5-07; Ord. No. 12-26, § 1, 11-7-12) 
Sec. 38-38. - Fees. 
    There is established the following fee schedule for the use of the ambulance service: 
(a)  A charge of $500.00 for each transportation of an individual requiring basic life support (BLS); 
(b)  A charge of $700.00 for each transportation of an individual requiring advanced life support, level I (ALS I); 
(c)  A charge of $850.00 for each transportation of an individual requiring advanced life support, level II (ALS II); 
(d)  In addition to the flat fees described in subsections (a), (b) and (c) above, each individual transported by the ambulance service shall be charged a mileage fee of $10.00 per mile. The mileage fee shall be assessed on the miles traveled from the location where the individual is picked up by the ambulance to the hospital where the individual is transported. 
(e)  In addition to the fees described in subsections (a) through (d) above, nonresidents shall be charged an additional fee of $50.00. 
(f)  A medical services fee of $250.00 shall be collected for each incident where: 
(1)  Ambulance service is requested by, or on behalf of, a patient; 
(2)  A medical services are provided to the patient by emergency medical personnel; 
(3)  The patient refuses ambulance transport; and 
(4)  The fire chief determines such services are beyond the scope of non-transport assistance normally provided without charge. 
(g)  All fees listed in subsections (a) through (f) above shall increase by three percent annually, effective on January 1 of each calendar year. 
(Code 1985, § 13-1-3; Ord. No. 88-27, § 1, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 91-32, § 1, 7-2-91; Ord. No. 92-32, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 06-37, § 1(a), 8-1-06; Ord. No. 12-09, § 1, 6-5-12; Ord. No. 12-20, § 1, 8-7-12) 
Sec. 38-39. - Reciprocal agreements. 
    The board of public works and safety of the city is hereby authorized and empowered to execute reciprocal agreements with other emergency ambulance services providing for cooperation between the emergency ambulance services, reciprocity of memberships and any other coordination and cooperation between ambulance services which the board of public works and safety determines to be in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 13-1-5(B)) 
Sec. 38-40. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Advanced life support, level I means the provision of an assessment by an advanced life support provider and/or the provision of one or more advanced life support interventions. 
    Advanced life support, level II means the administration of at least three different medications and/or the provision of one or more of the following advanced life support procedures: manual defibrillation/cardioversion, endotracheal intubation, central venous line, cardiac pacing, chest decompression, surgical airway or intraosseus line. 
    Basic life support means the provision of basic life support services as defined in the National EMS Education and Practices Blueprint for the EMT-Basic. 
    Nonresident means an individual who does not reside within the corporate boundaries of the city at the time service is rendered or who does not pay property taxes for real estate located within the corporate boundaries of the city which is owned by the individual at the time service is rendered. 
    Resident means an individual who resides within the corporate boundaries of the city at the time service is rendered, or an individual who pays property taxes for real estate located within the corporate boundaries of the city which is owned by the individual at the time service is rendered. 
(Ord. No. 06-37, § 2, 8-1-06) 
Sec. 38-41. - Use of fees. 
    A fund known as the "Fire Department Equipment Fund" is hereby created as a non-reverting fund. Ten percent of the fees collected pursuant to section 38-38 and other fees designated by the common council shall be deposited monthly in the Fire Department Equipment Fund to be used for the purchase and maintenance of equipment utilized for the provision of emergency medical services. The remaining 90 percent of the fees collected pursuant to section 38-38 shall be deposited monthly into the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 12-20, § 1, 8-7-12; Ord. No. 16-2, § 1, 1-9-16) 
Sec. 38-42. - Waiver of fees in case of hardship. 
    The clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to waive fees, in whole or in part, imposed under this article in cases of financial hardship at the request of patients who ask for assistance. Financial hardship may be shown by having annual gross family income less than 200 percent of federal poverty level and being unable to meet the financial obligation for payment of the fees. 
    The clerk-treasurer shall provide a report of fees waived under this section to the common council annually. 
(Ord. No. 15-8, § 1, 4-7-15; Ord. No. 15-21, § 1, 12-1-15) 
Secs. 38-43-38-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS EMERGENCY 

Sec. 38-56. - Creation of fund. 
    There is hereby created an emergency response fund which shall be a nonreverting fund. The fund shall be used for the purpose specified herein. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 4, 3-7-95) 
Sec. 38-57. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency action means and includes any action taken at or near the scene of a hazardous materials emergency to prevent or minimize harm to human health, to property, or to the environment from the uncontrolled release of a hazardous material. 
    Emergency response agency means the city police department, fire department, any other department or agency of the city, or any combination of agencies or departments, that provide(s) firefighting services, emergency rescue services, emergency medical services, manpower, equipment, or supplies at the scene of a hazardous materials emergency. 
    Emergency response fund means a non-reverting fund used for the purpose of replacing equipment and supplies expended or consumed responding to hazardous materials emergencies. The fund may also be used to finance emergency response agency training and education. 
    Hazardous material means a material or waste that has been determined to be hazardous or potentially hazardous to human health, to property, or to the environment by any of the following organizations: the United States Environmental Protection Agency; Nuclear Regulatory Commission; Department of Transportation; Occupational Safety and Health Administration or the solid waste management board. This term shall include all of the hazardous materials identified in 49 C.F.R. 172.101. 
    Hazardous materials emergency means an occurrence that involves the uncontrolled release or imminent uncontrolled release of a hazardous material into the environment and that creates the possibility of harm to human health, to property, or to the environment. 
    Person means an individual, a corporation, a partnership, or an unincorporated association. 
    Pesticide means a substance or a combination of substances commercially produced for use as an insecticide, a rodenticide, or a nematocide. 
    Responsible party means a person who owns hazardous material that is involved in a hazardous materials emergency or owns a container or owns or operates a vehicle that contains hazardous material that is involved in a hazardous materials emergency; and who causes or substantially contributes to the cause of the hazardous materials emergency. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 2, 3-7-95) 
Sec. 38-58. - Reimbursement for expenses. 
(a)  The City of Portage Fire Department may impose a charge on a person that is a responsible party with respect to hazardous materials emergencies that the fire department responded to; members of the Portage Fire Department assisted in containing, controlling, or cleaning up with respect to the eminent release of hazardous materials at a facility; involves a quantity of hazardous material that exceeds the spill quantities of hazardous materials that must be reported under 327 IAC 2-6.1-5, as in effect on January 1, 2001; and with respect to the release or eminent release of hazardous materials from a mode of transportation, involves a quantity of hazardous materials that exceeds the spill quantities of hazardous materials that must be reported under 327 IAC 2-6.1-6, as in effect on January 1, 2001. 
(b)  The city may obtain reimbursement under subsection (a) by filing an action for reimbursement in the Porter Superior Court. In the event it is necessary for the city to file suit to obtain reimbursement pursuant to this article, the city shall be entitled to collect reasonable attorney's fees in addition to any other amounts due. Funds collected in connection with a hazardous materials emergency exclusive of attorney's fees shall be deposited into the emergency response fund created by this article. 
(c)  The City of Portage Fire Department shall impose a fee pursuant to the state fire marshall schedule of services issued under IC 36-8-12-16(e) as follows: 
(1)  For the initial response with a fire engine, a fire truck, or a fire apparatus, including a hazardous material response unit, or a fire rescue unit dispatched on a fire or hazardous material incident, $250.00 per response vehicle except command/control vehicle, which is $100.00 per vehicle. 
(2)  For each hour or fraction thereof as on-scene assistance, $150.00 per response unit and $50.00 per command/control vehicle. 
(3)  For expendable materials such as absorption materials, emulsifiers, or other agents used in clean up operations, the actual replacement cost of those materials. 
(4)  For collection of debris, chemicals, fuel, or contaminated materials resulting from a spill, the actual cost of removal and disposal at an authorized location. 
(d)  A responsible party is subject to a penalty for failure to pay the full amount of a charge made under this section within 60 days after the issuance of the bill for payment by the fire department. The amount of the penalty is ten percent of the amount of the charge that remains unpaid on the due date. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 3, 3-7-95; Ord. No. 09-62, §§ 1-3, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 38-59. - Occurrences not covered. 
    This article does not apply to an occurrence involving the release or imminent release of less than 25 pounds of active ingredient of a substance or a combination of substances that (a) was commercially produced and sold as a fertilizer, fungicide, herbicide, or pesticide and (b) is, at the time of the occurrence, in the possession of an individual who acquired the substance or combination of substances with the intent to use it for the purpose intended by the commercial producer in a dwelling owned or occupied by the individual or in a yard adjacent to or surrounding a dwelling owned or occupied by the individual or on a farm owned or operated by the individual. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 5, 3-7-95) 
Chapter 42 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 10; community development, ch. 30; parks and recreation, ch. 58; planning, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 70; stormwater utility, Ch. 82, Art. III; waterways, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Environment, IC 13-1-1-1 et seq.; actions for nuisance, IC 34-1-52-1 et seq.; protection of public health, safety and welfare, IC 36-8-2-4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall be applicable for the purposes of this article: 
    Agency means a board, commission, department or other entity exercising a part of the executive, administrative or legislative power of the city. 
    City means the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    Public building means an enclosed structure or part of an enclosed structure that is owned, leased or occupied by the city or its agencies. 
    Smoking means the carrying or holding of a lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe or any other lighted smoking equipment, or the inhalation or exhalation of smoke from any lighted smoking equipment. 
(Ord. No. 05-22, § 1, 4-5-05) 
Sec. 42-2. - Prohibition of smoking in public buildings. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all public buildings in the city. This prohibition shall apply to all areas in those buildings, whether used as a place of employment or as a place for the conduct of public business. 
(Ord. No. 05-22, § 1, 4-5-05) 
Sec. 42-3. - Posting of signs. 
    The official in charge of a public building shall post conspicuous signs that read "Smoking is Prohibited by State Law and City Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 05-22, § 1, 4-5-05) 
Sec. 42-4. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  The official in charge of a public building in the city shall request persons who are smoking in violation of this article to stop smoking and may remove a person who fails to stop smoking after being requested to do so. 
(b)  A person who smokes in a public building shall be subject to a fine as provided by section 1-16 of the city's Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 05-22, § 1, 4-5-05) 
Secs. 42-5-42-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOISE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Land excavations, § 18-106 et seq.; noise caused by transient merchants, § 18-156. 
State Law reference- Regulation of noise emission by air pollution control board, IC 13-7-8-1; authority of city to regulate sound generation, IC 36-8-2-8. 

Sec. 42-26. - General definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    A-weighted sound level means the loudness of a sound measured through a filtering device intended to simulate human hearing. The level is designated dB(A) or dBA. 
    Commercial zone means zones C-1, C-2, C-3, C-4, C-5, and ES as established in the city by chapter 90. 
    Decibel (dB) means a unit for measuring the sound pressure level of a sound. 
    Frequency means an objective way to describe the pitch of a sound. 
    Hertz (Hz) means a unit for measuring the frequency of a sound, sometimes called "cycles per second." 
    Industrial zone means zones I-1 and I-2 as established in the city by chapter 90. 
    Light motor vehicle means any motorized vehicle in gross vehicular weight less than 8,000 pounds, including automobiles, vans, motorcycles, motordriven cycles, motor scooters, dune buggies, snowmobiles, all-terrain vehicles, go-carts, minibikes, trail bikes, and light trucks. 
    Modified exhaust system means any exhaust system in which the original noise abatement devices have been removed, altered, or replaced to produce more noise. 
    Noise means any unwanted sound. 
    Octave band means a way to divide the entire frequency range of sound into sections for more accurate measurements. 
    Plainly audible means any noise for which the information content is unambiguously communicated to the listener, including understandable spoken speech, comprehension of whether a voice is raised (agitated), or normal, or comprehensible musical rhythms. 
    Residential zones means zones R1, R2, R3, R4, M1, M2, MP and CR as established in the city by Chapter 90. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument designed to measure sound pressure levels. 
    Sound pressure level means an objective way to describe the loudness of a sound. 
    All terminology used in this article shall be in conformance with the applicable publications of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) or its successor body. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-1(A)-(J), (L)-(O); Ord. No. 18-12, § 1(a), 8-7-18) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 42-27. - Scientific definitions. 
    The concise, scientific definitions of the terms used in this article shall be: 
    A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level of sound measured through an A-weighted filter network. The level read is designated dB(A) or dBA. 
    Decibel (dB) means the unit used for comparing the sound pressure level of a sound to the sound pressure level of a reference sound having a sound pressure of 20 micropascals. 
    Frequency means the number of periodic oscillations, vibrations or waves per unit time, usually one second. 
    Hertz (Hz) means the unit used for measuring the frequency of a sound. The number of hertz is the number of cycles per second of a periodic sound pressure wave. 
    Octave band means a portion of the entire sound frequency spectrum contained between two frequencies A and B such that A = 2B. 
    Sound pressure level means 20 times the logarithm (Base 10) of the ratio of the measured sound pressure to a reference pressure of 20 micropascals. The sound pressure level is expressed in decibels (dB). 
SPL = 20LOG 10 Sound Pressure A

(Code 1985, § 9-1-2)

    The octave-band breakdowns of the dBA limits used in this article shall be: 
(1)  For a residential zone (55 dBA):

(Code 1985, § 9-1-3) 
Sec. 42-29. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found in violation of the motor vehicle noise limits set forth in this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $250.00. 
(b)  Any person found in violation of any other provision set forth in this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for the first offense; not less than $75.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for the second offense; and not less than $150.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for the third or subsequent offenses. 
(c)  During any trial concerning the provisions of this article, the court may admit evidence of the sound pressure level as tested by a sound level meter which meets or exceeds ANSI specifications for Type II equipment. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-8(A), (B), (D)) 
Sec. 42-30. - General prohibitions. 
    The making of, continuing, or causing or aiding to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary, or unusual noises which either annoy, injure, or endanger the comfort, repose, health, or safety of others is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. This general prohibition is not limited by the specific restrictions listed in section 42-31. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-4; Ord. No. 95-53, § 1, 11-8-95) 
Sec. 42-31. - Specific restrictions. 
    The following acts are declared to be unlawful: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn, signal device, or attachment on automobiles, motorcycles, bicycles, trucks, buses, or other vehicle, except as a necessary warning of danger to persons or property in the event of an emergency or when required by law. 
(2)  The creation of grating, screeching, grinding, squeaking, loud reports or shots, or other noises in the use of automobiles, motorcycles, or other vehicles, or appurtenances attached thereto. 
(3)  The creation of loud noises by the manipulation, handling, and playing of musical instruments, except in conjunction with authorized parades or public functions, a permit for which has been issued by the city. 
(4)  The creation of noise by any radio, television set, phonograph, musical instruments, tape or record players, amplifiers, and similar devices or the making of any loud, unnecessary, or boisterous noises at any hour of the day. 
(5)  The operation or permitting the use or operation of any mechanically powered saw, drill, sander, grinder, or any other domestic power tool, as well as any lawn or garden tool, lawnmower, or similar device used outdoors, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such a manner that will disturb any reasonable person nearby. 
(6)  Operating or permitting the operation of any tools or equipment used in construction, drilling, or demolition between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such a manner that will disturb any reasonable person nearby. 
(7)  Participating in any party or gathering between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. giving rise to noise that is plainly audible across property boundaries or between partitions common to two or more persons within a building. 
(8)  No person shall play, use, operate or permit to be played, used or operated, any radio, tape recorder, cassette player or other device for receiving broadcast sound or reproducing recorded sound if the device is located: 
a.  On the public way; or 
b.  In any motor vehicle on the public way; 
and if the sound generated by the device is clearly audible to a person with normal hearing at a distance greater than 50 feet. This subsection shall not apply to any person participating in a parade or public assembly for which a permit has been obtained. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-5; Ord. No. 95-53, § 2, 11-8-95; Ord. No. 99-19, § 1, 5-5-99; Ord. No. 09-25, § 1, 6-2-09; Ord. No. 09-38, § 1, 7-7-09; Ord. No. 18-12, §§ 1(b), (c), 8-7-18) 
State Law reference- Use of horns and emergency warning signals on motor vehicles, IC 9-19-5-2 et seq. 
Sec. 42-32. - Quantitative limits-Motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause the sound pressure level of the noise emitted during the operation of a light motor vehicle to exceed 80 dBA in speed zones of 35 m.p.h. or less within the city. The sound pressure measurement shall be made at a distance of not less than 15 feet from the edge of the lane of travel of the violator. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a light motor vehicle which causes excessive noise as a result of unnecessary rapid acceleration, deceleration, engine revving, or tire squealing. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-6(A)) 
Sec. 42-33. - Same-Stationary source. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause the sound pressure level at any point on the boundary of the property where the person is located to exceed the following limits: 
(1)  If a person is located within a residential zone, 55 dBA between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.; 
(2)  If a person is located within a commercial zone, 64 dBA at all times; and 
(3)  If a person is located within an industrial zone, 66 dBA at all times. 
(b)  If the property boundary lies between two zones, the lower limit shall apply regardless of the zone in which the person creating the noise is located. 
(c)  In addition to the above, no person within a residential or a commercial zone shall make or cause to be made any earth-shaking vibrations, perceptible without the aid of instruments, beyond the property boundary of the vibration source. No person within an industrial zone shall make or cause to be made any earth-shaking vibrations, perceptible without the aid of instruments, beyond the zone boundary of the zone in which the vibration source is located. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-6(B)) 
Sec. 42-34. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency or the emission of sound in the performance of work to prevent or alleviate physical or property damage threatened or caused by a public calamity or other emergency. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-7(A)) 
Sec. 42-35. - Permits. 
(a)  The board of public works and safety of the city shall have the authority to issue permits for: 
(1)  Holidays, celebrations, concerts, parades or other special events (public or personal); and 
(2)  Persons who demonstrate that bringing the source of sound or activity for which the permit is sought into compliance with the provisions of this article would constitute an unreasonable hardship on the applicant, the community, or other persons and that the impact on the health, safety and welfare of persons affected by the permit has been outweighed by such hardship. 
(b)  Permits may contain any conditions, including a time limit, that are necessary to limit the adverse impact of the activity. Noncompliance with any condition of the permit shall terminate it and subject the person holding it to the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The board of public works and safety of the city may issue guidelines defining the procedures to be followed in applying for a permit and the specific criteria to be considered in deciding whether to issue a permit. 
(Code 1985, § 9-1-7(A)-(C)) 
Secs. 42-36-42-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND DRAINAGE[3] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-56. - Statute adopted. 
    IC 8-1.5-5 concerning stormwater management systems is hereby adopted by the common council so as to make such Act and any and all amend ments thereto effective and operative in the city. Two copies of such Act are on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 90-54, § 1, 10-2-90)
