DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 46-26-46-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MERIT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Fire department merit systems, IC 36-8-3.5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-36. - Established. 
    A fire department merit system is created pursuant to IC 36-1-4-14. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 46-37. - Merit commission. 
(a)  A merit commission consisting of five commissioners shall be established. The commissioners shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Two persons who must be of different political parties shall be appointed by the mayor; 
(2)  One person shall be appointed by the common council; and 
(3)  Two persons who must be of different political parties shall be elected by the active members of the fire department. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, political affiliation shall be determined through the voter registration records of the three most recent primary elections. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 3, 9-3-91) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Members of commission, IC 36-8-3.5-1. 
Sec. 46-38. - Commissioners' qualifications and oath. 
    Each merit commissioner shall have been a legal resident of the city for three consecutive years immediately preceding his term and must be a person of good moral character. A commissioner must be at least 21 years of age and not currently a member of the fire department. No commissioner may be a past member of the fire department, except for retired members with a minimum of 20 years of service. A person may not serve on the commission if he receives any salary from the city except for nominal compensation received for serving on another board. Each commissioner shall take an oath of office to conscientiously discharge his duties. A signed copy of the oath shall be filed with the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 4, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 11-46, § 1, 11-1-11) 
Sec. 46-39. - Commissioner's terms, vacancies and removal. 
(a)  Term. The merit commissioners shall serve for four-year staggered terms. 
(b)  Vacancy. A vacancy on the commission shall be filled within 30 days by the appointing or electing authority. The selection is for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(c)  Removal. A commissioner serves at the pleasure of the appointing or electing authority and may be removed at any time. In the case of a commissioner elected by the fire department, the board of public works and safety shall call a meeting of the active members of the department under the procedures specified in subsection (d) if a recall petition signed by a majority of the active members is submitted to the board. 
(d)  Notice; vote. All the active members of the fire department shall be given at least three weeks notice. At the meeting the vote shall be taken by secret ballot. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, §§ 2, 5, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 46-40. - Election of commissioners and election meetings. 
    An election by the active members of the fire department shall be held at a meeting called specifically for that purpose by the fire department. The fire department shall give at least three weeks' notice of the meeting to all active members of the department by posting the notice in prominent locations in stations of the department. The notice shall also be read during shift roll calls. The notice must designate the time, place and purpose of the meeting. Only active members of the department may attend the meeting and at the meeting one of them shall be selected as chairman. All voting must be by secret written ballot. The other procedures for holding the meeting shall be as determined by the fire department and shall be posted in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 6, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 11-46, § 2, 11-1-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-8. 
Sec. 46-41. - Commission rules and meeting. 
    Within 30 days after the merit commission is selected, the commission shall adopt internal rules to govern itself including the time and place of regular monthly meetings and special meetings that are necessary to transact the business of the commission. A majority of the commissioners constitutes a quorum and a majority vote of all the commissioners is necessary to transact the business of the commission. Each year the commissioners shall select from among their number a president, vice-president and secretary. The commission shall keep a permanent record of its proceedings. The commission shall submit a proposed annual budget to the city as other budgets of the city are submitted. The city shall include in its budget an amount sufficient for the necessary expenses of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 7, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-9. 
Sec. 46-42. - Adoption of merit system rules. 
    The merit commission shall adopt rules governing: 
(1)  The selection and appointment of persons to be employed as members of the fire department subject to applicable pension statutes; 
(2)  Promotions and demotions of members of the department; and 
(3)  Disciplinary action or dismissal of members of the department. 
Prior to the adoption of any of these rules, the commission must hold a public hearing for consideration of the adoption of the proposed rules. Notice should be given at least ten days prior to the public hearing, in accordance with IC 5-3-1 et seq. The notice should state the time, place and brief subject matter of the public hearing. At least ten days prior to the hearing, one copy of the proposed rules shall be placed on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer for inspection by residents of the city and three copies of the proposed rules shall be forwarded to the chief of the fire department and retained on file in his office for inspection at all times by the members of the fire department. Any interested person residing in the city and any member of the fire department must be afforded an opportunity to present both oral and written evidence on any matter relating to the adoption of the proposed rules at the public hearing. The commission shall give due consideration to this evidence in making its final decision concerning the adoption of the proposed rules. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 8, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-10. 
Sec. 46-43. - Appointment and removal of members of the department. 
    The merit commission shall have the power to appoint and remove members of the fire department, except for a member of an upper-level policy-making position, which is considered to be the chief and assistant chiefs. The mayor shall appoint and may remove a member in an upper-level policy-making position. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 9, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-11. 
Sec. 46-44. - Removal of member in upper-level policy-making position. 
    The removal of a member from an upper-level policy-making position is removal from rank only and not from the fire department. When the member is removed, he shall be appointed by the merit commission to the rank in the department that he held at the time of his upper-level appointment or to any rank to which he had been promoted during his tenure in the upper-level position. If such a rank is not open in either case, the member is entitled to the pay of that rank and shall be promoted to that rank as soon as an opening is available. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 10, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-11. 
Sec. 46-45. - Qualifications and requirements for membership in department. 
(a)  To be appointed to the fire department an applicant must be a citizen of the United States, a high school graduate or equivalent, and at least 21 years of age, but under 36 years of age. 
(b)  No person may be appointed, reappointed or reinstated in the fire department if he has a felony conviction on his record. Applications for appointment or reappointment shall be filed with the merit commission and the applicant must provide satisfactory proof of the date and place of his birth. Passage of preliminary examinations deemed necessary by the commission shall be required of all applicants to determine general aptitude for service as a member of the department. These examinations shall include at a minimum, a written aptitude test, a physical agility test and a swim test and shall be conducted according to the procedures adopted by the commission. The results of the preliminary examination shall be filed with the commission; and if an applicant lacks the proper qualifications as evidenced by failure of any of the preliminary examinations, the commission shall reject the applicant. Upon passage of the preliminary examinations, the commission shall then rate the applicant according to physical condition, mental alertness, character, habits, and reputation pursuant to methods adopted by the commission. The commission which determines the passing score for the preliminary examination shall post an eligibility list by the order of scores of the applicants. This list shall be certified to the board of public works and safety. 
(c)  All eligible applicants may remain on the list for two years from the date of certification. After two years, a person must reapply as an applicant. At any time that a vacancy occurs in the fire department, the commission, upon written request by the chief of the fire department shall appoint the applicant having the highest score on the eligibility list to fill the vacancy. A probationary member is not entitled to a disciplinary hearing under section 46-50. That applicant shall be enrolled as a member of the department provided he is still of good character and passes the required physical examination. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 11, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 12-08, § 1, 5-1-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-12. 
Sec. 46-46. - Establishment of a promotional list. 
(a)  Eligibility. The eligibility of a member for promotion within the fire department is subject to the following: 
(1)  Full screening consideration for promotion may only be given to members who are qualified, according to this article and to the state law, in rank and length of service. 
(2)  Promotions to a rank may only be from the next lower rank, and any member being promoted must have served at the lower rank for a continuous period of at least six months. The only exception to this rule shall be through the provisions of section 46-47. 
(b)  Promotion list. Promotions within the fire department shall be made from an eligibility list, such eligibility being based upon the cumulative score of all rating factors. 
(1)  This list shall be maintained for a period of one year from the date of certification, after which time the list shall be retired and a new list shall be established; provided, however, that the old list shall remain in effect until the adoption of the new list. 
(2)  Any candidate on the list must reapply and retake the test. 
(c)  Competitive examination. The merit commission shall direct the chief to post a notice stating the time and place that the written examinations will be given to eligible applicants. 
(1)  At the time of testing for promotions, if no department member wishes to test for the next higher rank, exams may be given as described in section 46-47. 
(2)  The commission may employ instructors, purchase materials and make other expenditures to provide information for applicants for promotion examinations. 
(3)  The identity of a member taking the written examinations shall be withheld from the person grading the examination and all written examinations are confidential. 
(4)  The commission shall notify each member in writing of the score that the member received on the examination. The score received becomes a part of the permanent file of the member, and the member is entitled to access to his file for review at any time. 
(5)  A member who is aggrieved with the score received on the written examination may appeal to the commission for review of the score within ten days after receiving notice of the score. He may review the questions incorrectly answered by him and challenge the answer considered correct by the examiner. The commission shall either affirm the score or correct the score according to the findings of the review. 
(6)  The examination papers shall be kept under the commission's supervision. The papers shall be retired after the one year period during which the eligibility list is valid. The retired papers shall be kept for five years and then destroyed. 
(d)  Factors for evaluation of applicants. Rating of applicants shall be made according to criteria set by the merit commission. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 12, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 93-47, § 1, 12-7-93) 
State Law reference- Promotions, IC 36-8-3.5-13. 
Sec. 46-47. - Alternative testing. 
(a)  Second-round testing. If no eligible applicant qualifies for the list under the criteria provided in section 46-46, the merit commission may initiate a second round of testing to qualified personnel from the next lower rank as follows: 
(1)  Qualified personnel, for the purposes of this section, shall include: 
a.  Those persons from the immediately preceding rank who would have been able to take the test described in the above section except for the six-month eligibility requirement. 
b.  Those persons from the next lowest rank who took the test for promotion to the above rank and who passed as follows: 
1.  In the case of a captain, eligible persons include all lieutenants who were ineligible for the captain's test because of the six-month requirement, as well as all engineers who took the lieutenant's test and passed; and 
2.  In the case of a lieutenant, eligible persons include all engineers who were ineligible for the test because of the six-month requirement, as well as all the privates who took the engineer's test and passed. 
(2)  Eligibility lists compiled under this "second round" procedure shall be compiled and scored in the manner set forth in section 46-46(d). 
(b)  Alternative promotional testing procedure. If no candidate qualifies for the eligibility list under the second round procedure, the merit commission, in its sole discretion, may elect to do one of the following: 
(1)  Allow the chief to fill a vacancy by appointing an acting officer, who will hold and fill this position temporarily, but without the benefit of a permanent rank promotion; or 
(2)  Institute a third alternative testing procedure by the following procedures: 
a.  The chief shall inform the merit commission whenever he judges, in his discretion, that an existing vacancy orexpected vacancy will require a permanent replacement, and request the merit commission to institute alternative testing. 
b.  Upon receipt of such notice from the chief, the commission may instruct the chief to post or otherwise circulate notice asking all members interested in the vacant position to sign up for alternative testing. 
c.  The merit commission shall review the interested applicants according to the criteria set forth in section 46-46, but no new written test need be given; the commission shall make a recommendation to the chief for filling the vacant position, stating whether each applicant is qualified and ranking the applicants in order of the scoring criteria. In this case, ranking shall not be bound by any minimum score requirement; provided however, that the merit commission may decline to rank an applicant at all if, in its discretion and opinion, the applicant is not qualified for the vacancy due to overall low scores. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 13, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 93-47, § 2, 12-7-93) 
State Law reference- Competitive examinations, IC 36-8-3.5-14. 
Sec. 46-48. - Performance ratings. 
    The merit commission shall adopt rules for determining a performance rating. The rules shall require that a performance rating be made at least once every six months for each member of the fire department, including probationary members. The rating shall be made as defined in the commission's rules. Probationary members shall be rated in the same manner as other members of the department. The rating shall be submitted to the chief of the department and kept on file in his office under his supervision. The chief shall notify each member in writing of the rating that the member received. A member who is aggrieved with the performance rating given to him may appeal to the commission for a review of the rating. The appeal must be filed within ten days after notice of the rating has been sent to him. The commission shall either affirm or correct the rating. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 14, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-15. 
Sec. 46-49. - Vacancy in rank and promotions. 
(a)  When a vacancy in rank occurs, the merit commission shall certify to the chief the member with the highest score on the eligibility list for the particular rank. Within 30 days, the chief may recommend to the board that the vacancy be filled, at which time, the member with the highest score will then be certified by the board. 
(b)  All promotions shall be probationary for a period not to exceed one year. At any time during the probationary period, the member's performance may be reviewed by the chief and the chief may recommend to the commission that the promotion be revoked. At the end of the period, a probationary member's performance shall be reviewed by the chief, who shall recommend to the commission either that the promotion be made permanent or be revoked. The chief shall submit a written report and rating chart for use in making such report. 
(c)  The probationary member is entitled to appear before the commission and be heard on any matter detrimental to him in the chief's report. He is also entitled to be represented by counsel or another representative of his choice. 
(d)  If the promotion is finally revoked, the member may not be returned to a rank lower than that which he held before the probationary promotion. 
(e)  Actions by the commission other than making the promotion permanent may be appealed within 30 days to the circuit or superior court of the county, with the city being named as the sole defendant. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 15, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 93-47, § 3, 12-7-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-16. 
Sec. 46-50. - Disciplinary actions and procedures. 
(a)  The merit commission may take the following disciplinary actions against a regular member of the fire department: 
(1)  Written reprimand. 
(2)  Suspension with or without pay. 
(3)  Demotion. 
(4)  Dismissal. 
(b)  A member may be disciplined by the commission if: 
(1)  He is convicted of a crime; or 
(2)  The commission finds him guilty of a breach of discipline including: 
a.  Neglect of duty; 
b.  Violation of commission or department rules; 
c.  Neglect or disobedience of orders; 
d.  Continuing incapacity; 
e.  Absence without leave; 
f.  Immoral conduct; 
g.  Conduct injurious to the public peace or welfare; 
h.  Conduct unbecoming a member; or 
i.  Furnishing information to an applicant for appointment or promotion that gives that person an advantage over another applicant. 
If the chief, after an investigation, prefers charges against a member for any of the violations listed above, a hearing shall be conducted upon the request of the member. The commission shall hold the hearing as provided in the commission's rules. The hearing conducted under this subsection shall be held within 30 days after it is requested by the member. 
(c)  Written notice of the hearing shall be served upon the accused member in person or by a copy left at his last and usual place of residence. The notice must state: 
(1)  The time and place of hearing; 
(2)  The charges against the member; 
(3)  The specific conduct that comprises the charges; 
(4)  That the member is entitled to be represented by counsel or another representative; 
(5)  That the member is entitled to call and cross examine witnesses; 
(6)  That the member is entitled to require the production of evidence; and 
(7)  That the member is entitled to have subpoenas issued, served and executed. 
The commission shall have the power to compel the attendance of witnesses by issuing subpoenas, examine witnesses under oath and order the production of books, papers and other evidence by issuing subpoenas. If a witness fails to appear or fails to produce those written documents requested in writing by the commission, the commission may file an affidavit with the circuit court of the county setting forth the facts relative to the refusal. 
(d)  Upon filing the affidavit, a summons shall be issued from the circuit court and served by the sheriff of the county requiring the appearance of the witness or the production of information or evidence to the commission. Disobedience of this summons constitutes contempt of the circuit court from which the summons has been issued unless the action is found to be in good faith and with reasonable cause. Expenses related to the filing of an affidavit and the issuance and service of a summons shall be charged to the witness against whom the summons has been issued unless the circuit court finds that the action of the witness was taken in good faith and with reasonable cause. In that case and in any case in which an affidavit has been filed without the issuance of a summons, the expenses shall be charged to the commission. 
(e)  The decision to discipline a member must be based upon the preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing. Any member aggrieved by a decision of the commission may appeal to the commission within ten days of the decision. The commission shall on appeal review the record and either affirm, modify, or reverse the decision on the basis of the record and such oral or written testimony that the commission determines including additional or newly discovered evidence. The commission shall keep a record of the proceedings in cases of suspension, demotion, or dismissal. The commission shall give a free copy of the transcript to the member upon request if an appeal is filed. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 16, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-17. 
Sec. 46-51. - Appeal to circuit or superior court. 
    Any member who is aggrieved by a decision of the merit commission to suspend him for a period greater than ten calendar days, demote him or dismiss him may appeal to the circuit or superior court of the county. The appeal shall be made according to the Indiana Rules of Trial Procedure with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The verified appeal must be filed within 30 days after the date of the commission's decision. 
(2)  The city shall be named as the sole defendant. 
(3)  The city is assumed to have denied the allegations without filing a responsive pleading. 
(4)  The plaintiff must file a bond at the time of filing the complaint conditioned on the plaintiff prosecuting the appeal to a final determination and paying the court costs incurred in the appeal. 
(5)  Within 30 days after the service of summons the commission shall file in court a complete transcript of all papers, entries, and other parts of the record relating to the case. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 17, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-18. 
Sec. 46-52. - Suspension or reprimand by chief of department. 
(a)  In addition to the disciplinary powers of the merit commission, the chief may, without a hearing, reprimand or suspend without pay a member for a maximum of five working days. For the purposes of this section, eight hours of paid time constitutes one working day. 
(b)  If the chief reprimands a member in writing or suspends a member, or takes any of the actions under subsection (a) of this section, he shall within three business days, notify the commission in writing of the action and the reasons for the action. 
(c)  A member who was reprimanded in writing or suspended under this section may, within three business days after receiving notice of the reprimand or suspension, request in writing that the commission review the reprimand or suspension and either uphold or reverse the chief's decision. At its discretion, the commission may hold a hearing during this review. 
(d)  If the decision is reversed, the individual who was suspended is entitled to any wages withheld as a result of the suspension. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 18, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 93-47, § 4, 12-7-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-19. 
Sec. 46-53. - Mandatory retirement. 
    A member of the fire department shall retire from the department when he reaches his 65th birthday. However, a member of the department who is 65 years of age or older at the time the ordinance establishing the merit system takes effect may serve until the end of the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 19, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Retirement, IC 36-8-3.5-20. 
Sec. 46-54. - Reduction or enlargement of staff. 
    If it is necessary for the board of public works and safety to reduce the number of members of the fire department, the reduction shall be made by granting a temporary leave of absence, without pay or financial obligation to the city, to the appropriate number of members. The last member appointed shall be put on leave first with the other members also put on leave in reverse hiring order until the desired level is achieved. If the department is increased in number again, those individuals given a temporary leave of absence due to the reduction of staff shall be reinstated before any applicant from the eligibility list is considered. The reinstatements begin with the last member granted a leave. Any member on a leave of absence shall keep the commission advised of his current address. A member shall be informed of his reinstatement by written notice. Within ten calendar days after a member receives notice of reinstatement, he shall advise the commission that he accepts reinstatement and will be able to commence employment on the date specified in the notice. All reinstatement rights granted to a member terminate upon his failure to accept reinstatement within that period. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 20, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-21. 
Sec. 46-55. - Dissemination of rules. 
    All rules of the merit commission shall be furnished to each member of the fire department. Any amendments shall take effect 30 days after their adoption if copies have been furnished to all members of the department within that period. Otherwise, they do not take effect until copies are furnished to all members of the department. 
(Ord. No. 91-42, § 21, 9-3-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-22. 
Secs. 46-56-46-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- 1937 firefighters' pension fund, IC 36-8-7-1 et seq.; 1977 police officers' and firefighters' pension and disability fund, IC 36-8-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-66. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a firefighters' pension fund for the fire department of the city. Such fund shall be known as the "Firefighters' Pension Fund of the City of Portage, Indiana." 
(Code 1985, § 6-2-1) 
Sec. 46-67. - Board of trustees. 
(a)  There is hereby established a board of trustees of the firefighters' pension fund. Such board shall be known as the "Board of Trustees of the Portage Firefighters' Pension Fund." 
(b)  The board of trustees shall have the power and authority to adopt and enforce such a constitution and bylaws as may be necessary to enable it to effectively and properly carry into execution the purposes for which it was organized; provided, that such constitution and bylaws shall not in any way contravene this or any other ordinance of the city. 
(c)  The accumulation of funds, government, general organization, and all matters pertaining to such fund and board of trustees shall be done in accordance with the provisions of the laws of the state. 
(Code 1985, § 6-2-2) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Board of trustees, IC 36-8-7-3. 
Sec. 46-68. - Benefits under prior funds. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, effective January 1, 1990, the pension benefits for the surviving spouse, children and parents of a deceased firefighter who is a member of the 1937 Firefighters' Pension Fund shall be in the same amounts, terms and conditions as those benefits payable to those persons under the 1977 Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension and Disability Fund, as those benefits are set forth in IC 36-8-8-14.1. 
(Ord. No. 89-4, § 1, 1-3-89) 
State Law reference- Amount of benefits, determination of time served, IC 36-8-7-12.1. 
Sec. 46-69. - Death benefits. 
    Upon the death of a disabled, retired of [or] discharged member of the fire department who was receiving or entitled to receive a pension at the time of his death, or upon the death of a member in active service at the time of his or her death, the local board shall authorize and pay out of the 1937 fund: 
(a)  Twelve thousand dollars for a member who dies after July 1, 2008, 
as death benefits. 
    The death benefits described in this section shall be paid to the following: 
(a)  To the surviving spouse; 
(b)  If there is no surviving spouse, to the surviving children; and 
(c)  If there is no surviving spouse, and if there are not surviving children, to the estate; 
of the deceased member. 
(Ord. No. 94-35, § 2, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 98-22, § 1, 6-2-98; Ord. No. 08-46, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, § 2 of Ord. No. 94-35, adopted September 6, 1994, has been codified as herein set out in § 46-69. Said provisions did not expressly amend the Code. 
Secs. 46-70-46-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPEN BURNING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Open burning, IC 13-1-1.2-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Open burning means and includes fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly into the outdoor atmosphere without passing through a stack. 
    Refuse means and includes any garbage, paper, wood, metal, cinders, fly ash, trees, leaves, brush, and branches. 
(Ord. No. 91-56, § 1a, c, 12-3-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 46-92. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined an amount not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00. 
(Ord. No. 91-56, § 4, 12-3-91) 
Sec. 46-93. - Prohibited. 
    No person shall conduct an open burn of refuse anywhere in the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-56, § 2, 12-3-91) 
Sec. 46-94. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not prohibit the following activities: 
(1)  Outdoor fires for cooking, recreation or for ceremonial purposes. 
(2)  Regulated burning in the city to control vegetation growth on city property. 
(3)  Burning conducted by the fire department for the purposes of fire training. 
(4)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 91-56, § 3, 12-3-91; Ord. No. 07-15, § 1, 5-1-07) 
Secs. 46-95-46-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORAGE OF CHEMICALS AND COMBUSTIBLE SUBSTANCES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Regulated explosives, IC 22-14-4-1 et seq. 

Sec. 46-116. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Combustible, chemical and/or explosive substance means any flammable substance which is volatile when retained in storage and which shall be in excess of 600 gallons liquid measure or, four cubic feet solid measure, or four cubic feet gas form when measured at no more than 20 pounds per square inch pressure. 
(Code 1985, § 13-3-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 46-117. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of no less than $100.00 nor more than $300.00. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be a separate offense. Any violation of this article is also hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be enforced by any court of competent jurisdiction by injunction. 
(Code 1985, § 13-3-6) 
Sec. 46-118. - Approval required. 
(a)  No person shall for any purpose store or retain any combustible, chemical and/or explosive material, either in liquid, gas or solid form and/or a combination of either, within the city without first obtaining written approval by majority vote of the common council. 
(b)  Each person shall apply for written approval of the common council for the storage of combustible, chemical and/or explosive materials by making application in writing to the clerk-treasurer's office. An application form is available in the clerk-treasurer's office. Each application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the person requesting storage of combustible, chemical, or explosive material. 
(2)  The exact location proposed for the storage of the materials. 
(3)  The exact type of material requesting to be stored. 
(4)  The proposed manner of storage including a concise description of the proposed container to be used. 
(5)  An indication that the proposed storage complies with all federal and state regulations. 
(c)  The applicant shall, at the time the application is filed, pay to the clerk-treasurer the sum of $25.00 to cover the cost of investigating the application. 
(Code 1985, § 13-3-1; Ord. No. 91-10, § 1, 3-5-91; Ord. No. 07-15, § 2, 5-1-07) 
Sec. 46-119. - When storage prohibited. 
    The storage of any combustible, chemical and/or explosive substance shall not be retained above or below ground level where such storage location is within the distance of 100 feet from any school building, public building, public meeting place, or church. 
(Code 1985, § 13-3-2) 
Sec. 46-120. - Controlling restrictions. 
    Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon the use of land, buildings or structures than is imposed or required by such existing provisions of law, ordinance, contract, or deed, the provisions of this article shall control. 
(Code 1985, § 13-3-4) 
Sec. 46-121. - Minimum requirements. 
    The board of public works and safety and the common council shall be held to the minimum requirements adopted by the state for any governmental agency for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare to protect the public for adequate safety from fire and other dangers relating to combustible, chemical, and/or explosive substances. 
(Code 1985, § 13-3-5) 
Sec. 46-122. - Inspections. 
    The fire department shall be notified 48 hours prior to any work being performed. An inspection shall be required on all equipment, piping, tanks and electrical connections prior to any equipment, piping, tanks and electrical connections being covered or placed into service. 
(Ord. No. 95-20, § 1, 5-3-95) 
Secs. 46-123-46-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1-29 of Ord. No. 96-4, adopted Feb. 6, 1996, added provisions of Ch. 46, Art. V, to the Code, but did not specify section numbering. At the discretion of the editor, therefore, said provisons have been included as §§ 46-151-46-172, 46-185-46-190 and 46-201 herein. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-151. - Title. 
    This ordinance and all ordinances supplemental or amendatory hereto, shall be known as the "Fire Prevention Code of the City of Portage, Indiana", hereinafter referred to as "code" 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 1, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-152. - Purpose. 
    The purpose and intent of the code is to prescribe minimum requirements and controls to safeguard life, property or public welfare from the hazards of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling or use of substances, materials or devices and from conditions hazardous to life, property or public welfare in the use or occupancy of buildings, structures, sheds, tents, lots or premises. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 2, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-153. - Applicability. 
(a)  The provisions of this code and the fire safety rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission shall apply to existing buildings and conditions. 
EXCEPTIONS: 
(1)  Existing conditions which do not constitute a distinct hazard to life or property. 
(2)  The transportation of any article or substance under the jurisdiction of and in compliance with the regulations prescribed by the Armed Forces of the United States. 
(b)  Nothing in this code shall be construed, interpreted or applied to abrogate, nullify or abolish any law, ordinance or code adopted by the Common Council of the City of Portage governing the construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, use location, occupancy and maintenance of buildings. When any provision of this code is found to be in conflict with any building, zoning, safety, health or other applicable law, ordinance or code of the City of Portage existing on the effective date of this code or hereafter adopted, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the safety and welfare of the public shall prevail. 
(c)  The planning, design and construction of new buildings and structures to provide egress facilities, and built-in fire protection equipment shall be controlled by the fire and building rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission; and any alterations, additions or changes in building requirements necessitated by this code which are within the scope of said building rules shall be made in accordance therewith. 
(d)  Buildings built under and in full compliance with the building and fire safety laws and rules in force at the time of construction or alteration thereof, and that have been properly maintained and used for such use as originally permitted, shall be exempt from the requirements of this code pertaining to any of the following matters: 
(1)  Fire protection and structural elements. 
(2)  Required exits. 
(3)  Isolation of hazardous operations and mixed uses. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 3, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 96-37, § 1, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 46-154. - Adoption of fire prevention codes. 
(a)  The following fire safety rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission as set out in Article 22 of Title 675 of the Indiana Administrative Code are hereby incorporated by reference in this code, including later amendments to those rules as the same are published in the Indiana Register or the Indiana Administrative Code with effective dates as fixed therein: 
ARTICLE 22 - FIRE PREVENTION CODES 
1.  Indiana Flammable and Combustible Liquids and Gases Code. 
2.  Indiana Fire Prevention Code. 
(b)  Copies of adopted fire safety rules, codes and standards are on file in the office of the Fire Inspector of the City of Portage. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 4, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-155. - Enforcement Authority. 
(a)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of the chief of the fire department or such officer or designee who is an ex officio assistant to the state fire marshal under IC 36-8-17-5(a) and IC 36-8-17-8(b), to enforce the provisions of this code. The designated enforcement officer of this code is herein referred to as the "fire chief". 
(b)  The fire chief shall cooperate with the building commissioner responsible for enforcing the code of building laws and orders required to be enforced in the City of Portage pursuant to IC 36-7-2-9. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 5, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-156. - Inspections. 
(a)  The fire chief or designee shall cause all structures and premises except the interior of private single-family dwellings, and dwelling units in two-family and multifamily dwellings to be inspected for the purpose of ascertaining and requiring the correction of any conditions liable to cause fire, contributing to the spread of fire, interfering with fire fighting operations, endangering life or violating any of the provisions or intent of this code under IC 36-8-17-8(b). 
(b)  Special inspection fees shall be assessed as per the following schedule. Payment for special inspections shall be made to the clerk-treasurer's office no later than 24 hours prior to the inspection. Emergency after hours inspection fees shall be paid within three days after the inspection is completed. A fire inspection fee shall not be charged to a business for the annual fire inspection. If violations are identified during the annual inspection, the business owner shall be given a reasonable amount of time to correct those violations. A follow-up inspection shall be conducted to confirm whether the violations have, in fact, been corrected. A fire inspection fee shall not be charged for the first follow-up inspection at a business. However, a fire inspection fee shall be charged for each subsequent inspection conducted to confirm that the violations have been corrected. 
Special Inspection Fee Schedule 
Fireworks stand: temporary or permanent ..... $ 100.00 
Outdoor carnivals ..... 100.00 
Outdoor assembly tents ..... 30.00 
Fire inspection fee ..... 100.00 
Emergency after-hours inspections/testing ..... 200.00 
(c)  All fire inspection fees received shall be deposited in the fire department's maintenance and equipment fund and may be used by the chief administrative officer of the fire department for the purchase and maintenance of equipment. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 6, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 1, 5-8-08; Ord. No. 12-18, § 1, 8-7-12) 
Sec. 46-157. - Right of entry. 
    Whenever necessary for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this code, or whenever the fire chief or designee has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any structure or upon any premises any condition which makes such structure or premises unsafe, the fire chief or fire inspector shall be permitted to enter such structures or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the fire chief by this code; provided that if such structure or premises be occupied, the fire chief or fire inspector shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such entry is refused, the fire chief or authorized inspector shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 7, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 2, 5-6-08) 
Sec. 46-158. - Investigation of fires. 
    The fire chief or designee shall investigate, or cause to be investigated, every fire or explosion occurring within the city that is of a suspicious nature or which involves the loss of life or serious injury or causes destruction of or damage to property. Such investigation shall be initiated immediately upon the occurrence of such fire or explosion; and if it appears that such an occurrence is of a suspicious nature, the fire chief shall take charge immediately of the physical evidence, and in order to preserve any physical evidence relating to the cause or origin of such fire or explosion, take steps to prevent access by any person or persons to such buildings, structures or premises until such evidence has been properly processed. The fire chief shall notify the office of the state fire marshal pursuant to IC 36-8-17-7 and shall cooperate with said office in the collection of evidence and prosecution of the case. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 8, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 3, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-159. - Fire records; reports. 
(a)  The fire chief or designee shall keep a record of all fires and all facts concerning the same, including investigation findings, statistics and information as to the cause, origin and the extent of such fires and the damage caused thereby. 
(b)  The fire chief or designee shall submit a report of each fire occurring within the city to the office of the state fire marshal in accordance with IC 36-8-17-7, in the form prescribed by that office. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 9, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 4, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-160. - Violations; orders. 
(a)  Whenever the fire chief or designee observes a violation of a provision of this code or other ordinances under the fire chief's jurisdiction, the fire chief shall prepare a written notice of violation and order describing the violation and specifying a reasonable time for the required repairs or improvements to be made to correct the violation. The written notice of violation of this code shall be served upon the owner, a duly authorized agent or upon the occupant or other person responsible for the condition causing the violation. The notice of violation shall be served either by delivering a copy to the appropriate person(s) by ordinary mail to the last known post office address, delivered in person or by delivering it to and leaving it in the possession of any person in charge of the premises, or in the case such person is not found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof, in a conspicuous place at the entrance door or avenue of access; and such service shall be deemed the equivalent of personal notice. 
(b)  If the notice of violation and order is not compiled with within the time specified by the fire chief or designee, and if no review of such order has been initiated under IC 4-21.5-3-7, the fire chief shall request the legal counsel for the city to institute appropriate legal action to restrain, correct or abate such violation or to require removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or structure in violation of the provisions of this code or of any order or direction made pursuant thereto. A fee of $25.00 per violation shall be assessed for each day beyond the deadline. 
(c)  Temporary or emergency orders issued by the fire chief under IC 36-8-17-9(b) shall first be approved by the state fire marshal. 
(d)  When, in the opinion of the fire chief or designee, there is actual and potential danger to the occupants or those in proximity to any building, structure or premises because of unsafe structural conditions, or inadequacy of any means of egress, the presence of explosives, explosive fumes or vapors, or the presence of toxic fumes, gases or material, the fire chief may issue an emergency order, for the immediate evacuation of said building, structure or premises. All of the occupants so notified shall immediately leave the building, structure or premises and persons shall not enter or re-enter until authorized to do so by the fire chief or designee. Any person who shall refuse to leave, interfere with the evacuation of other occupants or continue any operation after having been given an evacuation order except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be deemed in violation of this code. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 10, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 5, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-161. - Administrative review; appeals. 
(a)  A person who is aggrieved by an order issued pursuant to section 10 of this code [section 46-160 of this article] or IC 36-8-17-9, shall have an opportunity to discuss the order with the state fire marshal, who may modify or reverse the order. 
(b)  An order issued pursuant to section 10 of this code [section 46-160 of this article] or IC 36-8-17-9, or an order affirmed or modified by the state fire marshal may be appealed to the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission under IC 4-21.5-3-7. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 11, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-162. - Remedies. 
    The attorney for the city, upon written notice from the fire chief or designee that a lawful notice and order to abate a violation of this code has been issued and a reasonable time for compliance has expired, shall bring action in the Circuit or Superior Court of Porter County, Indiana, for mandatory and injunctive relief for the enforcement of and to secure compliance with any order or orders made by the fire chief. Any such action for mandatory or injunctive relief may be joined with an action to recover the penalties provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 12, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 6, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-163. - On-site fire protection facilities required. 
    The fire chief or designee may require that any real estate development include the installation of such on-site fire protection facilities as fire hydrants and access roads as in his judgment are necessary to provide adequate water supplies and access on land to be developed. The installation shall be at the expense of the owner or developer. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 13, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 7, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-164. - Specifications. 
    All fire hydrants and water distribution systems required to be installed under section 15 of this code [section 46-165 of this article] shall be approved by and meet the specifications of the fire department and water supplier as to location, size and type of material and manner of installation. Construction shall be carried out under the inspection of the fire prevention division of the city and water supplier. Systems shall be designed in accordance with recognized standards and plans approved by fire department fire prevention division prior to construction. When any land is developed in such a manner that all or a substantial part of any building or structure thereon is or becomes in excess of 300 feet from the public water system for fire protection the developer shall provide such fire protection facilities and fire hydrants on the land as shall be determined necessary under this section to provide an adequate water supply. A hydrant shall be considered operation when it is available for use and meets the required fire flow established by the fire department based on the 2003 Indiana Fire Code. If the notice of violation and order is not compiled with within the time specified by the fire chief, and if no review of such order has been initiated under IC 4-21.5-3-7, the fire chief shall request the legal counsel for the city to institute appropriate legal action to restrain, correct or abate such violation or to require removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or structure in violation of the provisions of this code or of any order or direction made pursuant thereto. A fee of $25.00 per violation shall be assessed for each day beyond the deadline. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 14, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 8, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-165. - Location of fire hydrants. 
    Fire hydrants shall be located at least 50 feet from buildings but no further than 100 feet from fire department connections on buildings equipped with standpipe systems or automatic sprinkler systems nor more than 300 feet from an unsprinklered building. These distances shall be determined by measuring the footage from the building to the fire hydrant using approved fire apparatus access ways. No fire hydrant shall be located further than eight feet from the edge of an approved fire department access road or the curb line of a public or private street. If the notice of violation and order is not compiled with within the time specified by the fire chief, and if no review of such order has been initiated under IC 4-21.5-3-7, the fire chief shall request the legal counsel for the city to institute appropriate legal action to restrain, correct or abate such violation or to require removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or structure in violation of the provisions of this code or of any order or direction made pursuant thereto. A fee of $25.00 per violation shall be assessed for each day beyond the deadline. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 15, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 9, 5-8-08 
Sec. 46-166. - Maintenance. 
    All on-site fire protection facilities whether installed before or after the effective date of Ordinance No. 08-18 [May 8, 2008], shall at all times be maintained in good working order by the owner thereof. To this end, the fire chief or designee is empowered to mandate that the owner conduct periodic tests and inspections of the facilities by a contractor trained to conduct such tests and inspections. Results of such tests shall be forwarded to the fire chief and if the fire chief determines that the facilities are not being reasonably maintained as required by this article, he shall order that the owner or lessee of the land make the necessary repairs or changes within ten days or such time as in his judgment is reasonable. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with any such order. If the notice of violation and order is not compiled with within the time specified by the fire chief, and if no review of such order has been initiated under IC 4-21.5-3-7, the fire chief shall request the legal counsel for the city to institute appropriate legal action to restrain, correct or abate such violation or to require removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or structure in violation of the provisions of this code or of any order or direction made pursuant thereto. A fee of $25.00 per violation shall be assessed for each day beyond the deadline. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 16, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 10, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-167. - Interruption of service. 
    No fire hydrant or water distribution system, whether installed before or after the effective date of Ordinance No. 08-18 [May 8, 2008], may be removed from service without notifying the fire department, via the emergency service dispatch center, 24 hours before work is to begin. Emergency work to repair leaks or restore service may be done without prior notice. The fire department shall be notified of hydrant/water distribution system interruptions within one hour of emergency work by water company servicing personnel or any privately owned water distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 17, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 11, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-168. - Blocking access to fire hydrants. 
    When any on-site fire protection facility has been installed as provided in this article either pursuant hereto or prior to the effective date hereof the following shall be applicable: 
(a)  Hydrants; parking prohibited. With respect to hydrants located along private access ways where curbs exist, the curb shall be painted yellow or otherwise appropriately marked by the owner, lessee, or other person in charge of the premises to prohibit parking for a distance of 15 feet in either direction from any such hydrants In such cases where curbs do not exist, there shall be appropriate markings painted on the pavement, or signs erected, or both, giving notice that parking is prohibited for a distance of 15 feet from any hydrant. When the areas are signed or marked as provided herein, no person shall park or leave a vehicle standing within 15 feet of any fire hydrant. 
(b)  [Obstructions prohibited.] No person shall place or keep any post, fence, wall, tree, plantings or any obstruction of any kind near any fire hydrant connection, fire protection control valve, or fire department connection that would prevent such equipment from being immediately discernible or in any other manner deter or hinder the fire department from gaining immediate access to said equipment. A minimum of five feet clear space shall be maintained around the circumference of the equipment, as well as a five-foot pathway to connections, except as otherwise required or approved by the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 18, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 12, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-169. - Fire department access roads. 
    All fire apparatus access roads shall be approved by and meet the following specifications of the fire department: 
(a)  Bridges. When a bridge is required to be used as access under this section, it shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with applicable codes using designed live loading of fire apparatus. 
(b)  Number of access roads. When a fire apparatus access road exceeds 150 feet in length and serves multiple buildings or complexes, additional fire apparatus access roads may be required if, in the opinion of the fire chief or designee, a single access road may become blocked, endangering lives and/or buildings beyond the blockage. 
(c)  Access; snow clearance. When snowfall warrants, the clearance of snow from sidewalks and parking areas of any business owner, lessee or, other person in charge of the premises shall be required at the same time to remove snow from all access roads required under this section. Such snow clearance shall not cause any fire hydrant or fire department connection to become obstructed as specified in section 46-168. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 19, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 13, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-170. - Construction facilities. 
    Fire protection facilities are to be provided during initial stages of construction. When it is deemed that fire protection facilities required to be installed as required in this article, the shall be installed and serviceable prior to or at the time any combustible construction begins on the land, unless, in the opinion of the fire chief, the nature or circumstances of the facilities make it impractical. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 20, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-171. - Review of building plans by fire department and certificate of occupancy. 
(a)  [Plans.] Except as otherwise determined by the fire chief or designee, the plans submitted to the city building department in support of an application for a building permit to construct or modify any commercial or public building shall also be submitted to the fire department for review. Plans submitted must contain the official design release stamp of the Indiana State Building Commissioner. 
(b)  [Review.] When any plans are submitted under subsection (a), the fire chief shall cause them to be reviewed and determine whether such plans conform to the rules and regulations of the city fire prevention ordinance. A $50.00 fire department plan review fee must be paid upon submission of the plans to the city. The fire department review fee shall be deposited into the fire prevention gift fund. 
(c)  Certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy must be signed by both the planning department and the fire department after a final inspection of the building or structure is made. No building or structure shall be used or occupied until this certificate of occupancy has been issued. Issuance of a certificate of occupancy shall not be construed as an approval of any violation of the provisions of this code or of other ordinances of the city or rules and regulations of the state fire prevention and building safety commission. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 21, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 14, 5-8-08; Ord. No. 15-5, § 3, 3-3-15) 
Cross reference- Fire department fire prevention gift fund, § 2-162. 
Sec. 46-172. - Operations at fire or other emergencies. 
(a)  The fire chief and his authorized representatives who may be in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency involving the protection of life and/or property shall have the power and authority to direct such operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any fire, perform any rescue operation, investigate the existence of suspected or reported fires, gas leaks, or other hazardous conditions or situations or the taking of any other action necessary in the reasonable performance of their duty. In the exercise of such power, the chief may prohibit or remove any person, vehicle, vessel or thing from the scene of an emergency which may impede or interfere with the operations of the fire department. The fire chief may also prohibit or remove any person who, in the opinion of the fire chief, is not actually and usefully employed in the extinguishment of such fire or in the preservation of life or property in the vicinity thereof. 
(b)  Any person who obstructs the fire department in connection with extinguishing any fire, or other emergency, or disobeys any lawful command of the chief or officer of the fire department who may be in charge at such a scene or any part thereof or any police officer assisting the fire department shall be in violation hereof and subject to the penalties in this article. 
(c)  The chief or other officer of the fire department in charge at the scene of an emergency shall have the authority to place ropes, guards, barricades or other obstructions across any street, alley, place or private property in the vicinity of such operation so as to prevent accidents or interference with the lawful efforts of the fire department to manage and control the emergency and to handle fire apparatus. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 22, 2-6-96) 
Secs. 46-173-46-184. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 46-185. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, when used in this division shall have the following meanings: 
    Alarm user. Any natural person, firm, association, partnership, sole proprietorship or corporation which is in control of any building, structure or facility in which an alarm system is installed, operated or maintained. 
    Board. Board of public works and safety of the city. 
    False alarm. The activation of an alarm system eliciting a response by the fire department of the city which is not in response to actual or threatened danger to persons or damage to property. False alarm also means the activation of any such alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or maintenance, or negligence of the alarm user or his employees or agents; but it does not include alarm activation caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by an alarm user or alarm system installer or service, and is not unique to the particular system. 
    Notice. Written notice either by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service upon the addressee at his last known address. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 23, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 15, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-186. - Response to alarms determination of validity. 
(a)  Whenever an alarm system is activated in the city which results in an emergency response to the premises by its fire department, the officer on the scene of the activated alarm system shall inspect the area protected by the system and shall determine whether the emergency response was required or was a false alarm. 
(b)  If the officer at the scene of an activated alarm system determines the alarm to be false, the officer shall make a report of the false alarm, notice of which shall be sent to the alarm user. 
(c)  The fire chief or his designee shall have the right to inspect the premises to which a response has been made and may cause such inspection to be made at any reasonable time after the occurrence of a false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 24, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-187. - False alarms. 
(a)  Whenever an alarm user issues, causes to be issued, or permits the issuance of a false alarm, this section shall apply; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to a residential alarm user who is a natural person aged 65 or older. 
(b)  The fire department shall maintain appropriate records of all false alarms to which the department responds. After the fire department responds to two false alarms at a location on or after January 1 and before December 31 of any calendar year, it shall charge the alarm user a fee for each subsequent false alarm response in the amount of $100.00 for the third and fourth false alarm, and $500.00 for five or more false alarms, as reasonable compensation for the cost of the department's personnel, equipment and overhead for the response. The owner/occupant shall be notified in writing of each false alarm response, and upon the third and any subsequent notices will be required to submit payment to the clerk-treasurer for the said violation. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 25, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 16, 5-8-08) 
Sec. 46-188. - Automatic telephone dialing systems prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, install, maintain, lease, operate, or assist in the operation of an automatic telephone dialing alarm system over any telephone lines exclusively used by the public directly to request emergency service from the police department or the fire department of the city. 
(b)  The police chief or the fire chief or their designees, upon becoming aware of an automatic telephone dialing system installed or operated in violation of this section, shall order, in writing, the owner, operator, or lessee to disconnect and cease operation of the system within 72 hours of receipt of the order. 
(c)  Any automatic telephone dialing system installed prior to the effective date of this ordinance shall be removed within 30 days of the effective date of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 26, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-189. - Alarm silencer required. 
    No local alarm system and no alarm system shall be installed on any premises in the city which does not have an operable automatic resetting device to silence the alarm audible sounder within 30 minutes after activation and to prevent the alarm sounding again as a result of the same event that caused the original activation. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 27, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-190. - Manual fire alarm signaling devices. 
    When manual fire alarm signaling devices are installed and are not directly connected to the fire department or monitored by a 24-hour security service, a permanent sign shall be installed at each actuating device. These signs shall read as follows: 
IN CASE OF FIRE 
1.  Pull this alarm. 
2.  Telephone the fire department 9-1-1. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 28, 2-6-96) 
Sec. 46-191. - Recovery of fire protection costs. 
(a)  Pursuant to IC 8-1-2-103(d), the costs for the production, storage, transmission, sale, delivery, or furnishing of water for public fire protection purposes ("fire protection costs") shall be included in the basic rates and charges of all customers of Indiana-American Water Company, Inc. ("IAWC") located within the city in the manner and to the extent permitted by statute. 
(b)  Effective upon the date of this change in the manner of recovering fire protection costs, IAWC shall cease directly billing the city for fire protection costs other than charges for the construction cost for new hydrants installed on and after the date of the change, as provided in IC 8-1-2-103(d). 
(c)  Notwithstanding this change in the recovery of fire protection costs, the construction cost of any fire hydrants installed at the request of the city shall continue to be paid for by or on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-13, § 1, 3-1-05) 
Secs. 46-192-46-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 46-201. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of division 2 shall be fined the sum of $100.00 for the first violation and $200.00 for each subsequent violation. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any alarm system installed, operated or maintained in violation of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated in the manner as nuisances are now or may hereafter be abated under existing law. 
(c)  If any person, firm or corporation shall violate any other provision of this article or shall do any act prohibited herein, or shall fail to perform any duty lawfully required, within the time prescribed by the fire chief or designee, or shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey any lawful order given by the fire chief in connection with the provisions of this article shall be fined an amount not less than $25.00, nor more than $500.00. Each day such unlawful or prohibited activity continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  The remedies provided for herein shall be cumulative and not exclusive and shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 96-4, § 29, 2-6-96; Ord. No. 08-18, § 17, 5-8-08) 
Chapter 50 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]
