ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Administration of police department, IC 36-8-3-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 50-26-50-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MERIT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Police merit systems, IC 36-8-3.5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 50-36. - Established. 
    A police department merit system is created pursuant to IC 36-1-4-14. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 1, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 50-37. - Merit commission. 
(a)  A merit commission consisting of five commissioners shall be established. The commissioners shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Two persons who must be of different political parties shall be appointed by the mayor; 
(2)  One person shall be appointed by the common council; and 
(3)  Two persons who must be of different political parties shall be elected by the active members of the police department. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, political affiliation shall be determined through the voter registration records of the three most recent primary elections. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 3, 4-3-90) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Members of commission, IC 36-8-3.5-1. 
Sec. 50-38. - Commissioner's qualifications and oath. 
    Each merit commissioner shall have been a legal resident of the city for three consecutive years immediately preceding his term and must be a person of good moral character. A commissioner must be at least 21 years of age and not currently a member of the police department. No commissioners may be past members of the police department, except for retired members with a minimum of 20 years of service. A person may not serve on the commission if he receives any remuneration or salary from the city. Each commissioner shall take an oath of office to conscientiously discharge his duties. A signed copy of the oath shall be filed with the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 4, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 50-39. - Commissioner's terms, vacancies and removal. 
(a)  Term. The commissioners shall serve for four-year staggered terms. 
(b)  Vacancy. A vacancy on the commission shall be filled within 30 days by the appointing or electing authority. The selection is for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(c)  Removal. A commissioner serves at the pleasure of the appointing or electing authority and may be removed at any time. In the case of a commissioner elected by the police department, the board of public works and safety shall call a meeting of the active members of the department under the procedures specified in subsection (d) if a recall petition signed by a majority of the active members is submitted to the board. 
(d)  Notice; vote. All the active members of the police department shall be given at least three weeks notice. At the meeting the vote shall be taken by secret ballot. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, §§ 2, 5, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 50-40. - Election of commissioners and election meetings. 
    An election by the active members of the police department shall be held at a meeting called specifically for that purpose by the board of public works and safety. The board shall give at least three weeks notice of the meeting to all active members of the department by posting the notice in prominent locations in stations of the department. The notice shall also be read during shift roll call. The notice must designate the time, place and purpose of the meeting. Only active members of the department may attend the meeting and at the meeting one of them shall be selected as chairman. All voting must be by secret, written ballot. The other procedures for holding the meeting shall be as determined by the board of public works and safety and shall be posted in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 6, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-8. 
Sec. 50-41. - Commission rules and meetings. 
    Within 30 days after the merit commission is selected the commission shall adopt internal rules to govern itself including the time and place of regular monthly meetings and special meetings that are necessary to transact the business of the commission. A majority of the commissioners constitutes a quorum and a majority vote of all the commissioners is necessary to transact the business of the commission. Each year the commissioners shall select from among their number a president, vice-president and secretary. The commission shall keep a permanent record of its proceedings. The commission shall submit a proposed annual budget to the city as other budgets of the city are submitted. The city shall include in its budget an amount sufficient for the necessary expenses of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 7, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-9. 
Sec. 50-42. - Adoption of merit system rules. 
    The merit commission shall adopt rules governing: 
(1)  The selection and appointment of persons to be employed as members of the police department subject to applicable pension statutes; 
(2)  Promotions and demotions of members of the department; and 
(3)  Disciplinary action or dismissal of members of the department. 
Prior to the adoption of any of these rules the commission must hold a public hearing for consideration of the adoption of the proposed rules. Notice should be given, at least ten days prior to the public hearing, in accordance with IC 5-3-1 et seq. The notice should state the time, place and brief subject matter of the public hearing. At least ten days prior to the hearing one copy of the proposed rules shall be placed on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer for inspection by residents of the city and three copies of the proposed rules shall be forwarded to the chief of the police department and retained on file in his office for inspection at all times by the members of the police department. Any interested person residing in the city and any member of the police department must be afforded an opportunity to present both oral and written evidence on any matter relating to the adoption of the proposed rules at the public hearing. The commission shall give due consideration to this evidence in making its final decision concerning the adoption of the proposed rules. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 8, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-10. 
Sec. 50-43. - Appointment and removal of members of the police department. 
    The merit commission shall have the power to appoint and remove members of the police department, except for a member of an upper-level policy-making position, which is considered to be the chief, assistant chief, and captains. The mayor shall appoint and remove a member in an upper-level policy-making position. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 9, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-11. 
Sec. 50-44. - Removal of member in upper-level policy-making position. 
    The removal of a member from an upper-level policy-making position is removal from rank only and not from the police department. When the member is removed, he shall be appointed by the merit commission to the rank in the department that he held at the time of his upper-level appointment or to any rank to which he had been promoted during his tenure in the upper-level position. If such a rank is not open in either case, the member is entitled to the pay of that rank and shall be promoted to that rank as soon as an opening is available. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 10, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-11. 
Sec. 50-45. - Qualifications and requirements for membership in department. 
(a)  To be appointed to the police department an applicant must be a citizen of the United States, a high school graduate or equivalent, and at least 21 years of age, but under 36 years of age. 
(b)  No person may be appointed, reappointed, or reinstated in the police department if he has a felony conviction on his record. Applications for appointment or reappointment shall be filed with the merit commission and the applicant must provide satisfactory proof of the date and place of his birth. Passage of preliminary examinations shall be required of all applicants to determine general aptitude for service as a member of the department. These examinations shall be conducted according to the procedures adopted by the commission. The results of the preliminary examination shall be filed with the commission; and if an applicant lacks the proper qualifications, the commission shall reject the applicant. Upon passage of the preliminary examination, the commission shall then rate the applicant according to physical condition, mental alertness, character, habits, and reputation pursuant to methods adopted by the commission. The commission, which determines the passing score for the preliminary examination, shall post an eligibility list by the order of scores of the applicants. This list shall be certified to the board of public works and safety. 
(c)  All eligible applicants may remain on the list for one year from the date of certification. After one year, a person must reapply as an applicant. At any time in the police department when a vacancy occurs, the commission, upon written request by the chief of the police department, shall appoint the applicant having the highest score on the eligibility list to fill the vacancy. That applicant shall be enrolled as a member of the department provided he is still of good character and passes the required physical examination. All appointments to the police department are probationary for a period not to exceed one year. If the commission finds upon the recommendation of the department during the probationary period that the probationary member is unsatisfactory, he shall be notified in writing by the commission that he is being reprimanded, suspended or will not receive a permanent appointment. Upon notification that a member will not receive a permanent appointment his employment immediately ceases. Otherwise, at the expiration of the probationary period the member is considered regularly employed. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 11, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-12. 
Sec. 50-46. - Promotions. 
(a)  The rules adopted by the commission governing promotions must provide that the following factors be considered in rating a member of the department for a promotion: 
(1)  The score received by the member on a written competitive examination; 
(2)  The score received by the member on an oral competitive interview; 
(3)  The performance record of the member in the department, including the supervisor's evaluation for the one year immediately preceding; and 
(4)  The member's length of service. 
(b)  The commission shall determine the weight to be given to each one of the above-named factors. However, the member's length of service or the oral interview may not comprise more than 20 percent each of the rating. Competitive examinations may only be given to members who are qualified in rank and length of service. Promotions to a rank may only be from the next-lower rank, and any member being promoted must have served at the lower rank for a continuous period determined by the commission. Promotions shall be based upon an eligibility list, such eligibility being based upon the cumulative score of all rating factors. 
(c)  The chief of police shall notify the commission immediately of a vacancy for the rank of corporal, sergeant or lieutenant which the chief of police intends to fill. Upon notification of the vacancy, the commission shall give notice to the members of the Portage Police Department of the specific vacancy and the institution of the testing process. In order to be eligible for the corporal eligibility list, the sergeant eligibility list or the lieutenant eligibility list, the member must meet all requirements for the same at the time the commission gives notice of the vacancy. The eligibility list, once completed, shall be valid for a one-year period. After the one-year period, the eligibility list shall be retired. The retired list shall be kept for five years, after which it shall be destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 12, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 04-13, § 1, 3-2-04) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-13. 
Sec. 50-47. - Competitive examination requirements. 
    Before a written competitive examination may be held to fill a current or expected vacancy in the ranks, the members eligible to take the examination must be notified of the written materials from which the questions will be taken. The commission may employ instructors, purchase materials, and make other expenditures to provide information for applicants for promotion examinations. The identity of a member taking the written examinations shall be withheld from the person or persons grading the examination and all written examinations are confidential. The commission shall notify each member in writing of the score that the member received on the examination. The score received by a member on the written examination becomes a part of the permanent file of the member; and the member is entitled to access to his file for review at any time. The examination papers shall be kept under the commission's supervision. A member who is aggrieved with the score received on the written examination, may appeal to the commission for review of the score within ten days after receiving notice of the score. He may review the questions incorrectly answered by him and challenge the answer considered correct by the examiner. The commission shall either affirm the score or correct the score according to the findings of the review. The examination papers shall be retired after the one-year period during which the eligibility list is valid. The retired papers shall be kept for five years and then destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 13, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 98-18, § 2, 4-7-98) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-14. 
Sec. 50-48. - Performance ratings. 
    The merit commission shall adopt rules for determining a performance rating. The rules shall require that a performance rating be made at least once every six months for each member of the police department, including probationary members. The rating shall be made as defined in the commission's rules. Probationary members shall be rated in the same manner as other members of the department. The rating shall be submitted to the chief of the department and kept on file in his office under his supervision. The chief shall notify each member in writing of the rating that the member received. A member who is aggrieved with the performance rating given to him may appeal to the commission for a review of the rating. The appeal must be filed within ten days after notice of the rating has been sent to him. The commission shall either affirm or correct the rating. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 14, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-15. 
Sec. 50-49. - Vacancies in rank and promotions. 
(a)  When a vacancy in rank occurs, the merit commission shall certify to the chief of police the eligibility list in its entirety for that particular rank. Within 30 days, the commission, upon the recommendation of the chief, shall promote the member with the highest score at the top of the list to fill the vacant position. 
(b)  All promotions shall be probationary for a period not to exceed one year. At the end of the period a probationary member's performance shall be reviewed by the chief and the chief shall recommend to the commission that the promotion be made permanent or that the promotion be revoked. The chief shall submit to the commission a rating chart prepared by the commission for use in making the above stated report. The probationary member is entitled to appear before the commission and be heard on any matter detrimental to him in the chief's report. He is also entitled to be represented by counsel or another representative of his choice. 
(c)  If the promotion is finally revoked the member may not be returned to a rank lower than that he held before the probationary promotion. Actions by the commission other than making the promotion permanent may be appealed within 30 days to the circuit or superior court of the county, with the city being named as the sole defendant. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 15, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-16. 
Sec. 50-50. - Disciplinary actions and procedures. 
(a)  The merit commission may take the following disciplinary actions against a regular member of the police department: 
(1)  Written reprimand. 
(2)  Suspension with or without pay. 
(3)  Demotion. 
(4)  Dismissal. 
(b)  A member may be disciplined by the commission if: 
(1)  He is convicted of a crime; or 
(2)  The commission finds him guilty of a breach of discipline including: 
a.  Neglect of duty; 
b.  Violation of commission rules; 
c.  Neglect or disobedience of orders; 
d.  Continuing incapacity; 
e.  Absence without leave; 
f.  Immoral conduct; 
g.  Conduct injurious to the public peace or welfare; 
h.  Conduct unbecoming a member; or 
i.  Furnishing information to an applicant for appointment or promotion that gives that person an advantage over another applicant. 
If the chief, after an investigation, prefers charges against a member for any of the violations listed above, a hearing shall be conducted upon the request of the member. The commission shall hold the hearing as provided in the commission's rules. The hearing conducted under this subsection shall be held within 30 days after it is requested by the member. 
(c)  Written notice of the hearing shall be served upon the accused member in person or by a copy left at his last and usual place of residence. The notice must state: 
(1)  The time and place of hearing; 
(2)  The charges against the member; 
(3)  The specific conduct that comprises the charges; 
(4)  That the member is entitled to be represented by counsel or another representative; 
(5)  That the member is entitled to call and cross examine witnesses; 
(6)  That the member is entitled to require the production of evidence; and 
(7)  That the member is entitled to have subpoenas issued, served and executed. 
The commission shall have the power to compel the attendance of witnesses by issuing subpoenas, examine witnesses under oath and order the production of books, papers, and other evidence by issuing subpoenas. If a witness fails to appear or fails to produce those written documents requested in writing by the commission, the commission may file an affidavit with the circuit court of the county setting forth the facts relative to the refusal. 
(d)  Upon filing the affidavit, a summons shall be issued from the circuit court and served by the sheriff of the county requiring the appearance of the witness or the production of information or evidence to the commission. Disobedience of this summons constitutes contempt of the circuit court from which the summons has been issued unless the action is found to be in good faith and with reasonable cause. Expenses related to the filing of an affidavit and the issuance and service of a summons shall be charged to the witness against whom the summons has been issued unless the circuit court finds that the action of the witness was taken in good faith and with reasonable cause. In that case and in any case in which an affidavit has been filed without the issuance of a summons, the expenses shall be charged to the commission. 
(e)  The decision to discipline a member must be based upon the preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing. Any member aggrieved by a decision of the commission may appeal to the commission within ten days of the decision. The commission shall on appeal review the record and either affirm, modify, or reverse the decision on the basis of the record and such oral or written testimony that the commission determines including additional or newly discovered evidence. The commission shall keep a record of the proceedings in cases of suspension, demotion, or dismissal. The commission shall give a free copy of the transcript to the member upon request if an appeal is filed. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 16, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-17. 
Sec. 50-51. - Appeal to circuit or superior court. 
    Any member who is aggrieved by a decision of the merit commission to suspend him for a period greater than ten calendar days, demote him or dismiss him may appeal to the circuit or superior court of the county. The appeal shall be made according to the Indiana Rules of Trial Procedure with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The verified appeal must be filed within 30 days after the date of the commission's decision. 
(2)  The city shall be named as the sole defendant. 
(3)  The city is assumed to have denied the allegations without filing a responsive pleading. 
(4)  The plaintiff must file a bond at the time of filing the complaint conditioned on the plaintiff prosecuting the appeal to a final determination and paying the court costs incurred in the appeal. 
(5)  Within 30 days after the service of summons the commission shall file in court a complete transcript of all papers, entries and other parts of the record relating to the case. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 17, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-18. 
Sec. 50-52. - Suspension or reprimand by chief of department. 
(a)  In addition to the disciplinary powers of the merit commission, the chief may, without a hearing, reprimand or suspend without pay a member including a police radio or signal alarm operator for a maximum of five working days. For the purposes of this subsection, eight hours of paid time constitutes one working day. 
(b)  If the chief reprimands a member in writing or suspends a member, he shall, within 48 hours, notify the commission in writing of the action and the reasons for the action. 
(c)  A member who was reprimanded in writing or suspended under this section may within 48 hours after receiving notice of the reprimand or suspension request in writing that the commission review the reprimand or suspension and either uphold or reverse the chief's decision. At its discretion the commission may hold a hearing during this review. 
(d)  If the decision is reversed the individual who was suspended is entitled to any wages withheld as a result of the suspension. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 18, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-19. 
Sec. 50-53. - Mandatory retirement. 
    A member of the police department shall retire from the department when he reaches his 65th birthday. However, a member of the department who is 65 years of age or older at the time the ordinance establishing the merit system takes effect may serve until the end of the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 19, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Retirement, IC 36-8-3.5-20. 
Sec. 50-54. - Reduction or enlargement of staff. 
    If it is necessary for the board of public works and safety to reduce the number of members of the police department, the reduction shall be made by granting a temporary leave of absence, without pay or financial obligation to the city, to the appropriate number of members. The last member appointed shall be put on leave first with the other members also put on leave in reverse hiring order until the desired level is achieved. If the department is increased in number again, those individuals given a temporary leave of absence due to the reduction of staff shall be reinstated before any applicant from the eligibility list is considered. The reinstatements begin with the last member granted a leave. Any member on a leave of absence shall keep the commission advised of his current address. A member shall be informed of his reinstatement by written notice. Within ten calendar days after a member receives notice of reinstatement he shall advise the commission that he accepts reinstatement and will be able to commence employment on the date specified in the notice. All reinstatement rights granted to a member terminate upon his failure to accept reinstatement within that period. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 20, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-21. 
Sec. 50-55. - Dissemination of rules. 
    All rules of the merit commission shall be furnished to each member of the police department. Any amendments shall take effect 30 days after their adoption if copies have been furnished to all members of the department within that period. Otherwise, they do not take effect until copies are furnished to all members of the department. 
(Ord. No. 90-20, § 21, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 36-8-3.5-22. 
Secs. 50-56-50-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FUNDS FOR CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION 

Sec. 50-66. - Established. 
    There is hereby established funds to be utilized by the police department of the city for criminal investigations and undercover activities. 
(Code 1985, § 11-3-1) 
Sec. 50-67. - Appropriation. 
    Funds will be appropriated annually within the budget of the city by the common council for police department criminal investigations and undercover activities. The amount of such appropriation within the annual budget shall be determined by the common council given the yearly needs for such funds. 
(Code 1985, § 11-3-2) 
Sec. 50-68. - Disbursement. 
    Money budgeted for police department criminal investigations and undercover activities shall be disbursed only on approved claims allowed and signed by the chief of the police department and thereafter submitted to the clerk-treasurer of the city and only for payment of expenses directly associated with criminal investigations and undercover activities. 
(Code 1985, § 11-3-3) 
Sec. 50-69. - Documentation procedure. 
    The police department shall utilize a documentation procedure concerning funds utilized for criminal investigations and undercover activities similar to either: 
(1)  Guidelines for Confidential Expenditures Appendix J, Indiana Criminal Justice Planning Agency Financial Guide; or 
(2)  Guidelines for Withdrawal of Money and Reporting Procedures of Enforcement Aid Fund Monies, Indiana State Police Department. 
(Code 1985, § 11-3-4)

Sec. 50-84. - Video recordings.

The person requesting a copy of such recording shall be responsible for providing a blank tape or DVD for copying and reproduction purposes. 
(b)  All fees received by the police department for such reproduction of videotapes shall be deposited in a separate account to be known as the accident report account and may be expended at the discretion of chief administrative officer of the department for any department purpose reasonably related to the keeping of incident or accident reports and records or the prevention of street and highway accidents, traffic related arrest and any other type of traffic enforcement pursuant to IC 9-26-2.

(Ord. No. 09-27, § 1, 6-2-09; Ord. No. 12-27, § 5, 11-7-12)

(Ord. No. 09-65, § 1, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 12-27, § 5, 11-7-12) 
Sec. 50-91. - Use of fees.

(Ord. No. 12-27, § 6, 11-7-12)

DIVISION 5. - POLICE PENSION FUND 

Sec. 50-96. - Death benefits. 
    The 1925 fund shall be used to pay funeral benefits to the heirs or estate of an active or retired member of the police department who has died from and cause, in the following amount: 
(a)  Twelve thousand dollars for a member who dies after July 1, 2008. 
    The 1953 fund shall be used to pay to the beneficiary or estate of a member of the fund, active or retired, who: 
(a)  Dies from and [any] cause having served for one year or more as an active member of the police department; or 
(b)  Dies from and [any] while in the actual discharge of his or her duties as a police officer after having served less than one years as an active member of the police department twelve thousand dollars for a member who dies after July 1, 2008. 
    Any member of the fund may name a beneficiary to receive the amount provided for upon his or her death by designating in writing in such form as in prescribed by the local board and delivered to the board. The beneficiary may be changed from time to time by the member by canceling the designation and delivering a new designation to the local board. If the member makes no designation of beneficiary, the sum provided for shall be paid to the member's estate. 
(Ord. No. 94-35, § 1, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 94-35, § 1, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 98-22, § 2, 6-2-98; Ord. No. 08-46, § 2, 9-10-08) 
(Code 1985, § 11-2-1) 
State Law reference- Death benefits, IC 36-8-8-16. 
Sec. 50-97. - Funeral benefits. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund are hereby authorized and directed to pay from the police pension fund the sum of $1,500.00 for the payment of funeral benefits to the heirs or estate of any active or retired member of the police department who has suffered death from any cause. 
(Code 1985, § 11-2-2) 
Sec. 50-98. - Benefits under prior funds. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by law, effective January 1, 1990, the pension benefits for the surviving spouse, children, and parents of a deceased policeman who is a member of the 1925 Policeman's Pension Fund shall be in the same amounts, terms and conditions as those benefits payable to those persons under the 1977 Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension and Disability Fund, as those benefits are set forth in IC 36-8-8-14.1. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by law, effective January 1, 1990, the pension benefits for the surviving spouse, children, and parents of a deceased policeman who is a member of the 1937 Policeman's Pension Fund shall be in the same amounts, terms and conditions as those benefits payable to those persons under the 1977 Police Officers' and Firefighters' Pension and Disability Fund, as those benefits are set forth in IC 36-8-8-14.1. 
(Ord. No. 89-3, § 1, 1-3-89; Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 3-7-89)
