ARTICLE III. - POLICE RESERVES 

Sec. 50-121. - Establishment. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-8-3-20, up to 25 police reserves may be appointed to assist the city police department in the performance of law enforcement duties within the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 1, 5-8-91) 
Sec. 50-122. - Appointment. 
    Police reserves shall be appointed by the same authority that appoints regular members of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 2, 5-8-91) 
Sec. 50-123. - Rules and regulations. 
    The police chief, with the approval of the board of public works and safety, may adopt rules governing police reserves, including rules to limit the authority of the police reserves. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 3, 5-8-91) 
Sec. 50-124. - Qualifications and duties. 
    Police reserves may not be members of the city police department and may not be appointed until they have completed the training and probationary period specified by the rules adopted pursuant to section 50-123. Police reserves shall have all the same police powers as regular members of the city police department, except as limited by the rules adopted pursuant to section 50-123. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 4, 5-8-91) 
Sec. 50-125. - Compensation. 
    Police reserves appointed pursuant to this article shall receive no compensation for their duties and shall not be eligible to participate in any pension program provided for regular members of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 5, 5-8-91) 
Sec. 50-126. - Liability insurance. 
    Liability insurance shall be provided by the city to the police reserves under the city's self-insurance fund for claims arising from acts performed by police reserves within the scope of their duties as defined by the rules adopted in accordance with this article. In addition, the city shall provide worker's compensation insurance to police reserves for injuries sustained while performing their duties pursuant to the rules of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 6, 5-8-91) 
State Law reference- Worker's compensation, IC 22-3-1-1 et seq.; occupational diseases, IC 22-3-7-2 et seq. 
Sec. 50-127. - Uniforms. 
    While performing their duties, police reserves shall wear a uniform as prescribed by the rules of the city police department identifying them as city police reserves. 
(Ord. No. 91-20, § 7, 5-8-91) 
ARTICLE IV. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 50-128. - [Definitions.] 
    The following definitions shall be applicable for the purposes of this article: 
    Alarm conditions means alarms activated by unlawful violation of a user's property or other violations against which the systems were designed to protect, acts of God, other violent conditions, or by outside agencies of external forces not under the control of the owner, lessee or its employees or agents. 
    Alarm equipment supplier means any person, firm or corporation that sells, leases or installs automatic protection devices or signaling devices which transmit alarms upon receipt of a stimulus from a detection apparatus, or manually operated system. 
    Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices such as a solid-state unit, arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which the police department is expected to respond. 
    Alarm user means any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the City of Portage, except for alarm systems on motor vehicles. Also included are those systems which employ an audible signal emitting sounds or a flashing light or beacon designed to alert or signal persons outside the premises. 
    Central station means a facility whose prime purpose is to monitor incoming alarm signals 24 hours a day and relay the signal information to the appropriate authorities. 
    City means the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    Direct line means a telephone line leading directly into the communications center of the police department that is used only to report signals on a person-to-person basis. 
    False alarms means the activation of an alarm system caused by improper operation, negligence of the owner or lessee or its employee or agent, or equipment malfunction; provided, however, that the term "false alarm" shall not include alarm activation caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by an alarm user or alarm equipment supplier. 
    Local alarms means a signaling system which, when activated, causes an audible and/or visual signaling device to be activated in or on the premises within which the system is installed. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, association or society; but such term does not include the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    Police chief means the chief of the Portage Police Department or his authorized representative. 
    Police department means the City of Portage Police Department. 
    Public trunk line means a telephone line leading into the communications center of the police department for the purpose of handling emergency and administrative calls on a person-to-person basis. 
    Signaling device means an electrically operated instrument which automatically sends visual and/or audible signals to be registered by indicators at a monitor panel at the receiving terminal or central station. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Sec. 50-129. - Permitted devices. 
    No person shall use or cause or permit to be used, an alarm system utilizing signaling devices that automatically select a public trunk line of the police department and then reproduce any prerecorded message to report any robbery, burglary, fire or other emergency. 
    With the exception of local alarms, only signaling devices shall be permitted to be installed in the city for the purpose of reporting any robbery, burglary, fire or other emergency to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Sec. 50-130. - Automatic telephone dialing systems prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, install, maintain, lease, operate or assist in the operation of an automatic telephone dialing alarm system over any telephone lines exclusively used by the public directly to request emergency service from the police department of the city. 
(b)  The police chief or the fire chief or their designees, upon becoming aware of an automatic telephone dialing system installed or operated in violation of this section, shall order, in writing, the owner, operator or lessee to disconnect and cease operation of the system within 72 hours of receipt of the order. 
(c)  Any automatic telephone dialing system installed prior to the effective date of this article shall be removed within 30 days of the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Sec. 50-131. - Inspection. 
    The police chief shall have the right to inspect, at reasonable times, any alarm system on the premises where it is intended to be used to determine whether it is being used in conformity with the provisions of this article. Every alarm user shall be required to have its alarm system inspected at least once a year by an alarm equipment supplier licensed by the city and post a certificate of such inspection on the premises in plain view where the alarm system is maintained. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Sec. 50-132. - Local alarms. 
    Local alarms with an externally audible alert shall not make a sound similar to that of civil defense warning systems, and such alarms must have an automatic cutoff after 30 minutes of sounding. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Sec. 50-133. - Disconnection. 
(a)  When alarm conditions are discovered by the police department that evidence a failure to comply with the requirements of this article, the police chief is authorized to demand that the owner or lessee of the alarm system, or its representative, disconnect the alarm system until it is made to comply with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Any person affected by the police chief's order to disconnect an alarm system shall have the right to request the board of public works and safety to review the decision or action taken by the police chief by requesting review in writing within ten days after any adverse action or decision has been made by the police chief. The board of public works and safety may either affirm, modify or reverse any decision made by the police chief. 
(c)  In the event the city finds it necessary to order an alarm system disconnected, the city shall incur no liability by such action to the extent allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Sec. 50-134. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any alarm user having more than two false alarms per month shall pay a fine in the sum of $75.00 for each additional false alarm beyond the two permitted per month. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation, who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with, or who resists enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, shall upon conviction be fined not less than $75.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 01-18, § 1, 3-6-01; Ord. No. 02-07, § 1, 2-5-02; Ord. No. 12-27, § 7, 11-7-12) 
Chapter 54 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes, IC 35-41-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb the peace and good order of the city or any of its inhabitants by committing any riotous or disorderly acts, by quarreling or fighting or by challenging or attempting to provoke others to quarrel or fight, or to use any abusive or indecent language, menaces or threats of violence within the city. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-8(D), (E); Ord. No. 16-22, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 54-2. - Glue sniffing. 
    No person shall knowingly sell or offer for sale, deliver, or give away to any person under 18 years of age, unless upon the written order of parent or guardian, where the seller, offerer, or deliverer knows or has reason to believe that the substance will be used for the purpose of inducing symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, paralysis, irrational behavior, or in any manner change, distort, or disturb the audio, visual, or mental processes, any substances containing any of the following volatile solvents: toluol, hexane, trichloroethylene, acetone, toluene, ethyl acetate, methyl ethyl ketone, trichlorosthane, isopropanol, methyl isobutyl ketone, methyl cellosolve acetate, cyclohexanone, or any other substance which will induce symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, paralysis, irrational behavior, or in any manner change, distort, or disturb the audio, visual, or mental processes. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-1) 
State Law reference- Glue sniffing, IC 35-46-6-1 et seq. 
Sec. 54-3. - Curfews. 
(a)  It is a curfew violation for a child 15, 16, or 17 years of age to be in a public place: 
(1)  Between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. on Saturday or Sunday; 
(2)  After 10:30 p.m. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday; or 
(3)  Before 5:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, or Friday. 
(b)  It is a curfew violation for a child under 15 years of age to be in a public place after 10:30 p.m. or before 5:00 a.m. on any day. 
(c)  This section does not apply to a child who is: 
(1)  Accompanied by his parent, guardian, or custodian; 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult specified by his parent, guardian, or custodian; or 
(3)  Participating in, going to, or returning from: 
a.  Lawful employment; 
b.  A school sanctioned activity; or 
c.  A religious event. 
d.  A core First Amendment activity involving free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, or the right of assembly. 
(d)  A law enforcement officer may not detain a child or take a child into custody based on a violation of this section unless the law enforcement officer, after making a reasonable determination and considering the facts and surrounding circumstances, reasonably believes that: 
(1)  The child has violated this section; and 
(2)  There is no legal defense to the violation. 
(e)  Any minor who is found in violation of this section shall be therewith removed to his home by the police department of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-2; Ord. No. 00-69, § 1, 12-5-00; Ord. No. 16-19. § 1, 12-6-16) 
State Law reference- Curfews, local option, IC 31-6-4-2. 
Sec. 54-4. - Removal of vegetation. 
(a)  All owners of real property within the city are required to cut and/or remove any and all grass, weeds, and other rank vegetation growing thereon when growth exceeds nine inches from the ground. 
(1)  Rank vegetation shall mean any plant exceeding six inches in height. Trees, shrubberies, flowers, ornamental grasses, and agricultural crops exceeding nine inches are not to be considered rank vegetation. 
(b)  The city's code enforcement department and clerk-treasurer's office shall be responsible for the administration of this division. 
(c)  A ten-day written notice to cut and/or remove all grass, weeds, and other rank vegetation exceeding six inches from the ground shall be issued by the code enforcement department or a designated representative. Such notice shall be served personally by the code enforcement department or any police officer of the city upon such property owner, if a resident; or, by certified mail addressed to the property owner's last known address, and posting the notice in a prominent place on the property. Notice must be given to the owner of record of real property with a single owner, or at least one of the owners of real property with multiple owners, at the last address of the owner as indicated in the records of the county auditor on the date of the notice. 
(d)  If an initial notice of a violation of this section was provided as required by subsection (c) above, a continuous abatement notice may be posted at the property at the time of abatement which will serve as notice to the property owner that each subsequent violation during the same year for which the initial notice of the violation was provided may be abated by the city, or its contractors. 
(e)  If a property owner fails to remove such grass, weeds, and other rank vegetation described in this section within the time prescribed in subsection (c), the code enforcement department may provide for the removal of such weeds and rank vegetation and the clerk-treasurer shall make a certified bill of the cost(s) incurred by the city in such removal including administrative and removal costs. Such bill shall be served personally by the code enforcement department or any police officer of the city upon such property owner, if a resident; or, by certified mail addressed to the property owner's last known address, and posting the bill in a prominent place on the property. Such property owner shall have ten days from the date of receipt of the bill within which to pay such amount to the clerk-treasurer. 
(f)  If a property owner fails to pay or appeal such sum specified in subsection (e) within the time prescribed, a certified copy of the bill of costs shall be filed in the office of the Porter County auditor and the auditor's office shall place the amount so claimed on the tax duplicate for the property affected by such work and the total amount including any accrued interest shall be collected as delinquent taxes are collected, and shall be disbursed to the general fund of the city. 
(g)  A property owner may appeal a notice of violation or a bill issued under this section by filing a written notice of appeal with the clerk-treasurer's office within ten days of the receipt of the notice of violation or bill. The appeal shall be heard by the board of public works and safety within 30 days after the notice of appeal is received. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-3; Ord. No. 08-15, § 1, 4-1-08; Ord. No. 15-13, § 1, 10-6-15) 
State Law reference- Violations on private property, IC 36-1-6-2; removal of weeds and rank vegetation, IC 36-7-10.1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 54-5. - Activities in unimproved land areas. 
    The unsupervised use of unimproved land areas within the city is declared a nuisance and the use of such unimproved land areas by any person not authorized to do so by the owner thereof, upon conviction, is deemed to be in violation of this section. The police department is authorized to take such measures as may be necessary from time to time to enforce this section. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-4) 
State Law reference- Criminal trespass, IC 35-43-2-2. 
Sec. 54-6. - Abandonment of refrigerators. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended, or discarded icebox or refrigerator or any other container of any kind which cannot be opened by a device on the inside. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, unattended or discarded, any icebox or refrigerator or other container of any kind which has an airtight snaplock or other such device thereon, without first removing the snaplock or device or doors from such icebox, refrigerator, or container. 
(Code 1985, § 13-4-1) 
Sec. 54-7. - Purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States. 
    Supplies manufactured in the United States shall be specified for all city purchases and shall be purchased unless the city determines that: 
(1)  The supplies are not manufactured in the United States in reasonably available quantities; 
(2)  The prices of the supplies manufactured in the United States exceed by an unreasonable amount the price of available and comparable supplies manufactured elsewhere; 
(3)  The quality of the supplies manufactured in the United States is substantially less than the quality of comparably priced available supplies manufactured elsewhere; or 
(4)  The purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States is not in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 1, 7-7-98) 
Sec. 54-8. - Cargo/storage containers. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to establish limitations and regulations for the use of cargo/storage containers within the city. 
(b)  Cargo/storage containers are permitted subject to the following limitations and regulations: 
(1)  Cargo/storage containers may be used for construction purposes in all areas of the city. 
(2)  Cargo/storage containers with a size of less than 10'×8'×8' may be used for nonpermanent storage in residentially zoned areas for no longer than 72 consecutive hours. Each additional 24-hour period or portion thereof that a residential cargo/storage container is used is a residentially zoned area shall constitute a violation of this division. 
(3)  Cargo/storage containers may be used for storage in industrially zoned areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-06, § 1, 2-1-05) 
Sec. 54-9. - Regulation of vehicle sales. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, "vehicle" means automobile, sport utility vehicle, van, minivan and truck having a gross vehicle weight less than or equal to 17,500 pounds or having a class IV vehicle designation. 
(b)  An individual may sell a vehicle in a residentially zoned area of the city, subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The vehicle must be the property of the person attempting to sell it. 
(2)  Only one vehicle may be offered for sale at a time, and a vehicle may be offered for sale for no longer than 30 consecutive days. 
(3)  No more than three vehicles may be offered for sale or sold at a single location per calendar year. 
(c)  An individual who is not a licensed vehicle dealer is prohibited from selling or offering to sell vehicles: 
(1)  On Willowcreek Road from Portage Avenue to Veterans Boulevard; 
(2)  On Central Avenue from County Line Road to Airport Road; 
(3)  On U.S. Highway 6 from County Line Road to the city's eastern boundary; 
(4)  On U.S. Highway 20 (Melton Road) from County Line Road to the city's eastern boundary; and 
(5)  On any parcel of property which is zoned commercial. 
(d)  This section shall not prohibit or restrict vehicle sales by licensed vehicle dealers operating within the city. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the code enforcement department and the Portage Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 06-02, § 1, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 54-10. - Use of consumer fireworks. 
(a)  Consumer fireworks may not be used, ignited or discharged within the corporate limits of the city, except as set forth below: 
(1)  Between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and two hours after sunset on June 29, June 30, July 1, July 2, July 3, July 5, July 6, July 7, July 8 and July 9; 
(2)  Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on July 4; and 
(3)  Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31 and 1:00 a.m. on January 1. 
(b)  As used in this section, consumer fireworks shall have the meaning set forth in IC 22-11-14-1. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty, the city's police officers and code enforcement officers may confiscate consumer fireworks from any person using, igniting or discharging them in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-28, § 1, 6-5-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-28, § 1, adopted June 5, 2007, added § 58-9 to the Code. At the editor's discretion, said provisions have been redesignated as § 54-10 to better reflect their content and to maintain the organization of the Code. 
Sec. 54-11. - Excessive police calls. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide administrative and civil remedies against businesses that permit, allow, or fail to prevent excessive calls for police services related to anything other than ambulance calls, welfare checks, routine traffic stops and motor vehicle accidents. These excessive calls compromise public health, safety and welfare to the City of Portage. 
(b)  Definitions. As used herein, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
(1)  Business. Any individual, sole proprietor, corporation, limited liability company and any other type of business entity which engages in business or commercial activities, including the sale of goods, within the City of Portage. 
(2)  Calendar month. The period which begins on the first day of one of the months as named in the calendar and which ends on the last day of that same month as named in the calendar. 
(3)  Calls for service. Calls for service is any call made for any purpose by the business or the businesses customer's whether the call is to 911, or any other method of contact excluding ambulance calls, welfare checks, routine traffic stops, and motor vehicle accidents. 
(4)  Manager. The individual or entity that is responsible for management of a business as defined herein. 
(5)  Owner. The individual or entity which owns a business as defined herein. 
(6)  Police service cost. The costs as established in subsection (c) below. 
(c)  Cost recovery required for excessive calls. 
(1)  Every owner responsible for the management and regulation of a business is required to pay police service costs of $250.00 for: 
a.  Each call in excess of ten that are not excluded herein within a calendar month but less than 20; 
b.  Any calls in excess of 20 that are not excluded herein within a calendar month are required to pay police service cost of $500.00. 
(d)  Notice. Prior to the issuance of a police service cost invoice, the City of Portage Police Department shall provide the owner and/or manager with notice that the business has exceeded five calls in that particular month and is approaching the threshold amount of calls which will result in the business' responsibility for police service costs. 
(e)  Billing. Police services costs due in accordance with this article shall be billed to the owner and/or manager with responsibility to manage the business by the city police department through a police service cost invoice and shall be due and payable to the office of the clerk-treasurer within 30 days of such billing. 
(f)  Appeal. The owner or manager of a business which has received a police service cost invoice and wishing to contest said invoice shall submit a written appeal to the board of public works and safety, care of the office of the clerk-treasurer, within ten days of postmark date of said police service cost invoice. The decision of the board of public works and safety shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 18-5, § 1, 4-6-18) 
Sec. 54-12. - Mailboxes. 
(a)  Purpose. The City of Portage has a responsibility to clear snow and ice from roadways. During the course of keeping the roadways free of snow and ice, damage to mailboxes may occur due to their close proximity to the roadway. 
(b)  Responsibility of property owner. Each property owner shall be responsible for ensuring the mailbox structure(s) serving their property are kept in good repair. A mailbox structure shall be defined as a private box into which mail is delivered, especially one mounted on a post at the entrance to a person's property. Mailbox structures should be constructed and maintained in a manner consistent with their close proximity to the roadway and so as to not pose a threat to the public health, safety or welfare. Property owners shall be responsible for keeping the area around their mailbox free of snow and ice. All mailbox structures shall be installed pursuant to United States Postal Service guidelines and applicable city building codes. 
(c)  Inspection. The city may, from time to time, inspect and/or document any mailbox structure. If a mailbox structure is found to be in an aged or weakened condition, the property owner may be sent a letter indicating the need for the property owner to repair or replace the mailbox structure. The city's failure to inspect, document or notify the property owner of the condition of any mailbox structure does not alleviate the property owner of their responsibilities under this section. 
(d)  Damage claims. If a property owner believes their mailbox structure has been damaged or destroyed by a city vehicle, then the property owner shall file a claim with the city within ten days of the date of the incident on a form provided by the city. Claims for damage to mailbox structures which were not in compliance with this section or were in disrepair, aged or in a weakened state will be denied. Incomplete claims will be denied. The maximum claim amount is $175.00. 
(e)  Appeal. A property owner may appeal a denial of their claim to the board of public works and safety by sending written notice of appeal to the office of the clerk-treasurer within 14 days of the date of the denial of their claim. The decision of the board of public works and safety shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 18-14, § 1, 10-2-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-14, § 1, adopted Oct. 2, 2018, set out provisions intended for use as Sec. 54-11. Inasmuch as there are other provisions so designated, these provisions have been included as Sec. 54-12, at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 54-13-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OBSCENITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Amusements and entertainments, ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Obscenity and pornography, IC 35-49-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Display in an area to which minors have access means a display of material in a manner such that minors may see those portions of the material which include the material in the definition of "explicit sexual material." 
    Disseminate means to sell, give, rent, loan, lease, exhibit for a monetary consideration, or other valuable commodity or service, or sell admission tickets or admit holders of such tickets to the premises whereon the exhibition is presented. 
    Distribute means to transfer possession of, whether with or without consideration. 
    Explicit sexual material means any live performance or pictorial or three-dimensional material including, but not limited to books, magazines, films, or photographs which emphasize the depiction of uncovered adult human genitals or depict or describe in whole or in dominant part human sexual intercourse, masturbation, bestiality, oral, genital or anal intercourse, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, or flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship in a manner such that: 
(1)  The material as a whole appeals to the prurient interest in sex; 
(2)  The material portrays any such sexual conduct in a patently offensive way; and 
(3)  The material taken as a whole lacks serious literary, artistic, scientific, or political value. 
    Knowingly means knowing or having good reason to know the character of the matter or performance. 
    Matter means any book, magazine, newspaper, or printed or written material or any picture, drawing, photograph, motion picture, or other pictorial representation or any statue or other figure, or any recording, transcription, or mechanical, chemical, or electrical reproduction or any other articles, equipment, machines, or materials. 
    Minor means any individual under the age of 18 years. 
    Owner means any person who owns or has legal right to possession of any matter. 
    Sadomasochistic abuse means flagellation or torture by or upon the person as an act of sexual stimulation or gratification. 
    Sexual conduct means acts of masturbation, excretory functions, lewd exhibition of the genitals, sadomasochistic abuse, homosexuality, lesbianism, bestiality, sexual intercourse, or physical conduct with a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or the breasts of a female for the purpose of sexual stimulation, gratification, or perversion. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-1(A)-(G), (J)-(L)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- Definitions pertaining to obscenity and pornography, IC 35-49-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 54-32. - Distribution. 
    Every person who knowingly sends or causes to be sent, or brings or causes to be brought, into this city for sale or distribution, or in this city possesses, prepares, publishes, or prints with the intent to distribute or to exhibit to another, or who offers to distribute, distributes, or exhibits to another any obscene matter is guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-2) 
State Law reference- Importation or distribution of obscene matter, IC 35-49-3-1. 
Sec. 54-33. - Providing material to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to: 
(1)  Disseminate material which he knows or has reason to know is explicit sexual material to minors; 
(2)  Display material in which he knows or has reason to know is explicit sexual material in an area to which minors have access; or 
(3)  Misrepresent his age for the purpose of obtaining admission to an area where minors are being restricted. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-3) 
State Law reference- Providing obscene matter and performances before minors, IC 35-49-3-3. 
Sec. 54-34. - Defenses. 
    It is a defense to a prosecution under this article for the defendant to show: 
(1)  That the matter was disseminated for legitimate scientific or educational purposes; 
(2)  That the matter was disseminated or displayed to the recipient by a bona fide school, museum, or public library that qualifies for certain property tax exemptions under IC 6-1.1-10, or by an employee of such a school, museum, or public library acting within the scope of his employment; 
(3)  That he had reasonable cause to believe that the minor involved was 18 years old or older and that the minor exhibited to the defendant a draft card, driver's license, birth certificate, or other official or apparently official document purporting to establish that the minor was 18 years old or older; or 
(4)  That he was a sales clerk acting within the scope of his employment and that he had no financial interest in the place where he was so employed. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 35-49-3-4. 
Sec. 54-35. - Seizure of materials and arrests. 
    Where the subject matter is offered for distribution to the public as stock in trade of a lawful business or activity, no person shall be arrested for a violation of any of the provisions of this article unless the arresting officer shall have first obtained an arrest warrant, and no property shall be seized as evidence unless a search warrant shall have first been obtained; provided, however, that the quantity of materials seized shall encompass no more than is reasonable and necessary for the purpose of obtaining evidence. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-6) 
State Law reference- Warrant required for search or arrest, IC 35-49-2-3. 
Sec. 54-36. - Procedure. 
    Within ten days after arrest and seizure, and prior to trial, the city, defendant, owner, or other party in interest of any matter seized under this article may apply for and obtain a prompt adversary hearing for the purpose of obtaining a preliminary determination of obscenity. If the court determines at such hearing that the material is obscene, the material shall be held as evidence. In the case of films or motion pictures, at any time after arrest and prior to trial, or prior to any adversary hearing, for the purpose of obtaining a preliminary determination of obscenity, the defendant or owner of any matter seized may apply for, and upon a showing that other copies of the film or motion picture are not available to be exhibited, the court shall order that the applicant be permitted to copy the film or motion picture, at his own expense, so that showing can be continued pending a judicial determination of obscenity in an adversary hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 35-49-2-4. 
Secs. 54-37-54-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIREARMS AND RANGES 

Sec. 54-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airgun shall mean an instrument from which a projectile is propelled by a spring. 
    Airrifle shall mean any instrument in which, by means of a lever, air is pumped into a chamber and then released by pulling the trigger; and the release of compressed air forces out the pellet, or any instrument in which compressed carbon dioxide is used to propel the pellet or shot. 
    Supervised ground area shall mean a private or public area or space designated in a location or site wherein discharge of pellets or projectiles from an airrifle or airgun will prevent the same from transversing any ground or space outside the limits of such designated area or space and wherein a responsible person has power or authority to regulate and direct the activities of the use of such airrifle or airgun in such area or space. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-5) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 54-57. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined the sum of $50.00 for each offense. Each shot fired and/or arrow shot, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-5(G); Ord. No. 86-4, § 4, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 88-52, § 5, 11-1-88) 
Sec. 54-58. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-31, § 1, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, repealed § 54-58 which pertained to possession and/or discharge of air guns and air rifles and derived from § 9-3-5(B) of the 1985 Code; and Ord. No. 04-59, § 1, adopted Nov. 3, 2004. 
Sec. 54-59. - Discharge of weapons-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any, paintball gun or bow and arrow within the limits of the city; provided that this section shall not be construed to prohibit: 
(a)  Any officer of the law to discharge a firearm in the performance of his duty; 
(b)  Any member of an archery club or paintball gun club to discharge a bow and arrow or paintball gun in furtherance of purposes of the club when the activities of the club have been approved by the board of public works and safety. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-5(C); Ord. No. 88-52, § 2, 11-1-88; Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 3-2-04; Ord. No. 11-31, § 2, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 54-60. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-31, § 3, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, repealed § 54-60 which pertained to discharge of weapons for pest control and protection of land or crops and derived from Ord. No. 88-52, § 4, adopted Nov. 1, 1988. 
Sec. 54-61. - Hunting prohibited. 
    During state approved hunting seasons, and subject to with all state imposed hunting laws, archery hunting shall be allowed on any ten acre or larger parcel of land, north of Interstate 94. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-5(F); Ord. No. 86-4, § 2, 2-4-86; Ord. No. 10-27, § 1, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 54-62. - Skeet ranges. 
    Established and approved skeet ranges having a launching site and a line of fire, within land boundaries of the skeet range owner, are permissible so long as the shotgun shall not discharge a pellet or shot larger than a #71/2 shot. Shot fired upon a skeet range shall not fall upon any property not owned by the skeet range operators. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-5(D)) 
Sec. 54-63. - Rifle ranges. 
    Outdoor rifle ranges shall be constructed to afford maximum safety. Each range lot must be 150 feet minimum in length with the minimum of 25 feet on each side of said range. Range's length shall face north, northeast or east to avoid sun glare; all ranges from firing point to target must be level. Backdrops shall consist of a steep hill behind the target range with the minimum height of 20 feet above the target. An artificial backstop crib may be used so long as such backstop extends six feet above the line of target and six feet on each side of the target. Such artificial backstop crib shall be constructed of soft wood to permit bullet slugs to penetrate and shall be three feet thick filled with sand. Such crib backstop may be protected by a steel plate no less than one-quarter of an inch in thickness so long as the steel plate is installed at a 45 degree angle directly behind the target to deflect bullet slugs. Outdoor rifle ranges shall be limited to use of rifles using ammunition no larger than .22 caliber long rifle bullets. The ranges from firing point to target shall not be more than 100 feet maximum. Rifle and skeet range construction shall be supervised and inspected by the chief of police. 
(Code 1985, § 9-3-5(E)) 
Sec. 54-64. - Shooting contests. 
    The provisions of this article shall not prohibit nonprofit organizations and/or service clubs from sponsoring shooting contests (i.e., turkey shoots), as long as such contests are approved in advance by the board of public works and safety upon the recommendation of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 98-16, § 1, 4-7-98) 
Secs. 54-65-54-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 54-75. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish minimum requirements and standards for the maintenance of premises and structures in order to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 1, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 54-76. - Responsibility. 
    The owner of the property shall maintain property, including structures, in compliance with these requirements. A person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or permit another person to occupy premises which do not comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 2, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 54-77. - Definitions. 
    Debris and junk shall include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Paper, paper products and newspapers not being gathered for recycling and that are more than 30 days old; 
(2)  Empty, or partially empty, plastic or glass bottles and/or metal cans or empty receptacles of any and all types not being gathered for recycling; 
(3)  Bed springs and/or mattress(es); 
(4)  Rubber tires, rubber tubes, metal wheels, hubcaps or wheel covers; 
(5)  Building materials, including but not limited to, cinder blocks, bricks, lumber, plywood, plumbing and piping material and parts, siding, roofing and forms when no construction is in process upon the real estate; 
(6)  Home appliances or other metal machinery, home exercise equipment, or any home electronics equipment or household items no longer being used for the purpose for which they were manufactured; and 
(7)  Any waste or scrap materials, including motor vehicle parts and parts of other manufactured items. 
(8)  Downed trees, branches or any part thereof not stored as firewood in accordance with section 54-79. 
    Graffiti shall include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Any sort of noncommissioned paint or wording on the exterior of any structure. 
(2)  Any defacement of property involving paint or other permanent marking material. 
    Junk motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle which meets any one of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Does not carry current valid registration and/or license plates. 
(2)  Is partially dismantled or inoperable. 
    Public nuisance. A public nuisance includes the following: 
(1)  Those conditions which are known to the common law and the statutes of Indiana as public nuisances. 
(2)  Any real or personal property which is infected with contagious disease or is likely to cause an immediate health hazard. 
(3)  Any condition or use of premises or building exteriors which is detrimental to the property of others, or which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located, including but not limited to keeping, permitting or allowing any material, including but not limited to the following: 
a.  Debris and junk; 
b.  Junk motor vehicle; 
c.  Any compost pile which is of such nature as to spread or harbor disease, emit unpleasant odors or harmful gas, or attract rodents, vermin or other disease-carrying pests, animals or insects, provided that the presence of earthworms in a compost pile shall not constitute a nuisance; 
d.  Demolition remains stored for more than 30 calendar days; 
e.  Open excavations, uncovered or improperly covered holes whether lined or unlined, and dirt piles on any open or unfenced property within the city, unless the property is an active construction site that has not been abandoned for more than one month; 
f.  Automobile parts; disassembled automobiles and automobiles without engines; plumbing and piping materials and parts; scrap metal; unseaworthy or dilapidated boats; dilapidated, deteriorated or inoperable jet skis, snowmobiles, motorcycles, bicycles, trailers, mopeds or toys, any of which are not kept completely enclosed in a building; 
g.  Structures defaced with paint or wording; 
h.  Any waste water, filth, offal, garbage, rubbish, litter, animal waste or human excrement which is deposited, allowed, or caused to be upon any public or private property; 
i.  Any dead domesticated animal or parts, and any dead livestock or nondomesticated animals within the public view; 
j.  Trees, shrubbery, weeds, snow or other matter obstructing public ways or causing visual barriers which create vehicular traffic or pedestrian safety hazards; and 
k.  Any item not originally designed or manufactured solely for outdoor use. 
(4)  The placing or accumulating on or within any real or personal property, or permitting the same, of any matter which attracts or may attract rodents, insects or domestic or wild animals in such a manner as to create a health hazard or an unsanitary or dangerous condition. 
(5)  The storage of any explosive, combustible or other material which creates a safety or health hazard. 
(Ord. No. 08-45, § 1A., 9-9-08; Ord. No. 09-26, § 1, 6-3-09; Ord. No. 10-39, § 1, 8-3-10; Ord. No. 17-16, §§ 1, 2, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 54-78. - Neglected premises visible to the public. 
    It shall be the duty of every person, business entity, or trust owning or controlling a house or other building or premises, including vacant lots, visible from any public place or private premises, to maintain such premises in a reasonably clean and orderly manner. It shall be a violation of this section to abandon, neglect or disregard the condition or appearance of any premises. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 3, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 10-39, § 2, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 54-79. - Duty of maintaining private property. 
    No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any premises shall maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, nor shall any person keep or maintain such premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of the other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. All property located within the city shall be maintained within the following minimum standards: 
Property. 
a.  All fences and walls shall be maintained in a structurally sound manner to protect the public safety. 
b.  All grass and weeds and other vegetation shall be maintained so that the height shall not exceed six inches. This provision excludes trees, shrubs, ornamental grasses, wildflowers and other cultivated plants. 
c.  All premises shall be free from any stagnant water. 
d.  All outbuildings and accessory structures shall be maintained in a structurally sound manner to protect the public safety. 
e.  All property, including but not limited to undedicated streets, alleys and throughways, shall be maintained in a manner so that it does not create or constitute a public nuisance. 
f.  All property, included but not limited to undedicated streets, alleys and throughways, shall be maintained in a sound manner to protect the public safety. 
g.  All private property shall be kept free from graffiti at the owner's expense. 
h.  Branches extending over pedestrian walkways shall be maintained so that their height shall not be lower than seven feet. 
i.  Trees and shrubs which extend over any public road or street shall be maintained so that there is clearance of at least 15 feet over the road or street. 
Open and outdoor storage. The open and outdoor storage of appliances, building materials or rubbish, equipment, garbage, goods, glass, material, merchandise, rubbish, trash or similar items shall not be permitted, maintained or stored on any premises. 
Exceptions. 
a.  This section shall not prohibit the storage of debris in leakproof containers with close-fitting covers to prevent the distribution of debris by the elements, until removed from the premises for proper disposal. 
b.  Cut firewood for the personal use of the owner or occupant which is neatly and safely stacked in lengths not to exceed three feet. The cut firewood is to be stacked in the rear of the property. 
c.  Likewise it shall not prevent outdoor storage where permitted by municipal code. These exemptions shall not be interpreted to permit activity that would otherwise be prohibited by zoning laws. 
Composting. All compost piles shall be maintained using approved composting procedures to comply with the following requirements: 
a.  All compost piles shall be enclosed in a controlled standing compost system. Each pile shall be no taller than three feet and no wider than five feet. 
b.  The compost system shall provide adequate penetration of moisture for the compost materials and provide adequate ventilation for products or decomposition. 
c.  All compost piles shall be maintained as to prevent the attraction of rodents and pests. 
d.  All compost piles shall be maintained to prevent unpleasant odors. 
e.  The compost pile shall be located within the rear of the property unless the residence is located in the back of the property. In those instances, the property owner shall contact the department of planning regarding placement of the compost pile. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 3, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 08-38, § 1, 8-5-08; Ord. No. 08-45, § 1B., 9-9-08; Ord. No. 09-26, § 2, 6-3-09; Ord. No. 10-39, §§ 3-5, 8-3-10; Ord. No. 15-13, § 2, 10-6-15; Ord. No. 18-11, § 1, 8-7-18) 
Sec. 54-80. - Exterior structures. 
(1)  All exterior surfaces, including but not limited to doors, door and window frames, cornices, porches and trim shall be maintained in good repair. Exterior wood surfaces, other than decay-resistant woods, shall be protected from the elements and decay by painting or other protective covering or treatment. All siding and masonry joints shall be maintained weather resistant and watertight. 
(2)  All porches, decks, balconies, exterior stairways, and all appurtenances attached thereto, shall be maintained in a structurally sound manner, capable of supporting the imposed load and free from any hazardous conditions. 
(3)  Exterior walls of buildings shall be maintained free from holes, breaks, loose or rotting materials, and shall be maintained weatherproof and properly surface coated as needed to prevent deterioration. 
(4)  Roofs of buildings shall be maintained so that they are structurally sound and in a safe condition and have no defects which might admit rain and cause dampness in the interior portions of the building. All portions, additions and sections of a roof, including but not limited to the fascia, eave, soffit, sheathing, rafter tail, barge rafter, vent screening, gutter, down spout, roofjack, lead and metal flashing, shall be complete with all trim strips, moldings, brackets, braces and supports attached or fastened in accordance with common building practices. 
(5)  Windows of buildings shall be fully supplied and maintained with glass windowpanes or a substitute approved by the building commissioner, without open cracks or holes. Screens, if provided, shall be securely fastened to the window. 
(6)  Exterior doors of building shall be maintained so that they fit reasonably well within their frames so as to substantially prevent rain and wind from entering a building. Additionally, exterior doors shall be provided with proper hardware and maintained in proper working condition. 
Sec. 54-81. - Swimming pools and spas. 
    All swimming pools, hot tubs, spas or any other water-filled area shall be maintained in a sanitary condition to avoid the creation of any health hazard or a breeding ground for disease-carrying insects. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 3, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 54-82. - Enforcement, notice of violation. 
    It shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer, building commissioner or their agents to enforce the provisions of this article. Members of the police department may also enforce the provisions of this article. 
(1)  Enforcement may include: 
a.  Issuance of a written notice to the person responsible for the violation, indicating the nature of the violation, ordering the action necessary to correct, and specifying a reasonable amount of time for the correction of the violation or the performance of any other act required; 
b.  Issuance of a written warning to the person responsible for such violation; or 
c.  Issuance of a ticket (citation) to the person responsible for such violation. 
(2)  Notice of a violation shall be served: 
a.  Personally; 
b.  By certified mail, with return receipt requested, to the last known address; or 
c.  By First Class mail and by posting the notice in a conspicuous place on the building, structure or premises on which the violation exists. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 3, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 10-39, § 6, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 54-83. - Penalties. 
(a)  General penalties. Violations of the provisions of this article shall be subject to the same penalty as provided in section 1-16 of the Municipal Code of the City of Portage. In addition, any person violating this article shall pay and be responsible for all attorney fees incurred by the city in enforcing the provisions of this article. A junk motor vehicle maintained in violation of this article may be towed and impounded by the city upon the expiration of 20 days after the owner has been notified about the violation. The owner of a junk motor vehicle shall be liable to the city for the fees incurred in towing and storing the vehicle and may reclaim the vehicle upon payment of those fees. 
(b)  Penalties for failure to remove graffiti. Upon a report of existence of graffiti to the city, the property owner shall be given a written notice requiring the removal of said graffiti within 48 hours. The property owner may sign a waiver of liability graffiti clean up that is attached to Ordinance No. 09-26. If said waiver is signed by the property owner, the city will remove the graffiti from the property. If the property owner fails to remove the graffiti, or fails to sign the waiver of liability within 48 hours, the City of Portage Code Enforcement department or designee may remove the graffiti. If the city removes the graffiti, the property owner will be charged the greater amount of $200.00 or the actual cost to remove the graffiti from the property. Such charge may be collected using any and all remedies available to the city including placing a lien on the property. If such steps are required to collect the amounts owed to the city, the city may recover additional costs including those incurred in the filing of the lien and any and all attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 04-74, § 3, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 07-26, § 1, 6-5-07; Ord. No. 08-45, § 1C., 9-9-08; Ord. No. 09-26, § 3, 6-3-09) 
ARTICLE V. - ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS BUREAU 

Sec. 54-84. - Establishment of ordinance violations bureau. 
    An ordinance violations bureau is established for the city pursuant to IC 33-36-2-1. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-85. - Violations clerk. 
    The city clerk-treasurer is appointed violations clerk. The violations clerk and his/her staff, acting as his/her agents, shall accept: 
(a)  Written appearances; 
(b)  Waivers of trial; 
(c)  Admissions of violations; and 
(d)  Payment of civil penalties which do not exceed the amount specified in IC 33-36-2-3 as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-86. - Admissions of violations. 
    A person charged with violating an ordinance or the Municipal Code which is subject to admission before the ordinance violations bureau may elect to admit the violation, waive the right to trial and pay the civil penalty to the violations clerk without assessment of court costs. Payments may be made in person or by mail to the clerk-treasurer's office. Payments must be made or postmarked within 72 hours or three business days of issuance of a citation, except where otherwise provided for by the ordinance or Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-87. - Compliance. 
    Upon an admission of violation, and the payment of the civil penalties, the violator shall have five business days to achieve compliance with the original violation notice. Failure to comply within the allowed time shall allow the city to take further action in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-88. - Denial of violation. 
    If a person charged with a violation wants to exercise the right to trial, the person shall appear before the violations clerk and deny the violation or enter a written denial with the violations clerk. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-89. - Prosecution of ordinance violations. 
    If a person denies an ordinance or Municipal Code violation subject to the jurisdiction of the ordinance violations bureau, fails to satisfy a civil penalty assessed by the violations clerk after entering an admission of violation, or fails to deny or admit the violation, the violations clerk will report this fact to the city attorney. Proceedings in court will then be initiated against the person for the alleged ordinance or Municipal Code violation. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-90. - Schedule of ordinances. 
    The following schedule of ordinance and Municipal Code provisions shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the ordinance violations bureau. (See attached exhibit A.) The schedule identifies the amount of civil penalty to be assessed to a person who elects to admit a violation under this article. 
(a)  Any person, corporation or organization who commits more than one violation of any offense listed in the schedule within any 30-day period will be subject to an increased fine as set forth therein for each and every violation. Every day, or part of a day, that a violation is committed or continues in existence is a separate violation for which civil penalties may be imposed. 
(b)  The schedule establishes civil penalties to be assessed against a violator who elects to admit to an ordinance or Municipal Code violation but shall in no way impair the ability of the city to bring suit to seek imposition of any fine greater than that provided for by the schedule that is otherwise provided for by an ordinance, the Municipal Code and/or state law. 
(c)  The imposition of a penalty under this article does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative action. 
(d)  The schedule shall in no way impair the ability of the city to enforce ordinances and provisions of the Municipal Code outside the jurisdiction of the ordinance violations bureau. 
(e)  The code enforcement department and/or animal control department, as prosecuting officer, may issue citations for violations as prescribed by the schedule.
