Sec. 54-91. - Recovery. 
    In all cases where the same offenses may be made punishable or may be created by different clauses or sections of ordinances or the Municipal Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but no more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 54-92. - Collection of civil penalties. 
(a)  Civil penalties shall be paid to, receipted by and accounted for by the violations clerk under procedures provided by the state board of accounts. 
(b)  All sums collected by the violations clerk under this article shall be deposited in the city unsafe building fund unless otherwise designated by the specific ordinance or Municipal Code provision violated. 
(Ord. No. 06-01, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Secs. 54-93-54-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - POSTED SIGNS 

Sec. 54-115. - Violation of posted signs. 
    Any person who fails to comply with any sign authorized and posted by the City of Portage shall have committed an offense against the city and shall be prosecuted by the city ordinance violation bureau, and shall be subject to a fine in the amount of $60.00 per person, per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 10-59, § 1, 10-12-10) 
Secs. 54-116-54-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRUANCY 

Sec. 54-120. - Definitions. 
    Attend shall have the meaning set forth in I.C. 20-33-2-3. 
(Ord. No. 18-4, § 1, 1-23-18) 
Sec. 54-121. - Child found not in school. 
    Any child who: 
(1)  Is required to attend school under IC-20-33-2; and 
(2)  Is found during school hours, unless accompanied: 
a.  By a parent; or 
b.  With the consent of a parent, by a relative by blood or marriage who is at least 18 years of age; 
    In a public place, in a public or private conveyance, or in a place of business open to the public may be taken into custody pursuant to I.C. 20-33-2-23. Any child taken into custody under this section shall immediately be taken to the principal of the public or nonpublic school in which the child is enrolled. If the child is not enrolled in any school, then the officer shall deliver the child into the custody of the principal of the public school in the attendance area in which the child resides. If a child is taken to the appropriate school and the principal is unavailable, the acting chief administrative officer of the school shall take custody of the child. 
(Ord. No. 18-4, § 1, 1-23-18) 
Sec. 54-122. - Parental responsibility for school attendance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a parent to fail to ensure that the parent's child attends school as required by I.C. 20-33-2. 
(b)  Before proceedings are instituted against a parent for a violation of this subsection, personal notice of the violation shall be served on the parent by the superintendent or the superintendent's designee: 
(1)  Having jurisdiction over the public school where the child has legal settlement; or 
(2)  Of the transferee corporation, if the child has been transferred. 
(c)  Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 18-4, § 1, 1-23-18) 
Chapter 58 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Amusements and entertainments, ch. 6; community development, ch. 30; environment, ch. 42; personnel, ch. 62; waterways, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- General powers concerning recreation, culture and community facilities, IC 36-10-2-1 et seq.; Park and Recreation Law, IC 36-10-3-1 et seq.; powers and duties of park and recreation board, IC 36-10-3-10 et seq.; acceptance of gifts, donations and subsidies, deposit of money received, IC 36-10-3-18; special nonreverting capital fund, establishment and use, IC 36-10-3-20; special nonreverting funds, IC 36-10-3-22(b). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-26. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a single department of parks and recreation for the city to be known as the "Portage Parks and Recreation Department." 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-1) 
State Law reference- Creation of department of parks and recreation, IC 36-10-3-3. 
Sec. 58-27. - Public fees. 
    The parks and recreation department shall provide recreation facilities and programs to the public without charge as far as possible. However, the department shall be permitted to charge a reasonable fee for any particular activity or program and shall be permitted to utilize fees generated by such activities or programs to enable the offering of any other activities or programs. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-6) 
Secs. 58-28-58-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 58-41. - Composition, appointment. 
    The parks and recreation department shall be governed by a parks and recreation board, which shall consist of four members to be appointed by the mayor. No more than two of such appointees shall be of the same political party. In addition, there shall be appointed one ex-officio member to such board, to be selected from the membership of the school board, by the school board. This board shall be known as the "Portage Parks and Recreation Board." 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-2) 
State Law reference- Composition of park and recreation board, appointment of members, IC 36-10-3-4. 
Sec. 58-42. - Terms. 
    The parks and recreation board members shall serve for four-year staggered terms. All terms shall expire on the first Monday in January, but an appointee shall continue in office until his successor is appointed. The term of an ex-officio member shall be co-extensive with the term of his office, unless the school board at its first regular meeting of the year shall appoint another to serve as its representative. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-3) 
State Law reference- Terms of members, IC 36-10-3-5. 
Sec. 58-43. - Powers. 
    The parks and recreation board shall have all powers, privileges, and duties as provided by state law. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-4) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of board, IC 36-10-3-10 et seq. 
Sec. 58-44. - Compensation. 
    The parks and recreation board members shall be compensated at the rate determined by the common council, not to exceed the limits set forth in IC 36-10-3-9. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-5) 
Secs. 58-45-58-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK AND RECREATION IMPACT FEE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-1, adopted Jan. 14, 2014, did not specifically amend the Code and has been codified herein as superseding the former Art. III, §§ 58-55-58-70. Formerly, Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 06-68, §§ 1-16, adopted Dec. 12, 2006, and Ord. No. 07-36, §§ 1A and 1B, adopted July 3, 2007. 

Sec. 58-55. - Limitation on imposition of impact fee. 
    The impact fee may not be collected more than five years after the effective date of the ordinance as required by IC 36-7-4-1340, unless a replacement impact fee ordinance is adopted consistent with Indiana law. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 1, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-56. - Establishment of impact zone. 
    There is hereby established one infrastructure impact zone, the boundaries of which are co-terminus with the existing corporate boundaries of the city, as such boundaries may be extended from time to time through annexation, and over which boundaries the city exercises planning and zoning jurisdiction. In this regard, the city council specifically finds that there is a functional relationship between the components of the plan and that the park and recreational plan provides a reasonably uniform benefit to all citizens throughout the impact zone as of the adoption of this article. The city council further finds that all areas within the impact zone are contiguous as required by IC 36-7-4-1316. Except as provided herein, this article shall apply uniformly to all residential developments within the impact zone hereby established for which the city which (sic) require a structural building permit and which creates a need for new and additional park and recreational infrastructure. This article shall not apply to: 
(a)  Development meeting the requirements set forth in IC 36-7-4-1322(g); 
(b)  Improvements which do not require a building permit; 
(c)  Improvements which do not create a need for new and additional infrastructure, including the erection of a sign, construction of accessory buildings, structures or fences, or the alteration, renovation or expansion of an improvement where the use, or intensity thereof, has not changed; 
(d)  The replacement of a destroyed or partially destroyed improvement provided that the replacement improvement does not create a need for new and additional infrastructure over and above the infrastructure needed by the original improvement prior to the destruction or partial destruction thereof; and 
(e)  Nonresidential development. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 2, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-57. - Zone improvement plan. 
    As a precondition to the adoption of this article, the city undertook a comprehensive and detailed park and recreational impact analysis through the employment for that purpose of Lehman & Lehman, Inc. The city council now finds that the resulting study and data base constitute a sufficient study to constitute a "zone improvement plan" as contemplated by IC 36-7-4-1318. The city council does hereby adopt the plan prepared by Lehman & Lehman, Inc., dated September, 2013, as its zone improvement plan and specifically finds that the zone improvement plan contains the following elements: 
(a)  Reasonable estimates relating to the nature and location of development that is expected to occur within the impact zone during the following ten-year period from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived; 
(b)  A reasonable determination of the community level of service for the impact zone; 
(c)  A reasonable determination of the current level of service provided within the impact zone; 
(d)  A reasonable estimate of the nature, location, sequencing, and timing of the park and recreational requirements and costs necessary to provide the community level of service for the developments contemplated in subsection (a) hereof; 
(e)  A reasonable estimate of the share of the park and recreational costs identified in subsection (d) hereof that will be used: 
(1)  To raise the current level of service for existing development or provide service to existing development; or 
(2)  To provide service to new development. 
(f)  A reasonable estimate of revenues that: 
(1)  Are from sources other than impact fees; and 
(2)  Will be used to finance the cost identified in subsection (e)(1) above; 
(g)  A description of the nature and location of existing infrastructure in the impact zone. 
(h)  A general description of the sources and amounts of money used to pay for infrastructure during the previously five years. 
    Additionally the city council hereby adopts specifically the zone improvement plan as an official part of the comprehensive plan for the city, pursuant to IC 36-7-4-500 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 3, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-58. - Establishment of park and recreation impact fee. 
    Based on the plan, the city council determines that the park and recreation impact fee should be $697.00 per residential building permit. The city council hereby makes, as part of the record of these proceedings, all of the data collected, the calculations made, and the conclusions reached by Lehman & Lehman, Inc., in the process of developing and drafting the zone improvement plan, and specifically instructs the employees of the city to make such data and other information available to the public for review during regular business hours. 
    In the event any parcel of real estate subject to the zone improvement plan undergoes a change in use, redevelopment, or a modification, which change requires a building permit, and creates a need for new infrastructure, an impact fee will only be assessed for the increase in the burden on infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 4, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-59. - Credit in lieu of payment; exemptions. 
    Any person obligated to pay a fee pursuant to the terms of this article may have the option of financing, constructing, and dedicating park and recreational infrastructure owned and operated by a neighborhood association for the public benefit, all as described and defined in the plan and the city park board policy resolution dated on the 16th day of September, 2013, instead of making all or part of any impact fee payment to the city, and in accordance with the park and recreational specifications for such park and recreational infrastructure to be improved in force within the city's jurisdiction at the time. The fee payer, or other person or entity providing the infrastructure or improvement, shall be given credit for the actual costs of planning, financing, and constructing such park and recreational infrastructure for the city. A request for credit shall be presented prior to the issuance of the building permit. In the event the actual cost of such planning, financing, and construction do not equal the amount of the impact fee pursuant to the calculation provided for the schedule set forth in section 58-58 of this article, the remaining balance shall be due in accordance with the provisions stated hereafter. 
    Credits against impact fees otherwise due shall be allowed pursuant to this section for all infrastructure improvements constructed or furnished in accordance with IC 36-7-4-1313 and IC 36-7-4-1335. In addition, a fee payer or other person or entity responsible for the installing infrastructure or improvements may designate in writing a method of allocating its credits to future fee payers who may be successors in interest to the credits earned by the fee payer or others, as part of the certification provided for above. Any person or entity otherwise obligated to pay the fee established by this article whose property was totally or partially destroyed by fire, storm, or other casualty beyond his/her/its control, shall be exempt from said fee is he/she/it repairs or replaces the destroyed structure without creating a burden on infrastructure greater than the burden imposed by the destroyed infrastructure. In the event of such additional burden, the fee shall be calculated based only on the increased burden created by the structure. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 5, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-60. - Impact fee due upon issuance of a building permit. 
    The fee imposed pursuant to the terms of this article shall be due and payable upon the issuance of a building permit by the city. It is understood that the term "building permit" is synonymous with the term "structural building permit" as that term is used in IC 36-7-4-1323, in that the issuance of a building permit authorizes the applicant to commence construction activities, structural or otherwise. The fee which is calculated pursuant to the terms of this article, which is a per dwelling unit fee, shall be due at said time unless the amount of the fee upon calculation is greater than $5,000.00, in which case an installment plan may be requested by the applicant in accordance with the terms set forth in IC 36-7-4-1324(a) through (d). The city impact fee review board shall establish specific rules consistent with said code provisions for installment payments. The interest rate on any installment plan or deferred payment shall be established by the Indiana Code, as from time to time amended. 
    If a fee payer requests, the amount of the fee shall be assessed upon the voluntary submission of a development plan or upon the issuance of the building permit, whichever is earlier. For purposes of this section, assessment means the act of calculating the amount of the fee which shall be due. The city shall make such assessment within 30 days of the date of such voluntary request or at the issuance of the building permit with or without the request. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 6, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-61. - Lien rights established. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-7-4-1325, the city acquires a lien against the real estate which is the subject of the fee on the date a building permit is issued. Upon adoption, this article shall be recorded, and thereafter, it shall constitute constructive notice of the lien rights of the city with respect to a parcel of real estate which is the subject of an installment payment of the fee. The city may, in its discretion, file a specific instrument setting forth its lien rights with respect to a parcel of real estate which is the subject of an installment payment of the fee, and such instrument shall constitute actual notice in addition to the constructive notice provided for by the recording of this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 7, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-62. - Form of receipt. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall issue a receipt for any and all impact fees collected and the form of such receipt shall be as follows: 
Received of ______________ (fee payer) ______________________, this __________ day of ______________, the sum of $__________________ in (full) (partial) satisfaction of Recreational Impact Fees due pursuant to Portage City Council Ordinance No. 2014-___ relating to improvements to be constructed on the real estate located at and described on Exhibit A attached hereto and made part hereof, and subject to lien rights in favor of the City of Portage in the event of partial payment with payments remaining due. The remaining balance due (if any) is in the following amount: $___________. This impact fee is dedicated to the creation of the following infrastructure element in accordance with the Zone Improvement Plan: 
___________ 
Christopher D. Stidham 
Clerk-Treasurer 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 8, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-63. - Establishment of portage impact fee review board. 
    The city hereby establishes, pursuant to IC 36-7-4-1338, a city impact fee review board which shall consist of three citizen members appointed by the mayor and who shall qualify as follows: 
One member shall be a real estate broker licensed in Indiana; 
One member shall be an engineer licensed in Indiana; and 
One member shall be a certified public accountant. 
A board member shall not be a member of the city advisory plan commission. 
(a)  The term of office of the members of the board shall commence from the date of their appointment and expire five years from the date of appointment. 
(b)  At the expiration of the respective terms of each of the board members originally appointed, their respective successors shall be appointed in the same manner as the original appointee, and each such succeeding member shall serve for a term of five years. Each member shall continue to serve until his/her successor is appointed and qualified. 
(c)  In the event any person appointed as a board member shall fail to qualify as provided within ten days after mailing to him/her of notice of his /her appointment, or if any member after qualifying shall die, resign, vacate office, or in the event a member is unable to hear a petition due to a conflict of interest, the mayor shall fill such vacancy with a new or temporary (in the event of a conflict of interest) member meeting the qualifications of the member being replaced. A new member shall serve out the remainder of the vacated term, while a temporary member shall serve for the period necessary to dispose of the petition giving rise to the conflict. 
(d)  The board shall be governed by IC 36-7-4-1338(c) and all other applicable provisions of the impact fee statute. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 9, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-64. - Appeals. 
    Any fee payer who believes itself to be aggrieved by the calculation of the fee may appeal from such calculation to the city impact fee review board and the city impact fee review board shall conduct a hearing with regard thereto. At such hearing, the fee payer shall bear the burden of going forward with the evidence and shall present evidence addressing either of the following propositions: 
(a)  A fact assumption used in determining the amount of the fee is incorrect; or 
(b)  The amount of the fee is greater than the amount allowed under IC 36-7-4-1320, 36-7-4-1321 and 36-7-4-1322. 
    Upon conclusion of the hearing at which the matter is first presented, or at the conclusion of the hearing if the matter is continued, the city impact fee review board shall determine the appropriate amount of the fee based upon the facts presented and may reverse, affirm, modify, or make such adjustments in the fee, as it believes are appropriate under the circumstances, if any, including establishing the amount of an impact fee, a credit, a refund, or any combination of fees, credit, or refunds. 
    The city impact fee review board shall make written findings of fact supporting its decision and shall provide a copy of its decision to the city council and the fee payer involved in the appeal within five days after making its decision. 
    An appeal under this section must be filed no later than 30 days after the issuance of the building permit. The appeal shall be initiated with the filing of a petition for review with the city clerk-treasurer's office together with a filing fee in the amount of $100.00. The filing fee shall be refunded in full if: 
(1)  The petition for review is granted and the fee is eliminated, reduced or adjusted by the city impact fee review board, by independent action of the city, or by a court having jurisdiction; and 
(2)  The reviewing body determines that the amount of the fee, reductions, or credits were arbitrary or capricious. 
    The petition for review shall be in a form calculated to inform the city impact fee review board of the nature of complaint, the parties to the action, and the relief requested. In addition, the petition shall describe the new development on which the fee has been assessed, all facts related to the assessment of the fee, and the reasons the petitioner believes that the amount of the fee assessed is erroneous or is greater than the amount allowed by the fee limitation set forth in this article and the enabling statute. 
    The city shall not deny the issuance of a building permit on the basis that the impact fee has not been paid, or condition issuance of the permit on the payment of the impact fee. If the impact fee totals $1,000.00 or less, the city may require the fee payer to pay the impact fee or initiate an appeal under this section before the building permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 10, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-65. - Establishment of park and recreation impact fee fund. 
    There is hereby established the park and recreation impact fee fund of the city. This fund shall be a non-reverting fund and shall receive any and all sums collected pursuant to this article to be utilized in connection with the purposes set forth herein. The fund shall consist initially of one account based upon the current existence of one impact zone. In the event, and only in the event, that an additional impact zone is created hereafter, a separate account shall be maintained for each separate impact zone established within the city. Interest earned on the fund or on any account with the fund, shall be deposited and maintained within the fund or the separate account. The city clerk-treasurer shall maintain records of the status of the fund or any account which may be established therein, and shall make an annual report of the fund and accounts which shall be available to the public in general and fee payers, upon request. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-7-4-1332(e), the clerk-treasurer is designated as the city official responsible for acting on refund requests. In order to facilitate refunds when they may be due, the clerk-treasurer is directed to identify the purpose of any impact fee paid in order that a refund, if any, may be paid from the fund or account into which the fee was originally deposited. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 11, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-66. - Use of impact fees collected pursuant to this article. 
    Any and all fees collected pursuant to the provisions of this article may be utilized only for the following purposes by the city, acting by and through its board of parks and recreation, which for the purposes of this article is identified as the infrastructure agency contemplated by IC 36-7-4-1317: 
(a)  Providing funds to be utilized by the city for the purpose of paying the capital costs of new park and recreational infrastructure that is needed to serve the new development within the corporate limits of the city; 
(b)  An amount not to exceed five percent of the annual collections of the fee to be utilized for expenses incurred by the city for the consulting services used to establish the ordinance from which this article is derived; 
(c)  To pay any refund due pursuant to the terms of this article; and 
(d)  To pay the debt service cost of an obligation issued to provide new park and recreational infrastructure described in subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 12, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-67. - Indiana impact fee law. 
    The city council specifically acknowledges the existence of IC 36-7-4-1300 et seq. ("the 1300 Series Impact Fees") which regulates the imposition of impact fees by municipal corporations within the State of Indiana. The substantive and procedural requirements of IC 36-7-4-1300 et seq. shall control in the events of conflicts with this article which are unintended by the council. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 13, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 58-68. - Amendment and review. 
    The fee provided for herein is based upon data which, in large part, is subject to inflation and other economic and market forces over which the city has no control. The city council, may not less than once each year, cause a review to be made by city staff or consultants as may be required, to determine the continuing validity of the impact fee, the impact zone, and the zone improvement plan. The council shall consider and adopt such amendments as are necessary to cause a substantive compliance with all constitutional and statutory requirements. To the extent required by the facts and circumstances, this process shall include the steps necessary to update the zone improvement plan and the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 14-1, § 14, 1-14-14) 
Chapter 62 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 50; parks and recreation, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- City deputies and employees, IC 36-4-11-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Plan means the City of Portage Employee Medical Benefit Plan. 
    Productive time, expended by city employees, has the meaning attributed to that expression by the Act. No time for which an employee is paid by the city but is not working (including, by way of illustration and not limitation, paid major illness/injury leave, sick days, personal days, Kelley days, and holidays) shall constitute productive time for the purpose of determining entitlement to, or computation of, overtime wages. 
    The Act means the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 (29 USC § 201 et seq.) and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1985, §§ 2-4-1.5(C), 2-5-1; Ord. No. 85-44, § 2, 9-3-85) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 62-2. - Employee's retirement, savings or severance pay plan established. 
(a)  Authority. The council shall have the authority to create or confirm, to amend or modify, or to revoke or cancel a retirement, savings or severance pay plan with an employee or a class of employees. 
(b)  Payments. The payments and benefits from a retirement, savings or severance pay plan may be paid to an employee who is eligible under such pay plan, or in the event of the employee's subsequent death, payable to the employee's designated beneficiary or the employee's estate. The payments under such pay plan may be made in lump sum or installments, as established by the city and agreed to by the employee, or may be made to a nonqualified deferred compensation plan under IC 5-10-1.1-1(1), or to both. 
(Ord. No. 98-23, §§ 1, 2, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 62-3. - Employees gift fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created the "City Employees Gift Fund," which shall be a non-reverting fund. The fund shall be used to receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received as gifts for the benefit of city employees. 
(b)  Any gifts which are restricted or designated to a certain purpose in any manner shall be utilized only for such purpose and shall be maintained by the clerk-treasurer in separate ledger accounts to designate such purpose or use. Any gifts of money not restricted or designated to a certain purpose shall be used for the benefit of all city employees. 
(Ord. No. 00-36, §§ 1, 2, 8-1-00) 
Secs. 62-4-62-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERSONNEL POLICY 

Sec. 62-26. - Applicability. 
    This article shall be applicable to all employees, with the exception of firefighters and police officers. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-6; Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 5-7-08; Ord. No. 12-32, § 2, 12-4-2012) 
Sec. 62-27. - Holidays. 
    It shall be the policy of the city to insure that all full-time salaried and hourly employees have the following paid holidays each year: 
New Year's Day 
President's Day 
Good Friday 
Memorial Day 
Independence Day 
Labor Day 
Veterans Day 
Thanksgiving Day 
Christmas Day 
(1)  The mayor shall have the right to grant additional days, such as election days, if he deems it proper to do so. 
(2)  If any of the holidays fall on a Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be the observed holiday. 
(3)  If any of the holidays fall on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be the observed holiday. 
(4)  An employee must work his or her last scheduled day preceding and following a holiday in order to be eligible to receive compensation for the holiday. Notwithstanding the foregoing, an employee may receive compensation for a holiday when the employee has not worked the last scheduled day before and after a holiday if the employee: 
a.  Uses preapproved vacation and/or compensatory time on the last scheduled day before and/or after a holiday; or 
b.  Is ill on the last scheduled day before and/or after the holiday and his illness is verified by a doctor's certificate which is presented to the employee's immediate supervisor upon return to work. 
(5)  No employee shall receive more than eight hours' compensation for any designated and/or observed holiday. 
(6)  Part-time and temporary employees will not be paid for holidays. 
(7)  Notwithstanding the foregoing for shift-work employees, all holidays shall be observed on the day on which they fall. A shift-work employee who is required to work on a holiday shall be paid for actual time worked at an hourly rate equal to two times the employee's regular rate of pay, which shall include longevity and base pay. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-1; Ord. No. 89-50, § 1, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 02-14, § 1, 4-2-02; Ord. No. 04-60, § 1, 11-3-04) 
State Law reference- Legal holidays, IC 1-1-9-1. 
Sec. 62-28. - Payment of overtime wages. 
(a)  The city is hereby authorized to and shall pay overtime wages to all of its employees entitled thereto pursuant to the Act, at the rate prescribed by the Act, but only with respect to productive time (as defined in this article) expended by such employees for the benefit of the city. Excess productive time shall be approved by the appropriate department head or delegated person. 
(b)  In addition to subsection (a) above, the city is hereby authorized to and shall pay overtime wages to all employees who expend productive time in excess of eight consecutive hours in any one shift at a rate prescribed by the Act. Excess productive time shall be approved by the appropriate department head or delegated person. The expended productive time in excess of eight consecutive hours in any one shift will not be utilized for computation of total expended productive time for purposes of overtime computation pursuant to subsection (a) above. 
(c)  The city police department, fire department, and street department are hereby authorized, upon an emergency affecting or potentially affecting the public safety, health, or welfare, to call back to duty employees who are absent because of vacation, personal days, reduction days, or holidays. 
(d)  The city shall in all other respects comply with the Act. 
(e)  Employees not entitled to overtime wages pursuant to the Act shall be identified as exempt employees in the annual salary ordinance. 
(f)  Exempt employees may earn overtime wages as provided in section 62-36. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-1.5(A), (D); Ord. No. 85-44, § 4, 9-3-85; Ord. No. 08-102, § 1, 12-16-08; Ord. No. 13-23, § 1, 11-5-13) 
Sec. 62-29. - Vacations. 
    It shall be the policy of the city to insure that full-time salaried and hourly employees have the following paid vacations: 
(1)  Employees shall receive one week vacation after one year of service; two weeks of vacation after two years of service; three weeks of vacation after four years of service; four weeks of vacation after eight years of service; and five weeks of vacation after 13 years of service. 
(2)  To be eligible for a paid vacation in any year, the employee must not have been absent from work more than six calendar months during the previous year. 
(3)  A week, for the purpose of determining vacations, shall consist of seven consecutive calendar days, including holidays and weekends. 
(4)  All employees must schedule their vacation through their department head no later than March 1 of each calendar year. If more than one employee requests the same vacation and it would be inappropriate in the department head's judgment for more than one employee to take a vacation at the same time, the determination shall be based on seniority by the department head. 
(5)  Vacations do not accumulate and must be taken within the year earned or the vacation is forfeited with the following exceptions. Those employees whose initial earned vacation falls within the last quarter of the year must take the vacation before the end of the first quarter of the following year. 
(6)  Part-time and temporary employees will not be paid for vacations. 
(7)  Each employee who completes one calendar year of service with no time off due to illness, unpaid leave, injury or accident shall earn two extra days of paid vacation to be utilized in the following calendar year. These extra vacation days will not accumulate and must be taken in the year after which it is earned or it will be forfeited. For the purposes of this subsection a "day" is defined as eight hours of work. 
(8)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, employees may sell one week of vacation time back to the city for the sole purpose of depositing the funds received into the employee's 457(b) or similar tax-exempt or tax-deferred account designed to be used for payment of healthcare expenses, including health insurance premiums. Vacation time may be sold back to the city on terms and conditions approved by both the common council and board of public works and safety from time to time. 
(9)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, employees may sell vacation time back to the city for the sole purpose of depositing the funds received into the employee's HSA account established pursuant to the city's employee medical benefit plan. Vacation time may be sold back to the city on terms and conditions approved by both the common council and board of public works and safety from time to time. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-2; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1, 1-5-93; Ord. No. 02-79, § 1, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 12-32, § 3, 12-4-12; Ord. No. 13-2, § 1, 1-29-13; Ord. No. 15-3, § 1, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 62-30. - Sick leave, personal leave, funeral leave. 
(a)  Every full-time salaried and hourly employee shall be granted annual sick leave, with full pay, at a rate of six days for one year of continuous service; three personal days, with full pay, for one year of continuous service, and up to a maximum of three funeral leave days, with full pay, per death within the employee's immediate family. Days for personal leave and funeral leave may not be accumulated but must be used by December 31 of each calendar year in which the employee is entitled to take them. Unused sick leave may be accumulated up to 30 days. Upon termination of employment, an employee may be paid for the employee's unused sick leave up to a maximum of 30 days. 
(b)  Sick leave is to be utilized solely for the reason of illness or injury to the employee. In order to qualify for sick leave pay: 
(1)  Employees shall notify their supervisor of their absence prior to the start of the work shift; 
(2)  Employees shall keep their supervisors informed of the extent of their illness and the anticipated day of return to work; and 
(3)  A doctor's certification of any illness shall be obtained for any absence of more than two calendar days. 
(c)  An employee shall not be entitled to sick leave pay if at the time they are collecting worker's compensation benefits for the illness or injury. 
(d)  To qualify for personal days, employees must give prior notice to and have the approval of the department head. 
(e)  Funeral leave may not be utilized for deaths outside of the employee's immediate family. Immediate family consists of husband, wife, father, mother, son, daughter, stepchild, brother, sister, grandfather, grandmother, father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, grandchild, stepparent, step-grandparents, current spouse's grandparents, or foster children living in the household. 
(f)  The department head shall determine the number of days up to the maximum of three which shall be granted to an employee for funeral leave. 
(g)  Part-time and temporary employees are not entitled to paid sick leave, personal leave, or funeral leave. 
(h)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, employees may sell personal days back to the city on terms and conditions approved by both the common council and board of public works and safety from time to time. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-3; Ord. No. 88-10, § 1, 2-2-88; Ord. No. 90-11, §§ 1-4, 3-6-90; Ord. No. 92-21, § 1, 6-2-92; Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-6-01; Ord. No. 02-79, § 1, 12-10-02; Ord. No. 05-08, § 1, 2-1-05; Ord. No. 08-104, § 1, 12-16-08; Ord. No. 13-4, § 1, 2-5-13) 
Sec. 62-31. - Major illness, injury, maternity leave. 
(a)  Every full-time salaried and hourly employee shall earn major illness, injury or maternity sick leave (as further defined in paragraph (b) below), with full pay, at the rate of one day per month of continuous employment service. A month of continuous employment service for purposes of earning such leave shall constitute a month in which the employee works a minimum of 15 days. Work days shall include holidays, vacations, sick leave, personal leave and funeral leave but shall exclude days off from work due to workers' compensation leave, unpaid leaves of absence, major illness, injury, maternity leave and Family Medical Leave Act ("FMLA") leave. This earned leave may accumulate up to 90 days. A day, for the purpose of such leave, shall consist of one work day. 
(b)  Accumulated leave is to be utilized for maternity of the employee or major illness or injury of the employee or a dependent of the employee, or any purpose identified in the FMLA. By way of illustration and not limitation, major illness/injury shall not include cold, flu, strep throat, headaches, sinus infections, pinkeye, allergies, stomach aches, toothaches, muscle strains, muscle sprains, and similar conditions or injuries. This section shall not be construed as a requirement that an employee utilize FMLA time and major sick leave time concurrently. 
(c)  In order to qualify for major leave pay, the employee must comply with the following conditions: 
(1)  A physician must certify that the employee is suffering from a major illness, injury, or pregnancy. 
(2)  A physician must recertify each 30 days that the employee continues to suffer from the major illness, injury, or pregnancy. 
(3)  Accumulated maternity leave may be utilized during pregnancy or immediately following pregnancy. 
(4)  Major illness, injury or maternity sick leave must be taken in a minimum of three-day increments. 
(d)  Employees shall not be entitled to major sick leave if they are receiving worker's compensation payments or other benefits from the city and time lost shall not be deducted from accumulated sick leave. 
(e)  Part-time and temporary employees will not be entitled to accumulated major sick leave. 
(f)  All bargaining unit and non-bargaining unit employees may donate accumulated leave under this section to other full time employees. Employees may donate a maximum of five major illness days per year. Employees may receive a maximum of 15 donated major illness days per year. To be eligible to receive a donation of major illness time, the receiving employee must have exhausted all of his/her accumulated major illness leave. Before using donated major illness days, the receiving employee must have exhausted all of his/her vacation time and any other available paid time off. Donated leave may be used by the receiving employee solely for the care of a terminally ill dependent of the receiving employee or for that receiving employee's own life-threatening or terminal illness. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-4; Ord. No. 99-5, § 1, 2-2-99; Ord. No. 02-12A, § 1, 3-12-02; Ord. No. 05-28, §§ 1a.-1c., 6-7-05; Ord. No. 07-66, § 1, 10-2-07; Ord. No. 08-103, § 1, 12-17-08; Ord. No. 10-47, § 1, 9-7-10; Ord. No. 12-15, § 1, 7-3-12; Ord. No. 12-25, § 1, 11-7-12) 
Sec. 62-32. - Leaves of absence. 
    An employee may be granted a leave of absence for up to 60 days, without pay, if approved by the department head and the board of public works and safety. The employee will be required to return to work at the expiration of the leave of absence or be terminated. The city will not pay any benefits during the period of leave of absence. 
    Before an employee may be granted a leave of absence under this section, the employee must use all of his/her available: 
(a)  Vacation days and personal days; 
(b)  Annual sick leave days if the request for unpaid leave relates to the illness or injury of the employee; and 
(c)  All available major illness, injury, maternity-leave days if the unpaid leave is related to a maternity or major illness or injury of the employee or dependent of the employee. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-5; Ord. No. 05-28, § 1d., 6-7-05) 
Sec. 62-33. - Conflict with collective bargaining agreements. 
    To the extent any of the provisions of this article shall conflict with the terms of an approved collective bargaining agreement applicable to employees covered by this article, the terms of such collective bargaining agreement shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 06-46, § 1, 10-3-06) 
Sec. 62-34. - Non-exempt non-union employees-Compensatory time off. 
(a)  Non-exempt non-union employees shall be identified in the salary ordinance. 
(b)  When a non-exempt non-union employee works more than 40 hours in a workweek, the department head, at his or his discretion, may substitute compensatory time off for overtime pay. In order to substitute compensatory time off for overtime pay, however, the non-exempt non-union employee must have agreed to receive compensatory time off in lieu of overtime compensation as evidenced by completion of a compensatory time agreement. This agreement shall exist prior to the non-exempt non-union employee's performance of the overtime work. 
(c)  Where compensatory time off is substituted for overtime pay, the non-exempt non-union employee shall be entitled to compensatory time off at the rate of 11/2 hours of compensatory time off for each hour worked in excess of eight in any one shift or 40 in a work week. 
(d)  Where a non-exempt non-union employee earns compensatory time off, the employee shall be allowed to accrue up to 40 hours of compensatory time. Once a non-exempt non-union employee has accrued 40 hours of compensatory time off, the employee shall not accrue any additional compensatory time off until the non-exempt non-union employee's compensatory time off balance is reduced below 40 hours. 
(e)  When a non-exempt non-union employee has accrued 40 hours of compensatory time off, the employee shall be paid overtime for any hours worked in excess of eight in any one shift or 40 in a work week, until such accrued balance is reduced below 40 hours. 
(f)  Non-exempt non-union employees must submit requests to use earned compensatory time off to their department head. Department heads shall allow non-exempt non-union employees to use accrued compensatory time off within a reasonable period of time after the employee has made such a request, subject to the department head's discretion as to the needs of the department and in a manner that will not unduly disrupt the operations of the department. 
(g)  Non-exempt non-union employees may not take compensatory time off until the employee has earned compensatory time off. 
(h)  The mayor, in his/her discretion, may elect to pay out accrued but unused compensatory time off at any point during the calendar year, but in all cases employee accrued but unused compensatory time off balances shall be paid out in full by the end of the calendar year or upon separation from employment. In the clerk-treasurer's discretion, the clerk-treasurer may elect to pay out accrued but unused compensatory time off at any point during the calendar year for employees of the office of the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 13-23, § 2, 11-5-13) 
Sec. 62-35. - Exempt employees-Flex time off. 
(a)  Exempt employees shall be defined in the salary ordinance. 
(b)  Exempt employees are required to work the numbers of hours necessary to complete their assigned tasks in any given workweek. 
(c)  Exempt employees are entitled to overtime pay or compensatory time as provided in section 62-36. 
(d)  Exempt employees may be granted flex time off for hours worked in excess of 40 in a given workweek at the discretion of the mayor. 
(e)  Where flex time off is granted, the exempt employee shall earn flex time off at the rate of one hour of flex time off for each hour worked in excess of 40 in a workweek. 
(f)  Where an exempt employee earns flex time off, the employee shall be allowed to accrue up to 24 hours of flex time. Once an exempt employee has accrued 24 hours of flex time off, the employee shall not accrue any additional flex time off until the exempt employee's flex time off balance is reduced below 24 hours. 
(g)  Exempt employees must submit requests to use accrued flex time off to the mayor. The mayor shall allow exempt employees to use accrued flex time off within a reasonable period of time after the employee has made such a request, subject to the mayor's discretion as to the needs of the department and in a manner that will not unduly disrupt the operations of the department. 
(h)  Absent extraordinary circumstances, exempt employees may not use more than eight hours of accrued flex time off in any workweek. 
(i)  Exempt employees may not take flex time off until the employee has earned flex time off. 
(j)  Accrued flex time off hours may be carried forward from calendar year to calendar year subject to the 24-hour accrual limit. 
(k)  No payments shall be made for accrued flex time off, and no payment shall be made in lieu of taking flex time off. Under no circumstances will accrued but unused flex time off be paid out upon separation from employment. 
(Ord. No. 13-23, § 2, 11-5-13) 
Sec. 62-36. - Exempt employees-Compensatory time/overtime wages. 
    If an exempt employee is required to work hours in addition to his/her normal working hours due to an emergency affecting or potentially affecting the public safety, health or welfare, the exempt employee may receive compensatory time for those hours worked or be paid for those hours worked on the terms listed below: 
(a)  The exempt employee shall be entitled to compensatory time or payment at straight time for the hours worked in the emergency situation. 
(b)  Before an exempt employee receives compensatory time or payment for time worked during an emergency, the mayor and the council president must agree that the additional hours were worked as a result of an emergency. 
(c)  An exempt employee must submit a request for compensatory time or payment under this section to the mayor. 
(d)  An exempt employee shall not be paid for time worked in an emergency as described in this section unless both the mayor and the council president approve the payment. 
(e)  Exempt employees may not accrue more than 40 hours of compensatory time for work performed during emergencies as described in this section. 
(f)  Exempt employees must submit requests to use accrued compensatory time to the mayor. The mayor shall allow exempt employees to use accrued compensatory time within a reasonable period of time after the request has been made, subject to the mayor's discretion as to the needs of the department and in a manner that will not unduly disrupt the operation of the department. 
(g)  Under no circumstances will an exempt employee be paid for accrued but unused compensatory time pursuant to this section. Any accrued but unused compensatory time earned by an exempt employee shall be lost upon the exempt employee's separation from employment or transfer to a non-exempt position. 
(Ord. No. 13-23, § 2, 11-5-13) 
Sec. 62-37. - Disability benefits. 
    The city, subject to the limitations set forth in this section, shall provide reimbursement for expenses paid for Medicare Part B and D coverage, up to the level set forth below, for a former employee who has resigned his/her position with the city due to a disability: 
(a)  In order to be eligible, the former employee must have had at least five years of service with the city and must have resigned his/her position with the city due to a disability. Disability shall be evidenced by written verification of eligibility for Social Security disability benefits. Former employees will cease to be eligible for the reimbursement under this section upon attaining the age of 65 or upon losing his/her eligibility for Social Security disability benefits, whichever occurs first. 
(b)  Upon presentation of evidence of premium payment by the former employee for Medicare Part B and Part D, the city shall reimburse the eligible former employee at the following levels: 
(1)  Fifty percent of the premium for former employees with five years but less than ten years of service with the city; 
(2)  Seventy-five percent of the premium for former employees with ten years but less than 15 years of service with the city; and 
(3)  One hundred percent of the premium for former employees with 15 years or more of service with the city. 
(c)  As a condition of receiving disability benefits under this section, former employees shall sign an agreement requiring them to notify the city within ten days of losing their eligibility for Social Security disability benefits. This agreement shall provide that failure of a former employee to provide the required ten-day notice shall entitle the city to seek repayment of the reimbursement paid during the period of non-eligibility, including the city's costs and reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 14-10, § 1, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 62-38. - Veterans preference. 
(1)  Definition of a veteran. For the purpose of this section, a veteran is one who has been honorably discharged from any branch of the U.S. Military and who served: 
(a)  During a war; or 
(b)  During the period April 28, 1952 through July 1, 1955; or 
(c)  For more than 180 consecutive days, other than for training, any part of which occurred after January 31, 1955, and before October 15, 1976; or 
(d)  During the Gulf War from August 2, 1990 through January 2, 1992; or 
(e)  For more than 180 consecutive days, other than for training, any part of which occurred during the period beginning September 11, 2001 and ending on the date prescribed by Presidential proclamation or by law as the last day of Operation Iraqi Freedom; or 
(f)  In a campaign or expedition for which a campaign medal has been authorized. 
    Any Armed Forces Expeditionary medal or campaign badge, including El Salvador, Lebanon, Grenada, Panama, Southwest Asia, Somalia, and Haiti, qualifies for preference. A veteran who served at any time and who: (1) has a present service-connected disability or (2) is receiving compensation, disability retirement benefits, or pension from the military or the Department of Veterans Affairs. Individuals who received a Purple Heart also qualify. 
(2)  Recognition of veterans preference. The city shall recognize a veterans preference by hiring all open and competitive positions, excluding internal applicant positions only. Veterans preference is a credit of points available to qualified veteran applicants to recognize the training and experience they received as a result of serving in the military as well as sacrifice they have made for our nation. Veteran applicants receiving a passing score (or higher) either by written examination or an evaluation of your experience and education, will have five points added to their numerical rating. Veterans receiving a passing score on a promotional exam, are entitled to 21/2 additional points for their numerical grading. If an internal candidate applies for a position that is open to the public, internal candidates are entitled to the same veterans preference as external candidates. 
(Ord. No. 14-4, §§ 1, 2, 5-7-14) 
Secs. 62-39-62-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MEDICAL BENEFIT PLAN 

Sec. 62-81. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a medical benefit plan to be known as the "City of Portage Employee Medical Benefit Plan" for full-time employees of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-1) 
Sec. 62-82. - Fund established. 
    There is hereby established a separate fund, to be used for the purposes specified in this article, to be known as the "City of Portage Medical Benefit Plan Fund" (the fund). 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-2) 
Sec. 62-83. - Plan funding. 
    The plan shall be funded and paid for by the appropriations made by the common council for payment of the costs of providing medical benefits to city employees, and by employee contributions to the plan. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-3) 
Sec. 62-84. - Insurance. 
(a)  The clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to pay medical insurance premiums for claims in excess of the medical benefits payable and self-insured by the city, and the clerk-treasurer is further authorized to pay all costs and expenses incurred by the city in connection with the plan including, but not by way of limitation, costs of administration and audit. 
(b)  The city shall self-insure with respect to each eligible covered full-time city employee and such employee's dependents the first $120,000.00 of medical claims with respect to each such employee and such employee's dependents subject, however, to applicable deductibles and maximum benefits described in section 62-86. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-4; Ord. No. 90-12, § 1, 3-6-90; Ord. No. 91-7, § 1, 3-5-91; Ord. No. 92-11, § 1, 3-18-92; Ord. No. 01-13, § 1, 3-6-01; Ord. No. 13-1, § 1, 1-29-13) 
Sec. 62-85. - Claims, payment, deposit. 
(a)  The clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to pay all qualified and bona fide medical claims made with respect to each covered employee or dependent, subject to the limitations of section 62-84, and this section, and the clerk-treasurer is further authorized to delegate such responsibility to one or more administrators of the plan. 
(b)  The clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to draw upon the fund and to deposit for payment of claims, either in reasonable anticipation thereof or as actually accrued, such funds as shall be necessary from time to time to meet or provide for the city's obligations under the plan. Further, the clerk-treasurer may open in the name of the city one or more accounts at financial institutions for the purpose of implementing the provisions of this section, including such accounts by which funds from autonomous city boards or agencies may be aggregated and withdrawn for the purposes provided in this article. All employee contributions received with respect to the plan shall be deposited in the fund. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-5) 
Sec. 62-86. - Plan eligibility. 
    The plan covers all full-time employees of the city, subject to certain exclusions. Plan eligibility, benefits, exclusions, deductions, and other provisions relevant to the plan are set forth in the summary plan description, the provisions and conditions of which are incorporated herein and made a part of this article, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-6; Ord. No. 13-1, § 2, 1-29-13) 
Secs. 62-87-62-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DRUG AND ALCOHOL PROGRAM 

Sec. 62-106. - Policy statement. 
    This article is adopted to prevent the illegal presence of drugs and alcohol in the work place and to comply with the Drug Free Work Place Act of 1988. 
(Ord. No. 92-35, § I, 8-10-92) 
Sec. 62-107. - Awareness, education. 
    An awareness and education program shall be established for all employees of the city which shall: 
(1)  Provide important, timely, factual information about the hazards of alcohol and drug abuse in the work place, as well as provide in service training to all employees. 
(2)  Train the supervisory level employees on chemical dependency with specific focus on effective employee communications. 
(Ord. No. 92-35, § II, 8-10-92) 
Sec. 62-108. - Employee assistance. 
    An employee assistance program shall be established and made available to all employees of the city. The primary goal of the employee assistance program is to provide an effective, confidential, nonthreatening environment in which an employee of the city can seek help without the fear of career damage. 
(Ord. No. 92-35, § III, 8-10-92) 
Sec. 62-109. - Drug testing. 
    To reduce the incidence and prevalence of alcohol and drug abuse in the work place and to promote and foster confidence in the services provided by the city, a system of identifying as early as possible an employee who is abusing drugs shall be established. The drug testing policy shall comply with the following guidelines: 
(1)  Preemployment. All applicants for a vacant position within the city will be required to be tested for the presence of illegal or abused substances. Notwithstanding the foregoing, applicants for seasonal positions as referees and umpires at the park department shall not be subject to pre-employment drug testing. 
(2)  Postemployment. Any employee may be required to submit to a test to determine the presence of illegal or abused substances when there is reasonable suspicion. Reasonable suspicion shall be defined as the presence or occurrence of specific objective facts or events that the employee is at the time of suspicion, under the influence of drugs and/or alcohol. Such facts or events must be documented in writing and may include but are not limited to the following: 
a.  Observed possession or use of drugs or alcohol by the employee on the job or prior to reporting off-duty. 
b.  The smell of marijuana or alcohol on the employee's person. 
c.  The occurrence of an accident or incident involving personal injury or damage to property. 
d.  Mood swings, agitation, hyperactivity, explosiveness, violence, combativeness, or other remarkable behavior that is uncharacteristic of the employee. 
e.  Excessive absenteeism, tardiness, or other significant documented changes in employee performance. 
(3)  Employees affecting public health and safety. Any employee who may directly impact on the public safety, i.e. police officers, firemen, street department employees, may be required to submit to a test for the presence of illegal or abused substances on a periodic basis at time intervals to be determined by the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. 92-35, § IV, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 00-22, § 1, 6-6-00; Ord. No. 01-20, § 1, 4-3-01) 
Sec. 62-110. - Discipline for violation of drug-free policy. 
    Any employee determined to be under the influence of illegal drugs and/or alcohol is subject to discipline, including termination. Any employee who is convicted of a criminal drug statute in the work place must inform the city within five days of such a conviction. When the city learns of the conviction, the city must appropriately discipline the employee. The police merit commission, the fire merit commission and the board of public works and safety are each authorized to implement and impose any applicable discipline to the employees of the city under their respective jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 92-35, § V, 8-10-92) 
Sec. 62-111. - Implementation. 
    The board of public works and safety shall adopt policies and procedures for the implementation of the awareness, education, employee assistance, and drug testing programs in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 92-35, § VI, 8-10-92) 
Secs. 62-112-62-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COLLECTIVE BARGAINING 

Sec. 62-120. - Policy statement. 
    Public policy. It shall be the public policy of the City of Portage to allow collective bargaining in what the city deems to be appropriate bargaining units after an election in which a simple majority of employees in the bargaining unit establish that they wish to be represented by a labor organization. Elected officials, professional employees, confidential employees, and managers and supervisors are excepted from this article. The city recognizes that employees may form, join, or assist labor organizations and to bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing. The city further recognizes, however, that employees also have the right to refrain from any and all such activities and shall have the right to represent themselves individually in their employment relations with the city. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to supersede the provisions of existing state law. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-121. - Definitions. 
    Appropriate bargaining unit means a group of employees designated by the board of public works and safety ("board") for the purpose of collective bargaining. 
    Confidential employee means a person who assists and acts in a confidential capacity with respect to a management employee. 
    Employee means a regular, full-time, nonprobationary employee of the City of Portage. 
    Employer means the City of Portage. 
    Labor organization means any employee organization which seeks and/or successfully establishes that it has majority support among an appropriate bargaining unit. 
    Lockout means an act by the employer to prevent its employees from going to work for the purpose of resisting a demand of the employees' exclusive representative or for the purpose of gaining a concession from the exclusive representative. 
    Professional employee means an employee whose work is predominately intellectual and varied in character and whose work involves the consistent exercise of discretion and judgment in its performance and require knowledge of an advanced nature in a field of learning customarily requiring specialized study at an institution of higher education or its equivalent. The work of a professional employee is of such character that the output or result accomplished cannot be standardized in relation to a given period of time. 
    Strike means an employee's refusal, in concerted action with other employees, to report for duty or his willful absence in whole or in part from the full, faithful, and proper performance of the duties of employment. The definition of strike includes, but is not limited to such action as, the blue flu, sickouts, slowdowns, and sympathy strikes. 
    Supervisor means any individual having authority in the interest of the employer to hire, transfer, suspend, discipline other employees, or responsibility to direct them, or responsibility for evaluating employees' work performance, or to adjust their grievances, or effectively to recommend any of the actions listed above if, in connection with the foregoing, the exercise of such authority is not of a merely routine or clerical nature but requires the use of independent judgment. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 1, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-122. - Appropriate bargaining units. 
    The board shall, upon receipt of a valid petition for a representation election filed by a labor organization, designate the appropriate bargaining unit for collective bargaining. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 2, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-123. - Determination of representation. 
(a)  Any labor organization may file a written request with the board asserting that employees in a bargaining unit of the city desire to be represented by it for the purpose of collective bargaining and asking to be recognized as the exclusive bargaining representative. The request shall include a demonstration of support of at least 30 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit by means of a dated membership list or signed and dated membership cards of those employees desiring representation. Notice of the request shall be posted by the city in a place conspicuous to employees in the bargaining unit. 
(b)  Upon authentication of the list or cards, the board shall call and hold a representation election within 45 days from the date that the board determines the appropriateness of the bargaining unit. Such election shall not be held if: 
(1)  There is currently in effect a lawful written agreement between the city and an exclusive bargaining representative for the bargaining unit; 
(2)  Within the preceding 12 months, there has been held a representation election or a decertification election for the bargaining unit; or 
(3)  Voluntary recognition has been granted in the past 12 months. 
(c)  The board shall call and hold all elections within the time limits established by this section and according to the following: 
(1)  Included on the ballot in a representation election shall be any employee organization(s) submitting evidence of support of at least 30 percent of the city employees in the bargaining unit and a choice for no representation. The choices on a ballot in a decertification election shall be the incumbent exclusive bargaining representative, no representation and any employee organization(s) submitting evidence of support of at least 30 percent of the city employees in the bargaining unit; 
(2)  Voting shall be by secret ballot; 
(3)  Where a simple majority of the votes cast are in favor of representation by a labor organization and at least 60 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit have cast a vote, the board shall certify the labor organization as the exclusive representation for all employees in that appropriate bargaining unit. No labor organization shall be certified as an exclusive representative unless at least 60 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit vote in the election or run-off election. This subsection does not apply to decertification elections. In a decertification election, the labor organization must receive a simple majority of the votes cast in order to retain certification as representative of the employees in a bargaining unit. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a)-(c) of this section, the employer is required to recognize as the exclusive representative of its employees within an appropriate unit, a labor organization which presents to the employer evidence of its representation of a simple majority of the employees within the unit, unless any other organization, employee, group of employees, or labor organization representing employees within the unit files written objections to recognition with the board. In the absence of such objections, the board is not required to hold a hearing or to direct an election. Before recognizing an exclusive representative under the circumstances of this subsection, the board is required to post a written public notice of its intention to recognize the organization as exclusive representative of the employees within the unit. The notice must be posted for at least 30 days immediately preceding recognition. In the event objections are filed, an election shall be conducted in accordance with this section. 
(e)  The certified exclusive bargaining representative shall represent all employees covered by the terms of the collective bargaining agreement, whether or not the employees choose to join the union. 
(f)  The decertification of any employee organization which has been recognized as the exclusive bargaining representative of employees in an appropriate bargaining unit may be effected by the filing of a written request for decertification supported by a showing that 30 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit seek to have a decertification election. If, in the opinion of the board, the showing of interest in support of such a petition is sufficient, within 45 days, a decertification election shall be held. 
(g)  No decertification election shall be held if within the preceding 12 months, the board has held a representation election or decertification election for the bargaining unit. 
(h)  The following meetings shall be closed as defined by the open door law: 
(1)  Meetings for discussion of bargaining strategy for collective bargaining negotiations between the employer and the exclusive representative; and 
(2)  Collective bargaining sessions. 
(i)  A labor organization certified as the exclusive bargaining representative for employees prior to the effective date of this article shall be recognized without following the certification procedures set forth in this article. If such a labor organization is decertified, the provisions of the article shall apply to its recertification. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 3, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-124. - Prohibited practices. 
    No organization, its representative or other individual shall be allowed to solicit membership for an employee organization or labor union during an employee's duty hours by calling or holding a group meeting unless authorized by agreement. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 4, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-125. - Strikes and lockouts prohibited; penalties and sanctions. 
(a)  No employee or labor organization shall engage in a strike. No labor organization shall cause, instigate, encourage or support a strike, walkout or slowdown. The employer shall not cause, instigate or engage in any employee lockout. 
(b)  In the case of an action by bargaining unit employees where the employer alleges a strike has occurred, the board shall meet in emergency session, within 24 hours of the disclosure of this information, and determine whether a strike has indeed occurred. 
(c)  The board, after determining that a strike has occurred, shall direct that the collective bargaining agreement ceases to exist, and shall declare that the exclusive representative no longer represents employees in the bargaining unit involved. The board shall notify the employees in the subject bargaining unit of such action and advise them that they will not be privileged to bargain with the city through a collective bargaining agent for at least 12 months. In such case, the exclusive representative that represented the employees who went on strike shall be prohibited from collecting dues through payroll deductions, negotiating or representing employees in any fashion and shall be barred from serving as the exclusive representative of any bargaining unit of employees for a minimum of 12 months, at which time the city shall negotiate a new agreement unless decertification has occurred. 
(d)  In the case of a violation of this section, the city may petition the appropriate court to: 
(1)  Issue an order restraining and enjoining such violation; 
(2)  In the case of a strike, walkout or slowdown, impose on the employee organization a fine which will be set in accordance with the damages, loss of revenue and/or services involved. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 5, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-126. - Agreements. 
    Upon certification of an exclusive bargaining representative, the city and its representatives and the union and/or its representatives shall meet and confer at reasonable times and places to attempt to negotiate a collective bargaining agreement. The city's bargaining representatives shall include at least two, but no more than three, members of the common council appointed by the common council president. At least one common council member shall be present at all bargaining meetings. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall prevent the employer from negotiating on any issues, unless prevented by state or federal law. 
(b)  All agreements reached between the city and an exclusive bargaining representative as a result of collective bargaining will be reduced to writing in the form of a contract between the parties. 
(c)  A hand-executed copy of the agreement will be provided to each party and each will bear the cost of reproducing copies as needed. The city is responsible for providing copies and orientation to management employees, supervisors and confidential employees. The exclusive representative is responsible for providing copies and orientation to the employees in the bargaining unit. 
(d)  An agreement is effective when the union president and the mayor sign the agreement and it is approved by the common council. Provisions in multiyear agreements providing for economic increases in subsequent years shall be contingent upon the common council appropriating sufficient funds to fund the agreed-upon increase for a subsequent year. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 6, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 12-12, § 1, 6-5-12) 
Sec. 62-127. - Payroll deduction of employee organization fees. 
    The employer may, upon receipt of a written and dated authorization of an employee, deduct from the pay of such employee any fees designated or certified by the appropriate officer of that employee's exclusive bargaining representative, and shall remit those fees to the employee's organization. Provided that such authorization was executed subsequent to the passage of this article and presented to the employer within ten days of its execution. Provided further that such deductions are authorized by a valid collective bargaining agreement. 
    Employees may be required, pursuant to the terms of a lawful fair share agreement, to pay a fee which shall be their proportionate share of the costs of the collective bargaining process, contract administration and pursuing matters affecting wages, hours and other conditions of employment. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 7, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-128. - Unfair labor practices. 
(a)  It shall be an unfair labor practice for an employer to: 
(1)  Interfere with, restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of their right to join a labor organization; 
(2)  Discriminate in regard to hiring or condition of employment to encourage or discourage membership in any labor organization; 
(3)  Refuse to bargain collectively with an exclusive representative. 
(b)  It shall be an unfair labor practice for a labor organization or its agents to: 
(1)  Restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of their rights; 
(2)  Refuse to bargain collectively with an employer, if the labor organization is the exclusive representative. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 8, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-129. - Employment relations committee. 
    In the event a complaint is filed alleging that any person has engaged in or is engaging in an unfair labor practice as provided in this article, the mayor, at his discretion, may appoint a special committee to investigate it in an attempt to resolve the complaint. 
(a)  Only persons who have a minimum of three years of experience directly related to labor and employment relations in representing public employers, private employers or labor organizations; or teaching labor or employment relations; or administering executive orders or regulations applicable to labor or employment relations shall be appointed to the committee. 
(b)  However, the mayor and/or the city council may change these requirements if the mayor is unable to find suitable appointees meeting these qualifications. 
(c)  Members of the committee shall hold no other public office or employment by the city, state or other public agency or public employer, or be an officer or employee of any employee organization or any of its affiliates, who represent or seek to represent employees employed by the city. However, this restriction does not apply to persons on the teaching staff of a university who are knowledgeable in public administration or labor law so long as they are not actively engaged, other than as a member, with any labor or employee organization. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 9, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 62-130. - Impasse. 
    Either the employer or an exclusive representative may declare that an impasse has been reached between them in collective bargaining over the terms and conditions of employment and may request to participate in nonbinding mediation with Federal Mediation and Conciliatory Services. The services of the mediator including applicable per diem expenses shall be borne equally by the parties. Any individually incurred costs shall be borne by the party incurring them. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the parties from mutually agreeing to substitute an alternate procedure for resolving impasses in collective bargaining with that provided herein or from agreeing to utilize the services of a mediator not affiliated with Federal Mediation and Conciliatory Services. 
(Ord. No. 01-61, § 10, 11-6-01) 
Chapter 66 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]
