ARTICLE I. - OFFICIAL POLICIES OF THE CITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-1. - Title. 
    This chapter of the Portage Municipal Code shall be known, cited, and referred to as "the planning and development regulations." Any reference to this chapter following its effective date shall be construed to mean this entire chapter as it may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 1, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-2. - Authority. 
    This chapter is adopted by the city pursuant to its authority under the Indiana Code and other state and federal statutes as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 1, § 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-3. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the use and development of land within the jurisdiction of the city. It is designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare, and more specifically to: 
(1)  Support the goals, objectives, and policies of the comprehensive/land use plan and other plans adopted by the city; 
(2)  Reserved; 
(3)  Reserved; 
(4)  Fix standards to which the uses, buildings or structures within each district shall conform, therein restricting and regulating their location, construction, reconstruction, or alteration; 
(5)  Reserved; 
(6)  Prevent the overcrowding of land to ensure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; 
(7)  Reserved; 
(8)  Preserve and enhance the taxable value of land, buildings, and structures; 
(9)  Provide for the development of industrial areas which enhance the city's tax base without degrading the environment or quality of life; 
(10)  Preserve and enhance features of environmental or historic significance; 
(11)  Reserved; 
(12)  Designate and define the powers and duties of the bodies and/or official(s) administering and enforcing this chapter and the procedures by which the chapter is administered; and 
(13)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 1, § 3, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 05-42, § 1, 8-2-05) 
Sec. 66-4. - Effective date. 
    This chapter was adopted and became effective on July 6, 1999. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 1, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-5. - Repeal of preexisting code. 
    Upon this chapter taking effect after publication as required by law, the previous chapters relating to subdivisions and zoning, and all amendments thereto are repealed; provided that such repeal shall not affect the liability of any person for a violation of those chapters or amendments thereto or the right of the city to prosecute for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 1, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 66-6-66-10. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - OFFICIAL THOROUGHFARE PLAN 

Sec. 66-21. - Components. 
    The official thoroughfare plan of the city consists of a three part map, as amended, entitled: Part A. Thoroughfare Plan, Portage, Indiana, 1978, and accepted by the plan commission on October 10, 1978, and signed by the planning director and plan commission seal placed upon it; Part B. Street Classification System; and Part C. Right-of-Way and Building Setback Schedule. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 3, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-22. - Opening or widening of streets. 
    Whenever a street classified in the official thoroughfare plan is to be platted as a part of a subdivision, the required right-of-way for such a street shall be as specified in the official thoroughfare plan. Where a street borders a tract of land to be subdivided, the owner of such land shall be required to plat the full right-of-way designated for such street. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 3, § 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-23. - Location of streets. 
(a)  Wherever the location of a street is indicated in the official thoroughfare plan as an existing road or street, or a section or half section or other established property line, the location of the street shall conform to such location. However, a street lying wholly within a subdivision, and not designated as following an existing road or established property line, may be varied in its alignment when such variance promotes the plan of a neighborhood development unit in accordance with good site planning principles, and if such alignment provides for the continuity of traffic movement. 
(b)  Wherever the location of a street is indicated in the official thoroughfare plan as following an irregular alignment, or a revised alignment or is not referenced to an established line, it shall follow the alignment shown in the official thoroughfare plan. Such alignment shall be subject to a detailed survey, which may be provided by the plan commission or other public agencies, or by the owners of land to be subdivided if required by the plan commission. The survey for such street shall be subject to the approval of the plan commission prior to the dedication of the street. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 3, § 3, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-24. - Consideration by public agencies. 
    The board of public works and safety shall be guided by and give consideration to the general policy and pattern of street development set out in the official thoroughfare plan in the authorization, construction, widening, alteration, relocation or abandonment of the public streets, highways and related structures. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 3, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-25. - Issuance of permits. 
    Any permits authorized by the city, including, but not limited to, improvement location permits, permitting the erection, alteration, or relocation of structures and other improvements within the jurisdiction of the plan commission, shall be issued only if, in addition to satisfying the requirements of other city ordinances, the proposed street right-of-way as set forth by this article will be protected from encroachment. In this instance, the proposed street right-of-way lines will be considered as the front lot line of lots and tracts bordering such streets. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 3, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-26. - Thoroughfare plan. 
(a)  Part A. Map: The thoroughfare map and its accompanying notations, explanations, and other details is hereby declared to be as much a part of this article as if attached hereto [by reference only]. 
(b)  Part B. Street classification system: Specification for streets in the city are as follows: 
(1)  Primary arterial-Generally. 
a.  Minimum right-of-way: 100 feet (see schedule in subsection (c) of this section). 
b.  Pavement: Two to four moving lanes with turning lanes at selected intersections. 
c.  Controlled access: Entrances and exits limited per board of public works and safety requirements. 
d.  Parking: Prohibited within right-of-way. 
e.  Purpose: Fast, safe and efficient movement of traffic through the city. 
(2)  Primary arterial-Access road. 
a.  Minimum right-of-way: 140 feet (140 feet total includes state department of transportation right-of-way). 
b.  Pavement: Two to four moving lanes with turning lanes at selected intersections. 
c.  Controlled access: Limited to existing legal established points of access and new locations spaced every 660 feet, more-or-less, on quarter, quarter-quarter, section lines. An access road shall be provided, meeting city standards, to provide access to the highway or adjoining parcels of land. The board of public works and safety of the city may grant variances to allow temporary access points at locations other than those defined above. Such variances shall be temporary in nature, and the entrance allowed under same shall be removed by the owner at the request of the board when access roads become available on adjoining lands. The board shall have the authority to waive, in its entirety, the requirements for an access road, when proper, equivalent traffic circulation is provided and guaranteed. 
d.  Parking: Prohibited within ten feet of pavement. 
e.  Purpose: Safe and efficient movement of traffic through and in areas where the type of development will generate or draw larger than normal traffic volumes. 
(3)  Secondary arterial. 
a.  Minimum right-of-way: 70 feet. Within 200 feet of another arterial street: 100 feet. 
b.  Pavement: Two moving lanes with turning lanes at selected intersections. 
c.  Controlled access: Entrances and exits limited per board of public works and safety requirements. 
d.  Parking: Prohibited within ten feet of pavement. 
e.  Purpose: Safe, efficient movement of traffic within the city. 
(4)  Collector street. 
a.  Minimum right-of-way: 70 feet. 
b.  Pavement: Two moving lanes, and two parking lanes. 
c.  Controlled access: No special restrictions. 
d.  Parking: Each side per city standards. 
e.  Purpose: Collect traffic from local lanes and channel it to arterial roadways. 
(5)  Access roadway. 
a.  Minimum right-of-way: 50-foot right-of-way. 
b.  Pavement: Two moving lanes. 
c.  Controlled access: No special restrictions. 
d.  Parking: Prohibited on pavement. 
e.  Purpose: Movement of traffic through or from area affected by unique development conditions. 
(c)  Part C. Right-of-way and building setback schedule: Minimum right-of-way and setback distance requirements for the following streets are as follows: 
Table 1.2.1. Building Setbacks by Street Classification

Sec. 66-27. - Continuing authority of plan commission. 
    The plan commission may determine lines for new, extended, widened or narrowed thoroughfares in any portion of the area within the jurisdiction of the plan commission and certify to the common council the amended or additional plan under the same procedure as established for certification and approval of the official thoroughfare plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 1, Div. 3, § 7, 7-6-99)

ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - DEFINITIONS AND RULES OF WORD USAGE 

Sec. 66-61. - Word usage. 
    The following rules of word usage apply to the text of this chapter: 
(1)  The particular shall control the general. 
(2)  In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this chapter and any caption, illustration, summary table, or illustrative table, the text shall control. 
(3)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary. The word "may" is permissive. 
(4)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; words used in the singular number shall include the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary; use of gender specific pronouns shall be interpreted to include both sexes. 
(5)  A "building" or "structure" includes any part thereof. 
(6)  The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for," or "occupied by." 
(7)  Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions, or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or," or "either...or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.  "And" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply. 
b.  "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provision, or events may apply singly or in any combination. 
c.  "Either...or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provision, or events shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(8)  The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specified examples, but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. 
(9)  The title "planning director" as used in this chapter shall include planning staff as designated by the director. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 2, Div. 1, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-62. - Terms defined. 
    Wherever in this chapter any of the following terms are used they shall have the meaning indicated hereafter in this article: 
    Block means the property abutting one side of a street, and lying between the two nearest intersecting or intercepting streets, or between the nearest intersecting or intercepting street and railroad right-of-way, unsubdivided acreage, lake, river, or live stream; or between any of the foregoing and any other barrier to the continuity of development, or corporate boundary lines of the city. 
    Building line means a line formed by the face of the building, and for the purposes of this chapter, a minimum building line is the same as a front building setback line. 
    Building setback line, front means a line establishing the minimum allowable distance between a street or other right-of-way and any structure as measured from the front property line or right-of-way. (See "Yard, required.") 
    Building setback line, side or rear means a line establishing the minimum allowable distance between a property line and any structure as measured from the property line. (See "Yard, required.") 
    City means the City of Portage, Indiana. 
    City engineer means a qualified civil engineer registered in the State of Indiana employed by the city in the capacity of city engineer. 
    Comprehensive plan includes the complete comprehensive/land use plan of the City of Portage and its planning jurisdiction and all of its subsequent amendments for the development of the city, prepared by the plan commission and legally adopted. 
    Construction means on-site erection, fabrication, installation, alteration, demolition or removal of any structure, facility, or addition thereto, including all related activities, including, but not restricted to, excavation, clearing of land, blasting and landscaping. 
    Cul-de-sac means a short street having one open end to traffic and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
    Developer means any person engaged in subdivision of or construction on a lot or group of lots or structures thereon. 
    Easement means land or an interest in land that has been designated by lawful agreement between the owner or owners of the land and another person or persons, for a specified use only by such person or persons. 
    FHBM means the flood hazard boundary map. 
    Final plat means a map of subdivision with accompanying material, intended for final approval and recording, on the basis of which land can be transferred, leased, or encumbered. 
    FIRM means the flood insurance rate map. 
    Flood means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow, the unusual and rapid accumulation, or the runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood, regulatory means the flood having a one percent probability of being equaled or exceeded in any given year, as calculated by a method and procedure which is acceptable to and approved by the state natural resources commission. The regulatory flood elevation at any location is as defined in article IV, division 4, section 66-203. The regulatory flood is also known by the term base flood. 
    Flood protection grade or FPG means the elevation of the regulatory flood plus two feet at any given location in the SFHA. 
    Floodplain means the channel proper and the areas adjoining any wetland, lake or watercourse which have been or hereafter may be covered by the regulatory flood. The floodplain includes both the floodway and the floodway fringe districts. 
    Floodway means the channel of a river or stream and those portions of the floodplains adjoining the channel which are reasonably required to efficiently carry and discharge the peak flood flow of the regulatory flood of any river or stream. 
    Floodway fringe includes those portions of the floodplain lying outside the floodway. 
    Front yard setback means in all cases the front yard setback shall be measured from the right-of-way as shown on the adopted thoroughfare plan. 
    Grade means the ground elevation established for the purpose of regulating the number of stories and the height of buildings or structures. The established grade shall be either: 1) the finished grade if the finished grade is level, or 2) the average grade if the finished grade is not level. 
    Grade, average means the average of the elevation of the ground for each face of the building or structure. 
    Grade, finished means the level of the ground adjacent to a building or structure. 
    Jurisdiction means the incorporated territory of the city. 
    Lowest floor means the lowest of the following: 
(1)  The basement floor; 
(2)  The garage floor, if the garage is the lowest level of the building; 
(3)  The first floor of buildings elevated on pilings or constructed on a crawl space with permanent openings; or 
(4)  The floor level of any enclosure below an elevated building where the walls of the enclosure provide any resistance to the flow of floodwaters unless: 
a.  The walls are designed to automatically equalize the hydrostatic flood forces on the walls by allowing for the entry and exit of flood waters, through providing a minimum of two openings (in addition to doorways and windows) having a total area of one square foot for every two square feet of enclosed floor area subject to flooding. The bottom of all such openings shall be no higher than one foot above the enclosed area's floor. 
b.  Such enclosed space shall be usable for nonresidential purposes and building access. 
    Ordinance means a document containing regulations written either to stand on their own or as an amendment to an existing ordinance which, when adopted by the common council, becomes legally binding. 
    Parcel map means a map or drawing generally depicting subdivision data. 
    Plan commission means the city plan commission. 
    Planning director means the officer in charge of planning department who is appointed to administer the unified development code. 
    Planning jurisdiction. See "jurisdiction." 
    Plat means a map or chart indicating the subdivision or resubdivision of land, intended to be filed for record. 
    Public utility means a person, municipal department, board or commission duly authorized to furnish and furnishing under federal, state, or municipal regulation to the public: gas, steam, electricity, sewage disposal, communication, telegraph, transportation, or water. 
    Right-of-way means a parcel of land or easement, either public or private, on which an irrevocable right-of-access has been recorded for vehicles or pedestrians or both. A public right-of-way is one which has been dedicated for public use and may include streets, alleys, or sidewalks. 
    Roadway means the portion of a street right-of-way available for vehicular movement. Roadway width shall be measured from back of curb to back of curb. 
    Setback means the distance required to obtain minimum front, side, or rear yard open space provisions of this chapter. (See "building setback, front," "building setback, side and rear" and "tower setback.") 
    Special flood hazard area (SFHA) includes those lands within the jurisdiction of the city that are subject to inundation by the regulatory flood. The SFHAs of the city are generally identified as such on the flood insurance rate map and corresponding flood boundary floodway map of the city prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and dated June 1, 1982. The SFHAs of those parts of the unincorporated county that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city or that may be annexed into the city are generally identified as such on the flood insurance rate map and corresponding flood boundary floodway map prepared for the county by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and dated April 1, 1982. 
    Street means a right-of-way, other than an alley, usually affording the principal means of access to abutting property. The street may be designated as a highway, thoroughfare, parkway, boulevard, road, avenue, lane, drive, or other appropriate name. 
    Street, access means local streets which are parallel to and adjacent to arterial streets and highways. 
    Street, arterial, primary means a public street of large right-of-way so designated in the thoroughfare plan, and intended primarily for moving large volumes of traffic between origin and destination within a region. 
    Street, arterial, secondary means a public street of moderate right-of-way so designated in the thoroughfare plan, and intended primarily for moving moderate volumes of traffic between origin and destination within a region. 
    Street, collector means a public street of smaller right-of-way so designated in the thoroughfare plan, and intended to collect traffic generated by local streets and carry it to arterials. 
    Street, feeder (as regards entrance and exit ramps) means a street, usually an arterial, which provides access to and from an expressway by virtue of exit and entrance ramps to which it is connected. 
    Street, local means a public street intended for access to abutting properties. 
    Street, private means a paved area other than a driveway, located on private property for the purpose of providing vehicular or pedestrian access to and within that property. (See also "drive" and "driveway.") 
    Street, public means a public way for purposes of vehicular or pedestrian travel, including the entire area within the right-of-way. 
    Subdivider means any person engaged in developing or improving a tract of land which complies with the definition of subdivision. 
    Subdivision means the division of any parcel of land shown as a unit, as part of a unit, or as continuous units on the last preceding transfer of ownership thereof, into two or more parcels, sites, or lots, any of which is less than five acres in area, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership; provided, however, that the division or partition of land into parcels of more than five acres not involving any new streets or easements of access, and the sale or exchange of parcels between adjoining lot owners, where such sale or exchange does not create additional building sites, shall not be considered a subdivision. 
    Subdivision shall also mean the improvement of one or more parcels of land for residential, commercial or industrial structures or groups of structures involving the subdivision and allocation of land as streets or other open spaces for common use by owners, occupants or lease holders or as easements for the extension and maintenance of public sewer, water, storm drainage, or other public utilities and facilities. 
    Thoroughfare means a public right-of-way intended for the effective movement of pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
    Thoroughfare plan means the part of the comprehensive plan which sets forth the location, classification, general design, and construction priorities of existing and proposed public streets, to ensure effective vehicular movement, effective use of the land, and economic use of the public funds. 
    Variance means a modification of the literal provisions of the ordinance granted when strict enforcement of the ordinance would cause undue hardship owing to the circumstances unique to the individual property on which the variance is granted. The crucial points of variance are: 
(1)  Undue hardship; 
(2)  Unique circumstances; and 
(3)  Applying to property. 
    A variance is not justified unless all three elements are present in the case. A variance is not an exception. 
    Wetland means an area that is inundated or saturated by surface water or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that, under normal circumstances, does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions, commonly known as hydrophytic vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 2, Div. 1, § 2, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 05-42, § 1, 8-2-05) 
Secs. 66-63-66-70. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES 
DIVISION 1. - SUBDIVISION PROCEDURE 

Sec. 66-151. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the subdivision requirements of this development code is to promote the public health, safety, general welfare and preserve the aesthetic quality of the city through the regulation and control of the division of land. To achieve this purpose, the regulations contained in this development code are determined to be necessary to promote orderly growth and development, open space, conservation, protection and proper use of land; and to ensure adequate provision for traffic circulation, utilities, and other services in the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-152. - Subdivision approval process. 
    An applicant desiring approval of a primary or secondary plat of a subdivision of any land lying within the jurisdiction of the plan commission shall comply with the following procedure: 
(1)  Every applicant shall participate in a pre-application meeting with the City of Portage Planning Department. The purpose of the meeting is to: 
(a)  Acquaint the developer with the city's standards and requirements of all ordinances and the comprehensive plan. 
(b)  Review the intent of the procedures and requirements of the city. 
(c)  Acquaint the developer with any limiting characteristics of the property under review. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a completed application, the applicant will be placed on a DRC agenda. The applicant and his/her agent shall attend the meeting. 
(3)  Applications for primary and secondary plats shall be reviewed and forwarded to the plan commission within 30 days of receipt of a completed application. DRC recommendations based upon the goals and objectives of the City of Portage Comprehensive Plan as well as the established zoning and development standards of the City of Portage will accompany the completed application. 
(4)  A primary plat shall be reviewed and voted upon by the plan commission in a public hearing, as set forth in this division. 
(5)  A secondary plat shall be reviewed and voted upon by the plan commission, signed by the president and executive secretary of the plan commission, and filed with the Porter County Recorder, as set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 2, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 02-34, § 2, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 66-153. - General restrictions. 
(a)  The following actions may occur once the final plat has been signed and recorded: 
(1)  The granting of an improvement location permit, or the construction of any public improvements authorized thereby; 
(2)  Contracts made for the sale of any part of the subdivision. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued until the plat has been recorded. 
(c)  No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of the provisions of this article IV, administrative procedures. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 3, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-154. - Resubdivisions (replats). 
(a)  For any change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat, if such change affects any street layout shown on such map, or area reserved thereon for public use, or any lot line, or if it affects any map or plan legally recorded prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivision, such change shall be approved by the plan commission by the same procedure, rules, and regulations as for a subdivision. 
(b)  Whenever a parcel of land is subdivided and the subdivision plat shows one or more lots containing more than one acre of land and there are indications that such lots will eventually be resubdivided, the plan commission may require that such parcel of land allow for the future opening of streets and the ultimate extension of adjacent streets. As a requirement of the plat, dedications of rights-of-way shall be provided for the future opening and extension of such streets. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-155. - Variances to subdivision standards. 
(a)  Variances to subdivision standards of this unified development chapter shall not be granted by the board of zoning appeals, but may be granted by the plan commission subject to the applicable requirements herein. It is not within the jurisdiction of the board of zoning appeals to grant variances to subdivision regulations. 
(b)  It is the intention of this ordinance that all newly created lots conform to the provisions of this ordinance for lot area and width. Variances to these or other zoning standards may be granted subject to the provisions of article IV, division 5, zoning variances. It is not within the jurisdiction of the plan commission to grant variances to zoning regulations. 
(c)  Where the plan commission finds that extraordinary hardships or practical difficulties may result from strict compliance with the subdivision regulations of article 4, division 1 or if the purposes of these regulations may be better served by an alternative proposal, it may approve variances to said regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that such variances shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of these regulations; and further provided the plan commission shall not approve variances unless it shall make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that: 
(1)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public safety, health, or welfare, or injurious to other property. 
(2)  The conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable generally to other property. 
(3)  Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved, a particular hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of these regulations are carried out. Financial hardship does not constitute grounds for a variance. 
(4)  The variance will not in any manner vary the provisions of the comprehensive master plan or this unified development chapter. 
(5)  Where the variance impacts on design and construction of public facilities, all appropriate public agencies will be given ample time to comment in writing to the commission. 
(d)  In approving variances, the plan commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements of these regulations. 
(e)  A petition for any such variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time when the sketch plat is filed for the consideration of the planning director. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-156. - Primary plat contents. 
(a)  The owner or applicant shall provide a primary plat of the subdivision which shall show the manner in which the proposed subdivision is coordinated with the official thoroughfare plan and the comprehensive plan, and its provisions relating to the requirements of school and recreational sites, shopping centers, community facilities, sanitation, water supply and drainage, and similar matters, and other developments, existing and proposed, in the vicinity. However, no land shall be subdivided for residential use unless adequate access to the land over improved streets or thoroughfares exists or will be provided by the subdivider, or if such land is considered by the plan commission to be unsuitable for such use by reason of flooding or improper drainage, objectionable earth and rock formation, topography, or any other feature harmful to the health and safety of possible residents and the community as a whole. 
(b)  The subdivider shall provide the following: 
(1)  Location map, which may be prepared by indicating the data by notations on available maps, showing: 
a.  Subdivision name and location. 
b.  Any thoroughfares related to the subdivision. 
c.  Existing elementary and high schools, parks and playgrounds serving the area proposed to be subdivided, and other community facilities. 
d.  Title, scale, north point and date. 
(2)  A primary plat showing: 
a.  Proposed name of the subdivision. 
b.  Names and addresses of the owner, subdivider and city planner, land planning consultant, engineer, or surveyor, who prepared the plan. 
c.  Streets and rights-of-way, on and adjoining the site of the proposed subdivision, showing the names, which shall not duplicate other names of streets in the community, and including roadway widths, approximate gradients, types and widths of pavement, curbs, sidewalks, crosswalks, tree-planting, and other pertinent data. 
d.  Easements: Locations, widths and purposes. 
e.  Statement concerning the location and approximate size or capacity of utilities to be installed. 
f.  Layout of lots, showing dimensions and numbers. 
g.  Parcels of land proposed to be dedicated or reserved for schools or other public, semipublic or community purposes. 
h.  Contours at vertical intervals of two feet if the general slope of the site is less than ten percent and at vertical intervals of five feet if the general slope is greater than ten percent. 
i.  Ground water levels stated in inches below ground surface and given at points of lowest ground surface elevation. 
j.  Tract boundary lines showing dimensions, bearings, angles, and references to section, township, and range lines or corners. 
k.  Building and setback or front yard lines. 
l.  Legend and notes. 
m.  For property in a 100-year floodplain, any effect the floodplain would have on the development of the parcel. 
n.  Other features or conditions which would affect the subdivision favorably or adversely. 
o.  The primary plat of the subdivision shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals no more than 100 feet with northpoint, date and scale shown. 
(3)  A description of the protective covenants or private restrictions to be incorporated in the plat of the subdivision. 
(4)  A written schedule of a program of progressive development. 
(c)  The application shall be accompanied by a certified check or money prescribed by a fee schedule: 
(1)  For each petition for a plat or replat of a single-family subdivision, a fee shall be paid to and collected by the clerk-treasurer, the receipt for which shall accompany the petition. The petitioner is required to assume the cost of public notice and notice to interested persons. 
(2)  For each petition for a plat or replat of a multifamily subdivision, a fee shall be paid to and collected by the clerk-treasurer, the receipt for which shall accompany the petition. The petitioner is required to assume the cost of public notice and notice to interested persons. No part of any filing fee paid pursuant to this section shall be returnable to the applicant or petitioner. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 6, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-157. - Accompanying reports and data. 
    The tentative map shall be accompanied by the following data and reports: 
(1)  Street identification. Proposed streets shall be alphabetically labeled. 
(2)  Soil reports. A preliminary soils report may be required by the city engineer. 
a.  If a preliminary soils report is required, it shall be prepared by a civil engineer registered in this state and based upon adequate test borings, and shall be submitted to the planning department. 
b.  If the city has knowledge of, or the preliminary soils report indicates, the presence of critically expansive soils, liquefaction, or other soil problems which, if not corrected, would lead to structural defects, a soils investigation of each lot in the subdivision may be required by the department. The soils investigation shall be done by a civil engineer registered in this state, who shall recommend the corrective action which will prevent structural damage to each structure proposed to be constructed in the area where the soil problem exists. 
c.  The plan commission may approve, upon recommendation of the city engineer, the subdivision, or portion thereof, where a soils problem exists if it determines that the recommended action will prevent structural damage to each structure to be constructed, and a condition to the issuance of any building permit shall require that the approved recommended action will be incorporated into the construction of each structure. 
(3)  Title report. A preliminary title report, acceptable to the department, showing the legal owners at the time of filing the tentative map, dated within 90 days of the application being deemed complete. 
(4)  Environmental review. Information shall be submitted as required by the planning director to permit necessary environmental review. The various time limits contained in this chapter for taking action on tentative maps shall not commence until the subdivision application is deemed complete for processing, including all such environmental documents. The subdivider shall deposit and pay all fees as may be required for the preparation and process of environmental review documents. 
(5)  Preliminary engineering calculations. Information shall be submitted as required by the standard engineering specifications to demonstrate the adequacy of the design of the proposed improvements. This information shall be in conformance with the policies and procedures of the city engineer. 
(6)  Phasing. If the subdivider plans to file multiple final maps on the tentative map, a written notice to this effect shall be filed with the department. Phase lines shall be shown on the map(s). 
(7)  Solar access. Any plans and information relating to solar access may be required to be submitted at the time of the tentative map submittal pursuant to the provisions of this development code. 
(8)  Other reports. Any other data or reports deemed necessary by the planning director or city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 7, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-158. - Primary plat approval. 
(a)  Filing of application. After an application for approval of a plat of a subdivision has been filed, together with two copies of all maps and data, the plan commission shall review the primary plat and give its acceptance or return the plat to the subdivider with suggestions for changes. No application will be considered at a meeting unless it has been filed with the executive secretary of the plan commission at least 30 days before the date of hearing. 
(b)  Public hearing. 
(1)  After the planning department has given acceptance, it shall set a date for a hearing. 
(2)  The planning department shall notify the applicant in writing. 
(3)  The petitioner shall submit a notice for publication in one newspaper of general circulation to be published at least ten days prior to the public hearing and mail notices to all adjacent property owners. The planning director shall maintain file copies of the plat and construction plans when appropriate for public review prior to the hearing. The cost of publication of the notice of hearing shall be met by the applicant. 
(4)  The plan commission shall approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove the primary plat. If the approval is a conditional approval, the plan commission shall state the necessary conditions. If the plat is disapproved, the plan commission shall express the reasons for disapproval. 
(5)  Approval of the primary report shall not constitute approval of the secondary plat. Rather it shall be deemed an expression of approval to the layout submitted on the primary plat as a guide to the preparation of the secondary plat which will be submitted for approval of the plan commission and for recording upon fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations and the conditions of the conditional approval, if any. 
(c)  Standards for approval of primary plats. No primary plat of a proposed subdivision shall be approved by the plan commission unless the applicant proves by clear and convincing evidence that: 
(1)  Definite provision has been made for a water supply system that is sufficient in terms of quantity, dependability, and quality to provide an appropriate supply of water for the type of subdivision proposed; 
(2)  If a public sewage system is proposed, adequate provision has been made for such a system and, if other methods of sewage disposal are proposed, that such systems will comply with federal, state, and local laws and regulations; 
(3)  All areas of the proposed subdivision which may involve soil or topographical conditions presenting hazards or requiring special precautions have been identified by the subdivider and that the proposed uses of these areas are compatible with such conditions; 
(4)  The subdivider has the financial ability to complete the proposed subdivision in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations; 
(5)  The proposed subdivision will not result in the scattered subdivision of land that leaves undeveloped parcels of land lacking urban services between developed parcels; 
(6)  The subdivider has taken every effort to mitigate the impact of the proposed subdivision on public health, safety, and welfare. 
(7)  In addition to the aforementioned standard all subdivisions shall meet site design and improvement standards of article V. 
(d)  Conformance to preexisting regulations. Every primary plat shall conform to existing zoning regulations and subdivision regulations applicable at the time that the proposed primary is submitted for the approval of the plan commission unless the plan commission has taken official action toward amending the applicable zoning and subdivision regulations and the applicant has reason to know of that action. 
(e)  Primary plat. Approval shall be effective for two years from date of approval by the plan commission. The approval shall become null and void unless the subdivider has taken the following steps: 
(1)  Received secondary plat approval for units as proposed in the primary plat; or 
(2)  Renewed the primary plat approval. 
(f)  Renewal of plat. A primary plat shall be considered for a renewal by the plan commission upon request of the subdivider. Prior to the expiration date, the subdivider shall file a request with the plan commission for renewal of the primary plat approval. The plan commission shall review the plat for compliance with current standards, and consider the performance of the subdivider to date. The plan commission shall consider economic trends and other items which may be affecting the viability of the subdivision. To be included, but not limited, are changes in adjacent land uses, extensions or vacations of streets, revisions to zoning of abutting land and other items that may be pertinent. Renewals shall be for a time period of two years. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 8, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 01-02, § 1, 1-2-01) 
Sec. 66-159. - Secondary plat. 
(a)  Application procedure and requirements. 
(1)  The secondary plat may include all or only a part of the primary plat which has received approval and the applicant proposed to record and develop at the time, provided that such portion conforms to all requirements of these regulations. 
(2)  The secondary plat shall be printed in ink on mylar. 
(3)  The original drawing of the secondary plat of a subdivision shall be drawn to a scale of not more than 50 feet to one inch, provided that if the resulting drawing would be over 36 inches in shortest dimension, a scale of 100 feet to one inch may be used. Where necessary, the plat may be on several sheets accompanied by an index showing the entire subdivision. For large subdivisions the secondary plat may be submitted for approval progressively in contiguous sections satisfactory to the planning director. 
(b)  Contents of application. The final plat shall be prepared by an engineer or surveyor licensed in the State of Indiana and shall include the following: 
(1)  Primary control points, approved by the planning director or descriptions and "ties" to such control points, to which all dimensions, angles, bearings, and similar data on the plat shall be referred. 
(2)  Accurate boundary lines, right-of-way lines of streets, easements and other rights-of-way, property lines of residential lots and other sites; with dimensions, bearings and deflection angles, and radii arcs, and central angles of all curves, which provide a survey of the tract, with an error of not more than one foot in 5,000 feet. 
(3)  Name and right-of-way width of each street or other rights-of-way. 
(4)  Accurate metes and bounds description of the boundary. 
(5)  Source of title of the applicant to the land as shown by the last entry in the books of the county recorder. 
(6)  Street lines with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths of feet, with angles to streets, alley lines, and complete curb notes for all curbs included in the plan. 
(7)  Lot lines and dimensions. 
(8)  Accurate locations of any easements and any limitations on such easements. 
(9)  Accurate dimensions for any property to be dedicated or reserved for public, semipublic or community use. 
(10)  Building setback or front yard lines and dimensions. 
(11)  Location, type, material, and size of all monuments and lot markers. 
(12)  Plans and specifications for the improvements required. 
(13)  An accounting in table format of the following improvements as applicable: 
1.  Quantities of storm water inlets, catch basins, manholes and lift stations. 
2.  Linear feet of storm water pipe by size. 
3.  Quantity of sanitary manholes. 
4.  Linear feet of sanitary pipe by size. 
5.  Linear feet of roadway by width with right-of-way width noted. 
6.  Linear feet curbs. 
7.  Quantity of street lights. 
(14)  Restrictions of all types which will run with the land and become covenants in the deeds for the lots. 
(15)  Name of the subdivision and name and address of the owner and the subdivider. 
(16)  Title, north point, scale and date. 
(17)  Certificate by a registered professional engineer or registered land surveyor. 
(18)  Certificate of dedication of streets and other public property. 
(19)  Certificates for approval by the plan commission. 
(20)  Certificate regarding the relation of the parcel to the 100-year floodplain. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 9, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 10-30, § 1, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 66-160. - Secondary plat approval. 
(a)  When the secondary plat is submitted to the plan commission, it shall be accompanied by a notice from the planning director stating that there has been filed and approved with the following: 
(1)  A certificate signed by a registered professional engineer or a registered land surveyor, that all the improvements and installations for the subdivision required for its approval have been made or installed in accordance with specifications, and this certificate shall be accompanied by two sets of as-built prints; or 
(2)  That the subdivider has provided a written schedule of a program of progressive development, previously filed with and approved by the plan commission; and 
(3)  A certificate signed by a registered professional engineer or a registered land surveyor, that all the improvements and installations of the stage of program of progressive development to be entered into by the subdivider have been made or installed in accordance with the specifications and no occupancy permit will be issued until all stages of the program of progressive development are completed and certified to by a registered professional engineer or a registered land surveyor, and shall be accompanied by two sets of "as built" prints; or 
(4)  A bond or letter of credit which shall: 
a.  Run to the common council. 
b.  Be 125 percent of the amount determined by the public works department, and approved by the plan commission to be sufficient to complete the improvements and installations in compliance with this chapter and a schedule of progressive development approved by the plan commission. 
c.  Be with surety satisfactory to the plan commission. 
d.  Specify the time for the completion of the improvements and installations to be one year, unless otherwise extended by the board of works. Each extension shall be for one year. However, any bond or letter of credit may not expire unless the issuer of the bond or letter of credit provides 60-day notice, before expiration to the board of works and the board of works approves the expiration. 
e.  If the bond or letter of credit is extended by the board of works, the bond or letter of credit shall increase in five percent increments for each extension, unless the public works department determines the bond or letter of credit is sufficient to complete the improvements and installations in compliance with this chapter. If the public works department determines the bond or letter of credit is insufficient, then the public works department shall determine an amount to complete the improvements and installations in compliance with this chapter. 
(5)  This bond shall not be released or an occupancy permit issued until all improvements and installations for the subdivision shall be certified to by a registered professional engineer or a registered land surveyor, as being completed in accordance with the specifications and this certificate shall be accompanied by two sets of "as built" prints. 
(b)  Upon completion of the improvements and installations required of a subdivider for the approval of secondary plat, and prior to the acceptance thereof for public maintenance by the board of works, the subdivider shall provide a two-year maintenance bond which shall: 
(1)  Run to and be in favor of the City of Portage. 
(2)  Be 25 percent of the costs of the public improvements to assure and guarantee the maintenance of all improvements and installations during such two-year period. However, any bond or letter of credit may not expire unless the issuer of the bond or letter of credit provides 60-day notice, before expiration to the board of works and the board of works approves the expiration. 
(3)  Commence upon acceptance of the improvements by the board of public works and safety as applicable. 
(4)  Warrant the workmanship and all materials used in the construction, installation and completion of such improvements and installations to be of good quality and have been constructed and completed in a workmanlike manner in accordance with the standards, specifications and requirements of this chapter and the satisfactory plans and specifications therefor. 
(5)  Provide that for a period of two years after such installations and improvements have been completed or are accepted for public maintenance by any appropriate governmental unit or agency thereof, the subdivider will at his own expense make all repairs to such improvements and installations, or the foundations thereof, which may become necessary by reason of improper workmanship or materials, with such maintenance not to include any damage to such improvements and installations resulting from forces or circumstances beyond the control of such subdivider or occasioned by the inadequacy of the standards, specifications or requirements of this chapter. 
(6)  If the original two-year maintenance bond, or any extension, is set to expire and the installations and improvements have not yet been completed, or two years has not expired since the public improvements have been accepted for public maintenance, the subdividers shall appear before the board of works for permission of an extension. If an extension is granted, the bond shall be in an amount not less than 25 percent of the costs of the public improvements, but may be increased in five percent increments, to ensure and guarantee the maintenance of all improvements and installations during the extension, unless the public works department determines the bond or letter of credit is insufficient to complete the improvements and installations in compliance with this chapter. 
(c)  The plan commission shall approve, or disapprove within 30 days from the official submission date for the secondary subdivision plat. 
(1)  If the plan commission approves, it shall affix the plan commission's seal upon the plat, together with the certifying signature of its president and secretary. If it disapproves, it shall set forth the reasons for such disapproval in its own records and provide the applicant with a copy. 
(2)  If the plan commission disapproves the secondary plat, the applicant may appeal to the common council in the manner prescribed in article IV, division 9. 
(d)  Within one year from the date of the plan commission secondary plat approval, the secondary plat shall be recorded in the office of the county recorder by the subdivider. The subdivider shall provide the plan commission office with a reproducible quality mylar of the secondary plat, complete with the tax stamp from the office of the county auditor, and the recording stamp, plus all file data from the office of the county recorder. Two copies of the recorded plat shall be provided to the plan commission office, plus a copy shall be given to each public utility serving the area in the city. A copy shall be provided to the township assessor for his records. If the plat is not recorded within one year from the date of approval, it shall become null and void. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 10, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 01-12, § 1, 3-6-01; Ord. No. 10-38, §§ 1-5, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 66-161. - Assurance of completion of improvements. 
(a)  Applicability. As provided in this chapter, the subdivider has the option of either installing all required public improvements prior to the signing of the final plat, or in lieu of installation, posting a bond or other security. The following regulations are to assure the satisfactory completion of all improvements, whether installed before or after the final plat has been signed and recorded. 
(b)  Temporary improvements. The plan commission may require that temporary facilities be constructed until such time as permanent public improvements can be completed. In such case, the subdivider shall build and pay all costs for temporary improvements and shall maintain them until completion of permanent improvement or for the period specified by the commission. Prior to construction of any temporary facility or improvement, the subdivider shall file with the city a separate bond, suitable to the city, which shall ensure that the temporary facilities will be properly constructed, maintained, and removed. 
(c)  Failure to complete improvements. In those cases where a performance bond has been posted but the required improvements have not been installed within the terms of such performance bond, the city may declare the subdivider to be in default and require that all the improvements be installed regardless of the extent of the building development at the time the subdivider is declared to be in default. 
(d)  Inspection of completed improvements. 
(1)  The plan commission shall provide for periodic inspection of required improvements by the city engineer during construction to ensure their satisfactory completion. 
(2)  If the city engineer finds upon inspection that any of the required improvements have not been constructed in accordance with: 
a.  The construction standards and specifications required by article V of this chapter, 
b.  The approved final plat, or 
c.  The approved construction plans, the subdivider shall correct any errors immediately upon notification. Where the completion of improvements is covered by a performance bond, the subdivider and the bonding company shall be separately and jointly liable for completing the improvement according to specifications. 
(e)  Acceptance of dedication offers. 
(1)  General requirements. 
a.  Acceptance of formal offers of dedication of streets, public areas, and easements shall be by official action of the board of works. 
b.  The approval by the plan commission of a subdivision plat shall not be deemed to constitute or imply the acceptance by the city of any street, easement, or other public areas shown on said plat. 
(2)  Release or reduction of performance bond or other security. 
a.  The board of works shall not accept dedication of required improvements, nor release nor reduce a performance bond or other security, except in accordance with the following: 
1.  The city engineer shall submit a certificate stating that all required improvements have been satisfactorily completed; 
2.  The subdivider's engineer shall submit a certificate to the city engineer stating that the layout of all public improvements are in accordance with construction plans for the subdivision, and that the improvements have been completed, are ready for dedication to the city and are free and clear of any and all liens and encumbrances. 
3.  The subdivider shall submit as-built construction plans to the department of planning and development as follows: 
(i)  One copy on reproducible mylar, 
(ii)  Three copies on paper, and 
(iii)  One electronic copy in (.dwg) or other format compatible with Autocadd software. 
4.  The subdivider shall file a maintenance bond and/or agreement with board of works in an amount considered adequate by the engineer of the appropriate jurisdiction, in order to assure the satisfactory condition of the required improvements. 
5.  A performance bond or other security may be reduced only by the board of public works upon actual dedication of public improvements, and then only to an amount sufficient to complete the improvements and installations in compliance with this chapter at the time of the reduction. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 11, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 10-38, §§ 6, 7, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 66-162. - Assurance of maintenance. 
(a)  General requirement. The subdivider shall be required to maintain all improvements on the subdivided areas, including all lot improvements on the individual subdivided lots, for a period of two years after the date of their acceptance and dedication by the board of works. Improvements covered by the maintenance bond shall include but not be limited to: streets to minimum specifications of the applicable jurisdiction at the end of such period; sanitary sewers, storm sewers, and water lines, including lift stations, pumps, motors, connections and main lines installed in the subdivision; sidewalks, shoulders, side slopes, ditches, street signs, street lights and fire hydrants. 
(b)  Temporary maintenance. The plan commission may require the subdivider to provide for traffic control on streets and remove snow from streets and sidewalks until acceptance and dedication of said improvements by the board of works. 
(c)  Posting of maintenance bond and/or agreement. The subdivider shall be required to file a maintenance bond and/or agreement with the board of public works and safety, and prior to dedication in order to assure the satisfactory condition of the required improvements, as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 12, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 01-12, § 2, 3-6-01; Ord. No. 10-38, § 8, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 66-163. - Deferral or waiver of improvements. 
(a)  General conditions. The plan commission may defer or waive at the time of final approval, subject to appropriate conditions in the specific case, the provisions of any or all such improvements as, in its judgment, are not required to secure the public health, safety, and general welfare, or which are inappropriate because of inadequacy or lack of connecting facilities. 
(b)  Assurance for future completion. Whenever the plan commission considers it necessary to defer the construction of any improvement required herein because of incompatible grades, future planning, inadequate or lack of connecting facilities, or for other reasons, the subdivider shall pay his share of the costs of the future improvements to the city prior to signing of the final subdivision plat, or the subdivider may post a bond or agreement ensuring completion of said improvements upon demand of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 13, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-164. - Submission, signing and recordation of subdivision plat. 
(a)  Submission and review. Subsequent to the approval of the of the secondary plat by the plan commission, 11 paper copies of the construction plans, and one copy of the original of the subdivision plat on mylar. A check payable to the county clerk and recorder in the amount of the current filing fee shall be provided. No final approval shall be endorsed on the plat until a review has indicated that all requirements of the resolution have been met. 
(b)  Official certificates and deeds. The following form shall be used in final plats: 
Plan Commission Certificate 
    Under authority provided by IC 36-7 and an ordinance adopted by the common council of Portage, Indiana, this plat was given approval by the City of Portage as follows:

(c)  General requirement. 
(1)  Within 30 days after the approval of the secondary plat by the plan commission, the plat shall be signed by the president of the plan commission and planning director. 
(2)  Within ten days after the plat has been signed, said plat, along with other such legal documents as shall be required to be recorded, shall be filed with the Porter County Recorder, and if not so filed, shall have no validity and shall not be recorded without recertification by the city clerk and reapproval by the plan commission. 
(d)  Conditions for signing and recordation of plats. 
(1)  When a subdivision improvement agreement and security are required, the president of the plan commission and the secretary shall endorse approval on the final plat only after the agreement and security have been approved by the plan commission, and all the conditions of the resolution pertaining to the final plat have been satisfied. 
(2)  When installation of improvements is required prior to recordation of the final plat, the president of the plan commission and planning director shall endorse approval on the final plat only after all conditions of the resolution have been satisfied and all improvements satisfactorily completed. There shall be written evidence that the required public facilities have been installed in a manner satisfactory to the city as shown by a certificate signed by the city engineer stating that the necessary dedication of public lands and improvements has been accomplished. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 14, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-165. - Expiration. 
(a)  The approval or conditional approval of a secondary plat shall expire one year following approval by the plan commission. However, the plat may be extended pursuant to the requirements of section 66-166, extensions. 
(b)  Expiration of an approved or conditionally approved preliminary map shall terminate all proceedings and no final map or parcel map of all or any portion of the real property included within the tentative map shall be filed without first processing a new preliminary map. The final map or parcel map documents submitted for filing must be accepted as adequate for approval by the plan commission prior to the expired date. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 15, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-166. - Extensions. 
(a)  Request by subdivider. The subdivider may request an extension of the expiration date of the approved or conditionally approved preliminary map by written application to the department. The application shall be filed not less than 30 days before the map is to expire and shall state the reasons for the extension. The subdivider shall be solely responsible for filing the application. 
(b)  Plan commission action. The planning director shall review the request and submit the application for the extension, together with a report to the plan commission for approval, conditional approval, or denial at the next regularly scheduled plan commission meeting. A copy of the planning director's report and recommendation shall be forwarded to the subdivider prior to the meeting on extension. In approving, conditionally approving, or denying the request for extension, the plan commission shall make findings supporting its decision. The subdivider shall pay any increase in unpaid applicable development fees which have occurred since the date of the approval or conditional approval of the preliminary map. 
(c)  Conditions of approval. In granting an extension, new conditions or exactions may be imposed and existing conditions may be revised. 
(d)  Time limit of extensions. The time at which the preliminary map expires may be extended by the plan commission for a period not exceeding a total of three years. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 16, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-167. - Amendments to plats. 
(a)  Amendments to the preliminary map conditions of approval shall be presented to the plan commission for its approval. 
(b)  An applicant may not propose more than two amendments to any primary plat. 
(c)  Processing shall comply with the provisions for processing a preliminary map as contained in this chapter. Any approved amendment shall not alter the expiration date of the preliminary map. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 4, Div. 1, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 66-168-66-180. - Reserved.
