ARTICLE V. - SITE DESIGN AND IMPROVEMENT STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-331. - Applicability. 
    Except as otherwise provided below, the site design and improvement standards in this article are required for all subdivisions, planned developments, and any other new development or redevelopment of a site upon which such improvements do not currently exist. Exemptions from these requirements may be granted by variance or, in the case of the improvement standards from article V of this chapter, by a variance of the plan commission subject to article IV, division 1, section 66-155. Existing improvements that do not meet the standards of this article shall be subject to article IX, nonconformities. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 1, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-332. - Conformity with other regulations. 
(a)  In addition to the requirements established in these regulations, the improvement of land shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Applicable statutory provisions; 
(2)  Applicable provisions of this unified development chapter and all other laws of the applicable jurisdictions; 
(3)  The official comprehensive master plan and capital improvements program of the applicable jurisdictions, including all streets, trails, and parks shown on any official map; 
(4)  The rules and regulations of the state board of health, the department of natural resources, other appropriate state agencies and federal agencies; 
(5)  Applicable planning and regulatory guidelines, including access control or driveway manuals, parking and traffic control ordinances, and other applicable guides published by the state or local governmental units; 
(6)  The current edition of the "Indiana Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices" for installation of traffic control devices; and 
(7)  The rules of the Indiana Department of Transportation if the development or any lot contained therein abuts a state highway. 
(b)  To assure compliance with good engineering practice, the contractor, or developer is required to follow the latest issue of the "Indiana Department of Transportation Standard Specifications" for material and construction control, except when different specifications are: 1) explicitly described in these regulations, or 2) adopted by the engineer of appropriate jurisdiction and approved by all appropriate boards, commissions, agencies, and officials of the city or county. 
(c)  Plat approval may be withheld if a subdivision is not in conformity with the above laws, regulations, guidelines, and policies, the regulations of this article, or the purposes of these regulations as established in article I of this unified development chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 1, § 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-333. - Political and jurisdictional boundaries. 
    To eliminate potential jurisdictional disputes and to facilitate effective coordination and control of development, the plan commission shall be guided by the following policy: 
(1)  Whenever access to the development is required across land in another local government, the commission shall request assurance from that local governmental attorney that access is legally established, and from the local governmental engineer that the access road is adequately improved, or that a performance bond has been duly executed and is sufficient in amount to assure the construction of the access road. 
(2)  Lot lines shall be laid out so as not to cross boundary lines between adjacent units of local government which have separate governing bodies for the purpose of regulation and control of land use and development, as well as for tax purposes. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 1, § 3, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-334. - Character of land suitable for development. 
    Land that the plan commission finds to be unsuitable for subdivision or development due to flooding, improper drainage, steep slopes, rock formations, adverse earth formations or topography, utility easements, or other features that will reasonably be harmful to the safety, health, and general welfare of the present or future inhabitants of the subdivision and/or its surrounding areas, shall not be subdivided or developed unless adequate methods are formulated by the developer and approved by the plan commission, upon recommendation of the city engineer, to solve the problems created by the unsuitable land conditions. Such land shall be set aside for uses as shall not involve any danger to public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 1, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-335. - Adequate public facilities. 
    No primary plat shall be approved unless the plan commission determines that public facilities will be adequate to support and service the area of the proposed subdivision. The applicant shall, at the request of the plan commission, submit sufficient information and data on the proposed subdivision to demonstrate the expected impact on and use of public facilities by possible uses of said subdivision. Public facilities and services to be examined for adequacy will include roads, sewerage, and water service. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 1, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 66-336-66-340. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRINCIPLES AND STANDARDS OF DESIGN[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference- Construction of streets, etc., § 74-86 et seq. 

Sec. 66-341. - Conformity generally. 
(a)  The secondary plat of the subdivision shall conform to the principles and standards of design described in this division. In addition to the requirements established in these regulations, the improvement of land shall comply with all applicable statutory provisions, the local government building and housing codes, comprehensive plan, the land use plan, public utilities plan, and capital improvements program, including all streets, drainage systems, and parks shown on the official land use map; any rules of the health department and/or appropriate state or substate agencies, and the rules of the department of transportation if the subdivision or any lot contained therein abuts a state highway or connecting street. 
(b)  Plat approval may be withheld if a subdivision is not in conformity with the above laws, regulations, guidelines, and policies, the regulations of this article, or the purposes of these regulations as established in article I of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-342. - Streets and access. 
(a)  The street and alley layout shall provide access to all lots and parcels of land within the subdivision, and where streets cross other streets, jogs shall not be created. 
(b)  Proposed streets shall be adjusted to the contour of the land so as to produce usable lots and streets of reasonable gradient. 
(c)  Certain proposed streets, where appropriate, shall be extended to the boundary line of the tract to be subdivided so as to provide for normal circulation of traffic within the vicinity. 
(d)  Wherever there exists a dedicated or platted portion of a street or alley adjacent to the proposed subdivision, the remainder of the street or alley to the prescribed width shall be platted within the proposed subdivision. 
(e)  Widths of arterial streets and feeder streets shall conform to the width specified in the official thoroughfare plan. 
(f)  The minimum right-of-way of residential streets, marginal access streets or cul-de-sacs, shall be 50 feet. All cul-de-sacs shall terminate in a circular right-of-way with a minimum diameter of 100 feet, or other arrangement for the turning of all vehicles conveniently within the right-of-way. 
(g)  Alleys shall be discouraged in residential districts but should be included in commercial and industrial areas where needed for loading and unloading for access purposes and, where platted, shall be at least 20 feet in width. 
(h)  The centerlines of streets should intersect as nearly at right angles as possible. 
(i)  At intersections of alleys and streets, property line corners shall be rounded by arcs with at least 25 feet radii or by chords of such arcs. 
(j)  At intersections of streets the property line corners shall be rounded by arcs with radii of not less than 25 feet, or by chords of such arcs. 
(k)  If the smaller of the intersection of two streets is less than 60 degrees, the radius of the arc at the intersection of property lines shall be increased as deemed advisable by the plan commission. 
(l)  Intersections of more than two streets at one point shall be avoided. 
(m)  Where parkways or special types of streets are involved, the plan commission may apply special standards to be followed in their design. 
(n)  Whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a railroad right-of-way or a highway designated as a limited access highway by the appropriate highway authorities, provision shall be made for a marginal access street, or a parallel street at a distance acceptable for the appropriate use of the land between the highway or railroad and such streets. 
(o)  Horizontal visibility on curved streets and vertical visibility on all streets must be maintained along the centerlines as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets: 500 feet; 
(2)  Feeder streets and parkways: 300 feet; and 
(3)  Residential streets: 150 feet. 
(p)  Curvature measured along the centerline shall have a minimum radius as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets: 500 feet; 
(2)  Feeder and parkways: 300 feet; and 
(3)  Residential streets: 200 feet. 
(q)  Between reversed curves on arterial streets there shall be a tangent of not less than 100 feet and on feeder and residential streets such tangent shall not be less than 40 feet. 
(r)  Maximum grades for streets shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets, not greater than six percent; and 
(2)  Feeder and residential streets and alleys, not greater than eight percent. 
(s)  The grade of any street gutter line shall not be less than 0.4 percent. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-343. - Blocks. 
(a)  Blocks shall not exceed 1,250 feet in length nor be less than 400 feet in length. 
(b)  Blocks shall be of sufficient width to permit two tiers of lots of appropriate depth except where an interior street parallels a limited access highway or an arterial street or railroad right-of-way. 
(c)  In long blocks the plan commission may require the reservation of an easement through the block to accommodate utilities, drainage facilities, or pedestrian traffic. Pedestrian ways or crosswalks, not less than ten feet wide, may be required by the plan commission through the center of blocks more than 600 feet long where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation, or other community facilities. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 3, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-344. - Lots. 
(a)  Lot arrangement. The lot arrangement shall be such that there will be no foreseeable difficulties, for reasons of topography or other conditions, in securing building permits to build on all lots in compliance with this chapter and health regulations, in providing driveway access to buildings on the lots from an approved street, or in providing service to public sanitary sewer or approved sanitary disposal facilities. All lots shall abut on a street. 
(b)  Lot dimension. 
(1)  No lot or parcel shall be used for any residential use unless such lot abuts a public street for at least 60 percent of the lot width prescribed for the district in which the lot is located. 
(2)  Corner residential lots shall be wider than normal in order to permit appropriate setbacks from both streets and the erection of buildings. 
(3)  Where lots are more than double the minimum required area for the zoning district, the plan commission may require that those lots be arranged so as to allow further subdivision and the opening of future streets where they would be necessary to serve potential lots, all in compliance with this chapter. 
(4)  Widths and areas of lots shall be not less than that provided in article VII for the district in which the subdivision is located. 
(5)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for business, commercial, or industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for off-street parking and loading facilities required for the type of use and development contemplated, as established in this chapter. 
(c)  Lot lines. 
(1)  Side lines of lots shall be of approximately right angles to straight streets and on radial lines on curved streets. Some variation from this rule is permissible, but pointed or very irregular lots should be avoided. 
(d)  Double frontage lots and access to lots. 
(1)  Double frontage lots should not be platted, except that where desired along arterial streets, lots may face on an interior street and back on such thoroughfares. In that event a planting strip for a screen of at least 20 feet in width shall be provided along the back of the lot. Access may not be provided onto the arterials 
(2)  Lots with less than 200 feet shall not, in general, derive access exclusively from an arterial. Where driveway access from an arterial may be necessary for several adjoining lots, the plan commission may require that such lots be served by a combined access drive in order to limit traffic hazards on the street. Driveways should be designed and arranged so as to avoid requiring vehicles to back into traffic on arterials. 
(e)  Waterbodies and watercourses. If a tract being subdivided contains a water body or portion thereof, lot lines shall be drawn to distribute ownership of the water body among adjacent lots. The plan commission may approve an alternative plan whereby the ownership of and responsibility for safe maintenance of the water body is so placed that it will not become a local government responsibility. No portion of the minimum area of lot required under this chapter may be satisfied by land that is under water. 
(f)  Easements. Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least 15 feet wide except as modified by section 66-345(a)(1). Easements for streetlights shall be located as approved by the common council. Easements for sidewalks, bike or recreational trails shall be approved by the plan commission. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-345. - Utilities and easements. 
(a)  All public improvements and required easements shall be extended through the parcel on which new development is proposed. Proper usable, clear and graded easements shall be provided by the developer at the perimeter and within the development as required for proper installation and maintenance of streets, storm and sanitary sewers, drainage facilities, water mains, gas, electric, and telecommunications lines. These shall be constructed through new development to promote the logical extension of public infrastructure. The city may require the applicant of a subdivision to extend off-site improvements to reach the subdivision or oversize required public facilities to serve anticipated future development as a condition of plat approval. 
(1)  Easements shall be a minimum of 15 feet in width where located along a perimeter of a development, with a 12-foot easement width for each lot abutting another tier of lots. 
(2)  Easements for all other utilities shall be as required by the proper utility or board. Written confirmation of utilities involved as to the acceptability of easements for locations and widths shall be supplied to the plan commission by the developer at the time of preliminary plat hearing. 
(b)  In all new commercial, residential and industrial developments, utility facilities shall be designed and constructed for underground distribution and service. 
(c)  When it is the desire of the developer and utility to have electric and telephone lines placed in front of lots, those lines shall be located in easements adjacent and in addition to the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-346. - Building setback lines. 
    Building setback lines shall be as provided in article VII of this chapter. Building setback lines shall be shown on plats as dotted or dashed lines and wherever possible such lines shall be identified with the abbreviation S.B.L. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 6, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-347. - Street address code. 
    The final plat shall show the street address of each lot. The designer of the subdivision shall consult with the executive secretary of the plan commission to be sure that the subdivision numbering conforms to the official numbering system. The street address shall be shown on the street right-of-way adjacent to the front lot line and the number shall be in parentheses. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 2, § 7, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 66-348-66-360. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS OF IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 66-361. - Conformity with division. 
    The final plat of the subdivision shall conform to the standards of improvements described in this division. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-362. - Monuments and markers. 
(a)  Monuments and markers shall be placed so that the center of the pipe or marked point shall coincide exactly with the intersection of lines to be marked, and shall be set so that the top of the monument or marker is even with the finished grade. 
(b)  Monuments shall be set: 
(1)  At the intersection of all lines forming angles in the boundary of the subdivision; and 
(2)  At the intersection of street property lines. 
(3)  At street intersections and points of tangency along street center lines. 
(c)  Markers shall be set at all other lot corners not established by a monument. 
(d)  Monuments shall consist of metal bars not less than one-half inch in diameter and 30 inches in length, encased in a concrete cylinder at least four inches in diameter and 30 inches in depth. 
(e)  Markers shall consist of iron pipes or steel bars at least 16 inches long, and not less than one-half inch in diameter. 
(f)  All monuments and markets shall be properly set, as required by 1AC 865 Rule 12, prior to the time the plan commission recommends approval of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-363. - Streets. 
(a)  Streets, and alleys where provided, shall be completed to grades shown on plans, profiles, and cross sections provided by the subdivider and prepared by a registered engineer or land surveyor and so approved by the plan commission. 
(b)  Surfacing; cross section. 
(1)  Concrete curb and gutter shall be provided. 
(2)  Minimum surface grades shall be as follows: 
a.  Curb and gutter: 40 percent. 
b.  Paved ditches: 10 percent. 
c.  Earth ditches: 75 percent. 
(3)  Shoulders and side slopes of ditches where curb and gutter are not required shall be as follows: 
a.  Shoulder: Turf at least four feet wide. 
b.  Ditch backslope: Maximum slope of 3:1. 
c.  Ditch foreslope: Maximum slope of 4:1. 
d.  Bottom: Flat, minimum two feet wide. 
e.  In addition, erosion control shall be provided as directed by the city engineer. 
(c)  The street surface shall be of Portland cement concrete or a flexible pavement and shall be constructed in accordance with the design characteristics at least equal to those given below: 
_____

(d)  Upon application to the board of public works and safety, and with supporting data from field tests, alternate or lesser pavement thickness may be approved. Based upon experience in the vicinity of a proposed street and with supporting data from field tests, the board of public works and safety may require a pavement thickness greater than those specified in this division, and/or a subgrade drainage system. 
(e)  Prior to placing the street and alley surfaces, adequate subsurface drainage for the street shall be provided by the subdivider. Subsurface drainage pipe, when required, shall be coated corrugated pipe or a similar type not less than 12 inches in diameter approved by the plan commission. Upon the completion of the street and alley improvements, plans and profiles as built shall be filed with the plan commission. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 3, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-364. - Sanitary sewers. 
(a)  The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete sanitary sewer system, which shall connect with an existing approved sanitary sewer outlet. 
(b)  The plans for the installation of a sanitary sewer system shall be provided by the subdivider and approved by the Indiana Department of Environmental Management (IDEM) and the Portage Water Reclamation Board. Upon completion of the sanitary sewer installation, the plans for such system as built shall be filed with the Portage Water Reclamation Board. 
(c)  In this section on sewers, and in section 66-365 on water, the phrase "the subdivider shall provide" shall be interpreted to mean that the subdivider shall install the referenced facility. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-365. - Water. 
(a)  The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete water main supply system, which shall be connected to an existing approved municipal or community water supply. 
(1)  The developer shall install adequate water facilities (including fire hydrants) subject to the specifications of state or local authorities. All water mains shall be at least eight inches in diameter. 
(2)  The location of all fire hydrants, all water supply improvements and the boundary lines of proposed districts, indicated all improvements proposed to be served, shall be shown on the primary plat, and the cost of installing same shall be borne by the developer and included in the subdivision improvement agreement and security to be furnished by the developer. 
(b)  The plans for the installation of a water main supply system shall be provided by the subdivider and approved by IDEM. Upon completion of the water supply installation, plans for such system as built shall be filed with the plan commission. 
(c)  Fire hydrants shall be provided where city water supply is available. Fire hydrants shall be spaced no more than 800 feet part along public streets and also shall be no more than 800 feet from any residential structure. Fire hydrants and water mains placed on private property shall be located within dedicated easements along driveways or entrance roads and be accessible to fire department vehicles. All fire hydrants installed on private property shall be the responsibility of the developer. If said developer transfers ownership of the premises prior to construction of a structure on the premises, he shall inform the property owner of the above requirement. Adequate water supply as determined by the city engineer shall be provided to all fire hydrants. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-366. - Storm drainage. 
(a)  Purpose. These stormwater drainage regulations are intended to minimize off-site water runoff, increase on-site infiltration, encourage natural filtration functions, stimulate natural drainage systems, and minimize off-site discharge of pollutants. Stormwater shall be managed by the best and most appropriate technology and environmentally-sound site-planning and engineering techniques, which may include combined detention facilities, porous paving and piping, and swales; as well as traditional retention and detention facilities and storm sewers. The following criteria shall be used in designing and evaluating the drainage system. 
(b)  General requirements. 
(1)  The plan commission shall not recommend for approval any plat of subdivision that does not make adequate provision for storm and flood water runoff channels or basins. The applicant may be required by the plan commission to carry away by pipe or open ditch any spring or surface water that may exist either previously to, or as a result of the subdivision. 
(2)  The stormwater drainage system shall be separate and independent of any sanitary sewer system. 
(3)  Surface water drainage patterns shall be shown for each and every lot and block. 
(c)  Required public sewers. 
(1)  Accessibility to public storm sewers. 
a.  The applicant shall install storm sewer facilities, or if no outlets are within a reasonable distance, adequate provision shall be made for the disposal of stormwaters, subject to the specifications of the stormwater management board. However, in subdivisions containing lots less than 15,000 square feet in area and in business and industrial districts, underground storm sewer systems shall be constructed throughout the subdivisions and be conducted to an approved out-fall. Inspection of facilities shall be conducted by the city engineer. 
(2)  Design of public sewers. Storm sewers shall be designed in keeping with the requirement of the stormwater management board. 
(d)  Dedication of drainage easements. 
(1)  General requirements. When a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially to the lines of such watercourse, and of such width and construction as will be adequate for the purpose. Wherever possible, it is desirable that the drainage be maintained by an open channel with landscaped banks and adequate width for maximum potential volume of flow. 
(2)  Drainage easements. 
a.  Where topography or other conditions are such as to make impractical the inclusion of drainage facilities within road rights-of-way, perpetual, unobstructed easements at least 15 feet in width for drainage facilities shall be provided across property outside the road lines and with satisfactory access to the road. Easements shall be indicated on the plat. Drainage easements shall extend from the road to a natural watercourse or to other drainage facilities. 
b.  When a proposed drainage system will carry water across private land outside the subdivision, appropriate drainage rights must be secured and indicated on the plat. 
c.  The applicant shall dedicate, either in fee or by a drainage or conservation easement, land on both sides of existing watercourses to a distance to be determined by the planning commission. 
d.  Low-lying lands along watercourses subject to flooding or overflowing during storm periods, whether or not included in areas for dedication, shall be preserved and retained in their natural state as drainage ways. Such land or lands subject to periodic flooding shall not be computed in determining the number of lots to be utilized for average density procedures nor for computing the area requirement of any lot. 
e.  Structures shall not be permitted in the drainage easement. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 6, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 01-50, § 1a, 10-2-01) 
Sec. 66-367. - Sidewalks, bike trails and other linkages. 
    Sidewalks and other appropriate linkages are required in all subdivisions and will be provided by the developer before any certificate of occupancy permit shall be issued: 
(1)  Required improvements. 
a.  Sidewalks shall be included within the dedicated nonpavement right of way in a manner approved by the city engineer. 
b.  Curbs shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete and shall conform with the adopted city standards maintained by the city engineer. 
(2)  Pedestrian access. The plan commission may require, in order to facilitate pedestrian access from the roads to schools, parks, playgrounds, or other nearby roads, perpetual unobstructed easements at least ten feet in width. Easements shall be indicated on the plat. 
(3)  Bicycle, trails and other easements. The plan commission may require other easements to facilitate connections between subdivisions. Such easements shall be ten feet in width, perpetual and unobstructed. Such easements shall be provided where the subdivision lies in an area indicated for public bike trails, other recreational trails, or where such easement will facilitate the safe and efficient transportation of persons and goods from one area of the city to another. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 7, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-368. - Street signs. 
    The subdivider shall reimburse the city for the cost of materials for the installation of standard city street signs at all intersections of all streets. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 8, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-369. - Street lights and fire hydrants. 
(a)  The developer/subdivider shall provide, as part of the subdivision improvements, street lights to conform to the standards established by the board of public works and safety. 
(b)  Each street light location and the type shall be preliminarily approved by the city engineer and each fire hydrant location shall be preliminarily approved by the fire chief. 
(c)  The street light locations and fire hydrant locations shall be shown on the construction drawings and a final approval of each item is to be made by the board of public works and safety at the time of the secondary plat approval of the construction drawings for such subdivision. 
(d)  The subdivider shall enter into an agreement with the board of public works and safety, whereby guarantee is made for payment of rental fees for fire hydrants and street lights for a two-year period after the installation of such improvements. At the time of approval of final construction drawings, the subdivider shall deposit with the city, a maintenance bond in a sum sufficient to cover the costs of such improvements for two years, under the utility rate schedule then existing for such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 9, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 66-370. - Preservation of existing natural features and amenities. 
    Reasonable features that would add value to residential development or to the local government as a whole as herein defined, such as trees, watercourses and falls, beaches, historic spots, and similar irreplaceable assets, shall be preserved in the design of the subdivision. No trees shall be removed from any subdivision nor any change of grade of the land effected until approval of the primary plat has been granted. All reasonable features and trees on the plat required to be retained shall be preserved. The sketch plat shall show the number and location of reasonable features and tress as required by these regulations. 
(1)  Shade trees planted by developer. 
a.  As a requirement of subdivision approval the applicant shall plant shade trees on the property of the subdivision. Such trees are to be planted within five feet of the right-of-way of the road or roads within and abutting the subdivision, or, at the discretion of the plan commission, within the right-of-way of such roads. One tree shall be planted for every 40 feet of frontage along each road unless the plan commission shall grant a waiver. The waiver shall be granted only if there are trees growing along the right-of-way or on the abutting property which, in the opinion of the plan commission, comply with these regulations. 
b.  New trees to be provided shall have a minimum trunk diameter (measured 12 inches above ground level) of not less than two inches. Only Oak, Honey Locust, Hard Maples, Ginkgo, or other long-lived shade trees acceptable to the plan commission, shall be planted. 
(Ord. No. 99-37, Art. 5, Div. 3, § 10, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 66-371-66-390. - Reserved.

Sec. 66-562. - Filing fees required. 
(a)  Applications and petitions filed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be accompanied by the fees hereinafter specified: 
(1)  For each petition for approval of a subdivision, a fee as set forth below to be paid to and collected by the clerk-treasurer, the receipt for which shall accompany the petition: 
i.  Petition for primary plat approval, $100.00 plus $5.00 per lot, and 
ii.  Petition for secondary plat approval, $50.00, plus $1.00 per lot. 
The petitioner is required to assume the cost of public notice and notice to interested persons. 
(2)  For each petition for vacation of a plat/easement/public right-of-way, a fee of $100.00, to be paid to and collected by the clerk-treasurer, the receipt for which shall accompany the petition. The petitioner is required to assume the cost of public notice and notice to interested persons. 
(3)  For each miscellaneous petition requiring a public hearing, a fee of $50.00 and for each miscellaneous petition not requiring a public hearing, a fee of $25.00, to be paid to and collected by the clerk-treasurer, the receipt for which shall accompany the petition. 
(b)  No part of any filing fee paid pursuant to this section shall be returnable to the applicant or petitioner. 
(Code 1985, § 21-25-1; Ord. No. 92-34, § 1(A), (B), (E)-(L), 8-10-92; Ord. No. 99-64, § 1, 12-7-99; Ord. No. 05-43, § 1, 8-2-05) 
Note- See the editor's note to ch. 90. 
Sec. 66-563. - Special meeting fee. 
    In addition to the other fees required by this division, a special meeting fee as set forth below shall be paid by the petitioner for any special meeting of the plan commission or board of zoning appeals scheduled at the request of the petitioner: 
(a)  Plan commission: $675.00 and 
[(b)]  Board of zoning appeals: $625.00 
    The special meeting fee shall be paid to and collected by the clerk-treasurer, the receipt for which shall accompany the request for the special meeting. A special meeting called by the plan commission or board of zoning appeals on their own initiative will be held at no charge to the petitioner. 
(Ord. No. 05-43, § 2, 8-2-05)

Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, adopted Dec. 4, 2012, repealed former §§ 70-1, 70-51-70-56, 70-66-70-70, 70-81-70-84, and 70-96-70-100, and enacted new sections as set out herein. The former sections derived from §§ 7-1-1-7-1-9 and 7-1-11-7-1-15 of the 1985 Code; Ord. No. 87-15, §§ 1-5, adopted June 2, 1987; Ord. No. 90-23, § 1(7-1-22-7-1-23), adopted May 1, 1990; Ord. No. 91-57, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1991; Ord. No. 92-19, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 2, 1992; Ord. No. 93-43, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1993; Ord. No. 99-58, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 1999; Ord. No. 01-29, § 1, adopted June 5, 2001; Ord. No. 08-59, § 1, adopted Sept. 9, 2008; and Ord. No. 08-60, § 1, adopted Oct. 7, 2008. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 42; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Regulation of solid waste incineration, IC 13-7-21-1 et seq.; miscellaneous solid waste provisions, IC 13-7-22-1 et seq.; solid waste disposal, IC 36-9-30-1 et seq.; collection and disposal of waste, local option, IC 36-9-33-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, and other combustible materials in homes, stores, institutions, and industries for the purpose of cooking, heating and disposing of incinerated combustible rubbish. 
    City owned tote cart means a wheeled container with engraved city logos on the side of the container. 
    City approved tote cart means a wheeled container designed to be dumped or emptied by both semi- automated and fully-automated truck equipment systems. 
    Combustible rubbish means waste material capable of being burned without the use of auxiliary fuel. Such rubbish shall include paper, rags, excelsior, wood, bedding, straw, leather, boxes, cartons, etc. 
    Commercial garbage or trash means garbage or trash derived from the operation of business stores, hotels, or office buildings, and not the result of the ordinary operation of private residences, households, lodging houses, or apartment buildings. 
    Construction wastes or debris means wastes or debris from building construction, alteration or repairs, and dirt from excavation. Unusual or special manufacturing or trade wastes or debris are also classified as construction wastes or debris. 
    Garbage means all discarded and unwanted common household and kitchen wastes, rubbish, including, but not limited to, food, food residues, and materials necessarily used for packaging, storing, preparing, and consuming the same, and all waste materials resulting from the usual routine or domestic housekeeping, including, but not limited to, aluminum and steel cans; glass containers; plastic containers; crockery and other containers; metal; paper of all types, including newspapers, books, magazines and catalogs; boxes and cartons; cold ashes; furnishings and fixtures; textiles and leather; toys and recreational equipment; and similar items. 
    Noncombustible rubbish consists of inorganic wastes that cannot be burned or incinerated without the use of auxiliary fuel. Such rubbish shall include tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, and crockery. 
    Property cleanout means any waste, debris, garbage, rubbish or unwanted items being placed at the curb, easement or roadside for collection resulting from a structure clean out or the sale of real estate property, residential change of address, new resident or occupant. 
    Recyclable material includes but is not limited to (aluminum) cans, clean foil, pie tins, glass jars and bottles, newspapers, telephone books, office paper, catalogs, magazines, junk mail, cardboard, fiberboard, and mixed paper, plastic bottles, plastic milk jugs, plastic juice containers, cereal boxes, paper towel rolls, empty steel and tin cans. "Recyclables shall be interchangeable with "recyclable material." 
    Resident means the owner, or occupant of a single family residential unit, duplex or four-plex multifamily residential unit in the city. 
    Scavenger means any individual who shall go from place to place within the city on any vehicle, mechanical or otherwise, for the purpose of collection of garbage, rubbish, ashes, or waste materials, or any such individual who shall engage in the business of collecting garbage, waste material, ashes, or rubbish. 
    Tote cart means a city approved and or owned wheeled container designed to contain garbage, recyclable material and yard waste designed to be dumped or emptied by both semi-automated and fully-automated truck equipment systems. 
    Yard waste means grass clippings, landscape vegetation, plants, trees, small brush or limbs, leaves and other organic garden debris. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Secs. 70-2-70-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF SANITATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Article II, §§ 70-26-70-29, pertaining to the department of sanitation has been retained herein at the direction of the city. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 70-26. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a single department for the collection of refuse in the city, to be known as the "Department of Sanitation of the City of Portage." 
(Code 1985, § 15-1-1) 
Sec. 70-27. - Supervision authority. 
    The construction, acquisition, improvement, equipment, custody, administration, operation, and maintenance of facilities for the collection and disposal of refuse and services rendered thereby shall be under the supervision and control of the board of public works and safety of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 15-1-2) 
Sec. 70-28. - Powers and duties. 
    The department of sanitation shall have all the powers, privileges, and duties as provided by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1985, § 15-1-3) 
Sec. 70-29. - Street and sanitation department gift fund. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created the "Street and Sanitation Department Gift Fund," which shall be a nonreverting fund. The fund shall be used to receive and hold all money and other property which shall be received by the City of Portage Street and Sanitation Department as gifts. 
(b)  Appropriation of funds. Any gifts which are restricted or designated to a certain purpose in any manner shall be utilized only for such purpose and shall be maintained by the clerk-treasurer of the city, in separate ledger accounts to designate such purpose or use. Any gifts of money not immediately needed may be co-mingled with all other general funds. 
(c)  Investment of funds. The clerk-treasurer is hereby specifically authorized to invest such funds with, or separately from, the remainder of the general fund in any suitable manner as is now provided by state statute and/or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, §§ 1-3, 7-7-98) 
Secs. 70-30-70-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STORAGE; COLLECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-51. - Ash storage. 
    Ashes shall be stored separately in a tight metal or wood container not exceeding one bushel in capacity and equipped with a watertight cover. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-52. - Storage of construction waste. 
(a)  Construction wastes shall be stored on the premises where produced in such a manner that no rodents can be harbored, public health nuisances created or litter spread to adjacent public or private property. Such wastes shall be removed within a reasonable time after it is produced by the person, resident or contractor producing the waste. Construction waste may consist of but is not limited to items such as asphalt, concrete, building materials, drywall, plaster material, roofing, liquid paint and/or any hazardous waste. Construction waste generated through permitted projects by residents or contractors will not be removed by city services or crews. Construction waste shall not be placed in city approved/owned tote carts for collection by the city. 
(b)  Multiple types of man-made materials, gravel, stone or natural earth materials includes the following: bank or pea gravel, sand, silt, clay, river or landscape rock, mulch, wood chips, crushed concrete or aggregate, asphalt, crushed stone or limestone, mill slag or common earth dirt that has been excavated or removed by an occupant, owner or contractor from the parcel lot or the residential dwelling will not be removed by city services or crews nor are such mentioned materials to be placed in any tote cart for disposal. 
(c)  A dumpster of up to 20 cubic yard capacity may be permitted to be placed on private property for a period not to exceed eight weeks for the purpose of providing temporary storage of construction waste during residential remodeling activity. A dumpster of up to 20 cubic yard capacity may be permitted to be placed on private property for the purpose of providing temporary storage of construction waste during new residential construction, and for the duration of that construction, but not to exceed 16 weeks. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-53. - Private collection. 
(a)  Garbage, combustible and noncombustible rubbish may be collected by private individuals if they are permitted by the common council; provided that the vehicle's method of collection and disposal meets with the requirements of this chapter and with the requirements of the county board of health. 
(b)  No garbage or ashes shall be collected in the city unless it is stored in containers meeting the regulations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
State Law reference- Local boards of health, IC 16-20-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 70-54. - Storage, removal of animal remains. 
    Hides, hair, feathers, fish scales, offal, blood, portions of animals, fish, or fowl resulting from the killing, processing and preparation for sale of all slaughtered animals, fish, and fowl, shall be deposited in watertight metal containers equipped with tight fitting metal covers that are stored within the slaughterhouse, poultry kill plant, or market until removal in a manner specified by state laws and regulations. Such material shall be disposed of through licensed rendering plants. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
State Law reference- Meat and poultry inspection, humane slaughter, IC 16-42-16-1 et seq. 
Sec. 70-55. - Dumping. 
(a)  All garbage collected in the city shall be disposed of in an area established by the board of county commissioners or designated by the common council subject to rules and regulations for the use of such landfill or transfer station. Incineration of garbage and combustible rubbish is permitted, but it shall be incinerated in such a manner that no smoke, odor, or fire hazard will be created. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or dump garbage, rubbish, or other waste materials upon any public or private property excepting on public landfills established under the authority of the board of county commissioners; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit dumping or depositing of dirt, sand, and gravel, free of all garbage, combustible, and noncombustible rubbish, upon any privately-owned property, at the request of the owner, for the purpose of properly elevating the grade of such property or the unimproved part of such property. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit or suffer to be thrown or deposited or suffer or permit any child, servant, member of the family or other person under his control to throw or deposit any manure, rubbish, slops, putrid, or unsound animal or vegetable matter or any filthy, nauseous, or unwholesome liquid or slops or any substances that are liable to become unwholesome, in or into or upon any street, lane, alley, sidewalk, gutter, crossing lot, cellar, premises, or common. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-56. - Garbage collection fee. 
(a)  A garbage collection fee shall be assessed for each parcel of real estate or building served by the city garbage collection service. The city garbage collection service shall serve each single-family residential unit and each duplex located within the city. In addition, the city garbage collection service shall serve four-plex multifamily residential units. However, garbage will not be picked up from and no fee will be charged to a multifamily residential unit larger than a four-plex, to a multifamily residential unit which is part of an apartment complex, or from two or more four-plexes which are adjacent to each other and which are owned by the same person or entity. The fee is established as a flat minimum fee per month per unit served (See Fee Schedule) 
(1)  Senior citizens may apply for the senior citizen discount. If qualified, the senior citizen shall pay a flat minimum fee per month (See Fee Schedule). Applications for the senior citizen discount shall be available at the Utility Service Board office at 6071 Central Ave. Portage, IN 46368. An applicant shall qualify for the discount if the senior citizen provides proof that the applicant, or spouse, is the owner and is domiciled in a single-family residential unit or duplex, and the applicant or spouse is 65 years or older. The application for senior citizen discount shall be renewed yearly. 
(2)  A disabled person or a disabled American veteran may apply for the disabled person's discount. If qualified, the disabled persons shall pay a flat minimum fee per month (See Fee Schedule). Applications for the disabled persons discount shall be available at the Utility Service Board office at 6071 Central Ave Portage, IN 46368. An applicant shall qualify for the discount if the disabled person provides proof that the applicant, or spouse, is the owner and is domiciled in a single-family residential unit or duplex, and the applicant or spouse is disabled. This shall be evidenced by approval from Social Security Insurance (SSI), Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI), other written verification from the Social Security office of the disability, written verification from veterans affairs, written verification from railroad, police, or fire disability determination letter, or verification from county auditor/tax bill. The application for disabled persons discount shall be renewed yearly. 
    The monthly garbage collection fee shall increase by $0.25 per month on January 1 of each year beginning in 2017; provided that a review shall be completed every three to five years to determine whether this rate increase continues to be reasonable and appropriate. 
(b)  The garbage collection fee shall be billed monthly, in conjunction with the sanitary sewer fee. The garbage collection fee shall be billed and collected by the utility service board. All other costs, fees, fines, or other related charges in the replacement of missing tote carts, and in the collection of bulk items or any other yard waste / discarded materials will be collected by the clerk treasurer's office. The city may use all means necessary to collect and recover all past due accounts. All accounts due are subject to a penalty of ten percent if not paid on or before the expiration of the past-due date shown on the billing statement. In collecting past due accounts, the city shall be entitled to recover its costs of collection including reasonable attorney fees. 
(c)  The fees collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the city general fund and shall be used exclusively to defray the expenses of the department. 
(d)  Owners of residential units which will be served by the city garbage collection service, as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, who currently have contracts with private scavengers for garbage collection may receive an exemption from the garbage collection fee for the duration of the current term of that contract. All requests for exemptions shall be made to the board of public works and safety and shall be granted or denied by the board in its discretion. 
(e)  Persons served by the city garbage collection service may have garbage collection service vacated while they are out of town. Garbage collection service may be vacated for a maximum period of four months per calendar year. In order to have garbage collection service vacated, all of the following conditions must apply: 
(1)  The customer must occupy the residential property as his/her primary residence. 
(2)  The customer must intend to return to the residential property after being out of town. 
(3)  The customer shall pay a nonrefundable vacate fee (see Fee Schedule). 
(4)  The customer shall notify the utility service office of the time period during which garbage collection service should be vacated. 
    Garbage collection service shall resume when the customer returns to the property or upon the expiration of four months, whichever occurs first. At that time, the utility service department shall resume monthly billing for garbage collection service. 
(f)  Each customer that prepays the entire amount owed under this article for the current year on or before January 31 of that year shall be entitled to a discount of ten percent of the total amount owed. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12; Ord. No. 13-11, § 1, 6-4-13; Ord. No. 16-5, §§ 1, 3-1-16; Ord. No. 18-9, § 4, 6-5-18) 
Secs. 70-57-70-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 70-66. - Required; maximum number permitted. 
(a)  All city-owned tote carts provided to residential dwelling units shall at all times remain the property of the city. City-owned tote carts which are assigned to individual residential dwelling units shall remain on the premises or be returned to the city when the owner or occupants vacates. Each residential dwelling unit that pays a monthly garbage collection fee shall be provided one city-owned tote cart for garbage and one city-owned tote cart for recyclable materials. The resident that may exceed the limit volume of a city-owned tote cart can obtain additional city-owned tote carts through a request at the street and sanitation department. The resident will pay monthly an additional garbage collection fee equal to one-half of the regular garbage collection fee for each additional city-owned tote cart (see Fee Schedule). 
(b)  Residents shall keep the city-owned tote carts provided to them clean and in good repair. All city-owned tote carts that have been damaged through normal wear and tear will be repaired or replaced at no cost to the residential dwelling unit. Residents will be responsible for repair/replacement cost if a city-owned tote cart at a residential dwelling unit is damaged an excessive number of times, is damaged by fire, broken by abnormal means or lost (see Fee Schedule). Missing city-owned tote carts require a completed police report in order to waive replacement costs. 
(c)  On the scheduled residential garbage pickup day, all tote carts that need to be emptied of garbage or recyclable material shall to be placed at the street. Tote carts are to be placed three feet apart from each other, from any parked vehicle on street or any other object(s) that may interfere with automation collection. Tote cart wheels and handle are placed towards house and the directional arrow points toward street. All tote carts shall not be stored or placed in any area that impedes pedestrian or vehicular traffic in a public right-of-way. Failure to follow tote cart placement requirements may delay or interrupt residential garbage collection service. 
(d)  All tote carts containing garbage or recyclable materials will be emptied between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on the designated collection day. All tote carts shall be set out at curbside or street, on the designated collection day before 6:00 a.m. and no earlier than noon of the day proceeding the regular collection day. All tote carts shall be removed from curbside or street no later than noon on the day after the regular collection. The resident shall promptly clean up and remove any scattered garbage, rejected items and/or recyclable material from the property before noon on the day after the scheduled date of regular collection. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12; Ord. No. 13-11, § 1, 6-4-13) 
Sec. 70-67. - General specifications. 
(a)  The weekly amount of garbage to be collected from each residential dwelling unit shall be limited to a city owned tote cart with the lid fully closed. All garbage (except for large bulk items) shall be placed in a closed standard plastic garbage bag and then placed within the city owned tote cart with the lid fully closed. Any garbage discarded for collection that is found outside the tote will be labeled as the bulk item(s). 
(b)  Each residential dwelling unit that pays a monthly garbage collection fee shall be entitled to place, within the first week of each calendar month on their regular corresponding trash day, large reasonable bulk item(s) for collection. Bulk item(s) include but are not limited to: kitchen appliances, water heaters, washers, dryers, furniture, mattress sets, bound carpet/padding taped and cut into bundles no longer than five-foot lengths, deck wood material cut into bundles no longer than five-foot lengths, wood fencing cut into bundles no longer than five-foot lengths, wood sheds cut into bundles no longer than five-foot lengths (no asphalt or roofing shingles allowed), and waste/debris from small non-permit household remodeling projects that will need to be placed in large heavy-duty construction type trash bags not to exceed 50 pounds each. Large bulk items placed out for collection that exceed 40 square feet in ground area (five feet wide × eight feet long × five feet high) shall be considered excessive amounts and will result in a fee charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). Each hopper volume load (seven feet × six feet × five feet volume) will result in an additional fee charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). 
(c)  Extra bulk items collected outside of the time frame of the first week of the calendar month will result in fee charges to the resident. Bulk items totaling 40 square feet or less shall have a minimum fee of $25.00 (see Fee Schedule). Bulk items exceeding 40 square feet shall have a minimum fee of $100.00 (see Fee Schedule). The resident must request an extra bulk item pick-up through the street and sanitation department by leaving the resident's name, address and contact number. In addition to the bulk item fees listed above, each hopper volume load (seven feet × six feet × five feet volume) will result in an additional fee charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). 
(d)  Property clean-out being placed at the curb, easement or roadside for collection will result in a fee charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). Each hopper volume load (seven feet × six feet × five feet volume) will result in additional fee charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12; Ord. No. 13-9, § 1, 4-2-13; Ord. No. 13-11, § 1, 6-4-13) 
Sec. 70-68. - Storage. 
    Containers referred to in this division shall not be stored on public property or so placed that a nuisance shall be caused to adjacent residents, except that containers may be placed on public property for collection purposes only. The owner of a container placed on public property shall be responsible in case of damage resulting from the placement of such container. All rubbish to be accumulated by private individuals shall be stored on the property where such rubbish is produced until collected. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-69. - Reserved. 
Sec. 70-70. - Recycling Specifications. 
(a)  All recyclable material is to be placed loosely in the recycle tote cart are the following. All recyclable material must be clean and free from food and liquid contaminates. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section to knowingly dispose of motor oil antifreeze, car batteries, and other toxic materials in with garbage and/or recycling collection. 
(c)  E-waste is electronic waste or electronic equipment discarded devices such as computers, phones, televisions, monitors, printers, VCR, DVD players, stereo equipment, or anything with a circuit board. E-waste is NOT to be discarded in any tote carts. All E-waste is to be placed at the curbside or street as a bulk item within the first week of each calendar month on their regular corresponding trash day. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-71. - Yard waste. 
    Yard waste pickup is designed to be a service to residents with current trash collection accounts for routine maintenance of residential yards. It is the responsibility of the resident to remove yard waste debris from contracted services or residential lot clearing. Contractors are not permitted to utilize residential city services as a means of removal for commercial work performed at any location within or outside of the City of Portage. City crews are not permitted to remove debris generated in either of these circumstances. The city uses specialized equipment to pickup and process all yard debris. There must not be any man made foreign material mixed in with the yard waste. 
(a)  Grass clippings are highly recommended to be mulched, composted or recycled by the resident to avoid disposal through city services. By spreading grass clippings underneath shrubs or other areas, this process replaces moisture and nutrients in the soil. Grass clippings are not to be placed in city-owned tote carts. Grass clippings can be brought to the street department from 7:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. on scheduled work days. Residents must report to the office and show proof of residence before dropping off grass clippings. Grass clippings must be placed in biodegradable paper yard waste bags and be free from manmade materials. Yard waste bags must be placed in the designated area for grass clippings. Grass clippings in plastic bags will not be accepted. Residents who discard grass clippings for trash collection will incur a fee of $25.00 for each load collected (see Fee Schedule). One load shall consist of grass clippings totaling 40 square feet or less. 
(b)  The city, acting through its street department, shall provide curbside collection of tree limbs and leaves to residents. Tree limbs are collected on a weekly basis but are subject to change as necessitated by special circumstances, including but not limited to: holidays, special events, weather conditions or equipment breakdown. Any changes in the collection schedule can be obtained by calling the street department, Monday through Friday 7:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. Logs, limbs and branches are to be bundled and/or packaged not to exceed lengths of six feet. Excessive limbs and branches that exceed 20 cubic yard loads at a single residential stop will result in an additional fee charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). Tree log diameter size that is larger than eight inches in diameter will result in additional costs charged to the resident (see Fee Schedule). 
(c)  Ideal leaf and limb pick up seasons are as follows: Limb pick up service starts in the beginning of April and usually ends in early August. Leaf pick up service starts middle of October and ends in the middle of December. 
(d)  To be eligible for the curbside limb/leaf pickup service, limbs or leaves shall be placed on the easement/right-of-way (not in street). Anyone desiring limb or leaf pickup service may call the street department, Monday through Friday 7:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. and give their name, phone number and address before 1:00 p.m. on the date proceeding the day scheduled for their scheduled regular trash pickup. 
(e)  In addition to the ideal leaf and limb pickup season, the street department shall provide curbside tree limb collection service for the removal of storm related tree limb damage only after a severe storm event. The service shall be provided when determined necessary at the discretion of the superintendent of the street department. 
(f)  It is the responsibility of the resident to remove trees, limbs, landscape shrubbery, and yard waste from contracted services or private individual lot clearing. Contractors are not permitted to utilize city services as a means of removal for commercial work performed at any location within or outside of the City of Portage. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12; Ord. No. 13-11, § 1, 6-4-13) 
Sec. 70-72 - Appeal rights. 
    A customer who disagrees with the [amount] imposed under the fee schedule referred to in section 70-56 may appeal the imposition of the fee to the board of public works and safety by submitting a written request to the clerk-treasurer's office. The decision of the board of public works and safety shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 16-5, § 3, 3-1-16) 
Secs. 70-73-70-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTION VEHICLES 

Sec. 70-81. - Standing restricted generally. 
    No person owning or controlling any truck or other vehicle used for the carrying or transporting of any manure, offal, swill, garbage, or rubbish, or the contents of any catch basin or sink, or having upon or in any such truck or other vehicle any offensive or nauseous substance, shall cause or permit such truck or other vehicle, when in use for such purpose, to stand or remain in or near any building, structure, or premises occupied by any person, or to remain or stand upon or along any railroad, street or public way within 300 feet of any building, structure, or premises occupied or used for residence purposes within the city except for the purpose of making collections as provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-82. - Time limits for loading and unloading. 
    No person using a truck or other vehicle coming under this division shall cause or permit unreasonable delay for loading and unloading; nor should such person allow or permit such truck or other vehicle to pass along any street or public way for an unreasonable period of time. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-83. - Maintenance, storage and cleaning requirements. 
(a)  No person owning or controlling any truck or other vehicle coming under this division shall cause or permit any such truck or other vehicle to be in a needlessly or unnecessarily filthy or offensive condition. 
(b)  Persons owning or controlling trucks or other vehicles coming under this division shall cause all such trucks or other vehicles used, and all implements used in connection with the loading and unloading thereof, when not in use, to be stored and kept in such a place and in such a manner as not to create a nuisance. 
(c)  Persons owning or controlling trucks or other vehicles coming under this division shall cause all such trucks or other vehicles, and implements used in connection with the loading and unloading thereof, to be thoroughly cleansed and put in an inoffensive condition when stored or not in use. Such trucks, vehicles and implements shall be thoroughly washed at least once per day when in use. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-84. - Construction; spilling load. 
(a)  Trucks and other vehicles coming under this division and any box, can, or other container carried thereon or therein in which any of the substances controlled and regulated in this chapter shall be carried, shall be so constructed as to be strong and practically airtight and watertight so as to effectually prevent the same from emitting any odor and as to prevent any part of the contents thereof from falling, leaking, or spilling there from. 
(b)  No person owning or controlling any truck or other vehicle coming under this division shall cause or permit any such truck or other vehicle to be so loaded or of such faulty construction or in such defective condition or so out of repair or to be so improperly driven or managed that any manure, garbage, rubbish, offal, dirt, offensive liquid or other materials with which such truck or other vehicle is loaded as to permit such materials to drop or fall upon or in any street, public way or other place. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every person in the charge, possession or control of any truck or other vehicle coming under this division to replace at once on such truck or other vehicle any part of the contents which may have fallen, dropped or been spilled from any cart or vehicle, or from any box or receptacle conveyed thereon, upon any street, public way, or other place. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
State Law reference- Vehicles to be constructed to prevent contents from dripping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping, IC 9-21-8-48. 
Secs. 70-85-70-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROHIBITED STORAGE 

Sec. 70-96. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Discarded or abandoned means not presently utilized for the purpose initially manufactured. 
    Natural/man-made materials include gravel, stone, bank or pea gravel, sand, silt, clay, river or landscape rock, mulch, wood chips, crushed concrete or aggregate, asphalt, crushed stone or limestone, mill slag or common earth dirt. 
    Notice means the mailing, by first class mail, of a clear written statement of the violation, addressed to the address of the owner appearing upon the real estate tax rolls; and if such notice shall be returned, then by posting such notice on the property in question. 
    Person includes one or more individuals, a partnership, a corporation, a land trust, and any association whatever of any of the foregoing, whether such association is formal or informal in nature. 
    Refuse includes all materials which have no utilitarian use at the location of its storage or accumulation, and also includes materials such as discarded or abandoned paper containers, building materials, tires, garbage, trash, rubbish, parts of machines and motor vehicles, appliances, and all other materials commonly understood to constitute "refuse." 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 70-97. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, store, or accumulate any refuse, construction waste or natural/man-made materials in, on, or under any real estate located in whole or in part within the city, and it shall also be unlawful for any person owning real estate located in whole or in part within the city to permit any other person to dump, store, or accumulate refuse construction waste or natural / man-made materials in, on, or under such real estate. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-98. - Remedies and penalties. 
(a)  If any person shall violate any of the provisions of this division, the city may: 
(1)  Initiate an action for injunctive relief in any court of competent jurisdiction; 
(2)  After written notice to the owner of the property to remove any existing refuse, construction waste or natural / man-made materials and if such owner shall have failed to completely comply with such notice within ten days thereafter, enter upon the property and remove all of the refuse thereon situated, and do such other things as may be necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare in connection with such removal; 
(3)  Seek a fine for such violation, in an amount not less than $50.00 nor more than $2,500.00; and 
(4)  Undertake any other action deemed to be necessary and appropriate to protect and preserve the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(b)  The remedies and penalties described in this section are cumulative, and not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-99. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Notice of a violation of this division may be mailed, or posted as the circumstances require, by any designated representative of the city plan commission, code enforcement, by the city engineer, or by the city attorney or assistant city attorney. 
(b)  Actions seeking fines for violation of this division may be initiated by any of the persons mentioned in subsection (a) of this section, or by any member of the city police department. 
(c)  Actions for injunctive relief, and all proceedings in court shall be attended to by the city attorney, the assistant city attorney, or any other member of the city law department so authorized by the city attorney. 
(d)  In any proceedings to enforce the provisions of this division, regardless of whether such proceedings require court appearances or the filing of a lawsuit by the city attorney or other member of the city law department, the city shall be entitled to recover, in addition to all other rights and remedies under this division, all attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses, including the expense of removing, where applicable, incurred in connection with enforcement of this division, including such fees, costs, and expenses incurred on appeal, if any. 
(e)  It is the specific intent of the common council that taxpayers of the city not be burdened with the cost of correcting violations of this division unless the taxpayer is the violator. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 70-100. - Construction. 
    This division shall be construed so as to prohibit, to the greatest extent allowed by law, the acts described in section 70-97, and all acts related to or arising there from. 
(Ord. No. 12-30, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Secs. 70-101-70-120. - Reserved.
