ARTICLE IV. - SCAVENGERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Article IV, §§ 70-121-70-140, pertaining to scavengers has been retained herein at the direction of the city. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-121. - Separation from city. 
    No licensed scavenger shall, under any circumstances whatsoever, be considered as an agent, servant or employee of the city; and any and all operations of such scavenger shall be entirely independent of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-21(A)) 
Sec. 70-122. - Regulation of vehicles. 
    The common council is authorized, if it desires, to adopt standards and all reasonable rules and regulations governing the type of vehicles to be used by scavengers as well as the manner of collecting and handling garbage, rubbish, ashes, and waste material, and such other requirements as may be necessary for the protection of public health and safety. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-21(B)) 
Secs. 70-123-70-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 70-136. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than a city refuse collector or a scavenger licensed by the city to remove, displace, uncover or otherwise disturb any refuse container or the contents thereof placed on location, to go from place to place with any vehicle, mechanical or otherwise, for the purpose of collecting garbage, rubbish, ashes, or waste material or to act or serve as a scavenger without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-16) 
Sec. 70-137. - Application, contents. 
    Any person desiring a scavenger license shall make written application therefor to the clerk-treasurer, upon forms to be provided by the clerk-treasurer, giving the following information: 
(1)  Name, age and address of applicant; 
(2)  If presently employed, the name and address of applicant's employer; 
(3)  Number and description of vehicles to be used for collection of garbage, rubbish, ashes, and waste material; 
(4)  If such vehicles are motor driven the number of applicant's chauffeurs license; 
(5)  Two photographs of the applicant taken within the last 60 days from the filing of such application, which pictures shall be two inches by two inches, showing clearly the head and shoulders of such applicant; and 
(6)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-17) 
State Law reference- Chauffeur's license, IC 9-24-4-1 et seq. 
Sec. 70-138. - Inspection of vehicle. 
(a)  The application for a scavenger license shall be referred to the common council who, within ten days after notification of such application, shall inspect all vehicles and facilities of the applicant for the handling of garbage, rubbish, ashes, and waste material, to determine whether the same meet the standards of safety and sanitation fixed by this division. If such standards are met, the common council shall certify in writing its approval to the clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  All refuse collection bodies shall consist of steel and be of the fully enclosed packertype, so as to completely prevent latent garbage and refuse from slopping into the streets. All refuse collection bodies shall be painted and numbered as required by the common council. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-18) 
Sec. 70-139. - Fees and insurance. 
(a)  No scavenger license shall be issued until the applicant first obtains a certificate of approval from the common council, pays the license fee, and produces proof of liability insurance. 
(b)  The scavenger license fee shall be $100.00, and $25.00 per truck per year beginning as of January 1 of any year; provided, however, that any license issued after August 1 for the balance of the year shall be in the sum of $15.00 per truck. Such license fee shall be paid to the clerk-treasurer. 
(c)  Before any scavenger's license shall be issued, the applicant shall first furnish and deposit with the clerk-treasurer a certificate of insurance showing a public liability and property damage insurance policy insuring the applicant against liability for damages sustained by a person other than the employee of such applicant and occasioned by the negligent operation of the vehicles of such applicant. The insurance policy shall provide a minimum coverage in the amount of $25,000.00 for the injury or death of any one person as a result of any one accident and shall provide coverage in the amount of $50,000.00 in the aggregate for any one accident and $10,000.00 for property damage. Such insurance policy shall be written by a company authorized to do business in the state, and which company shall be approved by the common council. Such insurance policy shall provide that same cannot be cancelled until 15 days written notice of such cancellation shall have been given to the applicant, and the clerk-treasurer. If another certificate of insurance is not provided to the clerk-treasurer before the cancellation of the one then in effect, the license earlier issued shall automatically become null and void. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-19) 
State Law reference- "Proof of financial responsibility" defined, IC 9-25-2-3. 
Sec. 70-140. - Revocation. 
(a)  The common council may revoke any scavenger licenses as may have been issued under this division upon: 
(1)  Proof of conviction of violation of this article; 
(2)  A certification by the chief of police and/or any member of the common council that the licensee is in violation of the standards set or of any of its rules or regulations; or 
(3)  Failure to keep liability insurance in force. 
(b)  Except for failure to keep liability insurance in force, no license shall be revoked if the licensee shall fully comply with the necessary requirements within 20 days after having been notified in writing by the clerk-treasurer of the nature of such violation. 
(Code 1985, § 7-1-20) 
State Law reference- Hearing complaints against persons licensed by city, IC 36-4-5-5. 
Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; animals, ch. 10; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; cable communications, ch. 22; community development, ch. 30; planning, ch. 66; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Jurisdiction of city over streets, alleys and sidewalks, IC 36-1-3-9; local powers relating to public ways, IC 36-9-2-5 et seq.; city works board, IC 36-9-6-1 et seq.; municipal street lights, IC 36-9-9-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 74-26-74-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NAMES OF STREETS 

Sec. 74-36. - Naming procedure. 
(a)  All naming and renaming of new and existing streets, alleys, and other public rights-of-way within the city shall be done by resolution passed by the board of public works and safety at any regular meeting thereof or any special meeting called for that purpose. All street naming resolutions shall be submitted to the plan commission's director of planning, or his successor, for his recommendations prior to enactment by the board of public works and safety. 
(b)  No public building, park, port, marina, airport, hospital, street, alley, or any other public right-of-way, buildings or land within the city shall be named or renamed for a public official while such public official holds an elected office. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-1; Ord. No. 90-32, § 1, 6-11-90; Ord. No. 92-29, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Secs. 74-37-74-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADDRESS NUMBERS 

Sec. 74-46. - Numbering system. 
(a)  The streets within the city shall be numbered and renumbered in accordance with the numbering system set forth in the "Prospectus on Streets & Numbering by Portage Plan Commission, dated February 10, 1965," which is incorporated by reference to be a part of this division. The baselines therein set forth and the numerical designations thereon shown for such baselines are hereby adopted and made the official numbering base lines for street numbers within the city. All residences and commercial buildings within the city shall be numbered as follows: 
(1)  All such buildings on the east-west avenues in Section 34, Range 7 West, shall be numbered between the numbers 5000 and 5500; all such buildings on the north-south streets in such Section 34, shall be numbered between the numbers 500 and 1000-designation (A); 
(2)  All such buildings on the east-west avenues in Section 3, Range 7 West, shall be numbered between the numbers 5000 and 5500; all such buildings on the north-south streets in such Section 3, shall be numbered between the numbers 1000 and 1500-designation (B);

(Code 1985, § 16-1-2) 
Sec. 74-47. - Assignment of numbers. 
(a)  All specific building numbers shall be assigned by the plan commission by means of a measuring device to be applied to a section map of the section in question, such device to measure from section lines in increments of 10.56 feet. 
(b)  Each section described in section 74-46 shall bear an alphabetical designation to be used with the street numbers falling within such section, such letter to appear after each assigned number. The letter designations for each section are those shown at the end of the subsections in section 74-46. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-3) 
Sec. 74-48. - Display of numbers. 
    Each building, house, or other structure on a parcel of real estate which is or has been assigned a street number, shall have displayed and properly maintained thereon the assigned street number on a portion of the structure on or near the main entrance, which is plainly and readily visible by the naked eye from the street or other public way which adjoins the parcel. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-4; Ord. No. 88-32, § 1, 7-5-88) 
Sec. 74-49. - Structures distant from public way. 
    Every building, house, or other structure which has been assigned a street number, but which is so distant from the street or other public way which adjoins it as to be impractical to comply with the requirements of section 74-48, shall instead display the assigned street number on a light post, mailbox, fence, or other structure near the entrance of that parcel, which is plainly and readily visible by the naked eye from the street or public way which adjoins it. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-4; Ord. No. 88-32, § 2, 7-5-88) 
Sec. 74-50. - Specifications. 
    The assigned street number display shall employ raised Arabic numerals of a minimum of five inches in height, the color of which must clearly contrast with the background upon which they are placed. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-4; Ord. No. 88-32, § 3, 7-5-88) 
Sec. 74-51. - Apartments. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owners and managers of every apartment structure in the city to identify as prescribed in this division, the number of such apartment building. 
(b)  If more than one such apartment structure is located on a single zoning lot or within a development bearing a common name, each separate apartment structure shall have a separate and distinct raised Arabic number or raised Arabic letter, which number or letter shall be visible from the street or other public way which adjoins the parcel or structure. It shall be the duty of the owners or managers of every apartment structure in the city to conform to such requirement. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-4; Ord. No. 88-32, § 4, 7-5-88) 
Sec. 74-52. - Grace period. 
    Any person who violates this division shall have 30 days following written notification of noncompliance in which to comply without fine or other penalty. 
(Code 1985, § 16-1-4; Ord. No. 88-32, § 5, 7-5-88) 
Sec. 74-53. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $25.00 per day for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 88-32, § 6A, 7-5-88) 
Secs. 74-54-74-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND GUTTERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 74-76-74-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 74-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Developer means any person engaged in developing or improving a lot or group of lots or structures thereon for use for occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 89-37, § 4, 9-5-89) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 74-87. - Sidewalks-Required. 
    Sidewalks are required throughout the city and shall be provided by the developer before any certificate of occupancy permit shall be issued, and shall be constructed in compliance with the specifications set forth in section 74-90. 
(Ord. No. 89-37, § 1, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 74-88. - Same-Specifications. 
    All sidewalks made new, replaced, or repaired in the city shall be made in conformity with the provisions of this division and in accordance with the grades, plans, profiles and specifications furnished by the city engineer and on file in the clerk-treasurer's office, as adopted and approved by the common council. 
(Code 1985, § 16-2-1) 
Sec. 74-89. - Sidewalk and curb fund. 
(a)  Establishment of fund. The City of Portage Sidewalk and Curb Fund is hereby established. All funds which the city receives from property owners under the sidewalk and curb policy shall be deposited into this fund. The sidewalk and curb fund shall be a nonreverting fund. 
(b)  Uses of the fund. Monies accumulated in the city's sidewalk and curb fund may be used for the expenses incurred in designing, constructing, extending and repairing sidewalks within the city. Monies accumulated in the fund may be used for the foregoing expenses without further appropriation. 
(Ord. No. 98-15, §§ 1, 2, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 02-35, § 1, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 74-90. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  All sidewalks shall be constructed a minimum of five feet in width, except in the case of the continuation of an already constructed sidewalk which is less than five feet, but in no event to be constructed less than four feet in width. If the sidewalk under construction is a gap between already constructed sidewalks in the same block, it shall be constructed according to the width of the wider sidewalk adjoining to the new sidewalk, five inches in thickness and one course concrete according to the specifications that follow. Any surface of any walk when complete shall be in conformity with the grade given by the city engineer. All walks shall be laid with the inner edge on the property line, unless otherwise by special permit from the common council. 
(b)  The subgrade shall be constructed to the required depth below the finished surface as set by the city engineer and shall be thoroughly compacted to a firm smooth surface. All soft or spongy places not affording a suitable subgrade must be removed and replaced with a suitable material and compacted according to the above specifications. 
(c)  Side forms shall be rigid and held securely in place by stakes or braces with top edge true to grade. All sidewalks shall be five inches thick unless directed otherwise by the specifications herein or the city engineer. The sidewalk is to have a slope of one-quarter inch per foot measured across the parkway and sidewalk up from the back top of the curb, consistent with surrounding lawns and walks. 
(d)  Concrete shall consist of an approved Portland cement, a fine aggregate, a course aggregate, mixed in the proportion and manner specified in this section. 
(e)  All cement shall be first-class Portland cement of a reputable brand and conforming to the standard specifications of Portland cement (ASTM serial designation C-150). Shipment may be made in cloth sacks or paper bags plainly marked with the name of the manufacturer and the brand, trademark or other acceptable distinctive marking. Three to six percent air entrainment shall be in accordance with ASTM C-15. The cement shall be stored in a weathertight shelter having the floor raised off the ground. Fine aggregate for Portland cement concrete shall consist of hard, strong, durable particles of the following gradation: state department of transportation standard specification (Section 16) aggregate size #14 No. 1 or #14 No. 2. Screenings or crushed slag will not be permitted as a substitute for sand in concrete. Course aggregate shall be graded, washed gravel or crushed stone, in a maximum size of 11/2 inches consisting of clean, hard, durable particles free from dust, dirt, or other foreign substances. The use of dusty or dirty stone or gravel will not be permitted. The aggregate shall be stored and handled in a manner that will assure clean material free from foreign substances. Water used for concrete or mortar shall be clean, free from oils, acids, alkalis, or sewage. All concrete shall be mixed and proportioned to give good workability with a slump between four and six inches without adding more water than six U.S. gallons per 94-pound bag of cement. Concrete shall show a comprehensive strength of 3,000 pounds per square inch at 28 days. Water contained in the aggregate shall be taken into account in computing the water-cement ratio. 
(f)  Any mixer shall be of the batch type of a design and capacity, meeting the approval of the city engineer. Scales of an approved design shall be provided for the proper proportioning of the concrete. When necessary to mix by hand, a water-tight mortar box shall be used and the ingredients shall be turned together at least six times and more, if necessary, to obtain a mixture homogeneous in appearance. This may be done only on written approval by the city engineer. 
(g)  Three-quarter-inch bituminous premolded expansion joints shall be placed at 30-foot intervals in sidewalks and between sidewalks and any abutting structures, including curbs. 
(h)  Subgrade shall be moistened before concrete is placed. Concrete shall be placed in successive batches with the entire width of the slab struck off approximately one-half inch higher than the finished slab, then tamped and spaded along the edges and floated to an even surface. Slabs shall be four feet to six feet in length. The surface shall be divided by grooves at right angles to the centerline, the grooves shall be between one-eighth inch and one-quarter inch in width, all edges to be rounded with edging tools for a one-quarter inch radius. The elevation of the sidewalk shall be as set by the city engineer. When using transit mix trucks, the first discharge of concrete from the hoppers shall be wasted to the ground if it has been entrapped in the discharge worm vane and has separated, is too dry, or is not of proper homogeneity. 
(i)  Exposed surfaces of concrete shall be protected from premature drying by methods approved by the city engineer. All concrete shall be kept wet for not less than seven days, except that three days shall be considered sufficient if high early-strength Portland cement concrete is used. See the state department of transportation standard specifications for limiting weather conditions and concrete temperatures at time of placement, and other protecting and curing measures required. 
(j)  Where driveways are to be built across the sidewalk space, they shall conform to the sidewalk grade and shall be six inches in depth of the same quality and material as specified for walks. 
(k)  All alley crossings shall be constructed of concrete seven inches thick, of the same finish and material as specified for walks, and will be concave or straight as may be ordered by the city engineer. 
(l)  The material for all sidewalks built or repaired in the city after January 3, 1967 may be inspected by the city engineer and he shall have the right to inspect and approve same before they are used. All sidewalks made new or repaired shall be done under the supervision of the city engineer who may, in his discretion, inspect and report on the same before the approval and acceptance by the common council. If the city engineer does not inspect, approval and acceptance by the common council shall be automatic. 
(Code 1985, § 16-2-3) 
Sec. 74-91. - Maintenance procedures, specifications. 
(a)  When any sidewalk within the city shall become out of repair and it is necessary to make repair, consultation shall be made with the city engineer. When a portion of a sidewalk block or square is damaged, the entire block or square shall be removed and replaced. 
(b)  Whenever any sidewalk shall be ordered built, repaired, relaid or replaced, the dirt removed may be used by the city in improving the street upon which such building or repairs are being made or on streets, alleys or other public places the grading of which is of the same general plan. In case the city does not use the dirt, the property owner may remove it together with all old material within five days after the completion of such work. In case the property owner fails to do so, the contractor shall proceed to remove the same and the cost thereof shall be collected as part of the cost of such improvement. It shall be the duty of the contractor, at all times while building, repairing, relaying or replacing any sidewalk to see to it that the stakes indicating the grade of the same have not been tampered with. 
(Code 1985, § 16-2-5(A), (B)) 
Sec. 74-92. - Repair; notice to owner. 
    Whenever in the opinion of the board of public works and safety any new sidewalk should be built, or old sidewalks repaired, in the city, the board shall forthwith give notice to the owner of the abutting property or his agent, if residents of the city, and in case such owner or agents be nonresidents of the city, the board shall serve such notice by sending a copy thereof by registered letter to such owner or agent, if the address of such owner or agent be known, and if such owner or agent be nonresidents and their address unknown, or such real estate be vacant, or unoccupied, or the residence of the owner or agent be unknown, then a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place requiring such owner to build or repair the same within 45 days from the date of service of such notice. In case the owner shall fail to build or repair such sidewalks, after such notice has been given, then the city shall proceed to build or repair such walk and the costs, charges, and expenses thereof shall be charged against the owner of such property and shall be collected in the same manner as assessments for street improvements. 
(Code 1985, § 16-2-4) 
Sec. 74-93. - Tampering with grade stake, walk surface. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person or persons to tamper with or in any way interfere with any grade stake or any sidewalk or to deface or disturb any such walk while in the process of construction. 
(Code 1985, § 16-2-5(C)) 
Sec. 74-94. - Curb and gutter. 
    The installation of curbs and gutters shall be required throughout the city and shall be installed by the developer on the side of the street affronting the real estate on the street's surface. The curb and gutter shall be of a design approved by the city engineer. However, the city engineer has the authority to waive this requirement if it is not feasible to install curbs and gutters due to a lack of adequate stormwater collection facilities. 
(Ord. No. 89-37, § 2, 9-5-89) 
Sec. 74-95. - Revocation of requirements. 
    If a developer can show that the requirement for the installation of sidewalks, curbs, and/or gutters upon the terms and conditions set forth in section 74-90, and any amendments thereto, would cause an unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, he may petition the board of public works and safety for a waiver of such requirement or requirements, and the board of public works and safety, in its sole discretion, may grant such a requirement waiver. Such request and subsequent waiver shall be in writing. 
(Ord. No. 89-37, § 3, 9-5-89) 
Secs. 74-96-74-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SNOW REMOVAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Standards and specifications for lamps on snow removal equipment, IC 9-19-6-23. 

Sec. 74-116. - Duty of adjacent property owner. 
    It shall be the duty of all property owners to remove the snow from sidewalks which are on such property owner's land adjacent to a public street or on the public right-of-way adjacent to such property owner's land. 
(Ord. No. 90-14, § 2, 3-6-90) 
Sec. 74-117. - Storage of removed snow. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, suffer or permit the use by any other person of the public streets and roads within the city for the purpose of storing or disposing of any snow removed from the sidewalks, driveways, or other private or public areas from which snow might be removed. 
(Ord. No. 90-14, § 3, 3-6-90) 
Sec. 74-118. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined the sum of $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 90-14, § 4, 3-6-90) 
Secs. 74-119-74-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXCAVATIONS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Local regulation of excavations, IC 36-7-2-6, 36-9-6-14. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-141. - Standards and specifications for construction. 
(a)  It shall be the obligation of any person obtaining a license for an opening or excavation in the public right-of-way to backfill the excavation and replace the pavement as set forth in the following specifications: 
(1)  Backfill. All excavations under pavement shall be backfilled with clean granular material meeting the requirements of section 211 of the Indiana State Highway Standard Specifications. Each layer shall be compacted to at least 95 percent of the maximum dry density as determined by AASHO T99, as modified. Special care shall be taken in filling around sewers, water pipes, gas lines, etc., to keep the earth at the same height on both sides to avoid shifting of the pipeline. No removed paving materials or debris shall be used in backfilling the excavation unless approved by the board of public works and safety or its designee. Excavations not under pavement may be backfilled with virgin material removed from the excavation. 
(2)  Pavement and replacement. All pavement shall be replaced with a type of construction equal to or better than that which is removed and as approved by the city engineer. All cuts in pavement shall be first outlined with a saw cut not less than 11/2 inches deep. 
(3)  Concrete or brick pavements. Concrete used in the replacement of concrete or brick pavements not presently surfaced with an asphaltic material shall consist of six-bag concrete with seven percent air entrainment. Slump shall not exceed three inches. Coarse aggregate shall be limestone or blast furnace slag. No natural gravel aggregate will be allowed. Brick pavement will be replaced with eight inches of concrete except in some residential streets where the city engineer may require the brick to be replaced. Where concrete that has an asphaltic concrete surface is replaced, six-bag concrete shall be used and the concrete shall be finished flush with the surface of the existing concrete and the asphaltic surface replaced. 
(4)  Hot asphaltic concrete, sheet asphalt, emulsified asphalt, chip seals, and oil mat pavements. All asphaltic and oil type pavements shall be replaced with a hot asphaltic concrete surface conforming to the standard specifications, hot asphaltic concrete base, binder and surface of these prevailing specifications. The thickness of the pavement shall be equal to that which existed, but not less than three inches. Not less than 11 inches of coarse aggregate class A or B, size No. 53 shall be placed under any asphaltic concrete patch unless a concrete base is necessary. Asphalt placed over a concrete patch shall be cut back six inches around the concrete patch so that the two joints are offset. 
(5)  Temporary patch. If it is not possible due to weather conditions for the licensee to replace the pavement within 14 days following completion of work, a coarse aggregate base eight inches thick and a cold asphaltic surface shall be applied and maintained as a temporary patch until permanent repairs can be made. In no case shall a temporary patch be maintained more than six months before permanent repairs are made. 
(b)  For additional construction standards and specifications as required by the city, consult with the city engineer's office. Copies of details for construction are available at the office of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-142. - Work site security. 
    Any person making an excavation in or underneath the surface of a street, alley, or public place in the city shall erect and place suitable warning barriers, signs, and lights at or near the excavation, in such a manner as to prevent damage to persons and property that might otherwise result from or be caused by the presence of such excavation. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-143. - Commencement of construction, inspections. 
(a)  The licensee is required to contact the city engineer one day before the cut is to be made. An inspector will visit the construction site to determine that construction, safety, and repair methods as provided for in the approved license are implemented. The inspector shall verify that all of the conditions of the license are being met and work is in compliance with city standards. 
(b)  The number of interim inspections necessary will depend upon the type and size of the job. 
(c)  Upon completion of the work, the licensee is required to contact the city engineer. An inspector shall verify that all of the conditions of the license have been met and work is in compliance with city standards. Any equipment, surplus materials, and construction debris of any description shall be removed and the entire area put in a neat and orderly condition. All manholes, catchbasins or other structures disturbed or adjacent thereto shall be examined, any debris caused by the licensee shall be removed therefrom, or any damage caused by the licensee shall be repaired by the licensee. 
(d)  Upon acceptance by the inspector, the date of completion shall be noted on the inspection form. The licensee's performance and damage bond shall guarantee the maintenance of the work for a period of one year from that date. One year after the date of final inspection and approval, the licensee's bond shall be released, provided the quality and workmanship of the excavation have been maintained and the work remains in compliance with city standards. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-144. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall make an excavation or opening in or underneath the surface of any street, alley or public place in the city without a proper license from the city, or of larger dimensions than is authorized by such license, or without having on file a proper bond or certificates of insurance, or fails to erect or maintain suitable warning signs, lights or barriers at or near any such excavation in order to prevent damage to persons and property, or fails to fill in any excavation or opening promptly when the work has been completed therein, or who fails to apply for or pay for a license after making an emergency excavation, or who shall fail to, neglect, refuse or omit to perform or discharge any other act or duty imposed by this article, shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(b)  If any licensee shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or shall cause or create a public nuisance, or create a condition which is hazardous to the public health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise act unlawfully in connection with this article, the city may enjoin such person from further excavation activities. 
(c)  In addition to the remedies provided in this section, if any licensee shall violate any of the provisions of this article, the city may take all appropriate legal action to call and collect upon the surety bond posted by the licensee. 
(d)  In any action commenced by the city to enforce the provisions of this article, and in any legal proceedings initiated by any applicant or licensee, if the city shall prevail therein, the applicant or licensee shall pay the city's attorney's fees incurred in connection with such proceedings, at the rate customarily charged by the city's attorney to nonmunicipal clients. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-145. - Use of funds. 
    All fees received for issuance of licenses under this article shall be credited and go to the street department fund of the city. All fines and penalties shall be paid to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-146. - Location of city utilities. 
    Before the commencement of work under this article, the utility lines and facilities of the city within the area of the work shall be located. The licensee shall pay a fee of $150.00 for this location service. The location service fee shall be paid at the time the license fee prescribed by section 74-162 is paid. 
(Ord. No. 07-16, § 1, 5-1-07; Ord. No. 16-20, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Secs. 74-147-74-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 74-156. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, break, alter, change or disturb the surface of any street, alley, boulevard, or other public place, or the ground underneath any such surface, in the city, without first obtaining a license therefor, unless such person undertakes such activity pursuant to a formal request by the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1(A), 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-157. - Emergency situations. 
    If an emergency arises which requires any person to cut, break, alter, change or disturb the surface of any street, alley, boulevard, or other public place, or the ground underneath any such surface, in the city immediately, such person shall contact the city engineer's office. Verbal approval for the street excavation may be granted by the city engineer allowing the applicant to begin work immediately. However, the applicant shall appear at the clerk-treasurer's office the following day to complete the license application in accordance with section 74-158. In addition, any person obtaining approval for an emergency street excavation shall be required to comply with all the other terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1(B), 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-158. - Application, contents. 
(a)  Whenever any person shall desire to cut, alter, change, break, or disturb the surfaces or cut underneath the surfaces enumerated in sections 74-156 and 74-157, such person shall make and file with the clerk-treasurer a written and sworn application for a license on a form to be prescribed by the city engineer, setting out therein the following: 
(1)  The name, address and occupation of the applicant seeking the license. 
(2)  The reason for seeking the license. 
(3)  The nature of the work to be accomplished. 
(4)  The length of time within which the work is expected to be accomplished. 
(5)  The date when the work is expected to be commenced. 
(6)  The location and area of the surface to be broken. 
(7)  A project description including the length, width, and depth of the cut and whether in pavement or parkway. 
(8)  A description of the surface to be cut (e.g., asphalt, concrete, parkway, gravel, etc.). If more than one type of surface is to be cut, the length, width, and depth within each surface must be specified. 
(9)  Proposed safety features, as well as a proposed schedule outlining the extent of open excavation. 
(10)  If the license application involves grading and/or drainage work that will affect the city right-of-way, the following: 
a.  Drainage plan including all drainage structures and calculations. 
b.  Grading site plans. 
(11)  Any additional information that may be helpful to the city engineer. 
(b)  Such application shall have attached thereto a clearly drawn sketch of the location with all distances and dimensions marked, and four sets of construction plans. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-159. - Bond, insurance. 
(a)  Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this division, the applicant shall execute and file with the clerk-treasurer a bond or certified check in the penal sum of $5,000.00 with proper surety, conditioned that such obligors will indemnify and save the city harmless against loss or damage that may be caused by the excavation or that may arise or result therefrom, or from a failure or omission to keep or maintain adequate and proper warning signs, lights, or barriers at the site of the excavation, and further conditioned that the applicant will fill the excavation up to the surface thereof when the work is completed and that the surface shall be restored to its prior condition. The bond shall also contain a condition that in case an excavation is made by the principal obligor in an emergency when the clerk-treasurer's office is closed, he will apply and pay for the proper license on the first day such office is open. All bonds shall be subject to the approval of the board of public works and safety or its designee. 
(b)  If any applicant shall have on file a good and sufficient bond in the office of the clerk-treasurer, the same shall cover any one or more excavations for which a license has been issued, provided that the board of public works and safety or its designee may demand a new bond when in its judgment such is required by the number of excavations applied for by the applicant. 
(c)  Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this division, the applicant shall furnish proof of liability insurance in the following amounts: 
(1) Property damage $  250,000.00 (2) Injury, per person 250,000.00 (3) Injury, per occurrence 1,000,000.00  
(d)  The applicant must also show proof of premium payment for such insurance for a period of one year from the date of the commencement of work. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-160. - Application evaluation. 
(a)  The city engineer shall preliminarily evaluate the application solely for the purpose of determining whether it is complete and complies with this article. If not, it shall be returned to the applicant and no further action shall be taken by the city. 
(b)  If the application is complete, the city engineer shall review the plans submitted by the applicant to determine the effects of work site activity on drainage, erosion control, curbs, sidewalks and the need for restoration of vegetation and fences. 
(c)  The application evaluation by the city engineer shall be completed within ten days after the application is submitted. Based upon his evaluation, the city engineer may recommend that special conditions or requirements be attached to approval of the application. 
(d)  Upon completion of the application evaluation by the city engineer, the city engineer shall determine whether the application should be granted or denied. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 16-20, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Sec. 74-161. - Application fee. 
    Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $25.00, which fee shall be paid in the form of cash or by guaranteed negotiable instrument. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 74-162. - License fee. 
(a)  Upon the granting of a license under this division, the applicant shall pay an issuance fee in accordance with the following schedule which fee shall be payable in the same manner as the application fee: 
Fee Linear Feet 
of Excavation $40.00    1-500  80.00  501-1000  120.00 1001-1500  160.00 in excess of 1500 feet  
(b)  The standard fees set forth in the schedule above shall be adjusted for pavement which has been surfaced or resurfaced within three years of the date the application is filed in accordance with the following schedule: 
Pavement Age Adjustment to Fee  0-12 months 4 × standard fee 13-24 months 3 × standard fee 25-36 months 2 × standard fee  
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 05-29, § 1, 6-7-05) 
Sec. 74-163. - Time limits. 
(a)  License time limit. Upon approval of the license under this division, the applicant shall have three months in which to complete construction. If construction may require additional time for completion, a 30-day extension may be granted to applicant at no additional cost provided such extension is applied for prior to expiration of the license. If an extension request is not submitted prior to license expiration, construction will be halted until such time as licensee shall: 
(1)  Reapply for an additional street cut license; 
(2)  Obtain approval of the application; and 
(3)  Post bond, pay the required fees and comply with all other conditions of the license. 
Where a street cut license is issued in conjunction with a building permit, the license time limit shall be extended to coincide with the time limitations enforced by the building permit. 
(b)  Excavation time limit. For open cuts within a paved area, the excavation time limit shall not exceed one day. Before licensee leaves the site, pavement excavation must be replaced as specified in section 74-141 and returned to a traversable condition. For excavations within a parkway, the opening may remain exposed for a period of not more than ten consecutive days, provided adequate safety measures are applied. 
(c)  License limitations. License approval is granted solely for use as indicated on the plans and application as authorized by the reviewers representing the city engineer and the street department. Approval cannot be transferred to a contractor or location other than as indicated on the license without written permission of the board of public works and safety or its designee. 
(Ord. No. 91-41, § 1, 9-3-91) 
Chapter 78 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Special funds, ch. 2, art. IV, div. 4; Animals, ch. 10; civil emergencies, ch. 26; emergency services, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 50; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Traffic regulation, IC 9-21-1-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, IC 9-21-1-2 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a public way in an urban district that meets the following qualifications: 
(1)  Is open to the public for vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Is publicly maintained. 
(3)  Is one lane wide. 
(4)  Is designated as an alley by the local authorities on an official map of the urban district. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle means the following: 
(1)  The following vehicles: 
a.  Fire department vehicles. 
b.  Police department vehicles. 
c.  Ambulances. 
d.  Emergency vehicles operated by or for hospitals or health and hospital corporations under IC 16-22-8. 
(2)  Vehicles designated as emergency vehicles by the state department of transportation under IC 9-21-20-1. 
(3)  Motor vehicles that, subject to IC 9-21-20-2, are approved by the state emergency medical services commission that are: 
a.  Ambulances that are owned by persons other than hospitals; or 
b.  Not ambulances and that provide emergency medical services, including extrication and rescue services. 
(4)  Vehicles of the state department of correction that, subject to IC 9-21-20-3, are: 
a.  Designated by the state department of correction as emergency vehicles; and 
b.  Responding to an emergency. 
    Bicycle means any foot-propelled vehicle, irrespective of the number of wheels in contact with the ground. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway when at least 50 percent of the frontage of the territory for a distance of at least 500 feet is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for commercial transportation of property or persons. 
    Control-access highway means every highway, street, or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting property or lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from same, except at such points and only in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street, or roadway. 
    Crosswalk means any of the following: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway. 
(2)  A part of a roadway distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or property. 
    Driver means a person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Fire lane means a zone reserved exclusively for the use of emergency fire vehicles. 
    Intersection means the area embraced within: 
(1)  The prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two highways that join at, or approximately at, right angles; or 
(2)  The area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
Where a highway includes two roadways at least 30 feet apart, every crossing of each roadway of the divided highway by an intersecting highway is regarded as a separate intersection. If the intersecting highway also includes two roadways at least 30 feet apart, every crossing of two roadways of the intersecting highway is regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Laned highway means a roadway which is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Motor vehicle means: 
(1)  A vehicle except a motorized bicycle that is self-propelled; or 
(2)  A vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. 
    Motorcycle means a motor vehicle with motive power having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground. The term does not include a farm tractor or a motorized bicycle. 
    Official time standard means standard time or daylight-savings time as may be in current use within the city. 
    Official traffic control devices means a sign, signal, marking, and device, including a railroad advance warning sign, not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of a public body or an official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning, or guiding traffic. 
    Parking means the standing of a vehicle which is unattended by the driver thereof. 
    Passenger curb loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Prima facie speed limit means the maximum speed limit a person may travel along a street or highway without committing an offense against the state or city punishable as a misdemeanor. 
    Private road or driveway means every road or driveway not open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Residential district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district, when the property on the highway for a distance of at least 500 feet is primarily improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of a highway. 
    Roadway means that part of a highway improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and that is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times. 
    School zone, playground zone means any street or part thereof within 600 feet from any public or parochial school or playground, which is so marked or indicated by adequate signs, as to be plainly visible when set apart as such zone. 
    Shopping center means any group of two or more commercial establishments which provide public off-street parking. 
    Speed control signs means the signs with the prima facie speed limit reasonably visible upon its surface, used to notify the public of the prima facie speed limit. 
    Stop means a complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop, stopping or standing means any stop, stopping or standing of a vehicle which is attended by the driver thereof, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or a traffic control sign or signal. 
    Through street means a street or portion of a street at the entrance to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets is required by law to yield right-of-way to vehicles on the through street in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, street cars, vehicles, and other conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic authority means the traffic commission. 
    Traffic control signal means any device, whether manually, electrically, or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    Traffic division means the traffic division of the police department or, if a traffic division is not established, the term shall be deemed to refer to the police department. 
    Trailer means a vehicle: 
(1)  With or without motive power; 
(2)  Designed for carrying persons or property; 
(3)  Designed for being drawn by a motor vehicle; and 
(4)  So constructed that no part of the weight of the trailer rests upon the towing vehicle. 
The term does not include pole trailers. 
    Vehicle means, except as otherwise provided in this section, a device in, upon, or by which a person or property is, or may be, transported or drawn upon a highway. The term does not include devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Yield right-of-way means the required relinquishment to cross-traffic of the privilege of the immediate and prior use of the roadway before entering upon a particular intersection. 
(Code 1985, § 18-1-1; Ord. No. 90-27, § 1, 6-5-90) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- Definitions pertaining to motor vehicles, IC 9-13-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-2. - Application of chapter. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-13) 
State Law reference- Applicability of traffic regulations to person riding animal or driving animal drawing vehicle upon roadway, IC 9-21-1-10. 
Sec. 78-3. - Penalty; separate offenses. 
    Unless otherwise provided, any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00 and court costs. Each violation of each provision of this chapter shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-2) 
State Law reference- General penalty provisions as to motor vehicles, IC 9-30-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-4. - Removal, citation of large vehicles found in violation. 
(a)  Whenever a police officer finds a bus, recreational vehicle, camper, trailer, farm tractor, tractor, or truck larger than a one ton pickup truck in violation of section 78-335, such officer is hereby authorized to require the owner, driver, other person in charge of such vehicle, or property owner where such vehicle is located, to remove the same or turn the engine off, depending on the nature of the violation, so that it no longer violates this chapter. 
(b)  If any person so directed shall fail or refuse to cause compliance with this chapter, or if such bus, recreational vehicle, camper, trailer, farm tractor, tractor, or truck is unattended, such officer is authorized to provide for the removal of same at the owner's expense to the nearest available garage or other place of safety. Additionally, the officer may issue a citation and summons to the owner, driver, other person in charge of same, or property owner where such vehicle is located, to appear in court for possible imposition of penalties and court order to cease and desist. 
(Ord. No. 85-36, § 2, 8-6-85) 
Sec. 78-5. - Violation of specific provisions. 
    Any person who shall be in charge of, or have control over any vehicle, in, upon, or along the streets of the city and shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or who shall refuse to comply with any such provision, shall, except where different penalties are prescribed, for the first offense be subject to a penalty of up to $25.00, for the second offense be subject to a penalty of up to $50.00, and for a third offense be subject to a penalty of up to $75.00; provided that any person to subsequently violate any such provision may be assessed a fine not to exceed $2,500.00 for violating such section in excess of three times. In addition, any person violating section 78-335 shall pay and be responsible for all attorneys fees incurred in the city in enforcing that section. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-1; Ord. No. 85-36, § 2, 8-6-85; Ord. No. 99-38, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 78-6. - Violations deemed offense. 
    It shall be an offense against the city for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required by this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-11) 
Sec. 78-7. - Compliance with police, fire officers. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire department officer, when such fire department officer is in uniform. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-12) 
Sec. 78-8. - Collection and use of fines. 
    All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeitures of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be paid to the city treasury, and it is hereby mandated that all of the revenue therefrom be budgeted and appropriated for the construction, maintenance, and repair of public streets, bridges, and street structures, or for the installation and maintenance of traffic-control devices thereon and for the administration and supervision of traffic activities which will lead to more efficient enforcement. Such fund shall be known as the street and traffic improvement fund. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-12) 
State Law reference- Disposition of fines assessed for traffic ordinance violations, IC 9-21-1-2. 
Sec. 78-9. - Designation as officer. 
    The city's code enforcement officer shall be designated as an officer for purposes of IC 9-22-1. 
(Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 3-6-01) 
Secs. 78-10-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-31. - Traffic engineer designated. 
    The city engineer shall serve as traffic engineer in addition to his other functions, and shall exercise the powers and duties with respect to traffic as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-7) 
State Law reference- City department of traffic engineering, IC 36-9-7-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-32. - Vehicle inspection fund. 
(a)  The common council hereby makes the determination of the existence of a need and a special vehicle inspection fund is hereby created. 
(b)  The common council authorizes the police department to receive a $25.00 fee for inspecting a vehicle and making a record of the inspection upon the application form for the issuance of a certificate of title to such vehicle in accordance with IC 9-17-2-1, et seq., as adopted and amended. Such fee shall be deposited in the vehicle inspection fund. 
(c)  The common council authorizes the police department to receive a $100.00 fee for inspecting a vehicle for a salvage title, garbage title, taxi title, dealership title or commercial title. 
(Ord. No. 88-31, §§ 1, 2, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 08-30, § 1, 7-1-08; Ord. No. 12-28, § 1, 11-7-12) 
State Law reference- Inspection required, duties of inspector, IC 9-17-2-12. 
Secs. 78-33-78-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 78-46. - Established, composition. 
    There is hereby established a traffic commission to serve without compensation, consisting of the traffic engineer, the chief of police or one person designated by the chief of police, one member of the police commission, one member of the common council, road supervisor, and such members or other city officers and representatives of unofficial bodies as may be determined and appointed by the mayor. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-8(A)) 
Sec. 78-47. - Appointment of chairman. 
    The chairman of the traffic commission shall be appointed by the common council. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-8(A)) 
Sec. 78-48. - Meetings. 
    The traffic commission shall hold monthly meetings for the transaction of regular business. The commission shall meet at any time when with reasonable advance notice it is called into session by the chairman, the chief of police, or the mayor. The commission shall, in addition, meet biannually, once in the first half and once during the second half of the fiscal year to review current traffic problems. 
(Code 1985, §§ 18-2-8(A), 18-2-10) 
Sec. 78-49. - Bylaws. 
    The traffic commission shall adopt bylaws, not in conflict with city or state laws, for the regulation of meetings, conducting of business, and the creation of subcommittees. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-8(A)) 
Sec. 78-50. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the general duty of the traffic commission to: 
(1)  Conduct studies and investigations of traffic conditions, patterns, accidents, and problems; 
(2)  Analyze such studies and investigations for the purpose of developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions; 
(3)  Plan the operation of traffic on the streets and highways of this city; and 
(4)  Determine the installation and proper timing of traffic-control devices. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the traffic commission to: 
(1)  Coordinate traffic activities; 
(2)  Carry on educational activities in traffic matters; 
(3)  Supervise the preparation and publication of traffic reports; 
(4)  Receive complaints having to do with traffic matters; and 
(5)  Recommend to the common council and other city officials ways and means for improving traffic conditions, administration, and enforcement of traffic regulations. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the traffic commission, with such aid as may be rendered by other members of the police department, to: 
(1)  Enforce the street traffic regulations of the city and the state; 
(2)  Make arrests for traffic violations; 
(3)  Investigate accidents; 
(4)  Cooperate with other officers in the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions; and 
(5)  Carry out those duties especially imposed upon the commission by this chapter, the traffic ordinances of the city, and the state law. 
(Code 1985, §§ 18-2-1, 18-2-8(B), (C)) 
Secs. 78-51-78-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - POLICE 

Sec. 78-61. - Records of traffic violations. 
(a)  The police department or the traffic division shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of the city and of the state, of which any person has been charged, together with a record which shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Such record shall accumulate during at least a five-year period and from that time on the record shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. 
(b)  All forms for records of violations shall be serially numbered. For each month and year a written record shall be kept showing the disposal of all such forms. 
(c)  All such records and reports shall be public records, except juvenile records, which may be released only by a juvenile court. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-2) 
State Law reference- Juvenile court records, IC 33-12-3-3. 
Sec. 78-62. - Duty to investigate accidents. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents which occur on the public highways of this city and which result in property damage over $200.00 or any accident resulting in injury, and to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with the violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-3) 
State Law reference- Accidents and accident reports, IC 9-26-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-63. - Traffic accident reports. 
    The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. Such reports shall be available for the use and information of the city officials and the city traffic authority. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-4) 
State Law reference- Written report of accident by passenger or owner, IC 9-26-1-6; written report by law enforcement officer, IC 9-26-2-2. 
Sec. 78-64. - Records required, maintenance. 
(a)  The police department shall maintain a suitable record of all traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions, and complaints reported for each driver, which shall be filed alphabetically by the name of the driver concerned. 
(b)  Such records shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-5) 
Sec. 78-65. - Annual reports. 
    The police department shall annually prepare a traffic report which shall be filed with the common council. Such report shall contain information on traffic matters in this city as follows: 
(1)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the number of persons injured, and other pertinent accident data; and 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the traffic division of the police department. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-6) 
Sec. 78-66. - Regulations promulgated by chief. 
    The chief of police may propose such regulations as may be necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and make and enforce temporary and experimental regulations to deal with and provide for emergencies or special conditions, however: 
(1)  No temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than five days, unless, at a regular or special meeting, the traffic commission shall recommend that such regulation should remain in effect for a trial period not to exceed 90 days; and 
(2)  At or before the expiration of such 90-day period, the traffic commission may make such regulation permanent by incorporating such regulation in the schedules duly promulgated under the terms of this chapter, or, when applicable by presenting such regulation to the common council for purposes of having such regulation incorporated in this chapter. If such regulation is presented to the common council for such incorporation, the regulation shall remain in effect as a temporary regulation for an additional period not to exceed 90 days. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-9) 
Sec. 78-67. - Traffic citation forms. 
(a)  The chief of police shall provide books to include traffic citation forms for notifying alleged violators to appear and answer to charges of violating traffic laws and ordinances. Such books shall include serially numbered sets of citations in quadruplicate in the form prescribed and approved by the traffic commission. 
(b)  The chief of police shall be responsible for the issuance of such books to individual members of the police department. The chief of police shall require a written receipt for every book so issued and shall maintain a record of every book and each set of citations contained therein. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-3) 
Sec. 78-68. - Procedure when police stop for violations. 
    Except when authorized or directed under state law to immediately take a person before a judge for the violation of any traffic laws, a police officer who halts a person for such violations, other than for the purpose of giving him a warning notice, and does not take such person into custody under arrest shall take the name, address, and operator's license number of said person, the registration number of the motor vehicle involved, and such other pertinent information as may be necessary, and shall issue to him in writing on a form provided by the traffic commission a traffic citation containing a notice to answer to the charge against him in any court having jurisdiction within the city at a time at least five days after such alleged violation to be specified in such citation. The officer, upon receiving the written promise of the alleged violator to answer as specified in the citation, shall release such person from custody. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-4) 
Sec. 78-69. - Police records. 
(a)  Every police officer upon issuing a traffic citation to an alleged violator of any provision of the motor vehicle laws of this state or of any traffic ordinance of this city shall deposit the original and duplicate form of the citation with his immediate superior officer. 
(b)  The chief of police shall also maintain or cause to be maintained in connection with every traffic citation issued by a member of the police department a record of the disposition of the charge by the court. 
(c)  The chief of police shall also maintain or cause to be maintained a record of all warrants issued by any court on any traffic violation charges and which are delivered to the police department for service, and of the final disposition of all such warrants. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-5) 
State Law reference- Arrest warrants, IC 35-33-2-1 et seq.; search warrants, IC 35-33-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-70. - When citation constitutes complaint. 
    If the form of citation provided under section 78-67 includes information and is sworn to as required under the general laws of this state with respect to a complaint charging commission of the offense alleged in such citation to have been committed, such citation when filed with a court having jurisdiction shall be deemed to be a lawful complaint for the purpose of prosecution under this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-6) 
Sec. 78-71. - Written promise to appear. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate his written promise to appear given to an officer upon the issuance of a traffic citation regardless of the disposition of the charge for which such citation was originally issued. 
(Code 1985, § 18-17-7) 
Sec. 78-72. - Issuance of arrest warrant. 
    If any person fails to comply with a traffic citation given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the court, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance, the police department shall secure and cause to be issued a warrant for his arrest. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-11) 
State Law reference- Arrest warrants, IC 35-33-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-73. - Unattended vehicle in violation. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this city or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic citation, on a form provided by the clerk-treasurer, for the driver to answer to the charge against him within five days during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. at the place specified on the citation. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-8) 
Sec. 78-74. - Removal of vehicle. 
(a)  Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from a street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department, or otherwise maintained by the city under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a bridge, viaduct, or crossway, or in any tube or tunnel where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; 
(2)  When a vehicle upon a highway is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; or 
(3)  When a vehicle is left unattended upon a street or alley and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(b)  Whenever any officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records of the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, he shall fill out the proper forms provided. 
(c)  The board of works, with the recommendation of the chief of police, may enter into a towing agreement with one or more companies to provide vehicle removal and impounding services for the police department pursuant to the terms of the agreement and the requirements of this subsection. 
(1)  The chief of police shall develop objective standards to govern the operation of tow providers for the Portage Police Department. Towing agreements pursuant to this subsection shall comply with the objective standards. 
(2)  Towing agreements shall run for not more than one year commencing January 1 and ending December 31. The chief of police shall make their recommendation on towing agreements to the board of works no later than 30 days prior to the commencement of the agreement term. All towing agreements, regardless of commencement date, shall expire on December 31 of each year. 
(3)  For the purpose of the 2017 contract term only, the chief of police shall make their recommendation to the board of works no later than February 1 with agreements commencing on the date the agreement is fully executed and expiring on December 31, 2017. Any towing agreements already in place on the date of adoption of this section shall remain in effect until March 1, 2017 or the date the board of works first approves an agreement under this section, whichever shall occur first. 
(4)  If any towing company with an agreement under this subsection shall fail to comply with the terms of the agreement, the chief of police may immediately suspend the company and recommend to the board of works at their next meeting that the agreement be terminated immediately. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-13; Ord. No. 17-1, § 1, 2-7-17) 
Secs. 78-75-78-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic control devices, IC 9-21-2-1 et seq. 

Sec. 78-96. - Traffic commission authority. 
(a)  The traffic commission of the city shall have authority to: 
(1)  Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is a particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as it may deem necessary. 
(2)  Establish safety zones of any such kind and character and at such places as it may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  Mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary, and where such traffic lanes have been marked. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicles within the boundaries of any such lanes except when lawfully passing another vehicle or preparatory to making a lawful turning movement. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-13) 
Sec. 78-97. - Duties of street department. 
    The street department, with authority and supervision of the traffic commission, shall place and maintain traffic control devices and signals when and as required under the provisions of this chapter and traffic ordinances of this city to make effective such provisions. The street department may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as they may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of this city or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-1) 
Sec. 78-98. - Standards for devices. 
    All traffic control signs, signals, and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the state department of transportation or resolutions adopted by the common council. All signs and signals required under this chapter of a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-2) 
Sec. 78-99. - Obedience. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with the traffic ordinances of this city, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-3) 
State Law reference- Markings or signs to be obeyed by vehicle drivers, IC 9-21-4-18. 
Sec. 78-100. - Signs or markings not in proper place. 
    No provision of this chapter for which signs or markings are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular provision does not state that signs are required, such provision shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 9-21-1-3(b). 
Sec. 78-101. - Permitted signs; nuisance sign, signal or marking. 
(a)  This article shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property, adjacent to highways, of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for an official sign. 
(b)  Every prohibited sign, signal or marking is declared to be a public nuisance and the authority having jurisdiction over the highway is empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-9(B), (C)) 
Sec. 78-102. - Tampering. 
    No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact deface, injure, knock down, or remove any official traffic control device or any inscription, shield, or insignias thereon, or any other part thereof. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-10) 
Sec. 78-103. - Play streets-Designated. 
    The chief of police with the approval of the traffic commission shall have authority to declare any street or portion thereof a play street and to place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-11) 
Sec. 78-104. - Same-Driving restrictions. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street, or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed areas, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1985, § 18-3-12(A)) 
Secs. 78-105-78-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EQUIPMENT[4] 
Footnotes:
