State Law reference- Motor vehicle equipment, IC 9-19-1-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-126. - School buses. 
    No school bus vehicle used within the city shall be regulated by this chapter as to any special warning device since such devices are regulated by the state school bus committee. 
(Code 1985, § 18-17-6) 
State Law reference- School bus design and equipment, IC 9-19-13-1 et seq. 
Secs. 78-127-78-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LIGHTS 

Sec. 78-136. - Road repair, snow removal equipment. 
    All road repair and snow removal equipment and all towing trucks used and operated in the city by any person shall be equipped with a flashing yellow light visible from directly in front of the center thereof. 
(Code 1985, § 18-17-4) 
State Law reference- Lamps on snow removal equipment, IC 9-19-6-23. 
Secs. 78-137-78-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-156. - Funeral processions, parades; permit. 
(a)  Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right hand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as closely as is practical and safe. 
(b)  No funeral, procession, or parade containing 100 or more persons or 20 or more vehicles, excepting the forces of the United States Armed Forces, the military forces of this state, and the forces of the police and fire departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along the street except in accordance with a permit issued by the police department and such other regulations as are set forth in this chapter which may apply. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-2(B), (D)) 
State Law reference- Funeral processions, IC 9-21-13-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-157. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    No person shall drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-3) 
Sec. 78-158. - Backing of vehicles. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not back same unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-4) 
Sec. 78-159. - Motorcycles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motorcycle, motor scooter, or any other motorized two-wheel vehicle on any street within the city unless such motorcycle, motor scooter, or any other motorized two-wheel vehicle is equipped with a permanently installed muffler with no removable parts if such motorcycle, motor scooter, or other motorized two-wheel vehicle is so manufactured as to permit the permanent installation of such muffler and regardless of whether such permanent installation was made at the factory or not. 
(b)  As to all motorcycles, motor scooters, or other motorized two-wheel vehicles so manufactured as to not permit effective muffling of motor noise, all persons operating such machines shall do so in a manner so as to minimize noise while operating such motorcycle, motor scooter or other motorized two-wheel vehicle on public streets within the city. No muffling system on any motorcycle, motor scooter or other two-wheel motorized vehicle operated on the public streets within the city shall be altered from factory installation except an alteration so as to make such muffling system permanent and irremovable. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motorcycle, motor scooter, or other two-wheel motorized vehicle within the city unless such person has had duly issued to him and has in his possession while so operating such vehicle, an operator's permit or license. 
(d)  Penalties for violations of this section are set forth in section 1-16 of this Code. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-5(B), (C), (E), (F); Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, 7-3-12) 
State Law reference- Motorcycles, IC 9-21-10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-160. - Attaching sled to vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any sled shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a public roadway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-6) 
Sec. 78-161. - Traffic on school property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for motor vehicles to be driven in school parking lots exceeding the speed of ten miles per hour. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for motor vehicles to be driven on access roads to school parking lots exceeding the speed of 20 miles per hour. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for snowmobiles, go-carts, off-road vehicles or other similar types of motorized vehicles to be driven or operated on school property. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for vehicles to be driven or operated off designated roadways or parking lots. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for vehicles to be driven or parked on school property during school hours except by persons who are attending school, who are on official school business, or who are participating in approved recreational activities or school functions. 
(f)  Penalties for violations of this section are set forth in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-7) 
Sec. 78-162. - Off-road vehicles. 
(a)  The operation of off-road or licensed motor vehicles on private property without the written consent of the private property owner or tenant is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  The operation of off-road or licensed vehicles on public owned property without the written consent of the public body which controls such property is hereby prohibited; provided, however, that this shall not preclude the operation of licensed motor vehicles upon the public roads, streets, or highways. 
(c)  Any written consents required by this section shall contain the name of the operator, the identification of the vehicle to be used, the hours during which such operation is to be permitted, and shall be signed and dated by the person or authority granting such consent. Such consent shall be carried by the operator at all times during such operation and shall be exhibited upon demand therefor by any police officer. 
(d)  Penalties for violations of this section are set forth in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 18-12-8) 
Sec. 78-163. - Open alcoholic beverage containers. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverage has the meaning set forth in IC 7.1-1-3-5. 
    Container has the meaning set forth in IC 7.1-1-3-13. 
    Motor vehicle has the meaning set forth in IC 9-13-2-105, except that "motor vehicle," as used in this section, shall not include any chartered passenger vehicle licensed to operate within the state or any recreational vehicle as defined in IC 9-13-2-150 and which is designed to transport more than ten passengers, including the operator. 
(b)  Possession or consumption prohibited. A person who knowingly: 
(1)  Consumes an alcoholic beverage; or 
(2)  Possesses a container: 
a.  That has been opened; 
b.  That has a broken seal; or 
c.  From which some of the contents have been removed; 
while in a motor vehicle that is being operated upon a public highway within the city limits commits a violation of this section. 
(c)  Motor vehicles generally. The operator or owner of a motor vehicle who, while the motor vehicle is in operation knowingly keeps or allows to be kept in an area of the motor vehicle that is accessible to the operator or a passenger a container: 
(1)  That has been opened; 
(2)  That has a broken seal; or 
(3)  From which some of the contents have been removed; 
commits a violation of this section. 
(d)  Recreational, charter passenger vehicles. The operator of a recreational vehicle or chartered passenger vehicle licensed to operate within the state, who, while the motor vehicle is in operation, knowingly keeps or allows to be kept in an area of the recreational vehicle or chartered passenger vehicle that is accessible to the operator a container: 
(1)  That has been opened; 
(2)  That has a broken seal; or 
(3)  From which some of the contents have been removed; 
commits a violation of this section. 
(e)  Citations. An officer of the police department may issue a city ordinance violation citation to a person who violates this section. The first such citation issued to an individual shall impose a $50.00 fine. Each subsequent citation issued to an individual shall impose a penalty not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 92-24, § 1, 6-2-92) 
Sec. 78-164. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-21, § 1, adopted Dec. 6, 2016, repealed § 78-164, which pertained to driving on Keller Avenue or Fairview Avenue after rainfall and derived from Ord. No. 90-69, §§ 1, 2, adopted Dec. 10, 1990. 
Secs. 78-165-78-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SPEED[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Speed limits, IC 9-21-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 78-186. - Prima facie limit. 
    The prima facie speed limit of all streets and highways not specifically mentioned in section 78-188 below shall be 25 miles per hour. The prima facie speed limit in business or school districts shall be 20 miles per hour. 
(Code 1985, § 18-4-1; Ord. No. 09-40, § 1, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 78-187. - Determination of reasonable and safe speed. 
    The traffic commission shall determine whether the prima facie speed limit is reasonable and safe under the conditions found to exist on a street or a highway, or a portion of a street or a highway, on the basis of traffic and engineering investigations. 
(Code 1985, § 18-4-2; Ord. No. 09-40, § 2, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 78-188. - Schedule of limits. 
    The specific prima facie speed limits for the below listed streets and highways or portions of streets and highways, as determined by the traffic commission, shall be as follows:

Sec. 78-189. - Speed control signs. 
    The traffic commission shall direct the street department to erect speed control signs along the streets and highways within the city, thereby giving notice to persons of the prima facie speed limit as determined by the traffic commission. 
(Code 1985, § 18-4-4; Ord. No. 09-40, § 4, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 78-190. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person violating the prima facie speed limit, as posted along portions of the streets and highways and as recorded in Schedule 1, shall have committed an offense against the city and shall be prosecuted by the City of Portage Ordinance Violation Bureau. 
(b)  In every charge of the violation of any speed regulation in this chapter, the complaint of affidavit, and the summons, warrant and notice to appear shall specify the speed at which the defendant is alleged to have driven, and the prima facie speed limit as applicable at the location of the violation.

Sec. 78-191. - School zone. 
    The fine for exceeding the posted prima facie speed limit in a school zone is $80.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-52, § 2, 12-6-11) 
Sec. 78-192. - Construction zone. 
    The fine for exceeding the posted prima facie speed limit in a construction zone is $80.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-52, § 3, 12-6-11)

ARTICLE VII. - TURNS 

Sec. 78-211. - Signs indicating course to be traveled. 
    The traffic commission is authorized to place markers, buttons, or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating that the course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by law or ordinance. When authorized markers, buttons, or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles, no driver of such vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1985, § 18-5-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 9-21-8-21. 
Sec. 78-212. - Prohibited intersection turns. 
    The traffic commission is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left or U-turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day, and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs, or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(Code 1985, § 18-5-3) 
Sec. 78-213. - Compliance with intersection signs. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left, or U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign. 
(Code 1985, § 18-5-4) 
Sec. 78-214. - Proper direction of traffic. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district and, shall not upon any other street so turn a vehicle, unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1985, § 18-5-5) 
State Law reference- Making U-turn on freeway or interstate highway, IC 9-21-8-19. 
Secs. 78-215-78-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS 

Sec. 78-236. - Signs. 
    Whenever any ordinance of this city designates any one-way street or alley the traffic commission shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof; and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed in every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1985, § 18-6-1) 
Sec. 78-237. - Direction of traffic. 
    Upon these streets and parts of streets and in those alleys, described in such Schedule 2 as may be attached hereto and made a part hereof, vehicular traffic shall move only in the direction of traffic as is indicated on signs erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1985, § 18-6-2) 
State Law reference- Vehicles to obey one-way traffic signs, IC 9-21-8-9. 
Sec. 78-238. - Alternating directions of traffic. 
(a)  The traffic commission may determine and designate streets, parts of streets, or specific lanes thereon, upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one direction during specified time periods, and shall place and maintain appropriate markings, signs, barriers or other devices which are sufficient to give notice thereof. 
(b)  The traffic commission may erect signs temporarily, designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction, regardless of the centerline of the roadway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-6-3) 
Secs. 78-239-78-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CLASSES OF TRAFFIC ON CERTAIN HIGHWAYS 

Sec. 78-261. - Gross weight restrictions. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall operate any vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the amounts specified at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets so posted. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-1) 
State Law reference- Ordinances regulating the weight of vehicles, IC 9-20-1-3. 
Sec. 78-262. - Commercial vehicles exceeding 5,000 pounds gross. 
    Commercial vehicles exceeding 5,000 pounds gross weight shall be restricted at all times to those streets or parts of streets so posted, except such vehicles may be operated thereon for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise and then only by entering such street at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle and proceeding thereon no farther than the nearest intersection thereafter. This restriction does not apply to local public passenger bus operations. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-2) 
Sec. 78-263. - Commercial vehicles exceeding 10,000 pounds gross. 
    Except on the state highway system, no commercial vehicles with a gross weight in excess of 10,000 pounds shall be operated in any residentially-zoned district in the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day; provided if this restriction shall result in an undue hardship or unfair competition, the traffic commission shall have the power to authorize the issuance of special permits from time to time as deemed necessary for the protection of the rights of any specific person. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-3) 
Sec. 78-264. - Heavy machinery. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any type of construction machinery or other type of heavy equipment or machinery on any public street or road within the city without proper lugs or mats so as to prevent any damage or injury to the surface of such public road or street. 
(b)  Any person violating the terms of this section shall reimburse the city for any damages sustained by reason of such violation. This section shall not be construed to limit the remedies of the city for violations of the terms of this section, but shall be construed to supplement any existing remedies available to the city. 
(c)  Penalties for violations of this section are set forth in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-4) 
Sec. 78-265. - Traffic on U.S. Highway 20. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for motor vehicles over five tons empty weight to pass other motor vehicles on that portion of U.S. Highway 20 within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for motor vehicles commonly known and denominated as "tractors with trailers" to pass other motor vehicles on that portion of U.S. Highway 20 within the city. 
(c)  Penalties for violations of this section are set forth in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-5) 
Sec. 78-266. - Motor-driven cycles, bicycles, and other nonmotorized vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  The traffic commission is hereby authorized to determine and designate those heavily traveled streets upon which shall be prohibited the use of the roadway by motor-driven cycles, bicycles, or other nonmotorized traffic, and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  When signs are so erected giving notice thereof, no person shall disobey the restrictions stated on such signs. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-6) 
Sec. 78-267. - Obstructions to visibility at intersections-Prohibited. 
    On property at any corner formed by intersecting streets, it shall be unlawful to install, set out or maintain, or to allow the installation, setting out, or maintenance of any sign, hedge, shrubbery, or natural growth, or other obstruction to the view, higher than three feet above the level of the center of the adjacent intersection, within that triangular area between the property line and a diagonal line joining points on the property lines 25 feet from the point of their intersection, or in the case of rounded corners, the triangular area between the tangents to the curve and a diagonal line joining points on such tangent 25 feet from the point of their intersection. The tangents referred to are those at the beginning and at the end of the curve at the corner. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-7) 
Sec. 78-268. - Same-Exceptions. 
(a)  Section 78-267 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Permanent buildings, public utility poles, trees trimmed (to the trunk) to align at least eight feet above the level of the intersection; 
(2)  Saplings, or plant species of open growth habits, and not planted in the form of a hedge, which are so placed and trimmed as to leave at all seasons a clear and unobstructed cross-view; 
(3)  Supporting members of appurtenances to permanent buildings existing on January 4, 1978; 
(4)  Official warning signs or signals; 
(5)  Places where the contour of the ground is such that there can be no cross-visibility at the intersection; or 
(6)  Two signs mounted ten feet or more above the ground and whose supports do not constitute an obstruction as defined in section 78-267. 
(b)  No obstruction to cross-visibility shall be deemed to be excepted from the application of this section because of its being in existence on January 4, 1978, unless expressly exempted. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-8) 
Sec. 78-269. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the city attorney. However, the traffic commission shall investigate violations of this article as may be required. 
(b)  The traffic commission shall be empowered to declare what shall constitute a public obstruction nuisance, to prevent the same, require its abatement, authorize the removal of the same by the proper officers, and provide for the punishment of the person who may have created or permitted the existence of such nuisance, and to provide for the collection of such expenses either by causing them to be placed on the tax duplicate or by suit. 
(c)  Any obstruction maintained in violation of this article shall be deemed a public obstruction nuisance, and upon failure of the owner of the same to abate the same within 20 days after the posting upon the premises of notice to abate the obstruction nuisance signed by the traffic commission such representatives of the traffic commission as the commission may so authorize may enter upon the premises at reasonable times and remove or eliminate the obstruction. 
(Code 1985, § 18-13-9) 
Secs. 78-270-78-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING; YIELD RIGHT-OF-WAY[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Parking, IC 9-21-16-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-291. - Restrictions. 
    The provisions of this division prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-1) 
Sec. 78-292. - Duty to observe more restricted ordinances. 
    The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified times. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-2) 
Sec. 78-293. - Signs posted on streets. 
(a)  When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets so posted. 
(b)  When appropriate signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle between the hours specified on any day except Sundays and public holidays within the district or upon any of the streets so posted. 
(c)  When appropriate signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle between the hours specified on any day except Sundays and public holidays within the district or upon any of the streets so posted. 
(d)  When appropriate signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the specified time within the district or upon any of the streets so posted. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-3) 
State Law reference- Legal holidays, IC 1-1-9-1. 
Sec. 78-294. - Signs limiting parking time. 
    Whenever by this article or any other ordinance of the city any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets, it shall be the duty of the traffic commission to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-4) 
Sec. 78-295. - Through street parking and parking in front of mailboxes prohibited. 
(a)  No person, except the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, as defined by state law, or this chapter, shall park a vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, on any through street, as designated by section 78-311, when there exists two or more inches of snow. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to park any vehicle in a manner that any part of the vehicle blocks or obstructs the use of any mailbox by the owner or post office. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-5; Ord. No. 08-83, § 1, 12-3-08; Ord. No. 09-5, § 1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 78-296. - Parking during snow removal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on the paved or travelled portion of any street within the city for a period of time longer than five minutes for loading and unloading persons or passengers or 30 minutes for loading or unloading property at any time after snow begins to fall and the snow on the streets exceeds two inches in depth. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined the sum of $25.00 for the first offense, and $100.00 for each subsequent offense. In addition, the police department shall remove and impound any vehicle parked on the street in violation of this section. The owner of a vehicle so removed and impounded shall, in addition to any fine imposed under this subsection, be financially responsible for the expenses incurred in the removal and storage of his vehicle. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-6; Ord. No. 89-18, §§ 1, 2, 5-2-89; Ord. No. 90-13, §§ 2, 3, 3-6-90; Ord. No. 09-5, § 2, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 78-297. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Whenever any violation of the provisions of this article, excluding section 78-296, shall come to the attention of the police department, the owner or occupant of the vehicle shall be notified in writing of such violation on a form to be provided by the city for that purpose. 
(b)  Such notice forms shall be serially numbered and shall show the specific violation charged. 
(c)  The notice shall show the date, time and location of the violation, and the make, color, license number, and model of the vehicle. 
(d)  One copy of such notice shall be presented to the violator in person or, if he is not present, then placed on the violating vehicle. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-7; Ord. No. 09-5, § 3, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 78-298. - Failure to pay fine. 
    Whenever any person has been issued a notice for the violation of any provision of this article, the police officer issuing such notice shall file, or cause to be filed, in a court of competent jurisdiction an information charging such person with the violation specified in the notice. 
(Code 1985, § 18-11-9; Ord. No. 09-5, § 4, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 78-299. - Failure to respond to citation. 
    If a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing, or parking under the traffic laws or ordinances does not appear in response to a traffic citation affixed to such motor vehicle within a period of five days the traffic violation bureau shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the traffic citation was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that if such letter is disregarded for a period of five days a warrant of arrest will be issued. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-9) 
State Law reference- Parking tickets, IC 9-30-11-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-300. - Presumption of guilt. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Code 1985, § 18-18-10; Ord. No. 09-5, § 5, 2-17-09) 
Secs. 78-301-78-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPECIAL STOPS REQUIRED 

Sec. 78-311. - Designation of through streets. 
    The traffic commission shall determine those streets and parts of streets which may be through streets, and forward its determination to the common council for incorporation into the city's thoroughfare plan. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-1) 
State Law reference- Designation of through highways by local authorities, IC 9-21-1-3(a)(6). 
Sec. 78-312. - Placement of signs. 
(a)  Whenever any duly promulgated schedule of the traffic authority designates and describes a through street, the traffic commission shall direct the placement of a traffic control sign on each and every street intersecting such through street or intersecting that portion thereof described and designated as such, unless traffic at any such intersection is controlled at all times by traffic control signals. The traffic commission shall maintain any signs erected and installed pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(b)  At the intersection of two such through streets, or at the intersection of a through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, traffic control signs shall be installed and erected at the approaches of either or both streets as may be determined necessary by a traffic study. 
(c)  The traffic commission may determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than through streets, and may designate any such intersection by a stop sign and/or yield sign at one or more entrances to such intersections. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-2) 
Sec. 78-313. - Designation of hazardous intersections. 
    The traffic commission is hereby authorized to determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than through streets and may designate any such intersection and erect stop signs or yield signs at any one or more entrances to such intersections. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-3) 
Sec. 78-314. - Stop, yield sign characteristics. 
(a)  Every stop sign erected pursuant to this division shall bear the word "STOP" in letters not less than eight inches in height, and every yield sign shall bear the word "YIELD" in letters not less than seven inches in height. Such signs shall at nighttime be rendered luminous by steady or flashing internal illumination, or by a fixed floodlight projected onto the face of the sign, or by the use of luminous paints. Every stop sign and every yield sign shall be located as near as practicable at the nearest line of the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if none, at the nearest line of the roadway. 
(b)  In residence and business districts, and at any place where parked vehicles may frequently obscure the stop or yield signs, the signs shall be mounted so that their lower edge will be seven feet above the top of the curb, the left edge of the sign shall not be less than one foot nor more than three feet back from the face of the curb. Where there is a marked crosswalk on the pavement the sign shall be erected four feet in advance of the crosswalk line nearest to approaching traffic. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-4) 
Sec. 78-315. - Stopping at stop signs. 
(a)  When approaching a stop sign erected at or near an intersection at which there is one or more pedestrian crosswalk, every driver of a vehicle shall stop at the crosswalk before entering the intersection; or, if there is no such crosswalk at such intersection, every driver shall stop at a clearly marked stop line; or, if no such stop line exists at such intersection, then every driver shall stop at a point near the intersecting roadway where he has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. However, the provisions of this section shall not apply when a driver is otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  After the driver of a vehicle has stopped at the entrance to a through highway, such driver shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection of such through highway or which are approaching so closely on such highway as to constitute an immediate hazard, but such driver having so yielded, may proceed and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection on such through highway shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle so proceeding into or across the through highway. 
(c)  After the driver of a vehicle has stopped, in obedience to a stop sign, at an intersection where a stop sign is erected at one or more entrances thereto, although not a part of a through highway, such driver shall proceed cautiously, yielding to vehicles not so obliged to stop which are within the intersection or approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard, but he may then proceed. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-5) 
Sec. 78-316. - Stopping at yield signs. 
    The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall stop, if required for safety, before entering the crosswalk, or if there is no crosswalk, at a clearly marked stop line, or if the intersection is unmarked, at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting highway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-6(B)) 
State Law reference- Driving procedure in approaching yield sign, IC 9-21-8-32. 
Sec. 78-317. - Obstruction of intersection, pedestrian crosswalk. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space within the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate that person's motor vehicle without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1985, § 18-7-8) 
Secs. 78-318-78-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROHIBITED PARKING 

Sec. 78-331. - Prohibited parking areas. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  Between sidewalk and curb. 
(2)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the traffic engineer has indicated a different length by signs or markings. 
(3)  On the traveled portion of any roadway which does not have a curb or gutter, when such stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-1(A)(1), (8), (15)) 
State Law reference- Areas where stopping, standing or parking prohibited, IC 9-21-16-5. 
Sec. 78-332. - Restricted parking zones. 
(a)  Except as otherwise prohibited or restricted under this chapter or as prohibited or restricted by order of the traffic commission, it shall be lawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to place or park the same on any of the streets of the city at all times. 
(b)  The traffic commission is hereby authorized to determine and designate by proper signs, distances not exceeding 100 feet, at places where the stopping or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. Restricted parking zones as provided for in this chapter shall be plainly marked out and indicated by painted lines or other suitable devices. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-2) 
Sec. 78-333. - Alley parking. 
    No person shall park a vehicle, within an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-3) 
Sec. 78-334. - Trailer, tractor, semitrailer parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place or locate, or permit the parking, placing or locating of any automobile on any public street or highway within the city for a period exceeding 48 hours. 
(b)  Except for the expeditious delivery and pick-up of materials, or for construction use, it shall be unlawful for any person, owner or driver to park, or cause to be parked, any trailer with a cargo area more than ten feet long, semitractor or semitrailer upon any lot or parcel of property within the city zoned for residential use. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this section shall not apply to R.V. and boat trailers. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-4; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 11-8-95; Ord. No. 05-07, § 1, 2-1-05; Ord. No. 05-65, § 1, 12-13-05) 
Sec. 78-335. - Bus, truck, trailer parking restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, owner or driver to park, or cause to be parked, any bus, recreational vehicle, camper, trailer, farm tractor, tractor or class 8 truck upon any street, road, shoulder of the road or street, or alley within the city in any area zoned for residential, semicommercial or commercial use, except for expeditious delivery or pickup of materials, or for construction use. However, no such vehicle shall be parked on any of the streets or alleys in the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, or driver to park or cause to be parked any semitrailer upon any lot, within the city zoned for residential, semicommercial, or commercial use except for expeditious delivery and pickup of materials, or for construction use. This subsection shall not be applicable to motels, or to commercial trucking businesses located in the city in areas zoned for those purposes, nor shall it prohibit semitrailer parking in any nonresidential area north of U.S. Route 20 between the westerly city limits and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Overpass. No semitrailer shall be parked closer than 25 feet from the north edge of the pavement of U.S. Route 20. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, certain businesses located in an area zoned for that purpose which have continuously and presently maintain a semitrailer on such business for storage purposes shall be permitted to keep such trailer parked upon such business premises; such six specific businesses are: 
(1)  Brown Tire Company which currently has two trailers. 
(2)  Mill's Automotive which currently has one trailer. 
(3)  Hull Brothers Auto Parts which currently has three trailers. 
(4)  Five Star Food Center which currently has one trailer. 
(5)  Portage Jaycees which currently has one trailer. 
(6)  Coast-to-Coast Hardware which currently has one trailer. 
(d)  The businesses enumerated in subsection (c) of this section shall be entitled to maintain such trailers under the following conditions: 
(1)  So long as the respective businesses above set forth remain under the ownership of the present owner, and so long as the respective businesses above set forth remain of the same nature and type as they respectively are at the present time. 
(2)  Such right is not transferrable to a new owner. 
(3)  So long as the respective businesses above set forth shall not convert to a different type of business at the same location. 
(4)  Such businesses must keep and maintain the trailers presently located on such business premises and specified herein in a neat and presentable appearance. 
(5)  Such businesses may not physically change any of the trailers presently on their business premises. 
(6)  Such businesses must have permits for the current year. 
(7)  No additional trailers whatsoever may be added to the respective business premises. 
(8)  A one-time permit must be obtained during calendar year 1988, and such permit shall remain valid until such time as the trailers are removed; such permit fee shall be in the amount of $10.00 per trailer. 
(9)  Any violation whatsoever of subsections (c) and (d) of this section shall void the permit and all trailers on the property shall be considered in violation of this section. 
(10)  No additional alternate business shall be added at any time under any condition which may use the trailer for the nature of such business or enterprise. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, or driver of any vehicle described in subsections (a) and (b) of this section to allow the engine of such vehicle, or the engine/motor of any accessory to such vehicle, to operate continuously while the vehicle is parked, except during the expeditious delivery and pickup of materials. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to violate any of the terms and conditions of this section. 
(1)  A fine of $25.00 shall be assessed against first-time offenders. 
(2)  A fine of $50.00 shall be assessed against second-time offenders. 
(3)  A fine of $75.00 shall be assessed against third-time offenders. 
(4)  A maximum fine of $2,500.00 may be assessed against persons violating this section in excess of three times. 
The penalties specified in this subsection shall be in addition to any court costs assessed by any court of competent jurisdiction. Any person convicted of violating this section shall pay and be responsible for all attorney's fees incurred by the city in enforcing this section. 
(g)  The public purpose to be served by this section is to provide for peace and tranquility in the neighborhoods of the city, to eliminate safety hazards caused by the blockage or partial blockage of roadways and that vision of motorists within the city, and to enhance and maintain the beauty of our community. It shall not be necessary for the city to post street signs to put the public on notice of the provisions of this section, the passage of this section by the common council serving as sufficient notice. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-5; Ord. No. 85-16, § 1, 4-2-85; Ord. No. 85-36, § 1, 8-6-85; Ord. No. 87-23, § 1, 7-21-87; Ord. No. 88-44, § 1, 10-4-88; Ord. No. 05-65, § 1, 12-13-05) 
Sec. 78-336. - Central business district parking. 
    The traffic commission is authorized to prohibit parking on either or both sides of any street in the city between the hours and on days of the week specified by it, and to erect signs so indicating. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-6) 
Sec. 78-337. - Prohibited for display, repair. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any street or highway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale; or 
(2)  Washing, greasing, or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-7) 
Sec. 78-338. - Parking near schools. 
    The traffic commission is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking either on both sides of and adjacent to street or to school property when such parking would, in its opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either side of the street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-8) 
Sec. 78-339. - Street width size and parking. 
    The traffic commission is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed 20 feet or upon one side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed 33 feet. When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-9) 
Sec. 78-340. - One-way streets. 
    The traffic commission is authorized to erect signs upon either or both sides of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles. When such signs are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such side in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-10) 
Sec. 78-341. - Highway with two or more roadways. 
    If a highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon either or both sides of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The traffic engineer is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the side of any such one-way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1985, § 18-8-11) 
Sec. 78-342. - Fire lanes located in shopping centers. 
(a)  The city is authorized, empowered, and directed to enter into certain contracts with the owners or lessees of shopping centers located within the city to regulate the parking of vehicles in fire lanes at such shopping centers. 
(b)  The violation of the fire lane parking regulations in effect at any shopping center under contract with the city shall be a fine of $50.00 for each violation. Any vehicle parked in a fire lane shall be towed away and impounded at the owner's expense in addition to the fine. 
(c)  The fire chief or his duly authorized and designated representative(s) shall be authorized to enforce fire lane parking regulations. 
(Ord. No. 90-27, § 2, 6-5-90; Ord. No. 99-10, § 1, 3-2-99) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing or parking vehicle in fire lane, IC 9-21-16-5.5. 
Sec. 78-343. - Valid registration required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place, locate, or permit the parking, placing, or locating of any vehicle on any street, alley, or highway within the city unless the vehicle is validly registered and bears current and valid license plates. A person violating this provision shall be fined the sum of $50.00 for each violation. Any vehicle parked in violation of this provision shall be towed away and impounded at the owner's expense, in addition to the fine. 
(Ord. No. 95-57, § 1, 12-5-95) 
Sec. 78-344. - Parking on public property. 
    The traffic commission is authorized to prohibit or restrict parking on public property within the City of Portage. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on public property in violation of the prohibitions or restrictions established by the traffic commission. 
(Ord. No. 99-38, § 2, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 78-345-78-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - METHOD OF PARKING 

Sec. 78-356. - Angle parking areas-Where permitted. 
(a)  The traffic commission shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark and place appropriate signs upon such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal-aid or state highway within the city unless the state department of transportation has determined by resolution or order entered in its minutes that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. 
(b)  Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street. 
(Code 1985, § 18-9-2) 
Sec. 78-357. - Same-Method. 
    Upon those streets which have been appropriately designated by the traffic commission for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle closer than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such lines or markings. A vehicle must enter the parking space with a forward movement. 
(Code 1985, § 18-9-3) 
Sec. 78-358. - Special curb loading permits. 
(a)  The traffic commission is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1985, § 18-9-4) 
Sec. 78-359. - Nighttime parking. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked at nighttime upon any street within a business or residence district no lights need be displayed upon such parked vehicle. 
(b)  Whenever a vehicle is parked upon a street or highway outside of a business or residence district during the hours between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise, such vehicle shall be equipped with one or more lamps which shall exhibit light on the roadway side visible from a distance from 500 feet to the front of the vehicle and a red light on the roadway side visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear. 
(c)  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Code 1985, § 18-9-5) 
State Law reference- Display of lights upon parked or stopped vehicle, IC 9-21-7-8. 
Secs. 78-360-78-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LOADING; UNLOADING 

Sec. 78-371. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
    The traffic commission is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions of this division are applicable. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-1) 
Sec. 78-372. - Loading permits. 
    The traffic commission shall not designate or assign any curb loading zone upon special request of any person unless such person makes application for a permit for such zone and for two signs to indicate the ends of each such zone. The traffic commission upon granting a permit and issuing such signs shall collect from the applicant and deposit in the city treasury a minimum service fee of $35.00 per year or fraction thereof and may by general regulations impose conditions for the use of such signs and for reimbursement of the city for the value lost thereof upon its loss or damage and its return due to misuse or upon expiration of the permit. Every such permit shall expire at the end of one year. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-2) 
Sec. 78-373. - Loading, unloading passengers. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-3) 
Sec. 78-374. - Loading, unloading freight. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or any length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect except for the loading or unloading of passengers with a three-minute time limit. In no case shall a stop for loading or unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-4) 
Sec. 78-375. - Designation of bus and taxicab stops. 
    The traffic commission is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands, and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such manner as shall be determined to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop, bus stand, taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-5) 
Sec. 78-376. - Bus, taxicab operator's duties. 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not park such a vehicle upon any street at any place other than a designated bus stand. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at a designated bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone, except in the case of an emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand, or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such vehicle no further than 18 inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(d)  The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than in a designated taxicab stand. This designation shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading and unloading of passengers. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-6) 
Sec. 78-377. - Exclusive use of bus, taxicab stops. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1985, § 18-10-7) 
Secs. 78-378-78-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PEDESTRIANS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrians, IC 9-21-17-1 et seq. 

Sec. 78-401. - Pedestrian rights. 
    Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals as declared in IC 9-21-3-7 and 9-21-17-2 but at all other places pedestrians shall be granted those rights and be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 18-14-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 9-21-17-1. 
Sec. 78-402. - Inoperative traffic control devices. 
    When traffic control signals are not in place or are not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian if upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. But no pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. A pedestrian's right-of-way in a crosswalk is modified under the condition and as stated in IC 9-21-17-7 and 9-21-17-8. 
(Code 1985, §§ 18-3-6(A), 18-14-2(A)) 
Sec. 78-403. - Manner of crossing generally. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any other place than by route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb except in a crosswalk. 
(Code 1985, § 18-14-3(A)) 
State Law reference- Crossing diagonally prohibited, IC 9-21-17-10; use of right half of crosswalks required, IC 9-21-17-11. 
Sec. 78-404. - Use of crosswalks required. 
(a)  No person shall cross a street between two adjacent intersections which have traffic signals, except at a clearly marked crosswalk. 
(b)  No person shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business district. 
(Code 1985, § 18-14-5) 
Sec. 78-405. - Duty of drivers. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-14-8) 
State Law reference- Driver to yield right-of-way to blind pedestrian, IC 9-21-17-21. 
Sec. 78-406. - Solicitation in designated roadways. 
    It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to sit, stand or move within or upon a designated roadway, highway or a median between designated roadway or highway, or within the public right-of-way not exceeding 50 feet from the traveled portion of an intersection controlled by an automatic traffic signal or stop sign, or on private property immediately adjacent to a designated roadway, for the purpose of or while engaged in (by oral or written methods): 
(1)  Soliciting, or peddling, selling, advertising, donating, or distributing any product, property, or service, including but not limited to tickets, handbills, newspapers, or other printed material, to or from an occupant of a vehicle in the roadway; or 
(2)  Conversation or discourse with an occupant of a vehicle in the roadway. 
a.  Unless expressly allowed at designated intersections, subject to section 78-409. 
b.  Unless on private property, with written permission, in there possession, from the owner or owners designee, of the property. 
(Ord. No. 10-41, § 1, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 78-407. - Designated roadways. 
    The following are the designated roadways within the city: 
(1)  Highway 20 within the city. 
(2)  Route 6 within the city. 
(3)  Crisman Road from Highway 20 to Willowcreek/Crisman Overpass. 
(4)  Willowcreek/Crisman Overpass to 700 north. 
(5)  Central Avenue from Willowdale Road to Airport Road. 
(Ord. No. 10-41, § 1, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 78-408. - Designated intersections. 
    [The following are the designated intersections within the city:] 
(1)  Central Avenue and Willowdale Road. 
(2)  Central Avenue and Irving. 
(3)  Central Avenue and Vivian. 
(Ord. No. 10-41, § 1, 8-3-10) 
Sec. 78-409. - Solicitation in designated intersections. 
    Solicitation shall be allowed in designated intersections upon application for permit before the board of works; provided, however, that no person under the age of 16 shall be allowed to solicit in designated intersections. The board of works shall set the start and finish time of the solicitation taking into account traffic conditions and available day light, determine the size of any signage, and require any solicitor to wear a reflective vest. The permit from the board of works shall be valid for not more then 15 days. 
(Ord. No. 10-41, § 1, 8-3-10; Ord. No. 13-16, § 1, 9-3-13) 
Secs. 78-410-78-425. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - BICYCLES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles and motorized bicycles, IC 9-21-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 78-426. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-22, § 1, adopted June 1, 2010, repealed § 78-426 which pertained to licenses and derived from § 18-15-2 of the 1985 Code. 
Sec. 78-427. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-22, § 2, adopted June 1, 2010, repealed § 78-427 which pertained to sale and rental of bicycles and derived from § 18-15-3 of the 1985 Code. 
Sec. 78-428. - Duties of operators. 
(a)  Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by traffic ordinances of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this article and except as to those provisions of law and ordinances which by their nature can have no application. 
(b)  Every person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official traffic control signals, signs, and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(c)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left, or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall obey all the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(d)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right hand side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(e)  Persons riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall not ride more than single file except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(f)  Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-4(A)-(C), (F)-(H)) 
State Law reference- Rights and duties in general of person riding bicycle, IC 9-21-11-2; use of permanent and regular attached seat, IC 9-21-11-3; number of persons carried on bicycle, IC 9-21-11-4; riding more than two abreast, IC 9-21-11-6. 
Sec. 78-429. - Speed restrictions. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-5) 
Sec. 78-430. - Yielding right-of-way. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building shall, upon approaching the sidewalk, or the sidewalk area extending across the alleyway, yield the right-of-way to any and all pedestrians approaching on such sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-6) 
Sec. 78-431. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at a curb, in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-8) 
Sec. 78-432. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within 15 feet of a business entrance door. 
(b)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon the sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signals before overtaking or passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-9; Ord. No. 04-27, § 1, 5-5-04) 
State Law reference- Bicycle to be equipped with bell or other similar device, IC 9-21-11-8. 
Sec. 78-433. - Parental responsibility; application of article. 
(a)  The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  These restrictions applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated on any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-1(B), (C)) 
Sec. 78-434. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Whenever any violation of any other provision comes to the attention of a police officer, the violator shall be notified in writing of such violation on a form to be provided by the city for that purpose. Such notice shall be serially numbered and shall show the specific violation charged. The notice shall show the date, time, and location of the violation, and make, color, license number, and model of bicycle. One copy of the notice shall be presented to the violator in person. The notice shall require the person who has received it to appear within five business days, during the times specified on the notice, at the office of the clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  Any person who has been notified that he has violated a provision of this article may, within five business days after having been so notified, personally appear in the office of the clerk-treasurer concerning the charge as set forth in the notices and pay a prescribed fee, to-wit: 
(1)  For the first offense ..... $1.00 
(2)  For the second offense ..... 2.00 
(3)  For the third offense ..... 3.00 
(4)  For the fourth and subsequent offenses ..... 5.00 
(c)  Whenever any person has been issued a notice for the violation of any provisions of this article, and he shall fail or refuse to appear at the office of the clerk-treasurer within five business days after the service of such notice, or has appeared but fails or refuses to pay the clerk-treasurer the prescribed fine and settlement of such notice, the police officer issuing such notice shall file, or cause to be filed in a court of competent jurisdiction, an information charging such person with the violation specified in the notice. 
(Code 1985, § 18-15-11; Ord. No. 10-22, § 3, 6-1-10) 
Secs. 78-435-78-455. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TOY VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-456. - Streets and playthings. 
    No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk and when so crossing such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street as authorized by this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 18-2-14) 
Secs. 78-457-78-465. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SKATEBOARDS 

Sec. 78-466. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Skateboard means a narrow board of approximately four feet long mounted on roller-skate type wheels. 
(Ord. No. 89-14, § 1, 4-10-89; Ord. No. 98-30, § 1, 7-7-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 78-467. - Restricted on private property. 
    The use of skateboards on private property is hereby prohibited, unless the skateboard user is the owner or tenant of such private property, excepting those specific instances as set forth in section 78-469. 
(Ord. No. 89-14, § 2, 4-10-89) 
Sec. 78-468. - Prohibited on public property. 
    The use of skateboards, in-line skates (roller blades) or roller skates on public property is prohibited, except as permitted by special exception as set forth in section 78-469. 
(Ord. No. 89-14, § 3, 4-10-89; Ord. No. 98-30, § 2, 7-7-98) 
Sec. 78-469. - Special exceptions. 
    The following special exceptions to the provisions of this division shall apply: 
(1)  The use of skateboards on private property owned by other private individuals other than the skateboard user providing that the property owner or tenant provides the skateboard user with his written permission and consent to use by the skateboard user on his property. Such consent shall set forth the identification of the skateboard user; the hours during which such operation is to be permitted, and shall be signed and dated by the person granting such consent. Such consent shall be carried by the skateboard user upon his person at all times during such use, and shall be exhibited upon demand therefor by any police officer. 
(2)  The use of skateboards, in-line skates (roller blades) or roller skates on public property is prohibited, unless specifically allowed by regulation of the public body having control over such public property and approved by the board of public works and safety. The use of skateboards, in-line skates (roller blades) or roller skates on public property shall be in accordance with all rules established by the public body having control of such public property and/or the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. 89-14, § 4, 4-10-89; Ord. No. 98-30, § 3, 7-7-98) 
Sec. 78-470. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined a sum not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 89-14, § 5, 4-10-89) 
Secs. 78-471-78-490. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 78-491. - Stopping at crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to walk, run or pass under or over a railroad crossing gate while same shall be down or extended over the street or sidewalk. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the operator thereof, to raise by any means any gate lowered over any street or crossing. It shall likewise be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle, the rider of any bicycle or other conveyance or the rider or driver of any horse or team of horses to go around or encircle any railroad crossing gate which shall be lowered or extended over any street or sidewalk, except in such cases where a person or vehicle may be trapped under a gate lowered after entering such crossing. 
(Code 1985, § 18-16-1(B)) 
State Law reference- Stopping at railroad crossing, IC 9-21-12-5. 
Sec. 78-492. - Responsibility for crossing conditions. 
(a)  All persons owning or operating any railroad, whether steam, diesel, or electric, running through the city shall keep and maintain the crossing where such railroad crosses any public road or street in the city, in a state of repair, and in safe condition for the use of persons on foot or in vehicles. 
(b)  The railroad crossing, where the same crosses any public street or road in the city, shall be deemed to be in a state of disrepair when: 
(1)  It is in an unsafe condition for the use of persons on foot or in vehicles; 
(2)  Such crossing is not constructed in accordance with the grade of the public road or streets it crosses; 
(3)  Any plank becomes loose in a crossing constructed of planking, or when such planking is broken or split; 
(4)  Such crossing, regardless of what material it is constructed, becomes irregular or uneven for whatever reason, as to make the crossing unsafe in the judgment of the traffic commission; or 
(5)  Any crossing signal fails to function upon the approach to such crossing of any locomotive, engine car, or train of cars within the distance required for the activation of such signal. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not be construed as being used in a sense of limitation, and if any such crossing shall be in a state of lack of repair or unsafe condition from any other cause, the provisions of this article shall likewise apply. 
(Code 1985, § 18-16-2) 
State Law reference- Railroad crossings, IC 8-6-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-493. - City repair of crossings. 
    If any railroad shall fail or neglect to comply with section 78-492 after 30 days written notice by the authorities of the city, then the street superintendent of the city may repair any such crossing, keeping an itemized account of the cost thereof, and the city may recover the amount of the costs and expenses thereof, including reasonable attorney's fees, in any court of competent jurisdiction from the person owning and operating such railroad. 
(Code 1985, § 18-16-3) 
State Law reference- Repair of railroad grade crossings by local government, IC 8-6-12-1 et seq. 
Sec. 78-494. - Restrictions on switching. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to move freight railroad cars, gondola cars, freight cars, tank cars, or other railroad equipment in the operation commonly known as switching, in, along or upon railroad tracks located in a right-of-way which may be contiguous or adjacent to or adjoining any zoned residential or zoned apartment district in the city. 
(Code 1985, § 18-16-4) 
Sec. 78-495. - Obstruction of streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor, or person in charge of any engine or train of cars that is not in motion, to obstruct any passage of any street for a longer period than five minutes. 
(Code 1985, § 18-16-5) 
Sec. 78-496. - Limitations on blowing of whistles and ringing of bells. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, engineer or other person in charge of a locomotive being operated within the corporate limits of the city to sound the whistle or ring the bell on the locomotive engine at any public highway or street crossing where the crossing has an automatic, train-activated warning signal as set forth in IC 8-6-7.7-2, except in cases where an apparent emergency exists. 
(Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 78-497-78-510. - Reserved.
