Chapter 82 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; drain maintenance fund, § 2-161; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; cable communications, ch. 22; community development, ch. 30; environment, Ch. 42; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; personnel, ch. 62; planning, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Municipal utilities, IC 8-1.5-1-1 et seq.; municipal sewage works, IC 36-9-23-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - UTILITY SERVICE BOARD 

Sec. 82-1. - Creation of the utility service board. 
    There shall be created within the City of Portage, a board to be known as the "utility service board." Each and every utility owned and operated by the City of Portage shall be controlled by the utility service board. Each utility that previously had its own board shall now be controlled by a manager that answers to the utility service board. The individual boards for each and every utility owned and operated by the City of Portage shall be disposed of and the powers and duties of each board transferred to the utility service board on January 1, 2010 at 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 82-2. - Inclusion of stormwater facilities. 
    The utility service board shall, by virtue of this division, control any and all stormwater facilities located within the City of Portage and any area serviced by the stormwater management department after January 1, 2010 at 8:00 a.m. The utility service board shall serve as the board of directors of the stormwater management department. 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 82-3. - Makeup of the utility service board. 
    The utility service board shall consist of the members of the common council of the City of Portage pursuant to I.C. 8-1.5-3-3(a)(2). 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 16-29, § 1, 1-5-16; Ord. No. 17-7, § 1, 2-23-17) 
Sec. 82-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-7, § 2, adopted Feb. 23, 2017, repealed Sec. 82-4, which pertained to appointment of members and derived from the Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, adopted Oct 13, 2009; Ord. No. 16-29, § 1, adopted Jan. 5, 2016; Ord. No. 17-3, § 1, adopted Feb. 7, 2017. 
Sec. 82-5. - Finances. 
    Treasurer. The clerk-treasurer shall serve as treasurer for the utility service board without additional compensation. He shall deposit at least weekly all money collected from the utility to be kept in a separate fund subject to the order of the board. He shall pay out from board funds only on order of the board. 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 17-3, § 2, 2-7-17; Ord. No. 17-7, § 4, 2-23-17) 
Sec. 82-6. - Salaries of board members. 
    The members of the board shall not receive any additional compensation for service on the board. 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 16-29, § 1, 1-5-16; Ord. No. 17-7, § 3, 2-23-17) 
Sec. 82-7. - Powers and duties of board-Water reclamation department. 
    After January 1, 2010 at 8:00 a.m., the powers and duties of the utility service board shall include those as outlined in IC 8-1.5-3-4 and Portage Municipal Code section 82-44. 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 82-8. - Powers and duties of board-Stormwater management department. 
    After January 1, 2010 at 8:00 a.m., the utility service board shall act as the board of directors for the stormwater management department. The powers and duties of the board of directors shall include those as outlined in IC 8-1.5-3-4, and Portage Municipal Code section 42-57. 
(Ord. No. 09-63, § 1, 10-13-09) 
Secs. 82-9-82-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEWER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board shall mean the utility service board. 
(Ord. No. 92-12, § 1, 4-7-92; Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- "Board" defined, IC 36-9-23-5. 
Sec. 82-27. - Dumping of harmful wastes prohibited. 
    The board shall prohibit or regulate the dumping of harmful wastes into sewage treatment works in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1985, § 19-2-6) 
Secs. 82-28-82-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - UTILITY SERVICE BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2009, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 82-41-82-44, pertained to the water reclamation board, and derived from Code 1985, §§ 15-2-1-15-2-4 and Ord. No. 92-12, § 1, adopted April 7, 1992. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 82-41. - Created, general authority. 
    There is hereby created in the city, a board to be known as the "utility service board." The board shall supervise the control, acquisition, improvement, equipment custody, operation and maintenance of the Portage sewage treatment works. 
(Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 82-42. - Membership, terms, bond. 
    The composition of the board shall be as outlined in sections 82-3 and 82-4 of the Portage Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 82-43. - Organization, compensation. 
    The organization and compensation of the board shall be as outlined in sections 82-3, 82-4 and 82-5 of the Portage Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 82-44. - Powers and duties of the utility service board with regard to the water reclamation department. 
(a)  The board may establish bylaws, rules, and regulations for its own government. With respect to all matters of custody, operation, administration, and maintenance of the sewage treatment works, it shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the board of public works and safety and shall have full power to make all necessary construction, reconstruction, repairs, renewals, enlargements, extensions or additions to the sewage treatment works and execute any and all contracts therefor. 
(b)  The board may enter into all contracts or agreements necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties and the execution of its powers in carrying out the provisions of this article. Any contract relating to the financing or the acquisition or the construction of any works or to any trust indenture authorized, shall be approved by the common council. 
(c)  The board may employ, fix the compensation, and prescribe the duties of engineers, architects, inspectors, superintendent, manager, collectors, attorneys, and such other employees as in its judgment may be necessary; provided, that all compensation and all services incurred shall be paid solely from funds provided under the laws of the state. The board is prohibited from binding itself or the city beyond the extent to which money shall have been or may be provided under state law. 
(d)  The board shall operate, manage, and control the works and may order and complete any extensions or improvements to the works deemed necessary for the use of any available fund or fund to be made available. The board shall adopt rules and regulations for the use and operation of the works and other sewers and drains connected therewith so far as they may affect the operation of the works. 
(e)  All public ways or public works damaged or destroyed by the board in the performance of its duties shall be restored or repaired by the board and placed in their original condition, as nearly as practical out of funds provided, if requested to do so by proper authority. 
(Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 82-45. - Sanitary board-Establishment. 
(a)  A sanitary board for the management of the city's sewage works is established pursuant to I.C. 36-9-23-4. 
(b)  The board shall consist of three members. Two members shall be appointed by the common council. One of the members appointed by the common council must be a registered professional engineer. The mayor shall serve as a member of the board and as its chairperson. 
(c)  Each member shall serve a term of three years except that one of the initial members shall serve a term of two years and then three year terms thereafter. 
(d)  Members shall serve without compensation except reimbursement for necessary expenses incurred by the member in the performance of official duties. 
(e)  Each member of the board shall execute a bond in the amount of $15,000.00 for faithful discharge of all duties as a member of the sanitary board. Each bond shall be made payable to the State of Indiana. 
The treasurer of the sanitary board shall execute a bond an amount equal to the amount required for the bond required of the clerk-treasurer and made payable to the State of Indiana. If the treasurer of the sanitary board is the clerk-treasurer the clerk-treasurer need not execute a separate bond from the bond already required of that office. 
(Ord. No. 18-7, § 1, 5-1-18) 
Sec. 82-46. - Transition from utility service board. 
    The municipal sewage works is currently managed by the utility service board pursuant to section 82-41 of the Municipal Code of the City of Portage. It is contemplated by the mayor and common council that management of the sewage works may be transferred from the utility service board to the sanitary board established under section 82-45 of this division. Any such transfer shall occur pursuant to a separate ordinance passed and adopted by the common council. Until such time as the common council may adopt an ordinance transferring management of the sewage works from the utility service board to the sanitary board the utility service board shall retain exclusive custody, control and management of the municipal sewage works. 
(Ord. No. 18-7, § 1, 5-1-18) 
Sec. 82-47. - Duties. 
(a)  Upon transfer of management as described in section 82-46 of this division, the sanitary board shall then have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Operate, manage and control the sewage works and order any extensions or improvements the sanitary board considers necessary. 
(2)  Enter into all contracts or agreements necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties and the execution of its powers under I.C. 36-9-23 et seq. 
(3)  Employ, fix the compensation of, and prescribe the duties of engineers, architects, inspectors, superintendents, managers, collectors, attorneys, and any other employees the sanitary board considers necessary payable solely from the revenues of the sewage works. 
(4)  Recommend to the legislative body just and equitable fees for the services rendered by the sewage works. Any such recommendation shall include the anticipated expenses for the operation and maintenance of the sewage works to justify the fees recommended. The common council may establish just and equitable fees pursuant to I.C. 36-9-23-25. 
(5)  Issue and sell bonds of the sewage works in the name of the City of Portage for the improvement of the sewage works. The sanitary board may not issue any bonds under this subsection until it has secured the approval of the common council. The clerk-treasurer shall prepare the bonds for issuance and sell them in the manner determined to be in the best interests of the municipality. The bonds are a valid claims only against the sinking fund and the revenues of the sewage works. 
(6)  Submit a budget to the common council on or before November 1 of each year detailing the financial needs of the sewage works for the next year. The budget shall use the budget classification system prescribed by the office of the clerk-treasurer. 
Upon submission of the budget, the common council may approve, amend or reject the budget. If a budget for the sewage works is not approved on or before December 31 then the budget for the next year shall be the same as the then current year's budget. 
If during the year the sanitary board determines circumstances exist which require additional funds be appropriated and set aside from the funds of the department then the sanitary board shall submit a request to the common council describing the appropriation for which additional funds are needed, the amount of the current appropriation, the amount of the additional sums requested, and the source of the additional sums. The common council may approve, reduce or reject the request. 
(Ord. No. 18-7, § 1, 5-1-18) 
Sec. 82-48. - Finance. 
(a)  The revenue of the sewage works shall be kept by the clerk-treasurer and shall be kept separate and aside from the other funds of the city. The clerk-treasurer may expend money from the funds of the sewage works only upon proper approval by the sanitary board. 
(b)  The rates and charges affixed by the common council for the sewage works shall be billed to users monthly by the clerk-treasurer. The clerk-treasurer shall also include on the bills any charges due to trash and storm water services. Each rate and charge shall be separately listed on the bill clearly indicating the name of the rate or charge and the amount owed. 
(c)  Upon collection of each month's billing, the clerk-treasurer shall separate those amounts collected for the sewage works and deposit those monies into the separate funds determined by the sanitary board. The clerk-treasurer shall withhold from the monthly revenues collected on behalf of the sewage works a proportionate share of the costs incurred by the clerk-treasurer for billing. On or before October 15 of each year, the clerk-treasurer shall notify the sanitary board the total anticipated cost for billing for the next year and the estimated proportionate share attributable to the sanitary board. The clerk-treasurer shall determine the proportionate share by dividing the costs of billing by the number of boards with rates and charges on the clerk-treasurer's monthly billing. If the sanitary board objects to the amount of billing costs attributed to it by the clerk-treasurer then it may appeal to common council for a final determination. 
(d)  A sinking fund of the sewage works is hereby established pursuant to I.C. 36-9-23-21. The fund shall be used for the payment of: 
(1)  The principal of and interest on bonds issued by the sanitary board; and 
(2)  The charges of banks or trust companies for making payment of the principal or interest. 
The net revenues of the sewage works, after the payment of the reasonable expense of operation, repair and maintenance of the works, shall be pledged to the sinking fund. 
(Ord. No. 18-7, § 1, 5-1-18) 
Sec. 82-49. - Coordination with common council. 
    It is the desire of the common council to have a close working relationship with the Sanitary Board to better serve the residents of the City of Portage. The common council shall meet as a committee of the whole at least once per month at a time determined by the committee. The superintendent of the sewage works shall appear and provide a report to the committee of the activities of the sewage works for the preceding month and anticipated activities of the upcoming month. The committee may inquire with the superintendent as to the costs and expenses, and related matters, of the activities described. The committee may make recommendations to the superintendent on sewage works expenditures. 
(Ord. No. 18-7, § 1, 5-1-18) 
Secs. 82-50-82-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 82-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building sewer means the extension of the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade, or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Inspector means the person duly authorized by the board to inspect and approve the installation of building sewers and connection to the public sewer system. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surfacewater or groundwater. 
    Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of oxygen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer which is on public property and controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of any sanitary drainage system inside the walls of any building, which receives the discharge from soil or waste stacks and branches and conveys the same to a point three feet outside the building walls where it connects with its respective building sewer. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, groundwaters and surface waters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such stormwaters, groundwaters and surface waters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works means all facilities for collection, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Sludge means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the municipal sewage works of the city. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-1(A)-(Q), (S)-(W)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 82-57. - Prohibited deposits on property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-2(A)) 
Sec. 82-58. - Discharge into natural outlet. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this division. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-2(B)) 
Sec. 82-59. - Prohibited facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage, with the exception of a septic tank and absorption field. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-2(C)) 
Sec. 82-60. - Toilet facilities required; connection to sewers. 
    The owner of each house, building, or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is installed a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that such sewer is within 300 feet of the property line. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-2(D)) 
Sec. 82-61. - Private sewage systems; permit, requirements. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 82-60, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Before any commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the secretary-treasurer of the board. The application for such permit shall be filed with the secretary-treasurer of the board on a form furnished by the board, which applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information deemed necessary to the board. The sum of $35.00 as permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  A permit for private sewage disposal systems shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the designated representative of the board. Such representative shall be allowed to inspect any stage of construction, and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the representative when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 24 hours of the receipt of notice by such representative but within regular working hours. 
(d)  The type, capacity, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the current state department of health Bulletins Nos. S.E. 8 and S.E. 13 except as provided in this section. Copies of such Bulletins Nos. S.E. 8 and S.E. 13 are incorporated by reference as part of this section and two copies are filed in the offices of the board for public inspection. No septic tank shall be permitted to discharge into any natural outlet. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities except as noted below: 
(1)  The board shall issue permits for single-family installation of septic tanks in those areas having slight or moderate soil limitations as classified by the soil conservation service. Such shall be issued only for a tank size of at least a 1,000-gallon capacity with a field absorption system of at least 1,000 square feet of absorption area. Minimum lot area in such cases shall be one acre of suitable soils and/or usable terrain for the installation of such systems and have sufficient area for an additional 1,000 square feet of absorption field if required. 
(2)  The board shall not issue permits for individual septic tank installations for single-family residences in areas having soil classified as severe because of slow permeability, except for those soils in this classification having moderately well-drained characteristics as noted by the soil conservation service. Such permits for septic tank installations in these areas shall require a septic tank containing a minimum capacity of 1,000 gallons and a minimum field absorption system of 2,000 square feet of absorption area. Each lot shall contain a minimum of one acre of suitable soils and/or usable terrain for the installation of such systems and have sufficient area for the additional 2,000 square feet of absorption field, if required. 
(3)  The board shall issue permits for the installation of septic tanks for multifamily residences in those areas having slight or moderate soil limitations as classified by the soil conservation service. Duplex living units shall be required to have the one acre minimum lot area required for a single-family residence for the first unit and an additional one-half acre of lot area for the second unit. Each living unit shall have its own septic tank and absorption field in accordance with the requirements for single-family residences. Any living units in addition to the original two shall have an additional lot size of 13,500 square feet per additional unit and each additional unit shall have a 1,000 gallon septic tank and 1,000 square foot absorption field. Sufficient lot size shall be available for the installation of an additional 1,000 square foot absorption field per living unit. 
(4)  The board shall not issue permits for individual septic tank installations for multifamily residences in those areas having soil classified as severe because of slow permeability, except for those soils in this classification having a moderately well-drained characteristic as noted by the soil conservation service. Such permits, in these areas, shall require that duplex living units have a minimum lot area of two acres. Each living unit shall have its own septic tank (minimum capacity of 1,000 gallons) and absorption field (minimum 2,000 square feet). Any living units in addition to the original two shall have an additional lot size of one acre per additional unit and each such additional unit shall have a 1,000 gallon septic tank and 2,000 square foot absorption field. Sufficient lot area shall be available for the installation of an additional 2,000 square feet of absorption field for each unit, if required. 
(5)  The board shall issue permits for the installation of septic tanks and field absorption areas for commercial and industrial construction in those areas having slight or moderate soil limitations as classified by the soil conservation service using the estimated percolation rates currently established by the soil conservation service in conjunction with the tables to be found in the currently used state department of health Bulletin S.E. 13. Commercial and industrial sites in all cases shall have sufficient area for the installation of a second absorption field, if required. 
(6)  Permits for the installation of septic tank and field absorption systems for commercial or industrial construction shall not be issued by the board in those areas with soils classified as having severe properties because of slow permeability and poor drainage characteristics as noted by the soil conservation service. 
(7)  In those cases where percolation tests are utilized as the basis for permit issuance such tests shall be conducted and submitted by a registered engineer and/or land surveyor whose stamp shall be affixed to a data sheet or sheets. Such tests shall be conducted as outlined in the S.E. 8 Bulletin of the state department of health currently in use. Where tests are submitted for specific lots there shall be a minimum of three test holes and they shall be placed a minimum of 50 feet from any other test hole and all tests shall be conducted in the area designated for the installation of the disposal field. Any such test results with absorption rates greater than 60 minutes per inch shall not be acceptable. 
(e)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system as provided above, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this division, and any septic tanks, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material, except as noted in this section. 
(f)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(g)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(h)  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to such sewer within 60 days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank-run gravel or dirt, except as noted in this section. 
(i)  Where previously used for accommodating rainwater and/or groundwater collected by drain tiles around foundation footings, the homeowner may elect to utilize the private sewage disposal system for the disposal of such uncontaminated water only. Such usage will be confined to the use of structurally sound reinforced concrete or steel tanks with integral covers, and/or distribution boxes, together with the field tile drainage system. 
(j)  Inspection fees. An inspection fee of $50.00 per inspection visit shall be paid for any residential, commercial or other building sewer permit prior to the connection of the building to the Portage sanitary sewer system. A like sum shall be paid as an inspection fee for the connection of any residential, commercial or other building, to a private sewage disposal system. The inspection fees described herein shall be paid to the secretary-treasurer of the Portage Water Reclamation Department. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-3; Ord. No. 03-4, § 1, 2-4-03; Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 82-62. - Connection to public sewers; permit. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, open into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance therefor without first obtaining a written permit signed by the board or its authorized representative. 
(b)  There shall be two classes for building sewer permits: one for residential, and another for commercial services and services to establishments producing industrial waste. In either case, the owner or its agent shall make application to the secretary-treasurer of the board by a special form furnished by the board. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent by the board. A permit and inspection fee of $15.00 for any residential building sewer permit and $25.00 for a commercial or industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the secretary-treasurer of the sanitary board at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner, and the owner shall indemnify the board from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  Inspection fees. An inspection fee of $50.00 per inspection visit shall be paid for any residential, commercial or other building sewer permit prior to the connection of the building to the Portage sanitary sewer system. A like sum shall be paid as an inspection fee for the connection of any residential, commercial or other building, to a private sewage disposal system. The inspection fees described herein shall be paid to the secretary-treasurer of the Portage Water Reclamation Department. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-4(A)-(C); Ord. No. 03-4, § 1, 2-4-03) 
Sec. 82-63. - Separate connections for each building. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; however, where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot, both buildings being owned by the same person, and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. If a duplex building is owned by separate persons, each living unit shall be considered a separate building and a separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for each unit. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-4(D)) 
Sec. 82-64. - Materials, specifications. 
(a)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the inspector, to meet all requirements of this division. 
(b)  The materials and specifications listed here shall be considered as minimum requirements. 
(1)  All materials used in building sanitary sewers shall meet these minimum standards: 
ASA: American Standards Association, 70 East 45th Street, New York, New York 10017 ASTM: American Society for Testing and Materials, 1916 Race Street, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19103-1187 FS: Federal Spec. General Services Administration, Washington, D.C. 20405 CS: Commercial Standards, U.S. Department of Commerce, Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. 20401  
(2)  Each length of pipe, each fitting and piece shall have cast stamped or otherwise indelibly marked on it the maker's name or mark, weight, type, and class of the product, when such marking is necessary to properly identify the material and is approved by the applicable standard. 
(3)  The following is a list of approved materials and applicable standards, followed by additional requirements to be met by all materials: 
  Building 
Sanitary Sewer 
  Material ASTM Asbestos-cement sewer pipe C644, C428 and C500 Clay sewer pipe C200, C301 and C425 Cast iron sewer pipe A74 PVC plastic pipe D1784 and D3034  

(c)  All of the above pipe and any other pipe material that may be considered henceforth shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Inside diameters shall be a full six inches. 
(2)  Minimum crushing strength shall be 1,500 pounds per lineal foot. 
(3)  Asbestos-cement shall contain not more than one percent uncombined calcium hydroxide. 
(4)  The pipe and fittings shall be capable of withstanding the action of a motor device sewer cleaner or rotorooter without damage. 
(5)  PVC plastic pipe shall meet the requirements of ASTM Standard D1784, Rigid Poly (Vinyl Chloride) and Chlorinated Poly (Vinyl Chloride), compounds and ASTM Standard D3034 (SDR 35), Type PSM Poly (Vinyl Chloride) (PVC) sewer pipe and fittings, latest revisions. Pipe and fitting markings shall include the appropriate ASTM designations and cell classification numbers (12454-B or 12454-C or other approved classifications). Pipe and fittings not so marked will be rejected. Standard lengths shall be ten feet, 121/2 feet, and 20 feet. 
(6)  No building sewer shall be less than six inches inside diameter and shall be continued undiminished in size from the building drain to the street sewer, and in no case shall it be smaller. 
(7)  Building sewers shall be set at the minimum grade outlined below: 
Diameter of 
Building Sewer 
(inches) Minimum Grade in Feet per 1,000  6 6.0  8 4.0 10 2.6 12 2.2 14 1.6 15 1.4  
(d)  Joints and connections shall be watertight and capable of meeting the water or air tests specified in this code. The joints shall also be capable of holding a ten-foot head of water for 96 hours at a five-degree deflection without leakage. 
(1)  Caulked joints. Caulked joints for cast iron bell-and-spigot pipe shall be firmly packed with oakum and/or hemp and filled with molten lead not less than one-inch deep and not to extend more than one-eighth-inch below rim of hub. No paint, varnish, or other coatings shall be permitted on the jointing material until after the joint has been tested and approved. 
(2)  Cast iron rubber ring joint. A rubber ring joint meeting ASA 21.11 for type II and type III pipe shall be permissible. 
(3)  Clay pipe joints. All clay pipe joints shall meet the regulations of ASTM C425. 
(4)  Asbestos-cement joints. All joints shall be made with an asbestos-cement or plastic coupling, and two rubber sealing rings having a uniform, solid cross section, and conforming to ASTM D1869. The rings shall be contained in recessed grooves, and the joint shall be designed to maintain compression of the rings under maximum differential loading. The joint shall be so designed that the coupling will automatically be centered on joint. 
(5)  PVC plastic pipe joints. PVC plastic lengths shall be joined utilizing elastomeric gaskets as referenced in D3034 and meeting the requirements of ASTM Standard D3212, Joints for Drain and Sewer Plastic Pipes using Flexible Elastomeric Seals. PVC plastic pipe shall be so constructed that the initial internal vertical diameter does not decrease by more than five percent in order to provide the complete hydraulic carrying capacity conceived by the design engineer, and to obtain the joint performance at five percent maximum diametric deflection as specified in 7.4 of D3212. 
PVC plastic pipe shall be installed in full compliance with the recommended practice for underground installation of flexible thermoplastic sewer pipe, ASTM Standard D2321. In addition to the construction and testing procedures, the contractor shall be required to install the pipe in such a manner so that the diametric deflection of the pipe shall not exceed five percent and the materials surrounding the pipe shall be compacted to the required standard proctor densities outlined in D2321. The area requiring compaction shall include the bed and sidefill material and also the material placed above the pipe for a distance of 12 inches over the top of the pipe. 
(6)  Impermissible joints. Cold poured joints, taper fit joints, precast bituminous joints (slip seal), hot poured joints, and cement mortar joints are specifically prohibited, as are all other jointing methods not specifically permitted above. 
Adapters shall all be lead poured and caulked as described above or shall be made by means of rubber rings, or shall be rubber sleeves clamped over the pipe. No other jointing systems, as described in this subsection, shall be permitted. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-4(E)-(H)) 
Sec. 82-65. - Prohibited discharges into public sewers; testing. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or stormsewers, or to a natural outlet as approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes into any public sewer: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, so as to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant; 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works; and 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances of such quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works as is, including but not limited to ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(d)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the superintendent that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, or have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to the flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of the treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Celsius); 
(2)  Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (zero and 65 degrees Celsius); 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent; 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not; 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the superintendent for such materials; 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the superintendent as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters; 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
(8)  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5; or 
(9)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions); 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand (COD) or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works; or 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting sludge. 
(e)  If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged into the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in subsection (d) of this section, and which in the judgment of the superintendent may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of subsection (j) of this section. 
If the superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plans and the equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. 
(f)  Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients, except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(g)  Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(h)  When required by the superintendent, the owner of any properties serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(i)  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Waste Water, published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which a building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. The particular analysis involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls where pH's are determined from periodic grab samples. 
(j)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-5) 
Sec. 82-66. - Destruction of public sewers. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is part of the municipal sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under the charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-6) 
Sec. 82-67. - Inspections on private property. 
(a)  The superintendent, inspector, and other duly authorized employees of the board bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this division. The superintendent or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond the point having a direct bearing on the kind of source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the superintendent or duly authorized employees of the board shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to meet safe conditions as required in section 82-65(h). 
(c)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the board bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted at reasonable times to enter all private properties through which the board holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works line within such easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on such easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-7) 
Sec. 82-68. - New connections. 
    No new connections will be permitted to the sanitary sewer system that will result in the hydraulic capacity of the system being exceeded. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-8) 
Sec. 82-69. - Annual audits. 
    An annual audit will be conducted on the sewage system by an independent certified public accountant. The board shall keep proper books of records and accounts separate from all of its other records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made showing all revenues collected from said works and all disbursements made on account of the works, also all transactions relating to such works. There shall be prepared and furnished to the original purchasers of the bonds and, upon written request, to any subsequent holder of the bonds, not more than 90 days after the close of each fiscal year, complete operating income and expense statements of the works, covering the preceding fiscal year and the balances in the several funds and accounts created by this division. The fiscal year of the sewage works shall be from January 1 to December 31, both inclusive. Copies of all such statements and reports, together with all audits of the sewage works made available to the board by the state board of accounts or any successor body authorized by law to audit municipal accounts, shall be kept on file in the office of the Portage Water Reclamation Department. Any holder of the bonds then outstanding shall have the right at all reasonable times to inspect the works and all records, accounts, statements, audits, reports, and data of the Portage Water Reclamation Department relating to the sewage works. Such inspections may be made by representatives duly authorized by written instrument. 
(Code 1985, § 19-1-9; Ord. No. 09-86, § 1, 11-17-09) 
Secs. 82-70-82-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 82-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Connection charge means the fee for the connection into a public sewer. 
    Debt service charge means all costs incidental to all outstanding bonded debts of the sewer system, including principal and interest payments, and all reserves required by the bond ordinances. 
    Industrial user means any nongovernmental user of publicly-owned treatment works identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented under the following divisions: 
(1)  Division A, agriculture, forestry and fishing; 
(2)  Division B, mining; 
(3)  Division D, manufacturing; 
(4)  Division E, transportation, communications, electric, gas, and sanitary services; and 
(5)  Division I, services. 
Any user in these divisions may be excluded if it is determined that it will introduce only segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences only. 
    Industrial waste means all waste originating from an industrial user i.e., process water, cooling water, and clean-up water, but excluding segregated domestic wastes, or wastes from sanitary conveniences. 
    Local sewer or lateral sewer means a public sewer being a part of collection system lying in the public property or easements to serve users. 
    Major contributing industry means an industrial user of the publicly-owned treatment works that: 
(1)  Has a flow of 50,000 gallons or more per average work day; 
(2)  Has a flow greater than five percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the wastes; 
(3)  Has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in the standards issued under section 308(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972, as amended; and 
(4)  Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the municipal system receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works, or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    Normal domestic strength sewage means a waste water containing the following maximum concentrations of the following pollutants: 
BOD 5 , 260 mg/l 
Total suspended solids, 200 mg/l 
Ammonia nitrogen, 33 mg/l 
Total phosphorus, 10 mg/l (as P) 
    NPDES permit means the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) being the system for issuing, conditioning, and denying permits for the discharge of pollutants from point sources into navigable waters, the contiguous zone, and the oceans, by the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to sections 402 and 405 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended, public law 92-500, 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq. 
    Operation and maintenance costs means all costs incidental to the operation and maintenance of the sewer system, including replacement costs. 
    Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works are designed and constructed. (The term operation and maintenance includes replacement.) 
    Sanitary sewage means the waste from water closets, urinals, lavatories, sinks, bathtubs, showers, household laundries, basement drains, garage floor drains, bars, soda fountains, refrigerator drips, drinking fountains and stable floor drains. 
    User charge means the charge levied on user of the treatment works for the cost and operation and maintenance of such works, pursuant to section 204(b) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. 
    User rate means the charge to be collected by the board from users of the sewage works. 
(Code 1985, § 19-2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4.

(b)  Excessive strength sanitary surcharge rates: Industrial customers or customers requiring a state or local pretreatment permit whose surcharge parameter test exceeds the surcharge limits stated below, will be charged an excessive strength surcharge fee. This surcharge fee will be charged for each pound of a pollutant over the surcharge limit. The fee will be charged for each parameter on each day the surcharge limit has been exceeded. The fee will be charged for each day of discharge until the ensuing test results are below the surcharge limit. For example, if the parameter is not tested for three days after the first event, the user will be charged for each day until it is tested again, provided that the next testing is below the surcharge limit.

(c)  Residential vacate fee. Residential customers may have their sanitary sewer service vacated while they are out of town. Sanitary sewer service may be vacated for a maximum period of four months per calendar year. In order to have sanitary sewer services vacated, all of the following conditions must apply: 
(1)  The customer must occupy the residential property as his/her primary residence. 
(2)  The customer must intend to return to the residential property after being out of town. 
(3)  The customer shall pay a nonrefundable vacate fee in the amount of $20.00 and shall notify the utility service office of the time period during which sanitary sewer service should be vacated. 
(4)  The customer shall prepay storm water user fees for the period during which sewer service shall be vacated. 
Sewer service shall resume when the customer returns to the property or upon the expiration of four months, whichever occurs first. At that time the utility service department shall resume both monthly billings for both sanitary sewer and storm water services. 
(d)  Rate review. A review shall be completed every three to five years to determine whether the rate increases provided for in this section continue to be reasonable and appropriate. 
(e)  Prepayment discount. Residential customers who prepay their sewer bills in full for the calendar year by January 31 st shall receive a ten percent discount.

Sec. 82-84. - Applicability. 
(a)  The city shall be subject to and required to pay the rates and charges established in this division for usage rates and charges established in harmony therewith. 
(b)  The usage rates and charges may be billed to tenants occupying the properties served, unless otherwise requested in writing by the owners, but such billings shall in no way relieve the owner from liability if payment is not made as required by this division. The owners of the properties served, which are occupied by tenants shall have the right to examine the collection records of the board for the purpose of determining whether such usage rates and charges have been paid by such tenants, provided that such examination shall be made at the office at which such records are kept and during the hours that such office is open for business. 
(c)  The usage rates and charges fixed and established by this division shall become effective for all users as of the date any sewer passes each property and is available for their respective use. 
(Code 1985, § 19-2-4) 
Sec. 82-85. - Collection. 
    The usage rates and charges established by this division shall be collected by the board. The board may make and enforce such bylaws and regulations as may be deemed necessary for the safe, economical, and efficient management of the sewage treatment works, for the construction and use of building sewers connected to the sewage system, and for the regulation and collection of such usage rates and charges. 
(Code 1985, § 19-2-5) 
Sec. 82-86. - Parke Place Plaza sewer assessment. 
    Each acre of property within Parke Place Plaza shall be assessed a fee of $1,100.00, in addition to the connection charge, to compensate the board for the necessary upgrades to the Ashland Street lift station. The assessment fee shall be paid by the owner at the time the property is connected to the sewage works. The assessment fee shall be increased by two percent on January 1 of each calendar year after 2004 to account for increases in material and labor costs. 
(Ord. No. 04-45, § 1, 9-7-04) 
Sec. 82-87. - Elizabeth Avenue lift station subarea sewer assessment. 
(a)  The Elizabeth Avenue lift station subarea (EALS subarea) shall consist of the property bounded on the north by the Prairie Duneland Trail and the Indiana Toll Road, bounded on the west by Airport Road, bounded on the south by the PEDCOR Apartments development and bounded on the east by the east arm of Robbins Ditch north of Robbins Road and by McCool Road south of Robbins Road. Also included in the EALS subarea is an approximately 63-acre site bounded on the east by Airport Road, bounded on the north by Prairie Duneland Trail, bounded on the south by Oakview Meadows Subdivision and bounded on the west by the body of water commonly known as Susdorf Pond. The EALS Subarea contains approximately 790 areas and is depicted on the drawing attached to Ordinance No. 04-46 and marked "Exhibit 1." 
(b)  The EALS subarea, when fully developed, is expected to consist of 2,370 equivalent dwelling units (EDUs). An EDU represents a single-family residence and all other uses represent a fraction of an EDU, which fraction shall be determined by applying the factors identified in 327 IAC 3-6-11 entitled "Design Flow Rate Requirements For Collection Systems and Water Pollution Treatment/Control Facilities." 
(c)  Each EDU within the EALS subarea shall be assessed a fee of $238.00, in addition to the connection charge, to compensate the board for the necessary upgrades to the sanitary sewer system serving the EALS subarea. The assessment fee shall be paid by the developer after the developer's design has been approved by the water reclamation board and the developer obtains final plat approval for each phase of the development. The final plat shall not be signed by the plan commission nor shall any building permits be issued until the assessment fee has been paid. 
(d)  Homes which predate the construction of the lift station improvements and which are not currently connected to the sanitary sewer service shall pay the assessment fee at the time the home is connected to the sewage works. 
(e)  The developer of Sandalwood Subdivision shall pay the assessment fee for each EDU or fraction of an EDU within the subdivision upon the effective date of this section. 
(f)  The developer of Viking Village 3, Unit 2, donated property to the water reclamation board for the construction of the lift station. Consequently, the developer of Viking Village 3, Unit 2, shall be exempt from the assessment fee. 
(Ord. No. 04-46, § 1, 9-7-04)
